Title: Varane Avashyamund: Johny Antony: Making a person laugh in real life is an extremely difficult task
Content: The star-studded Varane Avashyamund could be noted for being Kalyani Priyadarshan‚Äôs debut, but it also heralded the arrival of a new comedian in the film industry ‚Äî Johny Antony . The filmmaker, who has helmed movies such as CID Moosa and Thoppil Joppan, had ventured into acting a few years ago but his role as the psychologist Dr Bose in the recent Anoop Sathyan directorial had the audience in splits. The director-actor talks about his role, his acting dreams, direction and more.I have always focused on being part of the film industry. I tried my hand at acting in Shikari Shambu at the insistence of its producer, director Sugeeth and scriptwriter Nishad Koya. After that Ranjith‚Äôs Drama happened in which I had a full-length role. So, gradually acting became a new area of interest for me and during the period, I was mostly offered comic roles. Anoop, was the assistant director of Lal Jose‚Äôs Thattumpurath Achuthan in which I did a role, when he told me about his plans for his debut directorial, Varane Avashyamund. He informed me that there is a doctor‚Äôs role in the film and I would fit the bill perfectly. Now, I am glad that people have accepted Dr Bose.As the captain of the ship, Anoop had a wonderful script and clarity on how the film would be. He welcomed my suggestions and gave me freedom to improvise too. Interestingly, my normal slang and way of talking were used for Dr Bose also. Apart from the tit-for-tat comedy dialogues, I think what made Dr Bose interesting was his dynamic body language. That made him funnier.More than the comedy situations and dialogues, there was an instance that touched my heart. It was a scene during a rainy day and after consultation, Dr Bose asks Major Unnikrishnan (Suresh Gopi) in the film if there is rain at his place. Suresh tells that usually soldiers are sent to places when there are natural disaster and nobody ever asks a soldier if there is such a problem at his place? That moved me.I have only acted in a few films but among them, I liked Anto Aliyan in Drama and the karate master in Thattumpurath Achuthan.Well, both are different. I love direction and wish to be known as a director. I would take up acting only when I don‚Äôt have any directorial commitments. It is fun to explore acting. Compared to direction, acting is a cakewalk for me. But there are some challenges too, because performing comedy is not easy. Making a person laugh is the most difficult task in life.I am part of a film directed by Arun Vaiga titled Upacharapoorvam Gunda Jayan. It‚Äôs a comedy-centric role and my character Purushan is lively just like Dr Bose.Also, I am working on a new directorial, a family drama which will have Biju Menon in the lead. I would like to add that I used to have conversations with Dileep and Sibi K Thomas, on CID Moosa‚Äôs sequel. If everything falls in place including Dileep and Arjun the dog, you can look forward to that.

Title: Shoot at Site: Colors is female-driven action drama with a twist
Content:
‚Äì Sajan Kalathin, cinematographer







‚Äì Ramkumar, actor





‚Äì Run Ravi, stunt director







Clad in tights and a smart denim jacket, Varalaxmi Sarathkumar is thrown to the ground after a few punches fly in the air. Briefly after, a ‚ÄòCut‚Äô is hollered, and the actress rubs the sand and dirt off her pants, moving towards the monitor at the MGR Film City. ‚ÄúFight comes naturally to me because I have been doing action in most of my films,‚Äù the actress says with a grin, as we catch a spot, escaping the sun, to discuss Colors , her new film.Directed by Malayalam filmmaker Nissar , the film is a female-driven action drama, we are told. However, there is more to it than meets the eye, says Varalaxmi, who plays a martial artiste in the film. ‚ÄúThe martial arts bit of it was very interesting and I got to do some funky stuff. It is too early to talk about the subject because if I explain it, the cat will be out of the bag,‚Äù she says with a laugh, before excusing herself to get her hands dirty in the sand for another shot.The film, which has a national level martial artiste on board for training, is big on styling and agility, the actress tells us just before going for the shot.Also starring Ramkumar, the film‚Äôs shooting is almost in its last stages. Ask the actor to describe his character and a small pause ensues. ‚ÄúI am not sure if I can talk about my role, because if I do, it might just unravel the entire plot,‚Äù he says, adding, ‚ÄúI am called the Sri Krishna of the film because I am the only man in this female-driven cast.‚ÄùYes, there‚Äôs Ineya and Divya Pillai in leading roles, too, and most of the film was shot in Kerala. Nissar, who has Malayalam films like Sudhinam and Three Men Army to his credit, adds that the film lended itself well to Tamil sensibilities. ‚ÄúThis is my 26th film and my first outing in Tamil. I thought this subject will be well-suited to Tamil sensibilities. I could gauge this because I am a big fan of Tamil films,‚Äù he says, going on to explain the film‚Äôs title. Like every character we meet in life, the characters in the film, too, have their own characteristic tones, he says. ‚ÄúThe characters in the film can be associated with different colours,‚Äù the filmmaker notes.Right from Podaa Podi, I have always been drawn to different roles. People are often confused and ask me if I am the lead or the supporting character or the negative character in my films. But don‚Äôt like to categorise myself into one particular slot. If you are an actress, you should be able to do anything and be convincing in that role. I don‚Äôt like falling into any kind of stereotypes. People have started accepting and writing female-centric films now. I am enjoying this whole space in Tamil cinema right now.‚Äî Varalaxmi, actressThis my second Tamil film after Virunthali. It‚Äôs an interesting film to shoot because the actionsequences, too, have a nice touch to them. While the action is subdued, it has turned out to be good on screen. The stunt master has handled the movements very nicely.I was initially scared to work with Nissar sir. But once I entered the set, it became easy. He tells us exactly what he wants from a scene, gets involved in the entire process and acts out every sequence.We choreograph the stunts after listening to the briefs from the cameraperson and the director. The stunts should be in keeping with the script. We also worked with a martial arts team from Kerala for the film. Cinema has its own style, so we picked up the movements that would best suit our sensibilities.

Title: Regina‚Äôs role in this film has a Ramayana connect
Content: One of the integral characters in the epic Ramayana is Shurpanakha, sister of Ravana. While several films have traced the journey of Ram, Sita and Lakshman, not many have exclusively dealt with Shurpanakha ‚Äî her character graph and her emotional journey. And that‚Äôs probably what pushed Caarthick Raju to explore the life of Shurpanakha in his upcoming film and draw a parallel between her and his lead character, played by Regina Cassandra The director has titled his film Soorpanagai and also released its first look, featuring Regina in a royal garb. ‚ÄúShurpanakha, or Soorpanagai as we call her, is an interesting character. We have read about how her parents consulted astrological charts to slot an auspicious time and star for her birth. She went through various emotional upheavals, has experienced love and hatred. But she was quite brutal, too,‚Äù says Caarthick.Ask him about the connection between the epic character and Regina‚Äôs role in the film, and he says, ‚ÄúRegina plays an archaeologist, Soorpanagai, and her personality is very similar to that of the mythological character. When she digs out some information during an excavation, she finds that she has similarities to this character that we‚Äôve shown in the first look. This portion takes place in the 1920s, where Regina‚Äôs character hails from a zamindar family. We have read about how Arabs execute people in front of a crowd if they have committed a crime. In our history, too, there was something called an irumbu kanni (iron maiden), a circular device with nails. This has a connect to the story as well.‚ÄùThe shoot of the film, which also stars Akshara Gowda and Sathish, is nearing completion. ‚ÄúAfter Chennai and Hyderabad, we are presently shooting in Courtallam,‚Äù he signs off.

Title: Kinshuk Vaidya to play Arjun again
Content: After exploring the friendship between Krishna and Radha, Siddharth Kumar Tewary ‚Äôs 'RadhaKrishn' will now highlight the bonding shared by Krishna and Arjun . Ask the producer if the track around Radha and Krishna is over, and he replies, ‚ÄúWe had earlier portrayed the relationship between Rukmini and Krishna. The Krishna-Arjun friendship is also an interesting part of Krishna‚Äôs life, but that does not mean that the show will move away from Radha and Krishna. It will always be about them and their journey.‚ÄùMeanwhile, Kinshuk Vaidya , who played Arjun in ' Karn Sangini ' last year, has been roped in to play the Pandava warrior in 'RadhaKrishn'. So, won‚Äôt it be repetitive to play Arjun again? Kinshuk replies, ‚Äú'Karn Sangini' was more about Karna and Arjun‚Äôs friendship. Karna was also the central character in that show. Here, the makers are exploring Krishna and Arjun‚Äôs friendship, which was the most important part of Mahabharat, but my track will only focus on the friendship.‚ÄùCoincidentally, Kinshuk‚Äôs actress girlfriend Shivya Pathania , who was last seen in 'Ram Siya Ke Luv Kush ', was seen playing Radha in the first episode of 'RadhaKrishn'. Point it out and he says, ‚ÄúShivya and I enjoy playing mytho characters, and we are happy that we get such powerful roles. It‚Äôs just a coincidence that both of us get such roles.‚Äù

Title: Wrestlers Sakshi Malik and Bajrang Punia talk about the pressures of representing the sport on the international stage
Content:
Ahead of the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, wrestlers Sakshi Malik , who had won a bronze in the previous edition, and Bajrang Punia are taking it one step at a time, in hope to clinch a medal for the nation. While their wins may be celebrated, pictures on social media often get negative comments when they have a bad run. Sakshi even admits she has stopped posting pictures online, because of the nasty comments. We caught up with the duo in Bengaluru, where they got candid with us. Excerpts from the chat...

There are a lot of expectations, especially from the wrestling team, ahead of the Olympics. How are you preparing for the same?

Sakshi: As of now, I‚Äôm focusing on the Olympic qualifiers that are scheduled to take place in May. I look at the tournaments one at a time. There is a lot of pressure from people, especially since I won the bronze at Rio Olympics. The expectations are high. But, it‚Äôs my job ‚Äî I have to give my best at every competition.

Bajrang: Every athlete prepares to win a tournament. Competing at the Olympics is every athlete‚Äôs dream and I have the same dream. I wish to win a medal for the country. I am working on my weaknesses and I am training non-stop, an athlete never stops training.

Whenever an athlete wins, the whole country celebrates. But when the same athlete loses, there is sharp criticism.

Sakshi: Pata nahi aisa kyun hota hai? When we win, everyone celebrates with us, but when we lose, everyone questions our ability to perform. This is not a good thing ‚Äî it‚Äôs like they are playing with our minds. Not only me, but all athletes and sportspersons work really hard. Winning or losing is a part of an athlete‚Äôs life. Ek second mei jeet jao, toh athlete superstar hai, lekin haar jao, toh uss athlete ne koi badi galti kar di hai. I won my medal at the Rio Oylmpics at the last minute ‚Äî in our sport, it comes down to the very last minute. If I lose a match at the last moment, then people raise questions about my fitness, my ability to perform. No one understands that it‚Äôs a contact sport and it is tough. We aren‚Äôt machines, we are humans too. It does feel bad when people say that I lost. Jeeti bhi toh mai hi thi. Why don‚Äôt people stand by me or any other athlete when we lose?

Bajrang: It all depends on what kind of people you choose to be with. If you are with people who talk negative about you, you will feel pressurised. My team and other athletes tell me before every bout, that I can win and I can do it ‚Äî it doesn‚Äôt matter who is your opponent. It all comes down to how your friends, family and others motivate you. At the same time, I feel, that we need sharp criticism sometimes. If you need to do well, you need such people. Haar se bhi kuch na kuch seekhne ko milta hai. We learn from criticism and that motivates me. When any athlete competes, they fight with conviction, including their opponent. No one prepares to lose, everyone trains to win a medal for their country.

What needs to be done to change this perception?

Sakshi: We play for our country first. It is such a proud moment for any athlete to win a medal for their country and do a victory lap with the tricolour. That time everyone supports us and wants to click our pictures. We receive a lot of love, but the moment we lose, everything changes. People need to support us in our good and bad times. If we have the support from everyone, especially during our bad times, it will motivate us to do better. People shouldn‚Äôt write us off after one loss, it is very demotivating. I cannot win a gold every single time. For instance, if I lose a tournament, but I put up pictures on social media, people question and say, ‚Äòwhy are you posting pictures? You have lost, what are you so happy about?‚Äô. This doesn‚Äôt happen with other athletes from other countries. I‚Äôve seen people support their athletes through thick and thin in other countries. In India, we are very quick to judge others. I think twice before putting up any pictures, because people will say, ‚Äòye toh parties mei jaa rahi hai‚Äô.

Is blocking comments a solution?

Sakshi: If I win and put up pictures no one will say anything. But, if I lose and put a picture of me trying to having a good time, then I have to think twice. I tell myself, ‚Äòtime kharab chal raha hai, toh soch ke pictures daalna‚Äô. This sort of attitude needs to change. This pressure ruins a lot of athletes. I put up pictures very rarely because of this mindset. Mann hi nahi karta hai, because it creates a lot of pressure on me. I block all such comments by not putting up pictures at all! But how many people will I block? Someone will see the pictures and comments and say, ‚ÄòDid you see what they have written about you?‚Äô

Bajrang: People will talk if you do well and they will talk if you lose too. People need to understand that winning or losing is a part of the game. We don‚Äôt train to lose. There is no athlete who wins every single time. If people know you well, they will never point a finger at you. They will tell you how to improve. I don‚Äôt react to such comments, I don‚Äôt read them also.

Title: Lasya Nagaraj to star in Helen remake in Kannada
Content: Bigg Boss Kannada season five fame actress Lasya Nagaraj has been roped in for the Kannada remake of the critically acclaimed Malayalam film Helen . The original starred actress Anna Ben in the lead. The Kannada remake will be directed by debutant filmmakers Arun Kumr and Sabu Aloysius, both of who come from advertising backgrounds. Mummy and Devaki film fame director Lohith H will be backing the film.‚ÄúI was completely moved by this film, which has emotions that are universal. While I had told myself that I would not back any remakes, I was sold by this film. We needed an expressive actress who the audience is not that familiar with. Lasya is a Bharatnatyam dancer and her dance videos showed her range of expressions. Add to this, her various audition tapes made us believe that she was the right choice,‚Äù says Lohith, who adds that the title and other details will be finalised soon. The film is slated to take off by this month end.

Title: Meet the Times She UnLTD. Entrepreneur Awards jury for Bengaluru
Content: After a successful chapter last year, we are all set to celebrate the exemplary entrepreneurial journey of women who have set up their own enterprises. Times She UnLTD. Awards, co-powered by Senco Gold & Diamonds, is proud to announce the esteemed jury panel comprising accomplished personalities, who will help to identify and recognise the game-changers. The jury panel will select women achievers from three categories ‚Äî Fitness & wellness, Home & Living and Travel & Experiences. During the Jury Meets, each finalist shall have the opportunity to present their story, business idea and entrepreneurship journey to the jury.The jury in the Fitness & Wellness category includes Yasmin Karachiwala, who is a much sought-after celebrity fitness trainer with 29 years of experience in the industry and Nawaz Modi Singhania, a leading fitness and wellness icon who is also the official fitness consultant for a variety of marathons, TV reality shows and radio programs. They are joined by fitness expert Wanitha Ashok and yogapreneur Master Akshar.The category for Home & Living will have Nisha JamVwal, a celebrated interiors architect and designer, an author and luxury brand consultant, as a jury member. Giving her company is interior designer Vinita Chaitanya, serial entreprenuer and co-founder of a one- stop interior and design marketplace Srikanth Iyer and co-founder of one of India‚Äôs leading Interior solutions platforms Ramakant Sharma, along with former business journalist-turned-entrepreneur Shaili Chopra. We‚Äôre excited to see them mentor the contestants with their diverse insights during the jury meets.The jury for the category of Travel & Experiences features names such as Sabina Chopra, the co-founder of one of India‚Äôs leading online travel agencies and Vandana Mohan, who has created waves as the wedding planner behind Deepika Padukone and Ranveer Singh‚Äôs stunning wedding ceremony in Italy. Joining the list is co-founder of one of India‚Äôs largest trekking organisation Sandhya Chandrasekharayya, along with Nisha JamVwal yet again, who is also a travel and lifestyle columnist and Brian Tellis, who has decades of experience in event marketing and is a well-known name in the anchoring, radio, theatre and music arenas.Visit our website to view the complete list of entry categories for this year‚Äôs awards.

Title: Sayantani Guhathakurta's Holi plans revealed!
Content: Like every year, actress Sayantani Guhathakurta , this year too will start her Holi celebrations by offering abir to the senior members of her family and then head to a Holi party with her friends. ‚ÄúEvery year I party and play Holi with my friend Nick Rampal and some of our other common friends. I also love playing Holi with my siblings at home. And nowadays, the Holi celebrations are spanned over two days. On the first day it‚Äôs Dol and the next day is Holi, so it is always double the fun and celebration. I also have a lot of events to attend and Holi special photo shoots to do during this time,‚Äù said Sayantani. But what‚Äôs Holi without khana peena? So, on asking Sayatani about her Holi lunch menu, she shared, ‚ÄúI do try a bit of bhang every year. And mangsho-bhat is a must on Holi.‚Äù

Title: Kashmir team in Kerala: The sea and Kerala‚Äôs rice and sambar capture the hearts of Kashmiri youth
Content:
Eighteen-year-old Imran Hussain Malik was seeing a beach for the first time in his life and it fascinated him. In fact, for the group of 131 visiting Kashmiri students, Neyyar Dam, coconut trees, beaches and even the Malayalam language was a thing of unending curiosity.

Coming from a land embroiled in calamities, the youngsters were excited about their new experiences during their six-day student exchange programme in Thiruvananthapuram, organised by the Nehru Yuva Kendra Sangathan and Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports. Apart from sightseeing, the team, from various districts in Kashmir aged between 18 and 22, had an interactive session with prominent personalities here and experienced the best of Kerala culture, games and food. It was all so new to them; they mistook jackfruit chips for fried onions.

Sharing his joy, Imran says, ‚ÄúI had mixed feelings when the sea waves kissed my feet for the first time in my life. We have shot many pictures and videos to show to family and friends back home. People here seem more mature in their behaviour, with a vibrantly mixed society, which thrives on harmony.‚Äù

Athira Santhosh, one of the volunteers who was a guide to the Kashmiri team , says it was nice to see their child-like curiosity about everything from the coconut shells to jackfruit. ‚ÄúNow they all are fans of our local cuisine and love chor and sambar. They have even learnt simple Malayalam words, like for hunger and ‚Äòwhat is your name‚Äô,‚Äù she says, even as Imran greets her with a ‚Äòsukhamano chechi‚Äô.

B Ali Sabrin, district youth co-ordinator at Thiruvananthapuram, who was guiding the team, says it was an interesting experience to see the students at their first DJ night. ‚ÄúWe arranged a DJ night and dinner for the team on the first day at Veli, but they just sat around watching quietly, despite the ear-thumping, dance music being played. When volunteers coaxed them to dance, they said they were experiencing this for the first time and did not know how to respond to music. We realised life is very different for youngsters there,‚Äù says Ali.

The students said they had come down to Kerala, thinking the State was poor, but the visit changed their notion. ‚ÄúWe enjoyed God‚Äôs Own Country. The hospitality, well-built houses, cheerful and friendly people, fresh, smoke-free air and lush green coconut trees were a novel treat for us. We have become fans of jackfruit and banana chips, which we are taking back with us to Kashmir,‚Äù says Rahi Riyaz Ahmed, social and environmentalist and team leader of the group.

Title: Chaitra Kotoor turns director; film to star fellow Bigg Boss inmates
Content: Former Bigg Boss contestant, writer and actor Chaitra Kotoor , who had assisted on the Hariprriya-starrer Soojidara, is all set to make her debut as a director with a satirical comedy that touches upon serious issues like casteism, toilet facilities and lack of shelter for poor, all of which are issues plaguing society. Chaitra says, ‚ÄúTurning director has been my plan from the time I got into the Kannada film industry. But I did not want to make a run-of-the-mill commercial flick. Instead, I wanted my journey as a filmmaker to begin with a subject that can bring about a change in the way people think about social issues like caste and how the downtrodden are treated in society. I don‚Äôt want to be preachy in the narrative, even though I have chosen serious subjects, which is why I have chosen to present them in satire format. Major portions of the movie will be shot at a vataara in Bengaluru.‚ÄùAs for the casting, Chaitra is looking at having her fellow Bigg Boss contestants in the film. ‚ÄúMost of the contestants are perfect fits for roles in the film. Bhoomi Shetty had agreed to be part of the project when I narrated the story to her inside the Bigg Boss house. I am hoping to get Shine Shetty also on board,‚Äù says Chaitra.

Title: This serial will give me a big reach here: Jai Akash
Content: Actor Jai Akash , who‚Äôs taken up the lead role in the serial Neethane Yenthan Ponvasantham , is quite excited about his TV stint. Even though he is busy with films, the actor says that he couldn‚Äôt refuse this offer.He says, ‚ÄúI am busy with two Telugu films ‚Äî Andala Rakshasadu and Jenma Jenmala Bandham. In Tamil, I was working on Munnal Kadhali, which is ready for release. I also have Olipadhivaalan, Lungi Raja and Aama Naa Porikidhaan. So, I never thought of doing television until I got this offer. When the channel approached me, I thought I would give it a try and listened to the story first. They told me that it is a remake of the hit Kannada serial, Jothe Jotheyali. They gave me a link and asked me to watch a few episodes. I started watching that night and ended up pulling an all-nighter. I couldn‚Äôt stop as I loved the way the story progressed. The hero‚Äôs character was written very well. He is a self-made millionaire. But he is a very kind, generous and down-to-earth person. The heroine, too, falls for his kind nature. The subject was nice and the serial was shot like a big-budget film. I decided not to miss this opportunity and took up the offer. And now, I enjoy playing the role of Suryaprakash.‚ÄùJai Akash is certain that this serial will give him a big exposure among Tamil audiences. He says, ‚ÄúI am grateful to the channel and producers for selecting me. More than films, this serial will give me a big reach here. Television and internet are big now. I am certain that this will help me in my film career as well. Also, I have a lot of scope to perform.‚ÄùBut serials are long-term commitment. With so many projects in the pipeline, how will he manage both television and films? He says, ‚ÄúOh yes, the channel had told me that it will go on for at least two years. I have allotted 15 days for the serial‚Äôs shoot every month and the remaining days are for my film commitments.‚Äù The actor says that he will be choosy about his projects from now on. ‚ÄúI want to be selective and do the right kind of films,‚Äù he signs off.

Title: Sayantani Ghosh‚Äôs character to be bumped off in 'Naagin'
Content: A month after Jasmin Bhasin ‚Äôs character was bumped off in 'Naagin 4', another principal character‚Äôs track is all set to wind up. Actress Sayantani Ghosh ‚Äî the original naagin of Indian television ‚Äî who joined the franchise this season, will soon exit the show.When contacted, Sayantani said, ‚ÄúYes, my character is winding up. As a show, 'Naagin' has to keep the audience on the edge of their seats and hence, the team has to introduce high-points and shockers at every stage. The creative team has decided that killing my character would serve as a big high-point.‚ÄùSo, how has she taken the development? ‚ÄúSee, parting is never easy, as you get attached to the team. As an artiste, you feel bad, but such is the nature of this industry. Also, no character is above the show. Though the show is doing well, it hasn‚Äôt matched up to the last seasons‚Äô ratings, yet. In my 15 years of experience, I have understood that TV shows are governed by the ratings. I hope that the track, which marks my exit, works. That will be a big consolation (smiles).‚Äù

Title: Santhosh to compose for Kadaisi Vivasayi instead of Ilaiyaraaja?
Content: We‚Äôd reported that director Manikandan , who had worked with Ilaiyaraaja in Kuttrame Thandanai, will be teaming up with the maestro again for his Kadaisi Vivasayi . While the film‚Äôs trailer and the poster had also mentioned the maestro‚Äôs name as part of the crew, we now hear that Ilaiyaraaja is not doing the film anymore and that Santhosh Narayanan has taken over as the composer.While Manikandan remained unavailable for comment till the time of going to press, a source says, ‚ÄúIlaiyaraaja had started work on the movie a few months ago, but there were certain aspects where the director and the composer didn‚Äôt agree with each other. So, they have parted ways amicably. Manikandan then approached Santhosh Narayanan to compose music, and work is on in full swing.‚Äù

I won my medal at the Rio Oylmpics at the last minute ‚Äî in our sport, it comes down to the very last minute. If I lose a match at the last moment, then people raise questions about my fitness, my ability to perform. No one understands that it‚Äôs a contact sport and it is tough. We aren‚Äôt machines, we are humans too. It does feel bad when people say that I lost. Jeeti bhi toh mai hi thi. Why don‚Äôt people stand by me or any other athlete when we lose?Bajrang: It all depends on what kind of people you choose to be with. If you are with people who talk negative about you, you will feel pressurised. My team and other athletes tell me before every bout, that I can win and I can do it ‚Äî it doesn‚Äôt matter who is your opponent. It all comes down to how your friends, family and others motivate you. At the same time, I feel, that we need sharp criticism sometimes. If you need to do well, you need such people. Haar se bhi kuch na kuch seekhne ko milta hai. We learn from criticism and that motivates me. When any athlete competes, they fight with conviction, including their opponent. No one prepares to lose, everyone trains to win a medal for their country.Sakshi: We play for our country first. It is such a proud moment for any athlete to win a medal for their country and do a victory lap with the tricolour. That time everyone supports us and wants to click our pictures. We receive a lot of love, but the moment we lose, everything changes. People need to support us in our good and bad times. If we have the support from everyone, especially during our bad times, it will motivate us to do better. People shouldn‚Äôt write us off after one loss, it is very demotivating. I cannot win a gold every single time. For instance, if I lose a tournament, but I put up pictures on social media, people question and say, ‚Äòwhy are you posting pictures? You have lost, what are you so happy about?‚Äô. This doesn‚Äôt happen with other athletes from other countries. I‚Äôve seen people support their athletes through thick and thin in other countries. In India, we are very quick to judge others. I think twice before putting up any pictures, because people will say, ‚Äòye toh parties mei jaa rahi hai‚Äô.Sakshi: If I win and put up pictures no one will say anything. But, if I lose and put a picture of me trying to having a good time, then I have to think twice. I tell myself, ‚Äòtime kharab chal raha hai, toh soch ke pictures daalna‚Äô. This sort of attitude needs to change. This pressure ruins a lot of athletes. I put up pictures very rarely because of this mindset. Mann hi nahi karta hai, because it creates a lot of pressure on me. I block all such comments by not putting up pictures at all! But how many people will I block? Someone will see the pictures and comments and say, ‚ÄòDid you see what they have written about you?‚ÄôBajrang: People will talk if you do well and they will talk if you lose too. People need to understand that winning or losing is a part of the game. We don‚Äôt train to lose. There is no athlete who wins every single time. If people know you well, they will never point a finger at you. They will tell you how to improve. I don‚Äôt react to such comments, I don‚Äôt read them also.

Title: Brew a storm in your tea cup with blue pea flowers
Content:
Move over black and green tea. How about trying some blue tea instead? This variant not only tastes good, but has plenty of health benefits as well. Currently trending in a few tea bars and health cafes in Kolkata, this herbal tea is made by infusing blue pea or butterfly pea flowers (Aparajita). The beverage has zero caffeine content and changes colour when a dash of lime is added to it. Priti Sen Arora, owner of a city caf√© that specialises in a variety of tea concoctions, said, ‚ÄúApart from rendering a beautiful lilac or purple colour, butterfly pea flower is a mood enhancer, stress reliever and is filled with anti-inflammatory properties. It is also said to improve cognitive function.‚Äù

Unique properties of butterfly pea flower

What sets the butterfly pea flower apart from other flowers is its unique property to change colour when it comes in contact with anything acidic. The bright blue colour of the flower extract will turn pink or purple due to a change in the pH level when a few drops of lime juice are added to it. When some hibiscus leaves are added to the tea, one can get a beautiful red-coloured beverage. Rituparna Banerjee, founder of a city-based culinary studio, said, ‚ÄúIn one of our food pop-ups, where we introduced blue pea flower tea, and squeezed a lemon into it to show the guests how the colour changed from blue to purple, they were surprised. I think this change of colour adds a lot of drama and is therefore enjoyed by all age groups.‚Äù

Influence of butterfly pea flowers in Bengali cuisine

The butterfly pea or the Aparajita flower is used to worship Lord Shiva in West Bengal . Talking about the influence of the flower in the Bengali cuisine, food historian Pritha Sen said, ‚ÄúThe Aparajita flower is used in our household for various religious rituals. Digging into the history of the usage of the flower in the Bengali cuisine, I found that it has not been used much except for the fact that the Rajbansi community of north Bengal used this flower extract to add colour in sherbets.‚Äù

Usage in global cuisine

The flower is widely used in Southeast Asia as a natural food colouring added to glutinous rice. In Burmese and Thai cuisines, butterfly pea flowers are also dipped in batter and fried. In the Kelantan region of east Malaysia, people add a few buds of the flower in a pot while cooking white rice to impart a bluish tint, which is known as nasi kerabu . In Thailand and Vietnam, the tea is often mixed with honey and lemon to enhance the taste and give the beverage a pink-purple colour. It is found in both hot and cold variants.

Health benefits of blue tea

The blue flower is packed with loads of health benefits. ‚ÄúThe tea is not just a great antioxidant but also reduces inflammation. It‚Äôs a stress reliever and helps improve eyesight too. This type of tea has been there for ages and is quite popular in Southeast Asian countries. The trend is fast catching up in the city and is definitely a rage for its colour changing property,‚Äù said chef Urvika Kanoi, owner of a city caf√©.

1. Promotes weight loss

2. Acts as natural paracetamol

3. Improves eyesight

4. Combats the effect of diabetes

5. Improves heart health

6. Packed with antioxidants

7. Treats menstruation problems

8. Combats hair loss

9. Effective against stress, anxiety and depression

10. Has anti-inflammatory properties

Items you must try at eateries

1. Butterfly pea flower tea (hot or cold)

2. Dumplings

3. Butterfly pea flower beer

4. Butterfly pea flower cheesecake

5. Lassi

6. Cocktails or mocktails

How to brew Butterfly pea flower tea at home?

Ingredients: 500 ml of water, 10 dried butterfly pea flowers

Method: Boil water in a saucepan. Remove the sepal (green part) of the flower and pour it into the saucepan. Let it boil for 10 minutes. As flowers start to fade, the water will turn blue. Since these flowers don‚Äôt have a distinct smell or taste, one can add spices like cloves, cardamom or ginger before pouring it into a cup. You can also add a dash of lime to enhance the taste and see the beverage turn purplish pink from blue.

Title: Sara Ali Khan: Dhanush and Sara Ali Khan to begin film shoot in Varanasi
Content:
Picture of her Varanasi outing that Sara Ali Khan posted on Instagram (BCCL/ @saraalikhan95)

Picture of her Varanasi outing that Sara Ali Khan posted on Instagram (BCCL/ @saraalikhan95)

(L) Sara Ali Khan (R) Dhanush clicked at Varanasi airport (BCCL)

The star cast of Aanand L Rai ‚Äôs next directorial venture Atrangi Re, Dhanush and Sara Ali Khan, reached Varanasi on Monday. While Dhanush, who is reuniting with his Raanjhanaa director with this film was spotted at the Varanasi airport in the morning, Sara Ali Khan reached the city late in the afternoon.Picture of her Varanasi outing that Sara Ali Khan posted on Instagram (BCCL/ @saraalikhan95)The film, written by Lucknowite Himanshu Sharma , will be shot in and around Varanasi, familiar turf for Aanand, who had canned a large portion of his Sonam Kapoor and Dhanush starrer film Raanjhanaa in the city.Sara, who is reportedly playing a character from Bihar and will be seen in a double role in the film, took time out to explore the city. She shared pictures of a boat ride in the Ganga with the beautifully lit ghats in the background on her Instagram account.Picture of her Varanasi outing that Sara Ali Khan posted on Instagram (BCCL/ @saraalikhan95)Dressed in a traditional outfit the Kedarnath actress also attended the famed Ganga aarti at Dashshwamedh ghat. She made sure to enjoy her stay before the actual work starts.The film is slated to be canned in some parts of the city including Kashi station. A set is also being prepared at Kharaujha village in Chandauli for the shooting.The locations of the film, that also stars Akshay Kumar , were finalised after a recce by the director and Himanshu who visited Varanasi in mid-January.(L) Sara Ali Khan (R) Dhanush clicked at Varanasi airport (BCCL)

Title: Are you constantly staring at your phone? Watch out!
Content: Tamanna Jha (37), financial expert with a stock analyst firm, was on the brink of losing her job, courtesy a culprit that fits into the palm of her hand. The need to constantly check her phone and chat with friends resulted in her being given a stern warning at her workplace last month. Why? She was over-engrossed on her phone, which saw her narrowly miss making a timely assessment of current stocks. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not something I am proud of, but also something I couldn‚Äôt help. Reaching for my phone as soon as I get anywhere is like second nature to me and every time it beeps, I have to see what my chat groups are saying,‚Äù she admits. ‚ÄúI just missed making a huge loss and have been warned to reduce my phone screen time in office now,‚Äù she adds. She‚Äôs not the only one. Digital addiction is a growing new-age problem affecting everyone, from professionals to students and even, homemakers. This addiction to the smartphone screen can cost you more than being in troubled waters at just the workplace ‚Äî it can ruin relationships, cause digital eye strain and up the risk of lifestyle diseases too.The point has been outlined often enough. Terms like a ‚Äòcyber widow‚Äô, which describes a woman whose partner can‚Äôt be separated from his gadget or even ‚Äòphubbing‚Äô or phone snubbing, only reiterates this. Result? Smartphones continue to contribute to the breakdown of long-term relationships and even play a growing role in divorces. Affirms psychiatrist and counsellor, Dr Pavan Sonar, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve seen at least 50 per cent of cases of disharmony between couples cropping up on account of digital addiction. Often, one partner can‚Äôt gauge what the other is doing on screen. We also see intimacy taking a backseat as a fallout of this. It simply holds no priority for people. There is a tendency to always want the phone at hand and to be glued to the screen. This mostly happens in the night hours. ‚ÄòMe time‚Äô or ‚Äòwe time‚Äô has become screen time and that changes the bedroom dynamics.‚ÄùMumbai‚Äôs colleges have swung into action to deal with the situation. Says Karina Ailsinghani, SYBA student from Jai Hind College, ‚ÄúToday, we have no network in classes; it‚Äôs network-free to try and curb the menace.‚Äù The college has a ‚ÄòWellness Cell‚Äô, which also helps tackle issues like screen addiction. Says Mahek Punjabi, head of the cell, ‚ÄúWe have had experts talk about the ills of screen addiction. It has been seen that those who are depressed use a phone as a form of escape, where their virtual world becomes less lonely to them. They want X number of followers and ape dangerous stunt videos for attention. Stalking also starts early with gadget addiction.‚ÄùA total phone ban is tough, so colleges are working around the issue. Says Dr Minu Madlani, principal of KPB Hinduja College, ‚ÄúWe have to allow it on an experimental basis for degree college students. In some lectures students are asked to surf for information online, making the phone a learning tool. That said, overall there is a definite screen addiction menace and there is an urgent need to reduce that addiction. We also plan to roll out campaigns such as a ‚ÄòNo Phone Day‚Äô, where kids keep the gadgets out and get awarded.‚ÄùAmisha Mehta, parent to a four-year-old, is a case in point about how the younger kids are unable to look away from digital screens. ‚ÄúMy daughter Alina wouldn‚Äôt eat breakfast unless we put the phone in front of her. It has become so bad that she cries and refuses to eat unless we do so. We previously gave her the phone to distract her; now she can‚Äôt do without it,‚Äù she says.Citing the case of such a ‚Äòdigital nanny‚Äô Dr Samir H Dalwai, a developmental pediatrician, says, ‚ÄúParents use a gadget as a means to distract their child to get their work done or a source of entertainment to make up for the missed affection. But this has its risks and parents need to come up with effective alternatives.‚Äù The trend of too much screen time in a child‚Äôs life has become so rampant that it got him and his team to come up with a #LimitMyScreenTime Campaign last month. He says, ‚ÄúWe see many children every day, each with developmental and behavioural concerns. And screen time plays a major role in worsening the situation. According to research, screen use among children aged 0-8 years has exploded over the decade. Currently, an average two-year-old spends up to two hours on a mobile device whereas the American Academy of Pediatrics strictly prohibits use of any screen for children below two years, except it in a supervised video chat. Over a period of time, concerns can arise such as headaches and back pains in older children due to sitting in front of televisions and computers. One of the other major drawbacks of excessive screen time is change in behavior and poor social communication skills. Watching violent and aggressive content which if left unchecked, can lead to similar behavioural changes in children.‚ÄùLooking down at your cellphone for long hours has its pitfalls‚Äî tightness and pain, for one. Says orthopaedic surgeon, Dr Milind Merchant, ‚ÄúThe forward bending position of the neck puts pressure on the spine and that causes neck pain. The longer you stay this way, the weight exerted around that area increases. This can lead to degeneration of the disc and in some cases, may cause it to migrate. We see youngsters at 18 and 20 years of age coming in with such problems. They spend long hours gaming or just being online. Constantly staring at the screen also strains the eyes and causes headaches.‚Äù Other risks arising out of this include Texter‚Äôs Thumb, Cellphone Elbow and Smartphone Pinky.

Content:

Neeraj Mishra (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

Rishi and Varun Mishra (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

(L) Kanako (R) Kishan Jalan (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

(L) Lisa Rishi and Austhia (R) Krishina (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

(L) Lizo (R) Mansha (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

(L) Ramesh Bhai (R) Preeti Agrawal and Jyoti Gupta (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

(L) Rajeshwar Acharya (R) Ravi Shankar Mishra (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

(L) Rosa Yanco (R) Seema Jalan (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

(L) Vijay (R) Anil Narayan Sharma (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

The annual musical fiesta Shivratri Sangeet Mahotsava was a melange of great performances, both by upcoming and established artistes. The three-day festival, that was inaugurated by spiritual guru, Rameshbhai Oza , began with the performance of Odissi dance by Yashna Sureka. Giving an auspicious start to her performance with Ganesh vandana, she went on to dance on Ganga strotam Devi Sureshwari Bhagwati Gange.Premchand Hombal (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)Bhagirath Jalan was the next artiste of the evening who rendered raag-based compositions like Piya Nahi Aye, Roko Na Dagar More Shyam. Later, he presented a bhajan Jai Hanuman Pawan Kumar . He concluded his performance with the famed Holi song Khele Masane Mein Holi. The highlight of the evening turned out to be Jal Tarang recital by Rajeshwar Acharya, whose finesse over the instrument was greatly applauded.Neeraj Mishra (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)The second day of the festival was mainly dedicated to upcoming artistes. Sitar recital by Neeraj Mishra gave a perfect start to the evening. Apart from several raga-based compositions, he concluded his performance with the song Hamari Ataria Pe. A vocal recital by young artists Rishi and Varun Mishra was the next performance of the evening. The duo began with a composition in Raag Maru Bihag and went on sing Tappa and Hori compositions. Odissi dance by Illeana Citaristi was another highlight of the evening.Rishi and Varun Mishra (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)The concluding day of the festival had the stalwarts of classical music performing on the stage. Yella Venkateshwar Rao one of the leading exponents of mridangam started his performance in Raag Charukeshi followed by a jugalbandi with violin, sitar, tabla and manjira. He concluded his performance with the song Vaishnav Jan on the instrument. Other highlights of the evening was vocal recital by Ajay Pohankar and Bharatnatyam by Premchandra Hombal .(L) Preetam Mishra (R) Aryan (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)(L) Bhagirath and Khushbu Jalan (R) Kaisthina (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)(L) Kanako (R) Kishan Jalan (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)(L) Lisa Rishi and Austhia (R) Krishina (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)(L) Lizo (R) Mansha (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)(L) Ramesh Bhai (R) Preeti Agrawal and Jyoti Gupta (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)(L) Rajeshwar Acharya (R) Ravi Shankar Mishra (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)(L) Rosa Yanco (R) Seema Jalan (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)(L) Vijay (R) Anil Narayan Sharma (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

Title: India can hurt Qatar again: Igor Stimac
Content:
Igor Stimac

PANAJI: Igor Stimac ‚Äôs best result since taking charge of the Indian team nine months ago is a goalless draw against Asian champions Qatar in Doha. That result put Indian football on cloud nine but were soon brought back to earth with last-minute draws against lowly Bangladesh and Afghanistan. Ahead of the last three games in the Fifa World Cup qualifiers, Stimac explains why he continues to bristle with confidence. Excerpts from an exclusive interview with TOI‚Ä¶

India are now out of the World Cup 2022 race. How confident are you that India can still make it to the Asian Cup 2023?

I am very confident. We have more quality than Bangladesh and Afghanistan, although we need to show that on the field for 90 minutes. We still haven‚Äôt found a way to fight with quality in the final third of the pitch. That was our main problem against Afghanistan and Bangladesh, even Oman when, for the first time, we had more ball possession and adopted a different approach to the game.

Are you worried that India are still without a win?

You have to look at the process which cannot make you certain about fulfilling your aim as you wish. There will be sufferings. We are now a team which is very difficult to beat, a team which does not concede too many goals. Whoever is there at the other end, it will be difficult to beat us. I am not saying it will not happen. It may. But it will also show our higher quality. Our next step of training in April and May is to work out in the final third and find a way when we are considered favourites, against teams ranked below us.

India had an excellent draw against Qatar but also frustrating results against Bangladesh and Afghanistan, where the team needed last-minute equalisers‚Ä¶

Equalising at the end of the games confirms the character of this team. It shows we never surrender. We now have a winning mindset and that‚Äôs the biggest gain for me in the past few months of our work together. Not winning these games is part of the process. I was aware of the danger (at the back) when we open ourselves and take more risks, but when I look at the number of players missing in the defensive line, I think we still showed quality.

You will continue to miss defensive players. How will you handle that?

It‚Äôs going to be very difficult. Once again, we have to field a team which hasn‚Äôt played before. We have nine days (during the camp) to find a solution. We need to go with the best conditioned players, the strong ones in terms of mindset and muscle. We also need players with certain technical ability to match Qatar. I have to convince my players that they need to enjoy this game. They need not worry about the result. Just go out, do your best and believe in what we are doing. This match will be a learning experience, particularly for the youngsters. Against Qatar, we need to find a way how we can hurt them. If we took a point off them when they were in their best form, and at home, we certainly have the opportunity now to find a way and hurt them one more time.

Bengaluru FC coach Carles Cuadrat said if he was in your position, he would be worried, pointing to the lack of goals and assists from many important players, particularly the likes of Udanta Singh and Ashique Kuruniyan‚Ä¶

That's nothing new. He should be more worried because he has a playoff to play and get the team to the final. I am the one who should be enjoying the good work of club managers, and not the other way round. With respect to all of them, who I consider friends, we should develop players together. They are the ones who have the chance to work on a daily basis and improve their abilities. I don‚Äôt have that joy. I am here to pick up the best players so that they can defend India colours and show to the world they have improved, thanks to their work at the clubs. Udanta and Ashique have been used as examples. I want to remind everyone who point at their lack of goals, just look at their defensive work, how much they have contributed to Bengaluru becoming the best defensive side (in the ISL ) and Gurpreet (Sandhu) having so many clean sheets. These players suffer upfront because they don‚Äôt have any time to relax during the game. They need to defend and produce (goals) upfront.

Title: Sara Ali Khan: Dhanush and Sara Ali Khan to begin film shoot in Varanasi
Content: The star cast of Aanand L Rai ‚Äôs next directorial venture Atrangi Re, Dhanush and Sara Ali Khan, reached Varanasi on Monday. While Dhanush, who is reuniting with his Raanjhanaa director with this film was spotted at the Varanasi airport in the morning, Sara Ali Khan reached the city late in the afternoon.Picture of her Varanasi outing that Sara Ali Khan posted on Instagram (BCCL/ @saraalikhan95)The film, written by Lucknowite Himanshu Sharma , will be shot in and around Varanasi, familiar turf for Aanand, who had canned a large portion of his Sonam Kapoor and Dhanush starrer film Raanjhanaa in the city.Sara, who is reportedly playing a character from Bihar and will be seen in a double role in the film, took time out to explore the city. She shared pictures of a boat ride in the Ganga with the beautifully lit ghats in the background on her Instagram account.Picture of her Varanasi outing that Sara Ali Khan posted on Instagram (BCCL/ @saraalikhan95)Dressed in a traditional outfit the Kedarnath actress also attended the famed Ganga aarti at Dashshwamedh ghat. She made sure to enjoy her stay before the actual work starts. The film is slated to be canned in some parts of the city including Kashi station. A set is also being prepared at Kharaujha village in Chandauli for the shooting.The locations of the film, that also stars Akshay Kumar , were finalised after a recce by the director and Himanshu who visited Varanasi in mid-January.(L) Sara Ali Khan (R) Dhanush clicked at Varanasi airport (BCCL)

Title: Coronavirus in India: Visas to nationals of 4 more countries on hold
Content:
Tourist in Agra wear protective masks in wake of the deadly novel coronavirus

NEW DELHI: India has suspended both regular (sticker) and e-visas granted to nationals of Italy, Iran , South Korea, and Japan on or before March 3, 2020. Those who are yet to enter India have been asked not to do so. And if they must come to India for any pressing reason, they should request for a fresh visa, according to a fresh set of ‚Äútravel and visa restrictions‚Äù issued by the Indian Bureau of Immigration (BoI) on Tuesday.

Coronavirus outbreak:complete coverage

Air India, too, decided to reduce frequency of flights. ‚ÄúTill March 31, our Delhi-Tokyo flight will fly four times a week, instead of five; Delhi-Seoul and Delhi-Milan will fly twice a week, instead of four, and Delhi-Rome will operate twice a week. Till May-end, daily flights Mumbai-Singapore-Delhi and Delhi-Bangkok-Mumbai will operate four and three times a week, respectively,‚Äù an AI spokesperson said.

Read our coronavirus live blog for all the latest news and updates

Diplomats, UN officials won‚Äôt be subject to visa curbs

The airline is reviewing the situation ‚Äúevery 15 hours‚Äù and is likely to decide on its Jeddah flight soon. The BoI order read: ‚ÄúAll regular (sticker) visas/e-visa (including visa on arrival) granted to nationals of Italy, Iran, South Korea, Japan and issued on or before March 3, 2020, and who have not yet entered India, stand suspended.

Those requiring to travel to India due to compelling reasons may seek fresh visa from nearest Indian embassy/consulate.‚Äù The order also said regular visa/e-visa granted to all foreign nationals who have travelled to China, Iran, Italy, South Korea and Japan on or after February 1, 2020, and have not yet entered India stand suspended with immediate effect.‚Äù However, diplomats, officials of UN and other international bodies, OCI cardholders , and air crew from these five countries have been exempted from restrictions.

Title: UN body goes to Supreme Court on CAA; ‚Äòinternal matter‚Äô, says government
Content:
CAA reflects our commitment on rights: Government

NEW DELHI: For the first time in India‚Äôs judicial history, a United Nations body ‚Äî the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (UNHCHR) ‚Äî on Tuesday sought to intervene as amicus curiae , or friend of the court, to assist the Supreme Court in adjudicating the constitutional validity of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). The UNHCHR said while CAA has a ‚Äúworthy and commendable objective‚Äù, it appears to discriminate against persecuted Muslim communities.The ministry of external affairs swiftly hit back, saying it was an ‚Äúinternal matter‚Äù and that ‚Äúno foreign party has any locus standi on issues pertaining to India‚Äôs sovereignty‚Äù and ‚Äúthe Indian Parliament‚Äôs right to make law‚Äù.Intervening in a petition filed by former Indian high commissioner to Bangladesh Deb Mukharji, who has challenged CAA, UNHCHR Michelle Bachelet Jeria stated, ‚ÄúCAA can potentially benefit thousands of migrants in an irregular situation, including refugees, who might otherwise face obstacles in obtaining protection from persecution in their countries of origin, including through the grant of citizenship. This is commendable.‚Äù However, she added, the law ‚Äúraises a number of issues related to India‚Äôs wider human rights obligations in the context of fundamental principle of non-refoulement, that is no forced repatriation of refugees to their home country.‚ÄùCountering United Nations high commissioner for human rights (UNHCHR) Michelle Bachelet Jeria‚Äôs statement against CAA, MEA spokesperson Raveesh Kumar said, ‚ÄúWe are clear that CAA is constitutionally valid and complies with all requirements of our constitutional values. It is reflective of our longstanding national commitment in respect of human rights issues arising from the tragedy of the Partition of India.‚Äô‚Äô‚ÄúIndia is a democratic country governed by the rule of law. We all have utmost respect for and full trust in our independent judiciary. We are confident that our sound and legally sustainable position would be vindicated by the Supreme Court,‚Äù Kumar added.The government‚Äôs reaction came after India‚Äôs permanent mission in Geneva was informed by the Office of the UNHCHR that it was filing an intervention plea against CAA in the SC seeking to present itself as an amicus curiae. SC officials could not confirm if the intervention application of Jeira, who was Chi- le‚Äôs first woman president, had actually been filed. An official in the registry said, ‚ÄúNo UNHCHR application has been filed on Tuesday in Deb Mukharji‚Äôs petition.‚Äù A spokesperson for the UN body said the high commissioner intended to shortly submit an amicus curiae brief on CAA in the SC in accordance with court‚Äôs procedures.Jeria said she and her predecessors ‚Äúhave filed amicus curiae briefs on issues of particular public importance within proceedings before a diverse range of international and national jurisdictions, including at the international level ‚Äî European Court of Human Rights, Inter-American Court of Human Rights, International Criminal Court ‚Äî and at national level ‚Äî US Supreme Court and final appeal courts of States in Asia and Latin America.‚ÄùShe clarified that though she intends to intervene in CAA proceedings as an amicus curiae in the SC, she would not give up her diplomatic privileges and immunity. This means she would not submit to the SC‚Äôs jurisdiction and not be liable for any adverse order against her.Referring to CAA promising expeditious citizenship for persecuted minorities, Jeria said, ‚ÄúThe factual basis for the arguments provided in the Statement of Objects and Reasons for the introduction of CAB for such preferential treatment, also find support in pronouncements by the UN human rights mechanism regarding the situation of religious minorities in Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan.‚Äù‚ÄúHowever, recent reports by the UN human rights treaty bodies, special procedures and other mechanism ascertain that there exist a number of religious groups considered religious minorities in these countries, especially of the Muslim faith, including Ahmadi, Hazara and Shia Muslims whose situations would warrant protection on the same basis as that provided in the preferential treatment proposed by the CAA,‚Äù she said. However, the UNHCHR is silent whether it had similarly moved Supreme Courts of Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh seeking protection of these groups.‚ÄúThe question also arises as to whether the differentiation made with regard to persecution on religious grounds, as opposed to other grounds, is sufficiently objective and reasonable, in particular taking into account the prohibition of refoulement and India‚Äôs obligations under international human rights law,‚Äù she said.Referring to India championing the right to ‚Äòequal protection of law‚Äô in 1949 for ‚ÄòInternational Covenant on Civil and Political Rights‚Äô, Jeria said, ‚ÄúIt is remarkable that after 60 years, this very issue lies at the heart of the SC deliberations as it examines CAA. This presents SC with a historic and unique opportunity to give practical meaning to this fundamental right (equal protection of law) at the domestic level.‚ÄùWhile requesting SC to take into account international human rights laws, norms and standards in proceedings relating to CAA, she gave an example of similar interventions by UNHCHR in judicial forums of other countries in human right issues.While a special rapporteur, an independent expert appointed to work on behalf of the UN, had earlier filed a plea in India‚Äôs Supreme Court on the Rohingya issue, this is probably the first time a UN body has sought to intervene in the top court on a domestic law.Jeria, who has a background of human rights activism and represented the socialist party in Chile, has been very critical of CAA since it was passed by Parliament in December and also the government‚Äôs handling of J&K. Speaking at the 43rd session of the Human Rights Council last week, she expressed concern over reports of police inaction in the face of attacks against Muslims by other groups, as well as previous reports of excessive use of force by police against peaceful protesters.On Kashmir , she had said that while life had been disrupted by heavy military presence, no steps had been taken to address allegations of excessive use of force and other serious human rights violations by security forces.India has in recent weeks pushed back against Turkey, Malaysia and entities of the US Congress for criticising provisions of CAA.

Title: Don‚Äôt panic, says PM Narendra Modi after review meet
Content: NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday reviewed the country‚Äôs preparedness to tackle a possible Covid-19 outbreak and told people not to panic. ‚ÄúDifferent ministries and states are working together, from screening people arriving in India to providing prompt medical attention,‚Äù he tweeted.‚ÄúThere is no need to panic. We need to work together, take small yet important measures to ensure self-protection,‚Äù Modi said. The PM also shared an advisory on the basic protective measures people can take to avoid contracting the virus, such as washing hands frequently; maintaining social distancing; avoiding touching eyes, nose and mouth; practicing respiratory hygiene and seeking medical care at the earliest if one has fever, cough and difficulty breathing.

Title: House logjam on, government offers debate after Holi
Content:
Lok Sabha Speaker Om Birla (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The logjam in Parliament does not show any sign of easing with the government seeking to schedule a discussion on the riots in Delhi on March 11 after Holi next week and the opposition adamant that the violence be debated before any significant legislative business is taken up.

Attempts to pass the ‚ÄòVivad se Vishwas‚Äô bill, which seeks to provide a resolution to tax disputes that add up to Rs 9.3 lakh crore, failed with just a few clauses passed on in the midst of protests in Lok Sabha on Tuesday afternoon when Congress‚Äôs Adhir Ranjan Choudhury vigorously contested the bid to pass the legislation.

As was the case on Monday, opposition and treasury bench members were seen jostling with each other after Speaker Om Birla ‚Äôs suggestion to discuss the Delhi riots on March 11, a day after Holi, was rejected. The government said it was willing to discuss the violence at a date set by the Speaker but to do immediately is avoidable since normalcy is just restored.

Rajya Sabha was adjourned thrice and could not transact any business on Tuesday over the opposition's demand for a debate on the Delhi riots. Leader of opposition Ghulam Nabi Azad wondered aloud why the government was adopting double standards by claiming on one hand that the situation in Delhi was normal but insisting that a discussion could not be allowed at present.

Despite Om Birla‚Äôs warning on Tuesday morning ‚Äî that any MP crossing to the other side would be suspended for the remainder of the session ‚Äî Lok Sabha witnessed dramatic scenes with Chowdhury rushing to the well to protest against the transaction of legislative business.

The Speaker had tried to resolve the standoff when he met opposition leaders in the afternoon. Though non-Congress opposition parties seemed ambivalent, Choudhury is understood to have stuck to his guns. Parliamentary affairs minister Pralhad Joshi sought to point out that the bill in question needed to be passed before March 31 as it had serious financial implications.

In Rajya Sabha, Azad said, ‚ÄúAll of us, whether in the opposition or government, condemn the incidents. That Delhi violence is talked about in foreign countries but not discussed even though Parliament is in session... is a little odd. We are not looking to confront the government. We are all saddened; the victims, be it from any community or religion, were fellow humans. 90% of those dead were in the 24-35 age group. Property and shops were also destroyed,‚Äù he said.

Leader of the House Thaawarchand Gehlot got up and said the government was ready for a discussion as per the schedule decided by the Rajya Sabha chairman. The deputy chairman then said the date and time for the discussion would be decided by the chairman.

In Lok Sabha, amid slogans of ‚ÄòDown, Down Amit Shah ‚Äô and ‚ÄòSave our India‚Äô, opposition MPs tore up papers even as Om Birla allowed finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman to introduce the Banking Regulation (Amendment) Bill, 2020. Though Lok Sabha passed six clauses of the ‚ÄòVivad se Vishwas‚Äô tax resolution bill amid the ensuing din, it could not pass the bill because of the ruckus that followed.

As Congress, TMC, SP and DMK MPs rushed into the well, BJP MP Locket Chatterjee attempted to prevent Chowdhury from moving towards the treasury benches. As Congress MPs rushed behind Chowdhury, BJP MPs Nishikant Dubey , Ravi Shankar Prasad and Jagdambika Pal rushed in to defuse tensions, but heated exchanges followed, forcing Om Birla to adjourn the House for the day around 2.15 pm.

Amid the din, BJP and Congress members pushed each other while some were seen banging the swivel door leading to the secretary general‚Äôs desk. Slanging matches and sloganeering continued even after the House was adjourned. Women and child development minister Smriti Irani engaged in a war of words with Congress MPs K Suresh and Benny Behanan over banging the secretary general‚Äôs door.

Even as opposition parties demanded that PM Narendra Modi address the House and called for Shah‚Äôs resignation, the Speaker strongly opposed waving of placards and banners. He asked Congress, ‚ÄúPlease say it as a party... do you want Parliament to be run with placards and banners... say so.‚Äù

Title: Girl and father held for aiding Pulwama bomber
Content:
‚ÄòArrested man was main conduit of funds for jihadis operating in

Jammu

and Kashmir'

NEW DELHI/ SRINAGAR : Days after the NIA arrested an overground Jaish worker who drove the Pulwama suicide bomber to the attack site, a father-daughter duo has landed in the agency‚Äôs net for allegedly facilitating and sheltering terror conspirators involved in the February 14, 2019, strike that killed 40 CRPF personnel.Tariq Ahmed Shah, 50, a resident of Hakripora village in Pulwama, and his daughter Insha Jan, 23, are accused of having harboured suicide bomber Adil Ahmad Dar , Pakistani terrorists Umer Farooq and Kamran (both killed in subsequent encounters with security forces in J&K), Jaish terrorist from Pulwama Sameer Ahmad Dar and another Pakistani terrorist Mohd Ismail, at their residence.The NIA claimed that Tariq Shah, a tipper truck driver in south Kashmir, admitted that his Hakripora house was used to shelter the terrorists as they planned the attack on the CRPF convoy. It was at his house that the video of Dar, released by Jaish after the Pulwama attack, was recorded before the attack, the agency claimed.Insha Jan provided the terrorists food and other logistics during their stay in 2018-19 on more than 15 occasions, each lasting two to four days, the NIA said.Initial interrogation revealed that Insha was in constant touch with Umar Farooq, the Pakistani IED maker, and was in communication with him over telephone and social media platforms, the agency claimed.Tuesday‚Äôs arrests come on the heels of the first big breakthrough with the arrest of Jaish overground worker Shakir Bashir Magrey, a resident of Hajibal in Kakapora , Pulwama. Magrey, as per the NIA, had driven Adil Dar to a point 500 metres short of the attack site. He had also helped secure material for the IED used in the attack and is said to have ordered ammonium powder, batteries and gloves from Amazon.As per sources, the Shah family comprising Tariq and Insha had earlier given shelter to Abu Dujana, slain Pakistani Lashkar-e-Taiba commander, during 2017-2018. They added that Tariq Shah was involved in ferrying terrorists from the Wagah border and was the main conduit of funds for terrorists operating in the Kashmir Valley.Dujana was killed in the vicinity of Hakripora, 13km from Pulwama town on July 13, 2018, after he deserted Insha and developed a relationship with another woman in a nearby village . It is also believed that Insha informed the police about Dujana‚Äôs presence in that house with another woman.Reports said the NIA, accompanied by police and CRPF, raided Tariq Shah‚Äôs residence early on Tuesday. Both, Tariq and Insha, were taken to the nearest police station before being handed over to an NIA team.

Title: Wife of Major killed in Jammu and Kashmir operation after Pulwama to join Army
Content:
Nitika Kaul, widow of late Major Vibhuti Dhoundiyal, has got a letter from OTA, Chennai. She currently works w... Read More

DEHRADUN: Nitika Kaul, widow of Major Vibhuti Dhoundiyal , who was killed in a military operation after the Pulwama terror attack, is all set to join the technical wing of the Indian Army .

Kaul, 26, currently working with a software company in Noida, has cleared the Army‚Äôs entrance exam ( Services Selection Board ) and also received a call letter from the Officers Training Academy , Chennai, her family members told TOI on Tuesday. Since her husband was killed in action, she was given a relaxation in age limit to appear in the recruitment test.

A video of Nitika bidding a tearful adieu to her husband was widely circulated on social media last year in which she was seen giving a message to her husband before he was laid to rest ‚Äî ‚ÄúYou said you loved me, but the fact is you loved the nation more‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll love you till my last breath. I owe my life to you.‚Äù Almost a year after Major Dhoundiyal was killed, Kaul is set to serve in the Army.

Hope I get opportunity to serve India the way my husband did: Nitika

Saroj Dhoundiyal, Kaul‚Äôs mother-in-law, told TOI that she is very happy for her daughter-in-law. ‚ÄúShe is a brave girl and takes care of us like a daughter. We are glad to have her in our lives,‚Äù she said, adding that she was the first to get the news of Kaul getting the offer letter. ‚ÄúIt feels great that she put me above her own parents and called me first,‚Äù she said.

Talking to TOI on the first death anniversary of her husband on February 18, Kaul had said, ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt resist myself to love what my husband loved the most. I hope even I will get an opportunity to serve the country the way he did.‚Äù Nitika and Vibhuti had met while in college and had got married in April 2018. A few months before their first wedding anniversary, Major Dhoundiyal was killed while taking part in an operation in J&K to flush out militants after the Pulwama attack.

Kaul, a Kashmiri Pandit who moved to Delhi in the 1990s, said that her mother-in-law motivated her to join the Army. ‚ÄúEvery time I see her, I see a hero. Her grief is no less, still she supported me throughout,‚Äù said Kaul, who has an MBA in marketing operations.

Title: 5 foreigners told to leave over stir: Government
Content:
An anti CAA protest (File photo used for representation)

NEW DELHI: Five foreigners were asked to leave India for violating visa norms by participating in protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, the government informed the Lok Sabha on Tuesday.

‚ÄúAs reported by the Bureau of Immigration , five foreign nationals who violated visa norms by participating in anti-CAA protests were asked to leave India,‚Äù junior home minister Nityanand Rai said in a written reply.

One of them was Jakob Lindenthal , a German exchange student in IIT-Madras. Another was Norwegian tourist Janne-Mette Johansson, who had participated in anti-CAA protests in Kochi in December 2019.

Title: With Vande Mataram stand, PM Narendra Modi tries to corner opposition on ‚Äònationalism‚Äô
Content:
PM Narendra Modi (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Raising the nationalism bar higher, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday took on his predecessor Manmohan Singh and others opposing the raising of ‚Äò Vande Mataram ‚Äô and ‚Äò Bharat Mata ki Jai ‚Äô slogans and said it was painful to see continuing resistance to chants dedicated to the motherland.

Referring to Singh‚Äôs recent criticism of what he called the misuse of ‚ÄòBharat Mata ki Jai‚Äô slogans, Modi said, ‚ÄúIt is strange and sad that a former prime minister sniffs foul play even in a slogan like 'Bharat Mata ki Jai' and looks at it with suspicion.‚Äù

At a recent event, Singh had said the slogan of 'Bharat Mata ki Jai' was being misused to construct a ‚Äúmilitant and purely emotional‚Äù idea of India that excluded millions of citizens.

Addressing the BJP parliamentary party meeting, Modi said he was aghast to see opposition to ‚ÄòVande Mataram‚Äô and ‚ÄòBharat Mata ki Jai‚Äô even after 70 years of freedom. ‚ÄúSinging of ‚ÄòVande Mataram‚Äô used to be opposed before independence but it is painful to see people having quarrel with chants dedicated to the motherland even 70 years after the country became free,‚Äù a source quoted the PM as telling BJP MPs.

‚ÄúIn the closed-door meetings of Congress, similar controversies were created over 'Vande Mataram' during the freedom struggle and singing it was adjudged to be a ‚Äògunah‚Äô (crime) with many people choosing to leave meetings of the Congress when it was played,‚Äù the source quoted the PM as saying.

‚ÄúIt is unfortunate and sad that 70 years after independence, raising a slogan like 'Bharat Mata ki Jai' is being depicted as a crime... It is equally unfortunate that a person who held the post of prime minister is saying so,‚Äù Modi said and added that such a view would disappoint and hurt any citizen of the country.

The PM‚Äôs remarks acquire significance also in that they come against the backdrop of the anti-CAA protesters displaying the national flag at their sit-ins ‚Äî something which has been interpreted as an attempt to weaken BJP‚Äôs hold over the ‚Äúnationalism‚Äù plank.

Modi‚Äôs speech is an indication that BJP is not just unwilling to let others freely grab a slice of its plank. It marked a challenge to opponents to take the game to a level where it would be uncomfortable. The opposition is not enthusiastic about Vande Mataram out of respect to the sensibilities of Muslims. The minority community has been opposed to the singing of Vande Mataram ‚Äî the popular anthem of the the freedom struggle ‚Äî on the ground that it represents idolatry. The community also did not warm up to Bharat Mata ki Jai for the same reason.

The resistance was one of the main reasons why Jana Gana Mana and not Vande Mataram was selected as the national anthem. Though the lines from Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyaya ‚Äôs iconic Anand Math were consecrated as the national song, the post-independence phase saw its progressive diminution.

For the BJP, Vande Mataram and Bharat Mata ki Jai have been an integral part of its imagination of nationhood. Under Modi, the two symbols loom even larger, with the PM beginning his speeches with Bharat Mata ki Jai. His rallies are marked by full-throated invocations of Vande Mataram.

In his first public meeting after the enactment of the CAA , Modi had noted the use of the national flag in protests against the new citizenship law to say that he expected the heartening spectacle to be followed through by similar respect for national symbols in all situations.

Addressing BJP MPs, Modi suggested that the opposition to Vande Mataram and Bharat Mata ki Jai had cast a greater responsibility on BJP workers. ‚ÄúThere are some parties for whom political interests are supreme but for us national interest is of utmost importance,‚Äù the PM said, adding that some forces were working to destabilise the country, which should be countered with the same strength.

‚ÄúIt is unfortunate that the country has been divided in two sides of ‚Äòdesh hit‚Äô (nation‚Äôs interest) and ‚Äòdal hit‚Äô (party‚Äôs interest). However, we BJP workers will have to strive for the nation and make it a winner,‚Äù Modi said, adding such a commitment to the nation can be fulfilled only with complete dedication.

Quoting the PM, parliamentary affairs minister Pralhad Joshi said, ‚ÄúVikas (development) is our mantra and peace, harmony and unity are prerequisites for the country's development. We should not merely speak about it but take the lead in ensuring peace, harmony and unity.‚Äù

Title: Stop playing clown, focus on coronavirus threat, says Rahul Gandhi
Content:
Dear @PMOIndia, Quit wasting India's time playing the clown with your social media accounts, when India is facing‚Ä¶ https://t.co/0TzZhnqzUd ‚Äî Rahul Gandhi (@RahulGandhi) 1583229119000

Title: DPR for expansion of Indrapuri reservoir almost ready: Minister
Content:
PATNA: The detailed project report (DPR) for the expansion of the reservoir of the Indrapuri barrage, also called Indrapuri Reservoir Project , was almost ready for submission to the concerned, water resources department minister Sanjay Kumar Jha said in the state assembly on Tuesday.

The expanded reservoir on river Sone would provide assured irrigation facility to the districts like Rohtas, Kaimur, Bhojpur, Buxar, Aurangabad, Arwal, Gaya and Patna.

Jha said work on the expansion of the reservoir would require the consent and cooperation from the governments of Jharkhand and Uttar Pradesh, as well as necessary clearances from the central bodies like Central Water Commission (CWC), Jal Shakti and Union forest and climate change ministries.

The minister was giving the government‚Äôs reply to the call attention question of several members, including Sudama Prasad, Satyadeo Ram and Mahboob Alam from CPI(ML), Mohammad Nematullah, Rahul Tiwari and Bhai Birendra from RJD and Ramdeo Rai from Congress, among others. They asked as to when the work would begin on the construction of the Kadwan dam.

Jha said the then CM had laid the foundation for the construction of Kadwan dam in 1990, but it remained confined to the files and exchange of letters with the officials concerned.

Later on February 14, 2017, CM Nitish Kumar held a detailed review meeting on the matter at Matianw village in Nauhatta block of Rohtas district to explore the ways to make the project feasible. In-depth discussions were held on various aspects related to Kadwan dam, including the interstate matters.

It was decided to rename the Kadwan dam project as Indrapuri Reservoir Project following the cabinet approval on June 28, 2017, besides on the preparation of the detailed report for administrative sanction to it. The consultant roped in to prepare the DPR started the work on August 28 the same year, Jha said.

He added that the consultancy firm had almost completed the work related to different aspects of the project and it was also ready to submit the required DPR. However, the consents of the UP and Jharkhand governments, besides clearances from the central government bodies would also be required before starting the expansion work on the reservoir.

For, the expansion of the reservoir would submerge ryoti land in Jharkhand, while the supply of water through Sone river has to be increased and kept steady by the UP government, Jha said.

Title: Check affiliation status of schools: CBSE
Content:
PATNA: As the new academic session is set to start from next month, the Central Board of Secondary Education ( CBSE ) has cautioned parents against admitting their kids to non-affiliated schools.

According to sources, the CBSE has noticed that some non-affiliated schools are misleading parents with their affiliated status. Many, whose affiliations are under process or rejected by the Board, are providing them with wrong information.

In a statement issued on Monday, CBSE secretary Anurag Tripathi said, ‚ÄúAs per clause 14.2.2 of its Affiliation Bye-Laws, 2018, the CBSE does not allow candidates of non-affiliated schools to appear for the Board exams. Therefore, parents, who wish to admit their ward (s) to CBSE schools, are alerted and requested to check their affiliation status first.‚Äù

CBSE‚Äôs city coordinator and principal of Baldwin Academy, Rajiv Ranjan Sinha, told this newspaper on Tuesday that the Board had taken the step to stop flying and non-attending students from writing the exams of classes X and XII.
