He said the walk would last two hours and participants would be informed of the different aspects of the garden‚Äôs ecology as well. ‚ÄúThe garden is known for local as well as exotic trees. A seasoned ecologist, Kedar Champhekar, will be present to guide participants on the walk,‚Äù he said.

Paranjpe said participants will get to learn about names of different birds such as wooded and water birds. ‚ÄúMany bird species are spotted at the garden. So, participants will get to learn a lot about them with the help of experts,‚Äù he said.

Title: Maharashtra: Dead leopard found in Junnar taluka
Content:
PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: A dead female leopard was found in Dholvad village, around 17km from Junnar taluka and 99km from Pune, on Tuesday morning.

Range forest officer (RFO) of Ottur, Yogesh Ghodke , said the dead leopard was found in an open field owned by farmer Shankar Nalawade.

Forest guard VR Adagale said, ‚ÄúA villager informed us about a dead leopard lying in a field around 10.15am, following which a forest department team rushed to the spot. The animal was around 12-15 months old. We took the animal to the Leopard Rescue Centre (LRC) at Manikdoh for post mortem.‚Äù

Veterinary officer Nikhil Bangar said, ‚ÄúThere were bite marks on the left side of its neck and on the chest region. Normally territorial fights occur between big leopards. This was a small leopard so it could have also been attacked by other wild animals such as hyenas, or even dogs.‚Äù

Title: You can soon dine in the open in south Delhi eateries
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhiites may soon treat themselves to a new dining experience. Taking a cue from European countries, south Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) is planning to allow open-air restaurants along with light music.A draft policy has already been prepared, a senior official said. ‚ÄúThe new policy will allow the existing health trade-licence holders to use their open space for such restaurants. Besides offering a new dining experience, the move will also help the civic body in generating more revenues,‚Äù he added.SDMC has around 2,000 restaurants and eateries under its jurisdiction and several hundreds of these establishments will be able to utilise their open space on the ground floor to expand their operations. The draft proposal will now be sent to the deliberative wing of the corporation for the final approval.The draft makes it clear that ‚Äúneither live band performances nor loud music will be allowed. Only light music like mellow jazz or ghazal can be played in the background,‚Äù another official said. Regulations prohibit noise levels to be higher than 45-55 decibels in the residential areas.However, unlike some west European countries, establishments will not be allowed to use the pavement space for seating arrangements. ‚ÄúOpen areas should be privately owned by a licensee and no public area can be encroached upon,‚Äù the official added.To prevent fire accidents, the draft prohibits any open-area kitchen. ‚ÄúFood will have to be prepared in enclosed kitchens, which will have to follow all safety standards in terms of hygiene and fire safety,‚Äù he said.To regulate these open-air restaurants, SDMC has decided that only people with a licence for running an indoor restaurant will be allowed to run these new facilities.While the draft proposes a licensing fee of around Rs 100 per square foot, the final rates will be decided by the standing committee and the SDMC House. ‚ÄúThis policy will now be sent to the standing committee and minor tweaks are expected,‚Äù the official said. Under the current plan, an open-air restaurant with a sitting capacity of 50 people may have to shell out Rs 45-50,000 annually.

Title: Dr B R Ambedkar image at all Ahmedabad police offices soon
Content:
A circular was recently issued directing that a portrait or statue of Dr Ambedkar be put up at all police stat... Read More

AHMEDABAD: City police seem to have decided to pay tribute to the father of the Indian Constitution, Dr B R Ambedkar , 70 years after the Constitution came into force on January 26, 1950. A circular was recently issued directing that a portrait or statue of Dr Ambedkar be put up at all police stations, ACP (assistant commissioner of police) and DCP (deputy commissioner of police) offices across the city.

Circular number 423/2020 issued on February 28 with the subject ‚Äú71st Republic Day‚Äù states, ‚ÄúIt is being informed that you will have to put a portrait/statue of Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar at the office or branches being headed by you. All have been directed to act accordingly because we are observing the 71st year of the introduction of the Indian Constitution.‚Äù

DCP, control, Vijay Patel, who issued the circular, said the decision was with an eye on teh birth anniversary of Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar on April 14. ‚ÄúBesides, we have been celebrating 70 years of the Indian Constitution, due to which the decision was taken,‚Äù said Patel.

He further said that they received an order from the home department to put up portraits of Dr Ambedkar. Patel said every police station must have a portrait of Dr Ambedkar now.

Police officials said police stations or other offices at present only have portraits of Mahatma Gandhi and Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel.

‚ÄúWe began putting up portraits of Mahatma Gandhi after they were presented by a trust three years ago. In October 2019, it was directed to put up portraits of Sardar Patel during the ‚ÄòRun for Unity‚Äô event. We do not have portraits of Dr Babasaheb in our police stations,‚Äù said a police official.

The official added that this should have done earlier, because the police administration and implementation of law are governed by the Constitution.

City police commissioner Ashish Bhatia also said that the circular to put up portraits of Dr Ambedkar was issued recently.

Title: Dogs suspected in retired headmistress‚Äôs death in Haripad
Content:
Representative image

ALAPPUZHA: A retired school headmistress , found unconscious with bite marks on her body, died while being shifted to a hospital at Haripad on Tuesday.

Neighbours said Rajamma, 87, of Pilappuzha, was attacked by stray dogs, but hospital sources said the wounds might not have caused her death.

The incident came to light around 7pm, when a woman from the neighbourhood reached Rajamma‚Äôs house, where she used to sleep since the elderly woman had been living alone.

The woman searched for Rajamma on not finding her in the house. She and a few others soon found Rajamma lying unconscious. Neighbours expressed suspicion that the dogs might have attacked her when she went to burn accumulated dry leaves.

‚ÄúThere were bite injuries on the back of her head and hands. There are no houses close by, and others did not hear anything. Though neighbours took her to Haripad Government Hospital , her life could not be saved,‚Äù police said, adding that the body has been kept in the morgue.

Haripad sub-inspector M Hussain said the exact cause of death could be ascertained only after post-mortem at Alappuzha Medical College Hospital on Wednesday.

‚ÄúWe also suspect that she might have fallen unconscious due to age-related ailments and after that dogs might have attacked her. However, we are awaiting an autopsy report,‚Äù the officer said.

Rajamma was the headmistress of Aroor Lower Primary School. She leaves behind son Sreekumar , and daughters Sandhya and Mini.

Title: Amaravati fight reaches ICJ as NRI alleges rights abuse
Content: VIJAYAWADA: The fight for Amaravati has now reached the International Court of Justice at the Hague, Netherlands, with a Telugu NRI advocate based in the USA knocking at the world court over alleged human rights violation in the capital region of Andhra Pradesh .The advocate, Kaveti Srinivas Rao, who runs a chain of law firms in the USA and other parts of the world, has made India a party to the case alleging that the Government of India (GOI) is silent on the ‚Äúviolation of human rights‚Äù in Amaravati.Farmers, who gave up their land for the AP capital city, have been on the streets for the last three months protesting AP government‚Äôs decision to shift the capital to Visakhapatnam.Srinivas is also moving the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva, Switzerland, seeking justice for the farmers of Amaravati. He named the Prime Minister, Andhra Pradesh chief minister and the Director-General of Police (DGP), AP, as the respondents. He alleged in his petition that there was gross violation of rights of farmers in Amaravati.The case is before the International Criminal Court, part of the ICJ. While disputes between nations is dealt by the world court, private persons can knock at the doors of the International Criminal Court.Srinivas said the petition was moved in the international court as the GOI had ‚Äúfailed‚Äù to take action on the human rights violations and police ‚Äúrepression‚Äù on the farmers protesting against the proposed shifting of capital from Amaravati.Dileep Thalluri, a representative of Kaveti Law Firm in India, said though the National Women Commission sent a team to Amaravati, no action was initiated on the violation of women‚Äôs rights.Dileep said Srinivas had appeared before the office of prosecutor in International Criminal Court and presented his arguments. Though the petition has been acknowledged by the office of the prosecutor, it is yet to be admitted.

Title: Protesters surround BJP chief‚Äôs car, waive black flags
Content:
Representative image

GAIRSAIN: BJP state chief Bansidhar Bhagat ‚Äôs vehicle was surrounded by General and OBC Employee Association members near the police barracading at Diwalikhal, about four-kilometre-away from the assembly building.

The protesters raised anti-government slogans and demanded that promotions of government employees be cleared immediately. Police team rushed to the rescue of Bhagat and his car was safely escorted towards the assembly building. Later Bhagat said, ‚ÄúThere was no stone pelting on my vehicle. The protestors raised slogans against the government in favour of their demands. There was no violence.‚Äù

Title: Journalist attacked by gang in Sivakasi
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: A reporter of a Tamil magazine, was attacked by an unidentified gang in Sivakasi in Virudhunagar district on Tuesday night.

The injured reporter, identified as Karthi, has been admitted to the Sivakasi government hospital. Karthi, Virudhunagar district reporter of the Tamil magazine ‚ÄòKumudham Reporter,‚Äô was attacked by a mob with poles and weapons in Sivakasi, in which he sustained injuries.

Sivakasi police sources said that a case would be registered after investigation. Many journalists associations have demanded the arrest of those responsible behind the attack.

Title: City‚Äôs beauty with brains is first runner-up in pageant
Content:
Sarita Samatkar: ‚ÄòMiss Skindrella‚Äô

Nagpur: Intellect, clarity of thought and witty answers the city software engineer Sarita Samatkar gave earned her the first runner-up prize at the national beauty pageant ‚ÄòMiss Skindrella 2020‚Äô.

The only Maharashtrian to participate in the contest held at Delhi to celebrate natural beauty and inner confidence, Sarita was at her best and was a picture perfect.

Sarita said, ‚ÄúI came to know about the beauty contest on Facebook. I was fascinated as the contest was more than just showcasing outer beauty. I had participated last year also and was selected in top fifty. This year, I was determined to make it to the finals.‚Äù

She said it was tough as there were over 20,000 participants from 33 cities, and the girls participating in the pageant had to solicit votes to make it to the list of the participants. Sarita mustered enough votes and finally landed in Delhi to participate.

‚ÄúI uploaded my pictures and got enough votes to enter straight away into the top 100. I then made it to the top 10. After this, I sent a video to the organizers where I explained why I want to participate in the competition,‚Äù Sarita said.

The contest was different in the sense there were no evening gown or swimwear rounds and ramp walk. She said, ‚ÄúThere were no parameters of having a specific body type. I had a question and answer round in which I gave honest opinion. My witty answers too weighed in my favour.‚Äù

Sarita won Rs1 lakh cash prize, a silver jewellery hamper and an opportunity to become ambassador for a brand that makes skincare products.

The jury members were journalist Ambika Singh, cinematographer-director Sandeep Salariya and actress Saheba Bali, besides others.

‚ÄúIt is an overwhelming feeling to be the only Maharashtrian in the contest and bring laurels to the city,‚Äù an elated Sarita said.

Title: Speaker dials Chamoli DM over poor internet services, mobile connectivity
Content:
Representative image

GAIRSAIN: Expressing his displeasure over poor mobile and Internet connectivity at Bhararisain in Gairsain area of Chamoli district , Speaker Prem Chand Agarwal said, ‚ÄúI was told that both mobile and Internet connectivity will be in place here by February 28, but it‚Äôs already March 3 and services are extremely poor still. I have called Chamoli DM and will definitely talk to her about the issue and see that it is taken care of at the earliest.‚Äù

Title: Ahmedabad woman rebuffs coworker, he threatens acid attack
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 19-year-old woman from the Krishnanagar area of city on Monday filed a complaint with city police alleging that a 22-year-old man, her superior at work, threatened to disfigure her with acid because she refused to enter a relationship with him.

The woman also alleged that the accused, Pravin Rathod, published morphed pictures of her, but Krishnanagar police did not invoke charges under the Information Technology (IT) Act against him.

In her FIR, Sakshi Shah, who a second year BA student at BD Arts College in Kadi, works at a multiplex in Krishnanagar as her father is dead.

She had met the accused, her supervisor at work, when she took up the job in November last year.

‚ÄúAs I was working with him, I started talking to him in a platonic manner but he began sending me messages frequently and would also call me every now and then,‚Äù Shah stated in the FIR.

‚ÄúRecently, he stopped me outside our workplace and told me that he wants a relationship with me and pressured me to accept his proposal. When I refused, he threatened to throw acid on my face,‚Äù she adds.

Even after this, Rathod tried contacting her several times. As she blocked his number, he kept calling from 10 different numbers. ‚ÄúHe had also morphed pictures of me with him and published them online,‚Äù she said.

She finally approached police and filed a complaint against Rathod.

Inspector V R Chaudhari of Krishnanagar police station said that they have booked the accused under IPC sections 507 (criminal intimidation by an anonymous communication) and 506(2) (criminal intimidation).

On why charges under the IT Act were not invoked, Chaudhari said police were yet to verify whether he had morphed and published the pictures.

Title: Officials inspect Vandiyur tank, discuss revival steps
Content:
Madurai: A team of officials led by the chairman of the Tamil Nadu Water Resources and Conservation and Rivers Restoration Corporation (TNWRCRRC), K Satyagopal, conducted an inspection at the Vandiyur tank on Tuesday and discussed ways and means by which the tank can be revived.

Only a small portion of the tank, measuring more than 600 acres, holds water due to encroachment in the inlet channels and other waters bodies, through which water was once fed to it.

Officials discussed the various measures to be undertaken to revive the tank including increasing the water capacity, removing encroachments, clearing inlet and outlet channels and to increase the height and width of bund.

The team also inspected the water recharging structure constructed under kudimaramarathu scheme. K Satyagopal, held discussions on revival of other water bodies as well, including Vaigai river in the city.

Madurai district collector T G Vinay, Madurai corporation commissioner S Visakan, city engineer S Arasu and officials from public works department were present during the inspection.

Title: 20-year-old ends life in Pune after being scolded by parents
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A youth (20) hanged himself on Sunday afternoon near his residence in Ambegaon Taluka, around 50kms from here, after his parents scolded him for being always engrossed in his cellphone.

The Manchar police have registered a case of accidental death in this regard. The deceased, Hritik Suresh Mankar of Kashimbeg village in Ambegaon Taluka, was pursuing bachelors in commerce from a college in Manchar.

Police said Mankar‚Äôs father worked in Mumbai and had visited his the house during the weekends. ‚ÄúOn Sunday, Mankar‚Äôs parents scolded him for spending too much on his cellphone,‚Äù an officer from the Manchar police said. The officer said they suspect that the scolding might have upset Mankar, who soon left the house and went to a shed adjacent to it. ‚ÄúThe parents said the youth did not return for nearly two hours, following which they called him on his cellphone. When they did not receive a response, they went out to look for him,‚Äù the officer said.

The officer said the family members soon located the shed. ‚ÄúThey found their son hanging from a rope tied to the iron bar of the roof of the shed,‚Äù the officer said.

‚ÄúThe family rushed Manchar to a nearby hospital but he was pronounced dead on arrival,‚Äù the officer added.

Title: Telangana needs Rs 10,000 crore for irrigation projects
Content: HYDERABAD: The Telangana government requires at least Rs 10,000 crore to complete canal and civil works on various irrigation projects. Though priority is given for irrigation sector and completion of irrigation projects, the state government is not in a position to earmark more funds owing to the fiscal condition.A senior irrigation official said there are several civil works that need to be completed with state funds (budget) since loan amount cannot be used other than on electro mechanical works and pump houses as per the rules. ‚ÄúThe government has been completing projects like Kaleshwaram, Palamuru-Rangareddy, Sitarama and Devadula projects with financial assistance from agencies like Power Finance Corporation for the past one year,‚Äù he said.A chief engineer of irrigation department said civil works were pending even in Kaleshwaram from Mid Manair to Konda Pochamma reservoir. ‚ÄúSimilarly, Sitarama and Palamuru-Rangareddy project works are also pending for the last one year. For some projects like Dindi, there is no linkage for financial assistance,‚Äù he explained.In the vote-on-account for the year 2019-20, the state government had allocated Rs 22,500 crore for irrigation projects and Mission Kakatiya works. But in September 2019, the budget was downsized to Rs 8,000 crore, including cost on establishment charges, official sources said.Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao in his budget speech said the government was completing the irrigation projects with funds obtained from the financial institutions and margin money. He also assured that works on Kaleshwaram, Palamuru-Rangareddy, Sitarama, Devadula and other projects would continue without interruption.Sources said the government so far has spent Rs 3,000 crore from the state budget. The government is looking to complete Kaleshwaram link up to Mallannasagar by June and Sitarama and other projects by next rabi. Last year, rejuvenation of lakes could not be taken up under Misison Kakatiya due to election season. The government is now aiming at completing rejuvenation of 20,000 lakes of total 45,000 this financial year.

Title: 37,000 Class XI students to take board exams from today
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: As many as 36,904 Class XI students from 323 schools in the district are expected to appear for their board exams starting Wednesday. A total of 17,924 boys and 18,980 girls, including 151 differently-abled and 32 poor-sighted candidates, will be writing their Language paper exam on Wednesday at the 120 designated exam centres in the district. In Madurai , 1,056 more girls are appearing for the Class XI exams when compared to boys.

This will be first time that the students will be writing the exam based on a new syllabus for 100 marks per subject. ‚ÄúThe new syllabus is definitely voluminous. Students were already facing difficulty when switching from Samacheer syllabus in Class X to the Class XI syllabus. So a new syllabus for Class XI is challenging. If the students do well now, they would find it easier when they move on to Class XII,‚Äù said a headmaster of a government higher secondary school.

To motivate Class XI students and teachers, many schools here are set to hold formal prayers on Wednesday morning before the exams. All centres have been equipped to provide uninterrupted water supply and electricity. The students are required to carry only their hall tickets and materials. Strict restrictions are also in place to prevent cheating.

Title: Telangana farmer‚Äôs Rs 9,000 UPI payment lands him in espionage case
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A farmer in a remote village of Jagtial district in Telangana landed in a soup for making an innocuous online payment to a person in Jammu and Kashmir . Reason: he sent Rs 9,000 to an accused in an espionage case. Ironically, the transactions were carried out a month after the accused was arrested.

A Jammu & Kashmir police team are questioning Linganna, 36, a farmer from Kusthapur village, for his role in the espionage case registered in January.

A three-member team of Arnia police in Jammu district, led by sub-inspector (SI) Hussain, arrived in Mallapur town in Jagtial district on Monday night. With the help of local police, the team picked up Linganna from Kusthapur village on Tuesday in relation to the espionage case.

According to police sources, J&K police had arrested Rakesh Kumar, a resident of Arnia on January 5, 2020, for sharing information about military establishments with a woman through Facebook. ‚ÄúPolice believe the woman was a spy working for Pakistan‚Äôs Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI) and they arrested Rakesh Kumar for sharing details of security installations in and around Arnia, a town close to the Line of Control (LoC),‚Äù a source said.

Over a month after Rakesh Kumar was arrested, Linganna had transferred Rs 5,000 into the bank account of Rakesh Kumar through Google Pay on February 13, 2020 and Rs 4,000 on February 25. ‚ÄúArnia police, who had analysed the bank account transactions of Rakesh Kumar, noticed the funds transfer from Linganna. After obtaining details from the bank, they reached Jagtial on Monday night to question him,‚Äù Telangana police said.

On interrogation, Linganna told police that he transferred the money on the instructions of his brother-in-law, Srinivas. Police said Srinivas, a native of Mogilpet village in Mallapur mandal, has been working in Dubai for the past 10 years.

‚ÄúThe Jammu & Kashmir police are questioning Linganna. They are now trying to get a warrant from a Jammu court,‚Äù Jagtial superintendent of police (SP) Ch Sindhu Sharma said.

Title: Kolhapur: Watch out for snakes in your premises with rising temperature
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

The surge in the mercury levels has also led to a rise in the number of snake bites in the district ahead of summer. The Chhatrapati Pramila Raje (CPR) hospital has had 13 snake bite cases on single day on Monday. Though snakes belong to the category of coldblooded animals, too much hot or too much cold can lead to their death. Hence, snakes in search of shade and wet places come out of their holes, increasing their chances of them coming in contact with humans.

Snake researcher Umakant Chavan said, ‚ÄúThough snakes are coldblooded animals, they don‚Äôt like it too cold or too hot. They are forced to leave their holes as the surge in the mercury levels also increases the ground level temperature. Snakes migrate to take shelter at shady areas which are cool like backyards, below wooden logs and wetlands. Nullahs and drainage, which are home to mounds of garbage, are found to attact rats. Hence, such places attract snakes as they are cool places to relax in hot summers and they also get their source of prey.‚Äù

Dhananjay Namjoshi , a citizen who takes immense interest in the study of snakes, said, ‚ÄúEarlier during winter, I used to get a call for rescuing snakes from the city limits once in three to four days. Now, I am getting a call everyday. The only precaution people can take to keep snakes away is to keep their surroundings clean. One must stay alert while going in wet areas or near garbage zones. Farmers should use gumboots to avoid snake bites.

‚ÄúThe ratio of snake bites in rural areas is far more compared to the that in the city. Many a times, snake bites go unreported in the rural areas as people there opt for traditional methods to treat bites,‚Äù said Namjoshi.

Assistant professor at CPR Hospital Vijaykumar Barage said, ‚ÄúSnake bite cases increase during the sugarcane cutting season. People in rural areas still go for traditional medication which can sometimes lead to death of a person. Anti-venom syringes should be taken as early as possible. These syringes are available aplenty at the CPR hospital and also at the primary health centres across the district. The anti-venom dosage is decided by the species of the snake and also the intensity the snake bite. For primary first-aid, a cloth can be tied above the area which has been bitten till the time the patient is taken to the nearby health centre for proper treatment‚Äù.

Title: Decisions on Munnar land issues to be based on consensus: Minister
Content:
E Chandrasekharan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The government will take a decision regarding the land issues in Munnar only on the basis of the consensus arrived at in the all-party meeting chaired by the chief minister on December 17, revenue minister E Chandrasekharan said in the assembly .

Replying to a submission by Devikulam MLA S Rajendran seeking a solution to the issues in Munnar, the revenue minister said the government will have to take certain actions as the court also has intervened in the matter. Rajendran said certain officials are taking steps contrary to what has been decided and this is causing difficulties to the public.

The minister said that the government had decided to cancel the thandapers of three buildings, including a hotel, in Munnar on the basis of the recommendation from the vigilance director as these had violated the conditions stipulated in the title. The titles were cancelled and an order has been issued to take the land back to the government on January 21. He said the government had taken action on the basis of the court‚Äôs intervention as well as the recommendation of the vigilance.

An order was earlier issued containing conditions to stop illegal constructions in Munnar. It had said that building permits should be granted only with the conditions, a town planning scheme should be framed for Munnar, etc. The minister said that the all-party meeting was convened after the public and the people‚Äôs representatives raised concerns against the order. He said that there are multiple cases relating to these issues before the high court as well as the National Green Tribunal.

Title: NCC officers, students receive training in disaster management
Content:
RB Udhayakumar, minister for revenue, disaster management and information technology, visiting a stall at the ... Read More

MADURAI: Around 1,500 students, 80 officers of the National Cadet Corps (NCC) took part in a disaster management training workshop conducted at Madurai Kamaraj University (MKU) on Tuesday. During the event, state ministers RB Udhayakumar and Sellur K Raju released pamphlets about disaster management.

The workshop is part of the state‚Äôs coastal disaster risk reduction project wherein NCC students and officers from colleges across Tamil Nadu are to be trained at a cost of Rs 1.23 crore. The inauguration event for the training program was held on February 19 in Chennai.

Practical fire safety and rescue demonstration was also done during the event while an exhibition of the work done by disaster management, fire safety and rescue departments was also organized.

The NCC students and officers who undergo the training will now in turn be creating awareness about disaster management attempting to reach a target of at least 1 lakh students, particularly from rural areas. Further, disaster management awareness programs are also to be held via street plays, villupattu, rallies, exhibitions and distributing pamphlets.

The coastal disaster risk reduction project is funded by the state government and World Bank at a cost of Rs 1560.194 crore to help reduce risk and damage of disasters in coastal areas. As part of the project, various initiatives like advancement of warning devices, building of houses that can withstand disasters, and conversion of electric lines to underground are being undertaken.

Title: Delhi Airport News: Airlines told to take precautions at Delhi airport on Coronavirus by DGCA
Content: NEW DELHI: The airlines and the Airport Health Organization (APHO), which is responsible for screening of flyers for the coronavirus, have been asked to stay alert and heighten vigil by the Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) at the Indira Gandhi International Airport (IGIA).While the passengers from Italy and Iran are also to be screened now, an airport official said no instruction had come to scan domestic travellers.Till early February, only four countries ‚Äî China, Hong Kong, Singapore and Thailand ‚Äî were on the mandatory screening list. It has now been expanded to 12 countries, including Japan, South Korea, Nepal, Indonesia, Vietnam and Malaysia.‚ÄúTo prevent the spread of Covid-19 (novel coronavirus 2019) in India, it has been decided to expand the universal screening of all passengers arriving on flights from Italy and Iran,‚Äù said a DGCA circular dated March 2. The universal screening of all passengers coming on flights from these 12 countries will be carried out immediately after they step out of specific locations at all airports and fill up a self-declaration form as per the instructions of the Union health ministry, it added.An APHO official at IGIA said filling up the self-declaration form, either in-flight or after deboarding, was mandatory. Following this, passengers will have to undergo a thermal screening. ‚ÄúThose showing symptoms are placed under a 14-day quarantine, while those without any symptom are also logged in and we have their data stored. If they develop symptoms or are infected later, we can track them,‚Äù said the official.The instructions further stated that all airlines should make in-flight announcements while flying from these countries and strict compliance needed to be ensured.On Tuesday, DGCA also asked the airlines to disinfect any aircraft arriving from Italy, Japan and South Korea, while boarding and departure of flights to the listed countries will need to be done only after a health screening of all passengers. The airlines have also been asked to provide masks, gloves and sanitisers to their staff and also at airports.The government on Tuesday suspended both regular (sticker) and e-visas granted to Italy, Iran, South Korea and Japan issued on or before March 3.An airport official said all precautions were being undertaken by the staff. ‚ÄúOur staff is providing all assistance to APHO for screening and further precautions will also be incorporated,‚Äù said an official.

Title: CBSE warns parents about unaffiliated schools
Content:
KOCHI: In the wake of the controversy over 29 students of city-based Arooja‚Äôs Little Stars School (ALSS) missing the CBSE Class X exam due to lack of affiliation of the school, the CBSE has issued an advisory notice to parents that they should not to be fooled by school managements that claim that their schools are ‚Äòfollowing CBSE-pattern‚Äô or are ‚Äòto be CBSE-affiliated‚Äô in their advertisements and websites.

The statement signed by CBSE secretary Anurag Tripathi said that such schools are not CBSE-affiliated and the students studying there will not be allowed to write CBSE Class X and XII examinations. CBSE officials said that the notice is the first step to stop the illegal use of board‚Äôs name by non-affiliated schools as a marketing tool.

‚ÄúIt has come to the notice of the Board that some of the non-affiliated schools whose applications are either under process or rejected by the Board, or they have not applied for affiliation at all, are misleading parents by displaying various display boards at schools, prominent locations and on website showing messages such as ‚Äòto be affiliated to CBSE‚Äô, ‚ÄòCBSE Pattern‚Äô, ‚Äòlikely to be affiliated to CBSE‚Äô, ‚Äòrunning under the aegis of CBSE‚Äô etc. It may be noted that as per clause 14.2.2 of its affiliation Bye-Laws, 2018, the board does not allow non-affiliated school to present the candidates to the Board‚Äôs examination,‚Äù said the statement.

The board also asked parents to check the affiliation status (including up to what class the affiliation is given by the board) of schools before enrolling their kids. ‚ÄúThe parents may go through CBSE affiliation website www.cbseaff.nic.in where link for region wise/state wise list of schools has been given and the same also contains list of disaffiliated schools,‚Äù the statement said.

Meanwhile, the Class X students of ALSS and their parents said that the high court‚Äôs interim order directing CBSE to allow them to write the remaining board exam this year has given relief to them. ‚ÄúOur kids are happy and they are busy preparing for the remaining exams. We hope there will be a way to write the missed exams too so that they will not lose one year,‚Äù said Francis Xavier, a parent.

Title: Need alternative plans to WTE plant: Councillors
Content:
Kochi: Councillors who attended corporation council meeting on Tuesday to discuss waste management stressed the need to consider alternative proposals with the National Green Tribunal (NGT) team questioning the viability of the waste-to-energy (WTE) plant at Brahmapuram. Reduction of waste at source, recycling and reuse, among other things, should be encouraged, they opined.

Councillors cutting across party lines raised objection against the state government‚Äôs decision to convert the concessionaire agreement, signed between the corporation and GJ Eco Power Private Limited allotting 23 acres of land for setting up the plant, into a lease agreement.

‚ÄúWe shouldn‚Äôt depend solely on the proposed WTE plant. Alternative projects must be considered, which can promote reduction, recycling and reuse of garbage,‚Äù said V P Chandran, secretary, LDF parliamentary party, Kochi Corporation.

A B Sabu, Congress councillor and former chairman of welfare standing committee, said the conversion of the concessionaire agreement into lease agreement would be detrimental for the local body. ‚ÄúThe private firm would be mortgaging the property for raising funds to set up the plant. If the private firm fails to repay the loan, the responsibility of paying back the amount would fall on the local body. Then, the corporation will lose the land,‚Äù Sabu said. C K Peter, councillor from Konthuruthy, said the local body has been shelling out a huge sum for transportation and treatment of waste and improving infrastructure facilities at the waste treatment plant at Brahmapuram.

‚ÄúThe corporation has spent Rs 3.22 crore for hiring trucks in 2015-16 fiscal while it increased to Rs 3.68 crore in 2016-17 fiscal. In 2017-18, the amount stood at Rs 4.78 crore and increased to Rs 6.86 crore in 2018-19. The cost of treatment of waste has also been going up,‚Äù Peter said.

K J Antony, opposition leader, said leasing out the 23 acres to the private firm can‚Äôt be approved. It will lead to alienation of the land, he said. Gracy Babu Jacob, a ruling front councillor, said the local body authorities have miserably failed in ensuring effective waste management. ‚ÄúThe corporation has been spending crores for hiring trucks for carrying garbage from the city to Brahmapuram. Still, many trucks, bought by the corporation have been lying idle at a yard,‚Äù she said.

Title: JMC proposes a budget of Rs 2,046 crore
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: The officials at Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC) have sent a proposed budget of Rs 2,046 crore to the Directorate of Local Bodies for approval.

Since the municipal board could not be constituted due to delay in municipal elections, the JMC commissioner formed a committee and the budget for 2020-21 was prepared.

A chief engineer, finance adviser, additional commissioner and other officers were part of the committee.

This year, the budget for both the municipal corporations has been bifurcated. For JMC Heritage, Rs 791cr and for JMC Greater, Rs 1,255cr have been allotted. Moreover, the JMC budget has been increased by Rs 171 crore since Rs 1,870 crore were allotted in the 2019-20 budget.

Financial adviser of JMC Mahendra Mohan said that they had sent the proposed budget before February 15. ‚ÄúWe made our calculations and prepared the budget. As per the rules, the budget can be 20% higher than the income of the urban bodies in the preceding financial year. We have followed this for the first time at JMC,‚Äù said Mohan.

Another reason for increase in the cost is that Rs 50 crore has been allotted for Delawas sewage treatment plant. The capacity of the plant is being increased for which Rs 250 crore will be spent. The state government will provide Rs 200 crore and the remaining amount will be provided by JMC.

The budget has been divided in many parts as per the requirements of both the municipal corporations. Surprisingly, major share has been given to JMC Greater and Heritage has been left behind.

The Walled City has been facing sewage problem for a long time still JMC Greater has been allotted more budget.

Therefore, many former councillors from the Walled City have expressed opposition to the decision.

Title: Kerala government, opposition lock horns over Periye twin murder probe
Content:
Kerala chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The opposition and the treasury benches in the assembly on Tuesday locked horns over the probe into the Periye twin murder case. Two Youth Congress workers, Kripesh, 20, and Sharath Lal, 24, were hacked to death, allegedly by CPM workers, at Periye in Kasaragod district last year.

Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said the government does not agree with the high court single bench decision to hand over the case to CBI and that is why it has decided to file an appeal. He said the fees for such appeals have been paid from the government exchequer on earlier occasions too and the practice will continue. The CM‚Äôs usage of the word ‚Äúloudmouth‚Äù and industries minister E P Jayarajan‚Äôs usage of unparliamentary wor-ds against the opposition triggered some tense moments in the assembly when the opposition rushed towards the speaker‚Äôs podium. The CM said things will progress as per law, and since the appeal is pending before a division bench, the government is awaiting its decision.

Seeking a leave for adjournment motion, Shafi Parambil MLA who piloted the demand, said that the government is deliberately causing hindrances in the probe by not handing over the case diary and related documents to the CBI, which the CBI officials have mentioned in their status report before the court.

He said that even though five months have passed since the high court single bench ordered the handing over of the case from the crime branch to the CBI, the crime branch is yet to hand over the documents to the CBI. Stating that the CPM had a clear role in the murders and which is why it is attempting to sabotage the CBI probe, he invited the attention of the chief minister to a recent speech by a CPM local leader in Kasaragod which justified the crime.

Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala asked if the party had no role in these murders, why was the government scared of a CBI inquiry and why it was trying to sabotage the investigation. Chennithala said that the government is trying to figure out ways to save the culprits, and the appeal before the division bench of the high court is a proof of the government‚Äôs mind-set. After speaker P Sreeramakrishnan refused to admit the adjournment motion on the basis of the explanation by the chief minister, the opposition members staged a walk-out.

Observing serious lapses in the police investigation, the high court had in September handed over the case to the CBI after dismissing the chargesheet filed by the crime branch.

The parents of the victims had moved the court seeking a CBI probe, saying police investigation was not on the right track. The state government had challenged the single-bench order for conducting a CBI probe, but a division bench declined to stay it.

Title: Study tours: Schools told to opt for approved tour operators
Content:
Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: State government has issued a set of guidelines to be followed by all school authorities, including CBSE and ICSE institutions, while taking their students for study tours or industrial visits.

A government circular in this regard said the school authorities should choose only government-approved tour operators for the purpose.

‚ÄúThe list of approved tour operators is available on the Kerala tourism website. The indiscriminate selection of tour operators without government registration often creates problems for the tour parties. One such incident in which a group of students from the state got stranded in New Delhi in the middle of their tour is the immediate reason for such a circular,‚Äù said state general education secretary A Shajahan.

Government could seldom act against unregistered tour operators if they dump the tour party in the middle of a journey or cause any other sort of grave inconveniences to student groups, government sources said. The circular wanted the top authorities in schools to take up the total responsibility of all student tours and industrial visits from their institutions.

‚ÄúThe government direction is welcome. There is no second opinion on the fact that top authorities in the schools should be personally responsible for tour programmes. If the government says there is a list of approved and accredited tour operators whose service the schools can opt for smooth conduct of study tours and industrial visits, it is a good suggestion. I think the government intervention would help school authorities in a big way,‚Äù said Kerala CBSE school management association working president G Rajamohan.

Title: Two dead in steel factory accident
Content:
Hyderabad: Two people died after sponge iron fell on them at a factory in Manoharabad of Medak district on Monday. The victims were identified as Suman, 26, of Veliminedu in Nalgonda, and Mahesh Yadav, 26, of Madhya Pradesh.

The mishap occurred at Mahalakshmi Profiles in Manoharabad. Suman drove the truck to the steel factory with a load of sponge iron on Monday night. The accident occurred when the sponge iron was being unloaded from the truck into a bunker at the factory. ‚ÄúWhen the sponge iron from the truck was being unloaded into the bunker with a crane, the stocked sponge iron suddenly collapsed on Suman and Mahesh. Both of them suffered injuries and they were declared brought dead at a hospital,‚Äù Manoharabad assistant sub-inspector (ASI) V Yadagiri said.

Two other workers, Shiva Naresh and Vimal Pal suffered injuries. ‚ÄúThey were rushed to a hospital in Medchal and are out of danger,‚Äù the ASI said. Police registered a case under sections 304-A and 337 of IPC. No arrests have been made yet.

Title: Sooraj firm on statement against Kunju
Content:
Kochi: Former public works secretary T O Sooraj has reiterated the statement that advance funds were released to the contractor with the knowledge of former PWD minister V K Ebrahim Kunju .

He made the statement before the vigilance investigators here, probing the Palarivattom flyover scam. The vigilance had recently questioned Ebrahim Kunju again.

Vigilance investigation had shown that former PWD minister and IUML MLA V K Ebrahim Kunju had given clearance for releasing Rs 8.5 crore as advance to RDS Projects, the company which had the contract for constructing the flyover. Kunju had taken the stance that as a minister he had done nothing wrong by giving clearance to the file regarding release of funds.tnn

Title: Wife of Major killed in J&K, set to join technical wing of Indian Army year after husband's death
Content: DEHRADUN: Nitika Kaul, widow of late Major Vibhuti Dhoundiyal, who was killed in a military operation after the Pulwama attack, is all set to join the technical wing of Indian Army.Kaul, presently working with a software company in Noida, has cleared Indian Army‚Äôs entrance exam (Services Selection Board) and also received a call letter from the Officers Training Academy, Chennai, her family members told TOI on Tuesday. Being a war widow , she was given relaxation in age limit in order to appear in the Army recruitment test.Nitika Kaul's video of bidding a tearful adieu to her husband was widely circulated on social media last year in which she was seen giving a message to her husband before he was laid to rest ‚Äî ‚ÄúYou said you loved me, but the fact is you loved the nation more‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll love you till my last breath. I owe my life to you.‚ÄùAnd almost a year after the Major was killed in action, Kaul, 26, is set to follow in his footsteps and join the Army.Saroj Dhoundiyal, Kaul‚Äôs mother-in-law, told TOI that she is "very happy for my daughter-in-law. ‚ÄúShe is a brave girl and takes care of us like a daughter. We are glad to have her in our lives,‚Äù she said, adding that she was the first to get the news of Kaul getting the offer letter. ‚ÄúIt feels great that she put me above her own parents and called me first,‚Äù she added.Talking to TOI on the first death anniversary of her husband on February 18, Kaul had said, ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt resist myself to love what my husband loved the most. I hope even I will get an opportunity to serve the country the way he did.‚ÄùNitika and Vibhuti had met while in college and had got married in April 2018. A few months before their first wedding anniversary, Major Dhoundiyal was killed while taking part in an operation in J&K to flush out militants after the Pulwama attack.Kaul, a Kashmiri Pandit who moved to Delhi in the 1990s, said that her mother-in-law motivated her to join the Army. ‚ÄúEvery time I see her, I see a hero. Her grief is no less, still she supported me throughout,‚Äù said Kaul, who has a MBA in marketing operations.

Title: Telangana firm on relaxing fiscal deficit limit
Content:
HYDERABAD: Even as Niti Aayog has asked the Telangana government to present its views on the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act, the state government is going to make three major demands, including releaxing fiscal deficit limit to 3.5% of GSDP, official sources said.

According to highly-placed sources, the state would also demand payment of the pending SGST compensation of Rs 700 crore the Centre owes to it. As per GST Act, states are compensated if there is a dip in tax collection.

Telangana will also raise its concerns on its contribution to central schemes. The state government‚Äôs contribution for centrally-sponsored schemes is presenlty fixed at 40%, which is 10% more than what was set before. ‚ÄúWe have been appealing to the Centre that money should be given to the state governments directly and how to spend and contribute for the schemes should be left to the states‚Äô discretion,‚Äù a senior official said. Not only Telangana, several other states have been demanding this, he said.

Though the state‚Äôs revenue receipts saw a dip, the fiscal deficit has been within limits prescribed by the FRBM Act. Fiscal deficit is the excess of government expenditure over receipts. Higher fiscal deficit of a government would mean a higher borrowing requirement in a financial year. The borrowed funds may be spent by the state for various purposes, officials point out.

The 14th Finance Commission had recommended that states maintain their fiscal deficit within 3% of their GSDP. It also suggested that the fiscal deficit limit should be relaxed to a maximum of 3.5%, but subject to condition that if states were able to contain their debt and interest payments to specified levels.

Title: Calangute church rd inaccessible as dispute continues
Content:
Calangute: One side of the Chogm road in front of Calangute church remains barricaded two months after it was cordoned off following a dispute between the Calangute comunidade and the village panchayat .

Sources at the comunidade said they had given a no objection certificate (NOC) to the Calangute panchayat to use the fields alongside the road to create free parking facilities for tourists during peak Christmas season.

However, in the last week of December, comunidade attorney, Anthony D‚ÄôSouza discovered that tourists were being charged a parking fee. He then lodged a complaint of cheating with the Calangute police and provided receipts for parking fees. D‚ÄôSouza claimed that the Calangute police failed to register an FIR. Police also closed the parking facility and placed barricades on the road to prevent any parking, thus blocking almost half the road.

It may be recalled that the road had been widened a few years ago due to traffic congestion and also to enable parking for large tourist buses. Every year during the peak season the area would be used for parking.

Title: Gujarat: Nayara Energy‚Äôs expansion plans face green challenge
Content:
File picture of the refinery at Vadinar

AHMEDABAD: Rosneft-backed Nayara Energy‚Äôs (formerly known as Essar Oil) plans for expansion of the existing refinery and setting up a new petrochemical complex at Vadinar near Jamnagar seems to have hit a hurdle after some villagers alleged that the company did not follow due process to get environmental clearance.

Nayara Energy‚Äôs expansion plan includes setting up a 10.75 million metric tonnes per annum (MMTPA) capacity petrochemical complex and expansion of the refinery from 20 MMTPA to 46 MMTPA for a total investment of about Rs 1.3 lakh crore.

A clutch of people from villages including Gagva, Khavdi, Meghpar, Padana, Jakhar, Vadinar, Timbdi, Devadiya and Lakhiya objected to grant of clearance by the Ministry of environment, forests and climate change (MoEFCC) on the grounds that a public hearing was not held, said Dilipsinh Jadeja who filed a petition in the Gujarat high court. He is a resident of a village near the Nayara‚Äôs project.

The environment appraisal committee (EAC) under MoEFCC deferred the matter after it was approached by the company for environmental clearance, according to an interim order passed by the high court recently. The court order cites the statement of the senior counsel of the respondent which says that the expert appraisal committee is to convene a meeting between February 25 to February 27 but has deferred grant of environment clearance for Nayara‚Äôs expansion plans.

Jadeja said that the company‚Äôs plans for expansion in Jamnagar was earlier on the agenda of the EAC for February 26 but now stands deferred.

In August last year, a public consultation was held over grant of environmental clearance to Nayara‚Äôs proposed expansion plans. Local villagers and others to be affected by the project were required to send responses in writing to Gujarat Pollution Control Board (GPCB) member secretary till August 5. GPCB forwarded the responses to the MoEFCC for consideration of grant of EC, a government source said. This was perhaps the first time that GPCB chose the public consultation route instead of a public hearing, sources added.

‚ÄúThere are legal guidelines that needs to be adhered to while granting environmental clearance. These rules have been grossly violated in this case. Such projects always require public hearing and it can‚Äôt be through public consultation,‚Äù said Jadeja.

In August 2017, a Rosneft-led consortium acquired Essar Oil for $12.9 billion and it was later renamed Nayara Energy.

‚ÄúEnvironmental clearance for the Vadinar project was valid till 2018. However, the proposed expansion was not carried out in the stipulated time-frame by the earlier promoters. The new promoters have decided to scale down the project. Also, no additional land was required for the expansion, hence the public consultation route was chosen by GPCB,‚Äù said a government official in the know of the matter.

Title: MKU syndicate to take call on charges against CoE, teacher
Content:
MADURAI: The Madurai Kamaraj University (MKU) syndicate is likely to discuss and take a decision on the alleged graft charges and wrongdoings of controller of examination, O Ravi and a misconduct complaint against a faculty member of an MKU constituent college in Thirumangalam . The MKU vice-chancellor M Krishnan asserted that the process is taking time but there has been no delay.

On February 18, the MKU VC had issued two charge memos to the CoE seeking explanation regarding two separate alleged wrongdoings. In the first incident on January 23, an unauthorized official from distance education centre accessed the consolidated mark sheets in the CoE office. The second incident on November 2019, wherein exam answer sheets being lost and found just when the results were to be announced on February 10. The CoE was also accused of corruption and bribery.

‚ÄúThe CoE has submitted his replies to both the memos. We will be taking up the matter at the next syndicate meeting that will be held soon,‚Äù said Krishnan, speaking to TOI.

On the other hand, a teaching faculty member from an MKU constituent college in Thirumangalam had been accused of indulging in unprofessional behaviour by several female faculties and students. An internal committee was also subsequently formed to look into the matter.

‚ÄúThe internal committee has not been unanimous in providing a final report and I‚Äôm yet to get a separate report from one of the members. Then, the final report will be placed in the syndicate for discussion to take the necessary action,‚Äù said Krishnan. The date for the next syndicate meeting is expected to be fixed soon.

Title: Gujarat high court moved for CAA protest nod
Content:
Gujarat high court

AHMEDABAD: Two organizations ‚Äî the Association for Protection of Civil Rights and Bharatiya Yuva Morcha ‚Äî have been seeking Gujarat high court directions to Surat police to grant permission for continuous protests, similar to those at Shaheen Bagh in Delhi, in the Limbayat area of the city.

The petitioners‚Äô advocate, Saquib Ansari, said protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Population Register (NPR) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC) took place at a private place in the Om Nagar area of Surat. As Limbayat police continued to interfere with the programmes, the organizers requested the police inspector and then the police commissioner to grant permission to continue the protest programmes, though there is no need to seek such permission for a protest at a private place.

The police authorities refused permission for the protest on February 8, and this brought the organizations to the high court seeking direction to Surat police to grant permission. The petitioners also requested interim relief from the HC, to ask the cops not to interfere with protest programmes that are not at a public place.

The state government, however, opposed the petition stating that the area witnessed violence and a policeman was attacked in Limbayat during a Bharat Bandh programme to protest CAA. Some 200 people were implicated in the case. Considering this argument, Justice A Y Kogje refused to restrain police action, but sought a reply from the authorities in response to the petition.

The authorities were asked to reply by Tuesday, but the hearing was adjourned.

Title: Flyers from Dubai, other transit hubs still not under corona lens
Content: MUMBAI: The Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) on Monday extended medical screening for coronavirus (Covid-19) to passengers on flights arriving from Italy and Iran besides those on flights from airports in East Asia. But for India, the proverbial elephant in the room are airports in West Asia, which are the most popular transit hubs for passengers flying into India. It‚Äôs there that India-bound passengers from airports in Europe, the US, and Africa would possibly mingle with those who have flown in from Iran and Italy before they board their onward connection.‚ÄúFor India, it‚Äôs critical to look into the possibility of India-bound passengers getting infected in transit hubs. A passenger typically spends at least 2-3 hours milling around with hundreds of other passengers, including those who have flown in from Iran and Italy,‚Äù said a senior airline official.For instance, eight direct flights from Tehran fly into Dubai daily, apart from six in total from Rome, Milan and Venice, bringing in over 3,000 passengers daily from these destinations into Dubai. Again, 17 daily flights link Dubai to Mumbai, the busiest international route into India. Apart from these, 12 flights from Dubai fly to Delhi, seven to Kochi, and six to Hyderabad daily.‚ÄúDubai airport gets the largest number of passengers from India. In 2019, 11.9 million passengers from India landed at Dubai and so, an equally large number would be flying out of Dubai to India,‚Äù said an aviation consultant. There are other West Asian airports like Doha, Abu Dhabi, Bahrain, and Riyadh where si-milar intermingling of India-bound passengers with those from Iran and Italy occur.The big problem with extending screening to passengers coming in from West Asian airports pertains to sheer volume. ‚ÄúIt would greatly increase the workload of airport health organisations as the number of passengers to be screened would jump manifold. It would decrease the efficiency of detection as human factors like fatigue would set in. From Dubai alone, about 8,000-9,000 passengers would be flying into Mumbai,‚Äù said a medical practitioner with an airline.Dr Om Srivastava, an infectious diseases expert, held a similar view. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not possible for medical staff to screen thousands of passengers day after day, without fatigue setting in. What is more realistic is to have a separate holding area for those travellers who may be of high risk, where they can be screened. Risk has to be identified. The rest of the passengers coming into the airport (should be) free to move on to their destinations. That way you are moving passengers fast.‚ÄùMeanwhile, a video posted to the official Twitter account of Dubai airport on Tuesday said that passengers from known high-infection areas are being screened twice. The airport has begun screening passengers using non-invasive thermal imaging technology.

Title: Secretariat needs to be razed to pave way for modern complex: Govt to HC
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: The state government on Tuesday appealed to the high court to allow it to go ahead with the construction of a new secretariat building in place of the existing one.

Advocate General BS Prasad listed out two reasons for the plea. The AG said that as the government wants to have an iconic structure befitting the stature of the state with all the state-of-the-art facilities, the courts cannot interfere in such policy decisions as long as they are not offending any of the constitutional provisions.

Secondly, he said, all the technical and cabinet committees that went into the issue had concluded that the existing secretariat buildings have become unsafe both in terms of safety of the inmates and security of VVIPs and VIPs. ‚ÄúIt has to be demolished to pave way for a new modern administrative complex that will have conference rooms to accommodate meetings with foreign dignitaries and huge meeting halls for meetings with all the heads of the departments and district collectors from all the 33 districts,‚Äù the AG said.

The bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy commenced its final hearing in the two PILs filed by Congress MP A Revanth Reddy and TJS vice president Professor P L Vishweswara Rao challenging the decision of the state in this regard on the ground that the existing buildings will last for another 50 years and hence need not be demolished.

The bench heard the state‚Äôs objections on the two petitioners and sought to know from it if there is bar on political rivals from approaching courts on public interest matters.

Stating that these petitioners were in fact coming in the way of public interest matters, the AG said that they did not provide any evidence or documents that the existing buildings will last for a longer time. ‚ÄúWith no proper passage, water leakages, loose wires, scattered parking and lack of space for separate VIP entries and many defects, the current structure is unfit to accommodate a secretariat,‚Äù the AG said, adding that except D and H blocks, all other blocks deserve to be demolished as they were useless.

Appearing for one of the petitioners, senior counsel S Satyam Reddy urged the court to reject the chief engineers‚Äô report on the buildings and direct any central agency or IIT, Hyderabad to send their experts to assess the strength of the existing buildings. The bench posted the case to March 5 for further hearing.

Title: No Central funds, Telangana to pay for 350-km regional ring road
Content: HYDERABAD: Telangana government is likely to develop the Rs 13,000 crore regional ring road using the state funds. Though Union road transport and highways minister Nitin Gadkari had in principle agreed to fund development of the road, Centre has not released money despite several representations made by the state government.Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao wants the ring road - stretching over 350-km - to be developed at all costs. The government is likely to allocate budget for the project in the current fiscal, facilitating commencement of work.The talk in the official corridors is that the central funding for development of highways has almost come to a halt after the May-2019 Lok Sabha elections.CM K Chandrasekhar Rao-led TRS government had planned to take up projects worth thousands of crores, that needed either central funding or handing over possession of defence land to the state government.The development of the regional ring road - which passes through Gajwel constituency represented by CM KCR - and the Patny to Shamirpet flyover project to ease vehicular traffic congestion was expected to get central funding and defence lands, respectively.A senior official said though the union road transport and highways ministry had given an in principle approval for the central funding to the regional ring road project, it has been stuck for an approval on paper from the central government. Nearly Rs 4,000 crore central funding is required for land acquisition alone to start work on the ring road project.HYDERABAD:The regional ring road is planned to be developed on par with international standards, connecting Sangareddy, Narsapur, Toopran, Gajwel, Jagdevpur, Bhongir, Choutuppal, Ibrahimpatnam, Chevella and Shankarapalli.

Title: Hoteliers can no more let out waste into drains
Content:
Residents and hoteliers who used to discharge waste to drains and canals from houses and hotels will no longer... Read More

Kochi: Hoteliers who used to discharge food waste and toilet waste to drains and canals will no longer be able to do so as the district administration has started closing these pipelines as part of Operation Breakthrough. Likewise, the pipelines which carry toilet from residences will also be closed.

District collector has given instruction in this regard and contractors have started closing the pipelines. However, residents have raised their objections and councillors are starting to feel the heat.

‚ÄúResidents and hoteliers used to discharge waste water to drains without any objection from authorities so far. But, with the closing of openings, residents won‚Äôt be able to do so. Though we reason with them, they, especially housewives, get angry with us. We tell them the drains are meant for stormwater and residents cannot discharge waste into them. The problem is that 90% residents in Kochi do not have facility in their houses to discharge waste water. Similarly, the hoteliers have been discharging all food waste to drains and blocking them,‚Äù said Krishnakumar, Ernakulam south councilor.

District administration officials said they have asked workers to close all the openings from toilets to drains and canals. ‚ÄúIf the residents raise the issue before the councillors, peoples‚Äô representatives should make them understand that the drains and canals are not the place to dump toilet waste,‚Äù said an official.

Meanwhile on Tuesday, the district administration has approved 28 more new works to be undertaken in the second phase of Operation Breakthrough. Works in the second phase are estimated to cost Rs 16.5 crore. About 75% works in the first phase have been completed. Though the government sanctioned Rs 10 crore for first phase, only Rs 4 crore has reached the account of the administration, said sources.

Title: All-party meet to discuss Census 2021 activities: Pinarayi Vijayan
Content:
THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Reiterating that the state government will not implement Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) or allow enumeration process for National Population Register (NPR) in the state, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan told the assembly on Tuesday that the government will convene an all-party meeting on March 16 to discuss the Census 2021 activities to be taken up in the coming months.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no need for any concern about CAA or NPR. Kerala government will not implement them, but will carry out only the enumeration process required for Census 2021,‚Äù the CM said, responding to allegations by opposition members that his repeated statements against CAA and NPR lacked clarity and were misleading.

The opposition raised the concern during a discussion on demand for grants for different government departments in the state budget which began on Tuesday.

‚ÄúThe timeframe and enumeration activities for Census and NPR are different, and there will be no overt or covert traps (in the form of questions) in the house-listing operations for the census,‚Äù Vijayan said. It has been decided to convene an all-party meeting on March 16 to discuss and allay such fears, he added.

Reacting to opposition allegations the government was making false claims in various fields, including the tall claim under Life Mission, the CM said the opposition‚Äôs negative attitude towards these achievements by the government for the welfare of people and the state was ‚Äòmost unfortunate‚Äô.

‚ÄúThe opposition, instead of being proud of Kerala‚Äôs achievements, seems to be jealous and unhappy,‚Äù he said.

Earlier, opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala alleged that the government was making tall claims through ‚Äòpaid news‚Äô and was cheating people. Taking part in the discussion, he also termed the ongoing vigilance investigations into former UDF ministers a ‚Äòwitch hunt‚Äô.

Title: Kottayam hospital deaths: Trust‚Äôs licence under lens
Content:
Representative image

KOTTAYAM: The health department on Tuesday cancelled the sanitary certificate of controversial Puthujeevan Trust Hospital for Psychological Medicine and De-addiction Centre in Changanassery where three deaths were reported in the last one week alone.

Officials from family health centre in Payippad panchayat and the health inspector from Karukachal have also found out that the hospital was functioning without licence from the panchayat. The hospital does not have proper waste management system also. Officials who visited the hospital on Tuesday have submitted a report to the Payippad panchayat regarding this. The panchayat will hold a meeting on Wednesday to take a final decision based on this report, said panchayat president Swapna Binu.

Meanwhile, the medical board is awaiting the chemical analysis report of the autopsy of the last person who had died in the hospital. According to primary findings, the death has been due to pneumonia. The report from the chemical analysis lab will also bring out the truth about the allegation that the lead content in the medicines given to the patients was high. The medicines given to the patients were also send to the lab in Amrita Institute for chemical analysis.

Title: Cracked ceiling of walkway in Johari mkt raises concern
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: The ceiling of walkway in front of shop number 280 in Johari Bazaar was cracked three years ago and was supposed to be restored by the Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC). However, the civic body has not taken any action so far. The worst part is that the cracked ceiling is supported by bamboos, thus raising a security scare. According to sources, the ceiling was cracked when the owner of the shop was doing some construction inside it. Later, the owner shut the shop but the cracked ceiling was still there. As per rules, verandas are supposed to be constructed by the JMC. However, several complaints to restore the ceiling fell on deaf ears, sources said. Shyam Mittal , a shopkeeper adjacent to shop 280, said that a few times these bamboos fell down in three years. ‚ÄúOfficials of JMC have visited the place many times, taken photographs but after that nothing happened. These bamboos have fallen two-three times after which shopkeepers have restored them at their expense to avoid any further causality,‚Äù said Shyam. The officials of JMC said that the issue is serious and they are taking note of it. Deputy commissioner of Hawa Mahal (East) Ramkishore Meena said, ‚ÄúWe will look into the matter. It will be resolved in no time and I have asked the official in-charge to take note of this.‚Äù General secretary of Johri Bazaar Vyapaar Mandal, Kailash Mittal said that this is the negligent attitude of the JMC officials.

Title: Dog attacks violate human rights: PIL
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

AHMEDABAD: A petitioner, Kirtikumar Bhatt, on Tuesday submitted before the Gujarat high court that inaction by of the authorities on preventing stray dogs from attacking humans is a violation of human rights and a violation of the UN Convention on Rights of the Child.

Based on Bhatt‚Äôs PIL, the HC issued notice to the authorities in January. However, Bhatt sought to add to his arguments and maintained that numerous dog attacks on people were a gross violation of the human rights of citizens of India. More than 17 million people suffer dog bites and about 18,000 people lose their lives to rabies every year in this country. The Protection of Human Rights Act, 1993, comes within purview of the Internal Security Division-III of the ministry of home affairs, reads Bhatt‚Äôs petition.

The petitioner further stated that majority of victims of stray dog attacks are children. The United Nations had brought out a ‚ÄòConvention on Rights of the Child‚Äô in 1989, and India acceded to it in 1992. Thus, attacks and killing of children by strays is a violation of the convention, Bhatt argued. In his PIL, Bhatt sought directions to the city police commissioner and the municipal commissioner to use police forces to curb the stray dog menace.

Title: Min inspects work at command centre
Content:
Hyderabad: Home minister Mohammed Mahmood Ali on Tuesday took stock of the ongoing works at the integrated command and control centre in Banjara Hills.

After visiting the centre, the minister instructed the officials to complete the remaining work at the earliest. He said the command centre conceived by the chief minister was coming up at a cost of Rs 350 crore.

‚ÄúThe twin towers housing various police wings under one roof will maintain global standards. Video analytic connected to over one lakh CCTV cameras, a giant video hall, control sensors, GIS and other facilities will stand out,‚Äù he said.

The twin building will have facilities like video and audio conferencing center with state and national level departments and agencies.

The massive building will also cater to the needs of crime analysis and monitoring, anti-terror commando teams, quick reaction teams, city disaster response unit, crowd control teams with a helipad on top of the building.

The Building will have modern and state-of-art facilities and work as one-stop center for incident management system like disaster response and crisis management, useful in emergencies.

Title: Centre may do away with Dalit quota: Bhatti
Content:
Hyderabad: Congress legislature party leader Mallu Bhatti Vikramarka on Tuesday alleged that the BJP government at the Centre is trying to do away with reservations for SCs and STs and said his party will not allow it to happen.

N Pritam taking over as chairman of Congress SC cell here, Vikramarka said there was no fear among any section as long as Congress was governing the country. ‚ÄúIn the last six years of Narendra Modi-led BJP government at the Centre, several sections of community are living under fear for safety of their lives and property,‚Äù he said.

In Telangana, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao promised to enhance SC reservations but has not done so far. ‚ÄúBoth KCR and Modi are no different when it comes to making empty promises to the people and seeking votes,‚Äù he said. tnn

Title: FC Goa juniors set the bar high
Content:
Panaji: FC Goa‚Äôs Under-18 side have qualified for the AIFF I-League for the third consecutive season and are now gunning for the title.

In their first season, FC Goa were knocked out in the quarterfinals. Last year, they went a step further and made it to the last-four stage. They gave their all but lost by a solitary goal to eventual champions Minerva Punjab FC.

In the Goa qualifiers, FC Goa secured 17 points from eight matches, the same as Dempo SC, but topped the group with a better head-to-head record and qualified directly for the main round. They lost only once to Salgaocar FC, who finished third. Dempo too got through, but will have to play five more games in the qualifiers before the main round.

The All-India playoffs will be held in May and coach Gavin Araujo is training his boys at the artificial turf at Chowgule, Margao. He believes it will help them get accustomed to the surface in Shillong.

‚ÄúWe had strong teams for the last two editions and it is the experience that will count this time. Sometimes it is difficult to match the (physical) strengths of our opponents but technique bails us out,‚Äù Araujo told TOI.

The A-license coach who is with the club since 2015 could be right. Forward Joybert Almeida has come up from the U-13 ranks and is playing his third season in this age group. There are five others who have experience at this level which includes Rayan Menezes and central midfielder Brison Fernandes.

‚ÄúI am with the club for the last three seasons and the club has taken good care of me. I wish to stay here longer and even help the club win the ISL title in the future, if I make it to the senior team,‚Äù said Joybert.

With Derrick Pereira as technical director, the U-18s follow the same philosophy that has helped the senior side become the most consistent outfits in the six editions of the Indian Super League (ISL). Short passing, possession and starting moves from the back has been the key to their success.

‚ÄúThanks to Derrick sir. He has aligned all our youth system to the first team, right from the style of play and formation. I think 18-year-olds are strong enough to play even against bigger opponents,‚Äù said Araujo.

Even if the juniors fall short, they have a lot of motivation and Mohammad Nawaz is a perfect example. The former India U-17 goalkeeper has made 32 appearances in the ISL over two seasons and has cemented his place in the senior side. Then there is Princeton Rebello, who also played for the U-18s.

Most of the players are keen to stay with FC Goa and brighten their chances of playing in the ISL. ‚ÄúWe want to work hard and win the (U-18) I-League title for the club,‚Äù said Brison.

Title: Retail price of bottled water capped at Rs 13
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The state government has issued an order capping the price of bottled water at Rs 13 per litre in the state. As per the order, no manufacturer can charge more than this retail price .

The government has issued the order regulating the price of the bottled water under the ambit of the Essential Commodities Act. The government has made it clear that there will be strict action against those selling bottled water at higher rates henceforth. As per the new rule, all bottles should have the price printed on it.

At present, one litre of bottled water costs Rs 20 in the state, and multiplex cinema theatres and star hotels charge a greater premium which varies between Rs 50 and Rs 100. The retailers also charge an extra amount for refrigerating the bottles.

Even though the state government had issued a notification declaring bottled water as an essential commodity (which gives it the authority to fix the MRP) much earlier, certain companies had approached the high court against it. ‚ÄúThe high court, both single and division benches, ruled in favour of the government,‚Äù said food minister P Thilothaman.

With the government issuing the order, the manufacturing companies will have to stick to the MRP of Rs 13 while printing it on the labels, he added.

Over the last couple of years, the manufacturers and traders have been opposing the government‚Äôs move to regulate the price of bottled water, following complaints from public against retailers and hotels charging exorbitantly at will. Meetings were held after the government notified it under Essential Commodities Act, and traders pointed out that the railways was charging Rs 15 for ‚ÄòRail neer‚Äô.

Once the price is fixed by the government, legal metrology officials can take action against traders selling it at higher price to consumers, the minister pointed out.

Title: 15 weather monitoring stns to be installed this month
Content:
Kochi: The first set of 15 automatic weather stations (AWS) will be installed in the state by the month-end. This is part of enhancing hazard vulnerability network in the state as there are several places where there are no weather monitoring networks to track rainfall, landslides, temperature and humidity.

Officials said while 100 stations are to come up, sites for installing 73 stations have been cleared and a government order has been issued. KSDMA officials said a team from the India Meteorological Department has been visiting the sites for final confirmation. ‚ÄúEach station would take at least 3-4 days to install. The IMD has assigned an agency for the purpose and they would be doing it simultaneously,‚Äù an official said.

The state government during its discussion had given priority to hilly regions, landslide-prone areas and dam sites. Hence, these areas have been included in the 15 sites where AWS would be installed in the first phase. Among the first lot, Peringalkuthu and Banasura dams have been marked.
