In Thiruvananthapuram, the model site proposed was at Ponmudy but when the team inspected, they found that the marked spot did not have mobile network and the site was moved a bit into the network area.

The sites have been identified with inputs from KSEB, irrigation department and Kerala water authority. Idukki district will get a total of 11 stations, of which nine have been identified including Cheruthoni and Peermade.

Meanwhile, construction of 14 disaster relief centres in seven districts is under way, with first three temporary disaster relief centres for victims of natural disasters expected to be ready by June. The centre can accommodate around 1,000 people and it is expected that the difficulties encountered by victims in relief camps have been addressed.

The places where the centres are coming up include Thazhava (Kollam), Cherutha and Mararikkulam (Alappuzha), Pallipuram and Thuruthippuram (Ernakulam), Kadapuram and Azhikkode (Thrissur), Vettam and Palapatti (Malappuram), Kathirur and Cheladu (Kannur), Kudlu, Pullur and Madoor (Kasaragod).

The construction site is being identified within 10 km of the coast and will function under direct control of the collector. There will also be a s helter management committee under the chairmanship of the local body. They will also have four groups of emergency response teams. The teams will be trained in shelter management, search & rescue, first aid and alert.

Title: N95 Masks: Price of masks jacked up in city
Content: NEW DELHI: The fear of Covid-19 spreading in the city has led to an unusual crisis ‚Äî shortage of masks and hand sanitisers in medical stores across the city.With supplies from China hit by the coronavirus outbreak, pharmacies said they are left with locally manufactured products mostly.‚ÄúThere aren‚Äôt enough masks in the market. If you want to buy one, you can take it or leave it,‚Äù shopkeepers are telling customers who protest at the high prices.The surgical masks usually sold for Rs 10 in the retail market are currently being sold at Rs 40. The N95 masks that have multiple layers for better protection and re-use are being sold for anything between Rs 150 and Rs 500. ‚ÄúWe are also paying extra to purchase the masks from suppliers,‚Äù said a shopkeeper, justifying the increased price.Online portals selling the masks and hand sanitisers said the demand for face masks, particulate respiratory masks, protective suits, sterile surgical gloves and safety goggles has gone up 10 times.Every time a patient coughs or sneezes, the droplets containing the virus are released and they tend to spread. Masks are advised for people who have symptoms such as coughing and sneezing so they don‚Äôt spread the virus causing the symptoms to others. However, healthier individuals also use it to avoid getting the infection, especially when visiting crowded areas such as hospitals or airports.Such is the crisis of masks that even health workers in hospitals are finding it difficult to get it. Resident doctors at Safdarjung Hospital, one of the nodal centres for quarantining and treatment of Covid-19 cases, have asked the authorities to ensure masks for all healthcare workers. ‚ÄúHealthcare workers are at maximum risk to catch the infection because they are directly in touch with patients. They need to be provided with all possible protective equipment to be able to work without fear or anxiety,‚Äù said a doctor.The spread of COVID19 has also increased the potential of drug crisis. To contain this, India, the world‚Äôs largest maker of generic drugs, on Tuesday restricted the export of common medicines such as paracetamol and 25 other pharmaceutical ingredients and drugs made from them.Though India is a source of about 20% of the world‚Äôs generic drug supply, pharma companies in the country are dependent on China for two-thirds of the chemical components needed to make them.The outbreak of coronavirus has shut factories in China and impacted supplies, leading to fears of a shortage of drugs and medicines.

Title: Reboot Kerala Hackathon at Fisat from March 6 to 8
Content:
Kochi: The Reboot Kerala Hackathon-2020 will be held from March 6-8 at Federal Institute of Science and Technology ( Fisat ), Angamaly. The event will be based on the themes selected by health and social justice departments.

Reboot Kerala Hackathon is an initiative of the department of higher education and the higher education department‚Äôs Additional Skill Acquisition Program (ASAP). It aims to provide students of higher education institutions a platform to solve some of the pressing problems we face in our daily lives, and thus inculcate a culture of product innovation and a mindset to solve problems.

The contest will be a 36-hours non-stop hardware and software competition, in which selected competitors will participate as a team to solve a given problem. A team will comprise six students representing an institution in which two of them will be girls.

‚ÄúThirty student teams from colleges across Kerala have registered. There will be six themes from the health department and one from the social justice department,‚Äù said C Mahesh, faculty, centre of high performance computing, Fisat.

The topics will be given on first-come-first-serve basis from Wednesday. The students will login on Friday morning and the deadline for logout will end on Saturday night. ‚ÄúThe health department has given problems on centralized infection management system, among other things. The aim of the event is to have the student community relate directly to real-time issues faced by the government,‚Äù said Bejoy Varghese, ASAP coordinator, department of electronics and communication engineering, Fisat.

He said solutions will be continuously evaluated throughout the hackathon by a jury that consists of 18 members. The first-round results will be published by Sunday 2am, where 15 out of the 30 teams will be shortlisted. They will deliver a 15-minute presentation on their solutions on Sunday morning before a panel of judges and selected solutions will be implemented by the health and social justice department.

Title: College magazine‚Äôs bold theme stokes row
Content:
Kannur: The cover page of People‚Äôs Cooperative Arts and Science College magazine is vivid with images: A banana partially sheathed in a condom. Behind it a woman‚Äôs face, which is part of peeling graffiti‚Ä¶ peeping eyes‚Ä¶ and the name ‚Äò Ura Marachathu ‚Äô (hidden by a sheath). Its content revolves around issues related to sexuality , sexual aggression and even sexual orientation. Menstruation, rape and even lesbianism find place in the magazine.

Now, the magazine recently published by SFI-controlled union in the college located at Munnad in Kasaragod has invited criticism from the moral police because of its theme. KSU and ABVP have approached the Prime Minister, the governor and even Kannur University‚Äôs VC against the magazine.

Staff editor Anu Sebastian said the content, finalized after deliberations, were written by students as part of programme in memory of playwright Girish Karnad.

‚ÄúAtrocities against women have underscored the lack of sex education. We wanted to bring the issue in public domain,‚Äù Sebastian said.

Sebastian said the response from girls was unprecedented as they dedicated their contributions to Kathua rape victim. When discussions were happening in 2018-19, issues related to sexuality, especially menstruation, in the backdrop of Sabarimala women entry was going on, said magazine editor Akash Pallam.

‚ÄúIn such a situation, we wanted the magazine to take a stand on such issues. Though the magazine committee organized a debate on Monday, those who criticized the magazine on social media were absent,‚Äù he said, adding that the provocative cover was deliberately chosen to highlight the society‚Äôs tendency to hide such issues.

The poem, Avarannere Kithachu (That day, they panted a lot) by Vineetha C, centres on the horrid feeling after rape while another girl, Ashwini C asks whether menstruation is impure. Illustration for articles has invited criticism and Reshma C‚Äôs fiction is based on the same issue. Another girl, Parvathi, delves into lesbianism present in the holy books, and how moral police decides everything. Arya A, who wrote about menstruation and related social issues, said it is time to debate such issues in public.

But, KSU Kasaragod secretary Martin Abraham said SFI has created an obscenity, which goes against women.

‚ÄúWe have filed a police complaint at Uduma. We have approached university VC, governor, PM‚Äôs grievance redressal portal,‚Äù he said.

Assistant professor Haritha Gopal felt that those, who termed the magazine anti-women, support patriarchy and they are obscene from within. ‚ÄúSwords are drawn against a magazine in which most contributors are women. They have raised a burning issue,‚Äù she said, adding that the lack of sex education and perversion of frustrated minds are the reasons for such objection. She added that society will reject the notion.

Title: GHMC chief to appear before HC on March 11
Content:
Hyderabad: Wondering whether the civic chief and his staff were playing hide and seek with the high court, a high court bench, headed by Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan, on Tuesday summoned GHMC commissioner Lokesh Kumar and his deputy, Pramod Kumar, to appear before the court on March 11. The bench was dealing with a plea that questioned the inaction of officials on polluting industries, particularly plastic units, at Shastripuram in Rangareddy.

The GHMC deputy commissioner initially gave a report to the court that there were only three plastic industries in the area. The bench got the matter cross verified with state legal services authority member secretary G V Subramanyam, who visited the area and informed the court that there were 250 unofficial plastic units in the area. After receiving a notice from the high court, the deputy commissioner furnished to the court another report in which he said there were 198 plastic units in the area. The commissioner and his deputy were asked to come to the court and explain the reasons for their inaction. TNN

Title: Revanth and kin encroached upon lake, govt land in Gopanpally: Report
Content:
A Revanth Reddy

HYDERABAD: Revenue officials have claimed Malkajgiri MP A Revanth Reddy and his brothers encroached upon 1.11 acre government land in survey number 127 in Gopanpally and 34 guntas in full tank level of Komatibanda kunta in neighbouring Rangareddy district. They also said there was a mismatch between the extent of land being claimed by Revanth Reddy and his kin and land in their actual possession.

Rajendranagar revenue divisional officer (RDO) K Chandrakala inquired into the issue on the directions of Rangareddy district collector Amoy Kumar and submitted her report on Monday. ‚ÄúWhile the land in survey number 127, purchased by Revanth and his brothers was 10.21 acres, the field verification revealed the compound wall with gates was coming to 12.02 acres,‚Äù the RDO said.

She said the compound wall was obstructing water sources to Komatikunta, which is against WALTA Act, 2002 and Section 24 of AP (TA) Land Revenue Act, 1317 Fasli. ‚ÄúTo initiate action, the deputy collector-cum-tahsildar may be instructed to take steps,‚Äù she said. On the land purchased in survey number 127 in Gopanpally, the RDO said the sale deeds executed in the name of Dabba Mallaiah and his kin do not appear to be genuine and the vendors, who executed the sale deeds as members of Dabba family seem to be ‚Äòimpersonators‚Äô. ‚ÄúAbout 5. 21 guntas unclaimed property shall be treated as ascheat/bonavantia land, she added.

Title: Chennai News - Times of India
Content:
Chennai: Two Sundays ago, at a meeting on the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019, organised at the Kerala Samajam in Chennai, former Union minister Palaniappan Chidambaram was the keynote speaker. "I can speak in English or Tamil, whichever you prefer."

This was uncharacteristic of Chidambaram, for whom it was either his way or no way, as this writer witnessed in the summer of 2004. The campaign heat for the Lok Sabha election was at its peak in Sivaganga parliamentary constituency. When the convoy of Congress candidate Chidambaram stopped at a nondescript junction on Karaikudi-Thirumayam Road and he rose to speak from the van.

Read the entire story on TOI+

Has spending time in jail made Chidambara a better politician?

Title: Redeem, Chothe to join FC Goa
Content:
Panaji: FC Goa have already started planning for next season with Redeem Tlang (NorthEast United FC) and Makan Winkle Chothe (Punjab FC) among the new signings.

FC Goa are certain to lose a few domestic players to other clubs as negotiations are now in the final stages. The Indian Super League ( ISL ) toppers don‚Äôt want to be found wanting and have braced for the exit with fresh signings.

Redeem, who did well with NorthEast United this season, was the first to agree a move to Goa, despite at least two other clubs seeking his signature. He could be an option for the new coach on the wing and his three goals with NEUFC suggests he is not hesitant to have a shy at goal.

The most exciting prospect, though, is Chothe. Just 19, and now a regular with Punjab FC in the I-League , the young striker from Manipur has won plenty of admirers at the youth level and is now beginning to show promise at the senior level too.

This season, he has already started 14 of the 15 games for Punjab FC and has been instrumental in guiding them to the second spot and has been among the goals too. NorthEast United were among the many clubs that were keen to have him on their rolls, but the bright prospect has been convinced that Goa is the best place to advance his career.

‚ÄúWe have a long-term contract with Chothe. We have all seen what he has done at the youth level and he has continued with the same form with seniors. He is an exciting prospect,‚Äù said a club official.

Chothe showed what he is capable of when he scored the match-winner against FC Goa in the Elite League 2018-19 semifinals at Nagoa ground. He also scored the opening goal in the final as Minerva Punjab coasted to victory. He also made five appearances for Minerva Punjab in the AFC Cup last season.

There will be more domestic signings, including a defender from the Goa Pro League.

Title: Huge haul: 450kg ganja seized, 4 held
Content: Hyderabad: In a major haul, 450 kilos of ganja was recovered in two different instances and four peddlers were arrested. Two ganja suppliers from Visakhapatnam and a receiver of the contraband, belonging to Mumbai, in the first case and five associates of the accused in the second case are absconding. In the first case, a trio was on their way to Maharashtra in an SUV when Rachakonda police nabbed them at Deshmukhi village crossroads on Vijayawada-Hyderabad highway. TNN

Title: Thanks to locals, it‚Äôs a clean sweep
Content:
Hyderabad: Not leaving the upkeep of the city to civic officials, volunteers have started taking matters into their own hands. Techies, doctors and even a pilot in training, are taking to the streets to help the civic body out.

One such group, comprising about nine core members and many volunteers, began their work last year. ‚ÄúWe have already worked on six spots ‚Äì in Miyapur, Kondapur, three in BHEL area and the most recent in Tellapur,‚Äù says Shrikanth Shankaran, who is training to be a pilot.

Shankaran says, ‚ÄúWe focus on segregation of waste into biodegradable and non-biodegradable material. After we complete that process we hand over the waste to Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation officials.‚Äù He says segregating watse itself reduces GHMC‚Äôs burden by half.

Explaining how a simple change can go a long way, Shankaran says if people just stop dumping their waste in knotted plastic covers, a lot of time and effort can be saved during segregation. The 26-year-old explains, ‚ÄúOften we find remnants of fruits and vegetables ‚Äì which can be used for manure ‚Äì dumped in plastic, which is known to non-biodegradable. Avoiding this must be the first step in proper waste management.‚Äù

Dr Vishnu Priya Cherukuri, working with the group, says most team members are professionals who volunteer in their spare time. ‚ÄúWe all need to make time because every effort goes a long way in making a change.‚Äù

Other groups too have been focussing on waste management. Residents of My Home Vihanga in Gachibowli, for instance, have taken it up on themselves to remove garbage from their society. They rue how development work in surrounding areas has led to an increase in construction and demolition (C&D) waste in the locality.

Residents claim that the GHMC collects nearly Rs10 crore property tax from My Home Vihaanga. But not much is done in terms of waste collection.

Recently, residents launched a campaign titled ‚ÄòMy Neighbourhood‚Äô as they started clearing C&D waste in the locality . ‚ÄúThere are close to 2,000 apartments here with a population of over 5,000 people. While we have been requesting GHMC to deploy three to four workers exclusively for our society, little efforts have been done to do so,‚Äù said RJ Singh, a resident of My Home Vihaanga.

Even after two years of running from pillar to post to get their drains cleaned by either GHMC or the railway authorities, residents of Dayanand Nagar have also begun to do the job themselves. ‚ÄúDue to poor drainage network in the colony, sewage gets accumulated under the railway tracks. While we were told that the drainage network will be extended and the situation will improve, nothing has been done so far. For the past two years, we ourselves have been cleaning the drains once a month,‚Äù said K Govind Narayanan, secretary of Dayanand Nagar Residents Welfare Association, which has approximately 3,500 people.

Similarly, yuder the group ‚ÄòHelping hands Humanity‚Äô, Prashant Mamidala and Satish Chandra have been trying to rejuvenate lakes. ‚ÄúWe have been working on lakes from the past four years, with almost no response from officials. They bluntly tell us that there are no funds.‚Äù He says they have taken up three lakes: Annarayani cheruvu (Nagaram), Raa cheruvu (Boduppal) and Saroor Nagar Cheruvu.

So members of HHH, are getting their hands dirty, pulling out hyacinth with their bare hands. Said Satish Chandra, ‚ÄúIt has been eight months since I have been personally following up on Saroor Nagar Cheruvu. We have seen people throw all kinds of garbage like plastic, waste material, construction material, Pooja items which are a pain to remove.‚Äù

Meanwhile, techie Amar Kokkanti (39) has been working alone with the GHMC to fill potholes. ‚ÄúI see complaints registered on the GHMC app and follow-up with officials. The idea is to make the officials accountable,‚Äô he said. He started his work in 2018 has worked on several area such as the Hafeezpet flyover, Lingampally, Madinaguda, Miyapur, Kothaguda. ‚ÄúI have seen accidents take place before my eyes and ante to ensure the city is a safer place for everyone,‚Äù he said.

Title: Woman‚Äôs body found buried in pit, police suspect husband
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: In a suspected case of murder , the body of a 32-year-old woman was found buried in a pit behind her under-construction house at Valikkunnu Colony in Pullanpara village under Venjaramoodu police station limits.

Police identified the deceased as Sini, daughter of Chellappan and Lalitha. Her husband, Kuttan, who is missing is the prime suspect. The couple has two sons, aged 15 and 12.

Venjaramoodu police registered a case on unnatural death and are on the lookout for Kuttan, who is a daily-wage labourer.

According to police, the body was found by Sini‚Äôs cousin Rajesh on Tuesday afternoon. Her husband had spread news that Sini was missing from Sunday evening and Rajesh had come to search for her.

While checking out the rubber plantation behind the house, he noticed an unusual amount of dry leaves over the pit that was dug to construct a septic tank. As this used to be an open pit, he grew suspicious. He cleared the leaves and started digging, to expose her left shoulder. He immediately alerted the police, who rushed to the spot and dug out the body.

The body was naked. Apart from a deep wound on the forehead there was no other major injury. Police suspect that she might have been bludgeoned using a blunt object such as a hammer.

The deceased was found with eyes popping out and tongue tightly lodged between the teeth, suggesting strangulation. Police also found a plastic mat and a small knife from the pit.

Cops suspect the murder to have been committed in another house in the locality, where the family was living. This house belongs to Chandran. Kuttan and Chandran were substance abusers and had been involved in a brawl a few days ago. During that fight, Chandran threw an acid-like substance on Kuttan‚Äôs face, inflicting burn injuries. Chandran was arrested and jailed following the incident. He lived alone and after his arrest Kuttan and Sini moved into his house along with their children.

‚ÄúWe found primer (zinc chromate compound used in spray paint) stains on the body of the deceased. A can of primer was found at Chandran‚Äôs house and this led us to suspect the murder took place there,‚Äù said a police officer who inspected the crime scene.

The children told the police they saw Kuttan assaulting and even threatening their mother by brandishing a circular saw.

They also revealed that he used to harass both them and their mother under the influence of alcohol.

There were times when Sini went to her brother‚Äôs house in Kollam to escape the violence. And that‚Äôs where everyone thought she was when Kuttan circulated news that she was missing.

‚ÄúWe have learned that Kuttan has travelled to remote villages in Karnataka as part of his job and we suspect that he could have fled to one such place now,‚Äù said Venjaramoodu station house officer inspector Aji Chandran Nair.

Title: Several switch to cabs as train schedules go off track
Content:
Begumpet MMTS ticket counter on Tuesday

HYDERABAD: With the cancellation of 16 MMTS trains between Hyderabad and Lingampally till March 7, and 15 MEMU and passenger trains running from different locations in the city affected by MMTS phase II work, passengers are switching to cabs.

‚ÄúI work in Gachibowli and take MMTS regularly with my friends. Today, I accidentally checked the railway app in the morning to check for any delays and found that the MMTS we take was cancelled. We decided to take a cab pooling service but it cost us almost twice the amount we usually pay‚Äù Vignesh P, a resident of Kundanbagh, who takes an MMTS train from Begumpet to Hi-Tec City twice daily, told TOI.

Another MMTS user, Swathi, who works at a telephone exchange in Moosapet and takes the MMTS from Sanjeeviah Park to Bharatnagar daily, said, ‚ÄúMy workplace is around 8 km away from where I stay and despite the delays, MMTS is still the cheapest and the fastest way to get there. And now, for the next five days, I will have to use a cab or an auto but either way it will ruin my budget‚Äù.

A huge number of techies travelling to Hi-Tec City and Gachibowli regularly are using car pooling options. While some of the passengers found out about the cancelled trains before reaching the station, some were still uninformed until they reached the station. ‚ÄúI just found out that a few MMTS trains are cancelled, and I don‚Äôt think I will be able to make it to my office in time,‚Äù said Piyush Sharma, another disappointed passenger who was at the Sanjeeviah Park MMTS station to board his train from Falaknuma to Lingampally at 9 am.

Other than MMTS, several MEMU and passenger trains from different locations in the city were cancelled. Among the affected trains too, some of the long-distance trains to Ballarshah in Madhya Pradesh and Howrah in Bengal were also partially cancelled and rescheduled in March, leaving thousands of passengers in the lurch. Passengers who have already booked their tickets are enquiring with railway officials for confirmation of the same. ‚ÄúDue to interlocking work for arrangements in connection with the quadrupling of track between Moula Ali ‚ÄòC‚Äô cabin and Ghatkesar stations as part of MMTS works, some trains were cancelled, partially cancelled, diverted and rescheduled,‚Äù said a South Central Railway official, adding, ‚ÄúWe are also replying to passengers‚Äô queries over our helpline numbers and on social media.‚Äù

Title: Vijayawada: 667 kg red sanders logs seized, 2 held
Content:
Representative image

TIRUPATI: Kadapa police on Tuesday arrested two red sanders smugglers and seized 667 kg of logs near Palakondala cross along Rajampet to Rayachoti road in Kadapa district.

According to Kadapa DSP U Suryanarayana, police teams led by RIMS police station circle inspector P Satya Babu and SIs T Hari Prasad and T Sudhakar conducted vehicular checks along the road in the early hours of Tuesday. During the vehicular checks, the spotted a vehicle heading towards Rajampet stopped all of a sudden and the inmates of the car tried to abscond after noticing police checks.

But the police teams present there managed to nab two persons who were identified as S Ilayaraja and P Thangaraj, both belonging to different parts of Tamil Nadu. After inspecting the vehicle, police seized 21 red sanders logs weighing 667 kgs, worth several lakhs in the international markets.

Title: 3 cops test positive for swine flu
Content:
Hyderabad: Three cops of Hyderabad tested positive for swine flu and have been been admitted to different hospitals for treatment.

Police commissioner Anjani Kumar confirmed that three cops have tested positive for swine flu and are undergoing treatment. ‚ÄúAs a precautionary measure, we have sent few other personnel for medical examination,‚Äù the commissioner said. TNN

Title: RU paper leak: No FIR filed even after two days
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Rajasthan University (RU) appears to be taking the paper leak matter reported on Monday lightly. Even though question papers of two subjects ‚Äî Zoology and Mathematics of BSc second year ‚Äî were out on social media at least 20 minutes before the commencement of the examination, RU authorities are reluctant to treat this as a ‚Äòpaper leak.‚Äô Administration has informed the police about the leak but no FIR has been filed even after two days.

As per the university administration, Veer Tejaji College, Radawas put the paper on social media 20 minutes before the exam started.

Rajasthan University chief examiner controller Vinod Gupta said, ‚ÄúIt will not be a leak as the students were already inside the classrooms. As per the norms, question papers are usually opened half an hour before the exam starts. Someone at the Veer Tejaji College, Radawas, notoriously shared the question paper about 20 minutes before the usual time of opening the question paper and posted it on social media.‚Äù

Gupta said that RU will file the FIR on Wednesday because police have asked for certain documents from the university and it is under process.

He further said, ‚ÄúWe have debarred the college from conducting any further exams. However, till March 6, the exams will be conducted as per the schedule as we cannot change the centre on such a short notice or else the students will suffer. A university supervisor will be present during the exams. From March 7, the exams will be shifted to any other centre.‚Äù

Title: Not many takers at JDA‚Äôs PRN regularisation camps
Content:
The JDA is organising camps to regularise 24 colonies in the scheme.

JAIPUR: The Jaipur Development Authority ‚Äôs attempts to fill its coffers by issuing lease deeds to Prithvi Raj Nagar residents are turning futile as not many plot holders are coming forward in regularisation camps.

The JDA is organising camps to regularise 24 colonies in the scheme. According to the sources, there are approximately 3,000 houses in these colonies. However, so far less than 200 people have applied and procured lease deeds. A source at JDA said, ‚ÄúThe JDA has not even issued 200 lease deeds (pattas) so far. The major reason is that many plot owners have expressed helplessness in affording the cost.‚Äù

After JDA increased the development charges and regularisation fee, the plot owners got discouraged. Giraj Singh Khangarot , president of Prithvi Nagar Sangharsh Samiti said, ‚ÄúThe people who have not taken lease deeds till date are really poor. The capable plot owners have already procured lease deeds. The government should be providing relaxation to these plot owners rather than increasing rates.‚Äù

The civic body has set a target to issue lease deeds to all the PRN plot holders till November 2020. Residents who will fail to procure lease deeds on time will have to pay double development and regularisation rates to regularise their plots.

BJP former councillor, Maan Pandit who is protesting against the increased rates said, ‚ÄúThe people have understood the government‚Äôs intentions. The idea is to benefit the mafias and suppress the poor. Our government had decided to acquire land above 1,000 sq yards and develop the area by selling that land. However, the decision was reversed.‚Äù

For a 100 square-yard plot, JDA will charge Rs 300 regularisation charge (per square yard), which will include allotment rates. Similarly, for plot size between 101 and 300 square-yards, JDA will charge Rs 480.

The agency will charge regularisation rates of Rs 720 (per square yard) for plots bigger than 301 square yards and up to 1,000 square yards. Owners having a plot of more than 1,000 square yards will have to give 1.5 times regularisation charges.

For regularising a marriage garden in the scheme, which has been developed on a plot size above 2,000 square yards, the JDA has fixed Rs 1,500 (per square yard) regularisation charge.

Title: MHA told to take call on Revanth security
Content:
Hyderabad: Justice Abhinand Kumar Shavili of the high court on Tuesday directed the ministry of home affairs (MHA) to take a decision on Congress MP A Revanth Reddy‚Äôs plea seeking security from central forces.

The judge gave the direction after hearing a plea by the MP, who wanted the court to direct the Centre to take a decision on his previous representation to the MHA. Assistant solicitor general Namavarapu Rajeswara Rao told the court that the MP‚Äôs representation has no date on it and the contents too were vague. The judge asked the MP to give a fresh representation and directed the MHA to take a decision on it within six weeks.tnn

Title: Committee to review T govt schemes
Content:
Hyderabad: The Telangana government on Tuesday constituted a three-member committee headed by finance minister T Harish Rao to review the Abhaya Hastham and Vaddileni Runalu schemes.

Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao-led state cabinet had decided in February to review the two schemes. The committee is scheduled to recommend further course of action to state government.

The committee will recommend further course of action. TNN

Title: Burglar arrested with 413 grams gold
Content: Hyderabad: The Task Force South Zone team, along with Nallakunta police, on Tuesday arrested a house burglar who was involved in two housebreaking offences in Nallakunta and Chilakalguda. Police recovered gold ornaments weighing about 413 grams and worth of Rs 17 lakh from his possession. The accused was identified as Mohammed Saddam Ali, alias Imran Ali, a resident of RTC Colony, Moula-Ali area. TNN

Title: Crop loss in some districts may spike mango prices this season
Content:
Vijayawada: Mango lovers will have to shell out a little more this year. Though the crop is in a much better state in the orchards of Krishna district, especially in Nuzvid region, compared to last year, crop failure in other districts in the state will spike the demand and price of Nuzvid mango variety.

Krishna district is home to one of the best mango varieties (Bangenapalli and chinna rasalu) that are exported in huge quantities to other parts of the country and also abroad. In Krishna, mango orchards spread over 70,000 hectares, including 24,000 hectares in Nuzvid region.

Speaking to TOI, assistant director, Horticulture department, Nuzvid, Ch Srinivasulu said the weather condition had helped mango production in Krishna district, but had bitten into production in Rayachoti (Kadapa), Prakasam, Chittoor and Vizianagaram districts. The average yield in the current season is over 5.5 tons per acre in Nuzvid region.

The current rate of the Nuzvid mango is anywhere between Rs 60,000 and Rs 65,000 per tonne. The price of the mango is likely to decrease to around Rs 35,000 per tonne in the peak mango season (April and May), Srinivasulu added.

In Vijayawada, the price of popular varieties of the mango (Bangenapalli, Totapuri, Rasalu) was ranged anywhere between Rs 400 and Rs 800 a dozen in the last season. Traders who export the fruit from Nunna Mango Market in Vijayawada to other parts of the state and country said mango lovers will have to pay more than last season to relish the fruit this year.

Compared to the previous year, mango yield in Krishna district has increased around 20 per cent in the current season. If a majority of the crop in Krishna district is diverted to other areas due to demand, there will be little left to meet the local demand, said D Dayakar Babu, assistant director of Horticulture, Krishna district.

‚ÄúWe relish the rasalu variety of mango. If the price of mango is beyond the reach, we will cut down the quantity of purchase,‚Äù says K Sangeeta, a resident of Vijayawada. The price of raw mango is around Rs 50, which is quite high this year. With the high prices of mango, many people can‚Äôt afford to buy raw mangoes to prepare pickle, she added.

Title: Garbage truck knocks down GHMC worker
Content:
Secunderabad: A 35-year-old Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) contract worker was killed on Tuesday when a GHMC garbage truck hit her two-wheeler at Radhika theatre crossroads in AS Rao Nagar.

Soundarya fell down and came under the rear tyre of the truck. ‚ÄúShe was riding a TVS Pep scooter when the municipal corporation‚Äôs truck hit her from behind,‚Äù said Kushaiguda inspector K Chandra Shekar.

Soundarya was wearing a helmet at the time (7 am) of the mishap.

She was rushed to a hospital where doctors declared her brought dead. She was on her way to Sainikpuri.

Police said Soundarya was a supervisor and resident of Nehru Nagar in Kushaiguda.

Truck driver G Narendar was taken into custody and booked under Section 304-A (causing death by negligence) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

The body was shifted to Gandhi Hospital.

Title: ‚ÄòRenting govt sports facilities to pvt players depriving poor‚Äô
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Congress MLA from Sadulpur and Olympian Krishna Poonia raised the issue that renting out government-owned sporting facilities to private sports academies is depriving the poor sportspersons of the state.

During the assembly session on Tuesday, Poonia, a Padma Shree and Arjuna Award recipient said, ‚ÄúThe private academies in stadiums like SMS charge fees which makes it impossible for children from poor background to avail facilities at the government-owned stadiums.‚Äù

Title: Mamtani‚Äôs camera catches bird‚Äôs eye view of nature, life
Content:
A chartered accountant Manish Mamtani focuses his photography that reflects the beauty of landscapes, nature a... Read More

Nagpur: It is almost surreal how an eye of Manish‚Äôs camera captures the beauty of landscape and nature at once. Manish Mamtani, a chartered accountant by profession, has taken the ‚Äògame‚Äô of photography to a high level. His clicked picture recently made it to the New Hampshire‚Äôs cover, a Visitors Guide published in USA in October 2019.

He focuses on work that reflects the beauty of landscapes, nature and greenery.

‚ÄúIt all started in 2010. I visited Yosemite National Park, California, in November of 2010 when I was still learning to use my first camera. I was awestruck by the beauty of this park,‚Äù said Mamtani.

His love for nature ventured him into photography. His work contains an array of different pictures, right from landscapes to breathtaking oceans and greenery. Some of his pictures also made its way to Nat Geo, Vanity Fair, Digital Photo, Digital Camera World and Better Photography Magazine.

‚ÄúI started taking pictures and sent them to various photography groups on social media. I got a good response and people liked my style of photography. This gave me a lot of confidence and improved me. This is when I decided to enter photography contests,‚Äù added Mamtani.

His work has won several national and international awards and honourable mentions, including Black and White Spider Awards, Share the Experience, London School of Photography, and Windland Awards. His work has been published in several national and international media, including Huffington Post, The Telegraph, The Australian, ZME Science, Perth Now, Upworthy, NASA, The National Parks Calendar, TWAN and many more.

Mamtani has a strong social media presence with over a million followers worldwide. He plans to conduct photography workshops in India which will be a learning opportunity for budding photographers.

Sharing his views about the kind of his type of photography which makes him stand out, he said, ‚ÄúPeople often tell me that they identify my pictures and say that we know this is clicked by Manish. I click pictures in raw mode and want to capture in an exact way as I saw it with a naked eye.‚Äù

‚ÄúI take landscape images to show how beautiful nature is and infrared images to show how I imagine this world to be. Aerial photography gives a completely new perspective to a place that is shot a million times. I call it a bird‚Äôs eye view photography,‚Äù added Mamtani.

Talking about his drone photograph which earned him a Nat Geo award, he said, ‚ÄúThe image was selected as the Editor‚Äôs Favourite. The image was shot in New Hampshire.‚Äù

Title: Kin blame college for youth‚Äôs suicide
Content:
Kozhikode: The family of final year BA Economics student of Malabar Christian College (MCC) Jaspreet Singh (21) ‚Äî who committed suicide on Sunday after being disqualified from writing exam due to shortage of attendance ‚Äî has said that it was the insensitive attitude of college authorities towards his repeated pleas to allow him write the exam, that led to his death.

His sisters, Balvind Kaur and Gurpreet Kaur, said on Tuesday that Singh had 68% attendance (as against the required 75%) as the family had to go to their ancestral home in Jalandhar following the demise of their grandmother.

‚ÄúHe had informed the college about the situation and had submitted documents before the college and university. Our father (Manmohan Singh) went to the college and pleaded with the teachers to show mercy. They were inconsiderate,‚Äù said Balvind, adding that the college did not even consider the medical certificate he had produced. When he approached the university, he was told that it was up to the principal to grant permission.

Manmohan, who was in tears, said, ‚ÄúI pleaded to give him one last chance, but they didn‚Äôt. Had they informed me six months ago, I would have gone and intervened. We were not even informed.‚Äù

Singh‚Äôs family, living in Kozhikode for the past 10 years, runs a hotel.

Meanwhile MCC principal Godwin Samraj said the college was following university regulations and Singh had utilized the 20% double condonation to make up for attendance shortage in the fourth semester.

‚ÄúAs it can be used only once, no further relaxation in attendance can be granted during the course. The student had not approached the college principal or the grievance cell after the semester attendance was published on February 7,‚Äù he said.

The principal denied the family‚Äôs allegation that a teacher from MCC had told him to ‚Äògo to Punjab and write the exams‚Äô.

Though the principal can allow a student to provisionally write an exam, it would later lead to complications as the varsity will not publish the result, said the principal.

Title: Wild boar injures 3 in Shamshabad
Content:
Hyderabad: Three persons were injured in an attack by a wild boar at Shamshabad on Tuesday morning.

According to forest officials, the attack took place in a house at Bahadur Ali Maqta locality around 6am.

‚ÄúA man, and his son and daughter-in-law were attacked when this wild boar, which might have lost its way, entered the house. The boar might have attacked them in self-defence after the family, on noticing it enter their house, tried to it ward off,‚Äù said Bheema Naik, district forest officer, Rangareddy.

The injured persons, Jangaiah (65), his son Yadagiri (45) and Manjula (35) were rushed to Osmania General Hospital (OGH) for treatment. ‚ÄúOur forest divisional officer and other staff visited the family who were admitted in hospital, and we are also giving them all the medical expenses,‚Äù said Naik. RGI Airport police said the wild boar might have come from the RGI Airport compound and went into Bahadur Ali Maqta locality. ‚ÄúYadagiri suffered some serious injuries,‚Äù said P Vijay Kumar, SHO, RGI Airport police station.

Title: Sports policy in state soon, says minister in assembly
Content:
File photo of Ashok Chandna

Jaipur: Minister of State for Sports and Youth Affairs Ashok Chandna on Tuesday said that sports policy will be brought in the state soon.

He said that players representing the state in national competitions will be given the benefit of reservation in government jobs.

Ashok Chandna was responding to the debate on the demand for grant of demand number 24 (education, arts and culture, sports and youth services) in the assembly on Tuesday. After discussion, the house passed the demand for education, arts and culture, sports and youth services for a grant of Rs 330 billion, 98 crore 13 lakh and 71 thousand.

Title: Like minerals, groundwater is state property, charge for it: Madras high court
Content:
Advocate-general Vijay Narayan submitted that the state has made a conscious decision not to charge extraction... Read More

CHENNAI: Groundwater is not less precious than minerals, so why can‚Äôt the government charge units that use water for commercial purposes?

Raising this pertinent question, the Madras high court said: ‚ÄúLike minerals, all the natural resources found under the ground are property of the state. We do not understand why extraction of groundwater is not charged when water is a scarce resource. The state cannot provide free meal to such industries particularly when they are commercially exploiting the natural resource.‚Äù

The division bench of Justice Vineet Kothari and Justice R Suresh Kumar made these observations after nudging the state government to seal more than 500 packaged water manufacturing units that were extracting groundwater illegally across the state.

Responding to the court‚Äôs query, advocate-general Vijay Narayan submitted that the state has made a conscious decision not to charge extraction of groundwater by packaged water manufacturers since it caters the drinking water needs of the people which the state could not provide. ‚ÄúThen what is the purpose of fixing flow meters to the extraction pumps,‚Äù the bench wondered.

To this, Narayan explained that meters are to check extraction quantity to cap ‚Äòover extraction‚Äô by manufacturers.

Narayan wanted the court to advise the manufacturers who are currently on ‚Äòstrike‚Äô to have faith on the judiciary and that such ‚Äòstrike‚Äô is not a good move.

Recording the submission, the bench said, ‚ÄúIf they think it (strike) will put pressure on this court, then they are mistaken.‚Äù

Denying the submission that the units are on ‚Äòstrike‚Äô, senior counsel P S Raman submitted that the units could not work since they have been shut down by the authorities in view of court order. This fact was explained in a media briefing, but it was misinterpreted as strike, he added.

Earlier, Narayan explained the court that of the 261 units functioning across the state, extraction points in 124 units have been sealed and that the rest will also be closed soon. Taking the report on record, the bench observed that the manufacturers must be made to pay a price for tapping groundwater in the past without proper licence. ‚ÄúThe past cannot be buried under the carpet,‚Äù the bench said.

Representing a group of manufacturers, Raman contended that the government has imposed adverse conditions only against packaged drinking water manufacturers whereas other water ‚Äòraw water‚Äô suppliers through trucks are still allowed to function.

He added that an appeal against the single judge order which upheld the government order pertaining to packaged drinking water units is already pending before the first bench of the court headed by the chief justice. Recording the submissions, the bench said that they would pass detailed order on Wednesday.

Title: Authorities brace for water woes in city
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The city, which finds itself in the clutches of soaring temperatures, will need to brace for a sterner test with the upcoming Attukal festival, when lakhs of devotees arrive to offer pongala.

In order to cater to the water requirements to around 15 lakh devotees from outside the city, KWA is planning elaborate arrangements, which will result in water shortage in several areas. The worst affected will be the higher-lying areas.

Officials of the water authority‚Äôs south division expect around 15 lakh people to pour into the city for the festival. ‚ÄúThe population of city is around 10 lakh. Arrival of an additional 15 lakh people means that we have to arrange double the quantity of water supplied per day. Several areas are already affected by water shortage,‚Äù sources said.

As part of Attukal pongala, KWA will stock up the 76-lakh-litre-capacity tank at Iranimuttam and the 100-lakh-litre tank at Vellayambalam. Several areas in the city will experience supply disruptions from March 6 to 9 as the authority diverts water from tanks in PTP Nagar and Observatory.

There will be partial disruptions in areas such as Vattiyoorkavu, Thirumala, Poojappura, Karamana, PTP Nagar, Nemom, Vellayani, Munnamoodu, Kodunganoor, Vayalikkada, Kallumala, Pappanamcode, Vellayambalam, Sasthamangalam, Vazhuthacaud, Jawahar Nagar, Kowdiar and Nandavanam from Friday.

On pongala day, on Monday, more areas will experience partial disruptions due to stocking of additional water in the low-level tank at Vellayambalam. This will result in a partial disruption in Vazhuthacuad, Thycaud, Valiyasala, PMG, Statue, Bakery Junction, Pulimoodu, Ottukuzhy, Manjalikkulam Road, Ayurveda College, Palayam, MLA Quarters, General Hospital, Pettah and Veli.

In 2013, a major pipe burst disrupted water supply in the city on the eve of Attukal pongala, which triggered conspiracy and sabotage rumours. Following this, KWA has taken to stocking water in advance. It will also provide water in tankers to pongala areas. KWA will install 25 tanks, 1,270 temporary taps and 50 showers in festival areas.

Title: NIA T unit registered 10 cases: Kishan
Content:
Hyderabad: The National Investigation Agency (NIA) has registered 319 cases since its inception in the state in 2008 and Telangana unit of NIA has so far registered 10 cases.

In response to a question in Lok Sabha on the performance of NIA, Union minister of state for home G Kishan Reddy said that judgment has been pronounced in 62 cases and 276 have been convicted in 56 cases.

Among the 319 cases, NIA had taken up investigation in 10 cases in offences committed in Telangana. Of the 10 cases, chargesheets have been filed in five. -Mahesh Buddi

Title: Jaipur: Mins draw speaker‚Äôs ire over ‚Äòhalf-baked‚Äô answers
Content:
File photo of C P Joshi

JAIPUR: Speaker C P Joshi was in his usual self during the Question Hour in the assembly on Tuesday. On not being answered properly to the questions put up by the MLAs during Questions Hour, Joshi, while showing strictness on the ministers, himself went ahead and clarified the question and instructed the ministers that instead of beating the bush they should answer to the question straight.

Senior ministers Shanti Dhariwal, B D Kalla, Govind Singh Dotasra and Pratap Singh Kachariyawas were at the receiving end for the speaker on Tuesday.

Parliamentary affairs minister Shanti Dhariwal could not give a straight answer to the question by Sandeep Sharma. Speaker then intervened and asked the minister that instead of repeating things, you should give a direct answer.

Joshi said the question is due to delay in the disbursal of pension of retired employees, the government had to pay Rs 50 lakh as interest, and what action was taken against the officials responsible for it.

The minister said the junior accounts officers on election duty were the reason for the delay. Stating the figures, he said that 1,865 cases of fixation are still pending, out of which 852 cases are added in 2020. Similarly Minister Pratap Singh Khachariyawas caught on the backfoot while replying to a question of Ganesh Godhra, on the re-introduction of Grameen Sewa buses in rural areas in Dungarpur district. The minister said rural transport service was discontinued by the BJP government. Leader of Opposition Gulabchand Kataria intervened saying the question is about the number buses presently operating and the time line of reintroduction of the remaining routes. The minister instead of giving the figures started reading out the routes where services were stopped.

The speaker dissatisfied with the reply, proceed to the next question. On the question of Amritlal Meena related to delay in disbursal of fees outstanding of BPL children in private school in Salumbar for the academic year 2019-20, education minister Govind Singh Dotasara told that the amount of Rs 138.47 crore fees outstanding left by the previous government was the reason for the delay in payment, the speaker said the minister is not replying to the question. Dotasara finally had to say that the fees due of 302 children for the year 2019-20 will be made by April.

Title: Road closures in Secunderabad Cantt a no-show in Rajya Sabha, residents miffed
Content:
A file picture of Gough Road in Secunderabad

SECUNDERABAD: A section of residents were irked over the Ministry of Defence‚Äôs (MoD) failure in recognising closure of roads in the Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB) limits in a question raised in the Rajya Sabha on March 2.

Andhra Pradesh MP Vijayasai Reddy sought details of closed roads in various cantonments across the country. The MP questioned whether it is a fact that due to road closure, general public are finding it difficult as they cannot pass through cantonment roads since barriers, checkposts and roadblocks have been installed by the Army.

While the response by the MoD did mention road closures in Bareilly and Amritsar cantonments, it did not find any mention of those closed in the Secunderabad cantonment. ‚ÄúIt is a glaring error by the minister not to include these illegally closed roads in Secunderabad in his reply. It indicates a totally cavalier attitude of the defence ministry to this critical issue which affects lakhs of civilians daily,‚Äù said Jeethender Surana, secretary of All Cantonments Citizens Welfare Association.

According to a letter issued by the SCB to the MoD in 2018, Rajendra Singh ji road network, Hislop ‚Äì Amherst road network and Gough road network are among the few roads which have been closed by the local military authorities. Commuters allege that the closure of arterial roads by the local military authorities results in long detours.

Residents living in Sainikpuri and its surrounding areas have sought a special board meeting by the SCB on the road closure issue. ‚ÄúMany roads closed in Secunderabad and they are no strategic importance; many running through the Golf course. Close down the golf course and open the roads,‚Äù tweeted ML Agarwal, a resident.

Title: Promised Rs 65 cr, cane farmers call off stir
Content:
Bijnor: Sugarcane farmers staging a dharna outside 21 police stations in Bijnor over pending cane dues called called off their protests on Tuesday after they were assured they would be paid Rs 65 crore over the next few days.

`

The nine sugar mills in the district owe a total of Rs 725 crore to some 75,000 cane farmers.

Confirming that the agitation has been called off, state president of Bharatiya Kisan Unions‚Äôs youth wing Digambar Singh, said, ‚ÄúOf the nine mills which owe Rs 725 crore, those in Bijnor, Chandpur, Bilai and Barkatpur have hardly paid anything to farmers.‚Äù

Talking with TOI, Digamber Singh said, ‚ÄúThe administration has assured us that Rs 65 crore will be paid by defaulter sugar mills. On Tuesday, the mills paid Rs 32 crore while Rs 33 crore will be cleared within the next 15 days. However, we want all dues cleared.‚Äù If administration fails to stick to its promises, we will raise banner again. ‚Äù

Yashpal Singh, district cane officer, said, ‚ÄúGovernment is set to release a subsidy of Rs 55 crore, which is pending since last year. Apart from this, the credit limit of Bijnor and Chandpur mills will to be extended to Rs 80 crore by the UP Cooperative Bank. In the coming days, mills will be able to pay farmers their pending dues. In facr, in Bijnor, we have paid 65% of total dues.‚Äù

Title: 100 tonnes of Nuzvid mango to be exported
Content:
Vijayawada: The government is set to export at least 100 tonnes of mangoes cultivated in the Nuzvid region to countries like Dubai, Singapore, South Korea, Maldives and Europe. Some of the mango growers in Nuzvid region were guided by the horticulture department on export standards, methods of cultivation, the right size, ripening methods, and fertilizers accepted by importing countries.

Assistant director at the horticulture department, Nuzvid, Ch Srinivasulu said the integrated pack house is located in Nuzvid and the mangoes to be exported is processed in IPH. After the mangoes are harvested, selected mangoes undergo cold water treatment, vapour heat treatment, hot water treatment or preserved in cold storage at the IPH to meet the standards of the export countries.

‚ÄúIn 2019, around 10 tonnes of mango (Banginapalli variety from Nuzvid) was exported to Europe, South East Asia, and few other countries via air cargo from Hyderabad and Chennai,‚Äù Srinivasulu added.

Title: Soon, scan QR code to pay for booze at Tasmac shops in Tamil Nadu
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: Tipplers may no longer have to carry wallets to Tasmac wine shops ‚Äî their phones would be enough to buy liquor bottles. In an attempt to curtail overcharging at liquor outlets, the state-owned marketing corporation is launching Unified Payments Interface (UPI) to eliminate cash transactions at the counters.

BHIM QR codes at wine shops will be available and consumers can just scan to pay online. This apart, point of sale (PoS) machines that are available at shops in Chennai and neighbouring districts will be provided across Tamil Nadu. Tasmac has floated tenders seeking services from commercial banks and system providers.

‚ÄúOnce the system is place, consumers need not pay any cash at the counters,‚Äù a senior Tasmac official told TOI.

Tasmac records sale of Rs 23 crore through cashless transactions by debit and credit cards a month. Its elite shops have a mobile wallet facility offered by a private player. Officials are expecting that the value generated through cashless transaction will jump substantially after the launching of UPI facility with at least 10% customers shifting to UPI.

Asked about complaints of overcharging in transactions involving debit and credit cards, a Tasmac official said audits are being conducted. ‚ÄúWe have suspended two employees following complaints of overcharging with regard to cashless transactions two months ago. Strict action will be initiated against such violations,‚Äù the official said.

Title: No drug overdose in Goa in last five years: CM Pramod Sawant
Content: PANAJI: Despite frequent allegations and numerous unnatural deaths that have drug abuse as prime suspect, the state government has said that ‚Äúnot a single case of drug overdose‚Äù has been reported in Goa since 2015.Whenever a person dies in the coastal belt in a suspicious manner, opposition parties have alleged drug overdose. Chief minister Pramod Sawant , however, said that ‚Äúsome cases of unnatural death have been reported‚Äù.In 2019, Goa police seized over 84kg drugs and arrested 239 persons. The total value of the drugs seized in 2019 was over Rs 5.9 crore.Replying to a question by leader of the opposition Digambar Kamat whether any deaths have occurred in the state due to overdose of drugs or narcotic substances from 2015 till date, chief minister Pramod Sawant, in a written reply in the assembly, stated, ‚ÄúSome cases of unnatural death have been reported during from 2015 till January 15, 2020, however, no cases of deaths due to drug overdose have been confirmed as per records available in police stations.‚ÄùOn the recent deaths during an electronic dance music (EDM) festival, Sawant said, ‚ÄúThree cases of unnatural deaths (UD) have been reported during music festival since 2015 till January 2020. All three UD cases were reported in 2019. To ascertain the exact cause of death, the police surgeon/medico legal officer has forwarded the viscera of the deceased persons to Central Forensic Science Laboratory (CFSL) Hyderabad. The reports are awaited.‚ÄùSawant said that inquiry into the three UD cases reported in December is in progress. Hence, it may be inappropriate to furnish documents pertaining to the cases to the members of the House.Recently, IGP Jaspal Singh wrote to CFSL, Hyderabad, to treat as ‚Äútop priority‚Äù the examination of viscera material of the three persons to take the inquest proceedings to a logical conclusion.

Title: Pune activists demand civic body cancel MRI machine tender
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

PUNE: Activists have slammed civic health officials for wasting taxpayers‚Äô money by issuing a tender for buying a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) machine when the MRI scan service was already available at two PMC-run hospitals for the benefit of needy patients.

The activists said the civic body had entered into an agreement with a private agency for starting diagnostic services, including MRI scans, for needy citizens at affordable charges in 2017 under the public-private partnership model.

Since then, the private agency has installed MRI machine at Kamla Nehru Hospital in Mangalwar Peth and works are on to install another at Sutar hospital in Kothrud. Besides, PMC-run Pote hospital in Padmavati has been providing MRI scan service to the needy patients.

‚ÄúWe demand immediate cancellation of the tender and suspension of the officials concerned. The officials had been highlighting the waiting period for the scan at the two civic-run hospitals for buying the new machine, which is a big lie. There is no waiting period at the Kamala Nehru Hospital and the waiting period at Pote hospital is five to six days against 10-15 days as claimed by the health officials,‚Äù activist Vivek Velankar of Sajag Nagarik Manch, an NGO, said.

He said as per the December 2017 agreement, it was the private agency‚Äôs responsibility to install the MRI machines, each unit of which costs around Rs 10 crore. ‚ÄúThe officials should first finish the work in hand and see how it works. They should pull up the private agency for taking so long to install MRI machine at Sutar hospital,‚Äù Velankar said.

‚ÄúBesides, such a service kicked off at Pote hospital three years before the 2017 agreement, for which another private agency was appointed to run the MRI scan service after purchasing a machine,‚Äù he said.

As per the proposal, the civic officials intend to purchase and install the MRI machine at Rajiv Gandhi hospital in Yerawada before roping in another private agency for providing the service. ‚ÄúThough the municipal commissioner asked the officials to submit the action plan within 15 days for the service, they did not do so. Instead, the health officials quickly floated the tender for buying the MRI machine after the proposal was approved on February 4,‚Äù Velankar said.

Anjali Sabne, assistant medical officer of health and head of the purchase at the PMC‚Äôs health department, said, ‚ÄúAs per the city‚Äôs geographical distribution, there has to be four to five PMC hospitals offering MRI scan service to curtail long commute and waiting period. We are going to purchase and install the machine at Rajiv Gandhi hospital, for which a private agency will be roped in to offer the service as per the CGHS.‚Äù

Title: Students protest college privatisation
Content: Hyderabad: Demanding the Telangana government to convert aided colleges into government degree colleges, students protested in front of the commissioner of collegiate education office on Tuesday. Students also demanded that the state fills vacant teaching posts in colleges. TNN

Title: NGO blames NMC, traffic cops for ignoring its study report
Content:
Nagpur: Non-functioning of pedestrians‚Äô signals, hawkers occupying roads and parking of vehicles within 50 meters of intersections make several roads of the city, including the Variety Square ‚Äî the most chaotic junction, vulnerable to accidents, according to a study carried out by an NGO, Janakroash.

The NGO involves in creating traffic awareness that supports the government for an efficient and safe traffic management system. The NGO, which has carried out an exhaustive study on deficiencies at traffic intersections, submitted its report to mayor Sandip Joshi.

The report said the NGO has always been acting as eyes and ears of Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) and traffic police. This has been done with an aim of reducing accidents and not for playing any blame game, the report said.

NGO vice-president Ashok Karandikar said the NGO had done a survey on about 80 intersections of the city a few years ago and submitted its report to the NMC and the DCP traffic office. There was no effective response from the then officials in charge, he said.

‚ÄúThis time also the NGO carried out study of intersections like Variety Square, Samvidhan Square, Chhatrapati Square, Wanjari Nagar TB Ward Square, Samrat Ashok Chowk, Agyaram Devi Chowk etc. The study found several deficiencies on these intersections like absence zebra markings or its poor visibility, stop lines, defunct pedestrian lights and timers. The deficiencies further point out the illegal parking of two-wheelers and autorickshaws at the intersection and the bus stops in the proximity of intersections,‚Äù he said.

The study has also exposed how the NMC‚Äôs ignorant attitude to finish cement concretization works has turned most intersections in the city into accident-prone spots. ‚ÄúOn several newly constructed roads, the intersections remained at lower levels than connecting roads causing risk of water accumulation in rainy season and of accidents,‚Äù the report said.

‚ÄúThese deficiencies due to non-development of intersections to match the newly constructed roads level have also remained unattended. If inaction is due to different ownerships of roads, it is time NMC took charge as a nodal authority,‚Äù it said.

According to the study, the intersections which need immediate attention included three on Central Bazaar Road, Bajaj Nagar Chowk, Shankar Nagar Chowk, Omkar Nagar Chowk and Shatabdi Chowk.

The NGO also urged the mayor to ensure that the NMC should take proactive measures to eradicate these deficiencies for the safety of people driving on city roads.

Title: APNGO women‚Äôs sports meet held
Content:
Vijayawada: The APNGO state president N Chandrasekhar Reddy on Tuesday inaugurated the sports and games meet of women employees of APNGO Association at Indira Gandhi Municipal Stadium here in Vijayawada. The sports meet was organised on the eve of International Women‚Äôs Day.

Reddy said that the sports meet was a great opportunity to relax for employees who work under a lot of stress all through the year. ‚ÄúWe are appealing to the government to grant child care leave to women employees for a maximum period of two years on the lines of Central government employees, ‚Äúsaid AP NGO leader Vidya Sagar. TNN

Title: BJP MLA gets threats over conversion issue
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: BJP MLA Shankar Singh Rawat on Tuesday claimed in the assembly that he was threatened on social media for raising the issue of religious conversion.

‚ÄúI had raised an issue in the House on February 28 after which I was constantly getting threats with dire consequences on social media, including Facebook and through SMSes,‚Äù Rawat said in the House during Zero Hour. While Rawat sought action against the culprits, Opposition leader Gulab Kataria said it is a serious matter and asked the legislator to move a breach of privilege motion. Rajendra Pareek, who was in the chair, directed the government to investigate the matter and inform the House.

Meanwhile, deputy leader of Opposition Rajendra Rathore raised the issue of frequent incidents of gas cylinder blasts and demanded that the government must hold a meeting with the representatives of the gas companies to ensure proper safety arrangements are in place.

Title: EFLU cancels student‚Äôs admission
Content:
Secunderabad: The English and Foreign Languages University ( EFLU ) cancelled admission of a student on Tuesday after he failed to submit qualifying degree certificate.

According to orders issued by EFLU, a candidate who was given provisional admission into masters of journalism and mass communication during academic year 2018-19 had given an undertaking at the time of admission that he would produce qualifying degree certificate from University of Calicut as per rules. ‚ÄúWhile the candidate has submitted transfer certificate issued by the University of Calicut which mentioned the completion of the said course, he has failed to submit his qualifying degree certificate,‚Äù read the orders.

When EFLU registrar wrote to University of Calicut in April 2019 seeking clarification on the status of the candidate‚Äôs completion of the degree, the varsity was informed that the candidate had not cleared semester 2 course ‚Äòtranslation and communication in Arabic‚Äô. However, he registered for the supplementary exam, April 2019, the result of which will be published soon.

Title: Rehabilitate polluting households, corp told
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The monitoring committee set up by the state to review progress of national green tribunal (NGT) cases has directed the city corporation to identify households and establishments, located near waterbodies, which discharge effluents into canals and rivers.

Chief secretary Tom Jose, chairman of the committee, stressed the need to identify them and arrange alternative locations for their rehabilitation at a review meeting held here on Tuesday. The district administration which undertook a survey as part of the project to revive Parvathy Puthanar had identified 1,700 households along the Kovalam-Akkulam stretch which require rehabilitation.

In April 2019, the corporation was asked to rehabilitate 8,050 households near Karamana river without septic tanks and which have been diverting sewage to the water body. In a meeting convened by chief secretary in April following a spot visit by NGT‚Äôs state-level monitoring committee, the corporation was directed to take preliminary steps towards rehabilitation of households without septic tanks. It was estimated the corporation would have to acquire 48 acres of land for the purpose. This assumes importance as the civic body is already facing difficulties in purchasing land for the Life Mission.

Sources said a major issue in forcing residents to move is that many of them had been given title deeds by the government in the past, in a way giving them legal right to reside near waterbodies. The civic body will have to be backed by various departments and the government in its move to identify households located close to waterbodies and initiate steps for rehabilitation.

Around 18,000 landless beneficiaries were identified under the Life Mission within corporation limits and over 8,000 have received homes so far. The meeting also decided to engage consultants for the preparation of DPR as part of laying sewage line in areas near polluted waterbodies. KWA has been directed to ensure a sewer network in the city in such a way the treatment plant at Muttathara works to full capacity. A DPR of the Rs 1,400 crore project will also have to be prepared.

Rejuvenation of Karamana river and Killiyaar through a series of short-term and long-term measures is expected to cost over Rs 1,500 crore.

Title: Pune: 7th edition of all women bike rally on Sunday
Content:
The bike rally will be organised in Pune and Chinchwad on March 8.

PUNE: The Maharashtra Times All Women Power Rally, a symbol of women's freedom and liberation, is now entering its seventh edition.

In the spirit of International Women's Day, the bike rally will be organised in Pune and Chinchwad on March 8. The rally is will be held across eight locations in the country. The event is open for any women who can ride a two-wheeler. The participants can also come with posters signifying the social cause they support.

The rally will start on Sunday at 7am from SP college on Tilak Road in Pune and from Elpro City Square Mall in Chinchwad. Participants from Pune can register by sending an SMS ‚ÄòPOWERRALLYPUN‚Äô to 58888. The interested parties from Chinchwad can SMS ‚Äò POWERRALLYPC ‚Äô to 5888. Participants can also register by logging on to www.allwomenpowerrally.com.

Every year, thousands of women from all walks of life participate in the rally, asserting their independence and breaking traditional gender stereotypes. To add onto the fun element this year, a prize distribution ceremony will be held. The award will be given in the following categories ‚Äî biggest group, best social message, best decorated bike, best decorated helmet, best traditional costume and best costume.

The event made its way to the ‚ÄúLimca Book of Records‚Äù in 2017.

That year, nearly 13,000 women from across the country participated in the rally.

Title: Former bureaucrats question lack of NPR data confidentiality
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

PUNE: A section of former bureaucrats and retired government officials has flagged the possibility of lack of confidentiality of the National Population Register data as against the Census.

The Census Act makes it compulsory for the government to keep the data collected during the process confidential. But there is no such requirement for the National Population Register (NPR) data under the citizenship rules, according to the office of the Registrar-General and Census Commissioner. It clearly states, ‚ÄúCertain information collected under the NPR will be published in the local areas for public scrutiny and invitation of objections, and some data will be shared for the verification purpose.‚Äù

A retired bureaucrat said, ‚ÄúA local register at the level of a tehsildar is supposed to give a decision on a citizen in the verification process, which we oppose vehemently.‚Äù

Some former bureaucrats and senior officials stated that there had been much confusion about if the Census and the NPR exercises were the same.

A former retired government official said the confusion arose partly from the government‚Äôs decision to conduct the exercises together, from April to September. Though they are completely different ‚Äî in purpose and origin ‚Äî there has been an attempt to pass them off as ‚Äúsimilar‚Äù or ‚Äúsame‚Äù.

The bureaucrats in an open letter earlier had stated that the data collected during the NPR would be used for determining citizenship.

Retired IPS officer Meeran Borwankar , who along with 73 former bureaucrats had issued a letter opposing the NPR drive, told TOI that while the Census was a time-tested process, the NPR was not. ‚ÄúI am personally against the NPR as I see a lot of harassment of the poor and marginalized sections of society,‚Äù she said.

According to a September 2019 notification of the Union home ministry, the enumerators appointed for the Census would also update the NPR. But apart from the house-to-house data collection, there was hardly anything common in the Census and the NPR, said a government official.

Senior government officials claimed that the data collected for Census gives a demographic and socio-economic population of the country, while the sole purpose of compiling the NPR is to create the National Register of Citizens .

Title: War of words over Lalit Modi in House
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: The House witnessed heated arguments during budget discussion on sports when independent MLA Sanyam Lodha mentioned former RCA president Lalit Modi for holding cricket administration to ransom.

Deputy opposition leader opposed comment on Modi as he was not a member of the House, while Lodha said since the discussion is on sports, there will be mention of RCA. The normalcy was restored after Rajendra Pareek ordered for deletion of Lalit Modi‚Äôs mention from the House records.

Lodha accused the previous BJP government of deleting the provision of domicile for contesting sports bodies‚Äô elections. First, the provision was waived for father (Lalit Modi) and then for his son (Ruchir Modi).

He said the result of the decision was RCA was dragged to the court for years and the interest of the players were hurt.

He also lauded the efforts of the Ghlot government and now RCA president Vaibhav Gehlot for his efforts to strengthen cricket infrastructure in the country.

Deputy opposition leader Rajendra Rathore objected to the mention of Lalit Modi and Vaibhav Gehlot who were not members of the House leading to heated exchanges between the ruling and opposition.

Title: Tamil Nadu mulling ban on plastic wraps for FMCG items
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: The Tamil government on Tuesday informed the Madras high court that it is considering banning single-use plastic wraps used to pack fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG) and other products. At present, such plastic wraps are exempted from the ban against single-use plastic.

‚ÄúPlastic used for packing are single-use plastics and throwaway type. Such packing medium gets discarded instantaneously once the unpacking is done, as it finds no other use. As a result, use of plastic in packing goods sealed prior to use and their instant disposal significantly contribute to generation of plastic waste which has not reduced despite ban on other single use plastics since January 1, 2019,‚Äù additional advocate general Arvind Pandian said.

In view of the reasons and the directions of the court, the Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB) has made a recommendation dated January 28, 2020 to consider removing the exemption provided to single use packaging plastics, Pandian added.

Recording the submission, a division bench of Justice S Vaidyanathan and Justice P T Asha observed that the state government has to give up the practice of supplying Aavin milk in plastic covers and follow the old method of using bottles or any other means.

The state should find new and innovate ways in phasing out plastic products, the bench added.

Adding that surprise inspections were being conducted across the state by TNPCB. Outlets including KFC, McDonalds and Starbucks were issued show-cause notices for not complying with the orders, Pandian said.

Recording the submissions, the bench suggested that students should appointed as brand ambassadors on rotation basis to create awareness against use of plastic products.

The bench added that the authorities shall place instructions in front of churches, mosques and temples on the implementation of the plastic ban. Shops selling offerings in places of worship should be instructed about using the traditional storage materials like baskets, paper bags, jute bags, plantain or other leaves, the bench said.

Title: Utkal univ ropes in foreign faculty, more in the offing
Content:
Bhubaneswar: Over the past three months, four visiting professors from foreign countries have been taking classes in different departments of Utkal University. These professors from Canada, Australia and the US are teaching tourism studies, social sciences and anthropology respectively.

Three more visiting professors will be coming to the university over the next few months from Belgium, Australia and Sri Lanka as part of the varsity‚Äôs plan to expose its students to the best minds in the world.

‚ÄúThis is the beginning of a new chapter in Utkal University. In the last couple of months, our students got to listen and learn from internationally-acclaimed professors. Students are exposed to classes that have a different teaching pedagogy, style and content,‚Äù said said vice-chancellor Soumendra Mohan Patnaik, on the sidelines of a two-day international conference on Science, Society and Politics in South Asia here on Tuesday.

‚ÄúTo take this exposure to the next level, we have decided to rope in more visiting faculties for different subjects and schools,‚Äù he said.

The university has signed MoUs with foreign universities for exchange of faculties. He said these professors would be adjunct professors in Utkal University and would keep on giving their expert advice in the days to come on curriculum upgradation or future references.

The university has also decided to start capacity development training for faculty and non-teaching staff of the university. They will be trained on how to teach better, how can students learn better and how to collaborate better in research and development. They will also be trained in an advance module for better teaching methodologies and advance use of ICT across departments.

‚ÄúWe have also sent a group of non-teaching staff to undergo training in administrative work to Madhusudan Das Regional Academy of Financial Management,‚Äù said Manoj Tripathy, training and capacity development expert in Utkal University.

Title: BDA hopes for AAI nod to tallest tower
Content:
Bhubaneswar: The Bhubaneswar Development Authority (BDA) is hoping to get approval from the Airports Authority of India (AAI) for its ambitious multi-modal hub project, supposed to be the tallest and iconic landmark in the city. The tower, which is part of the smart city mission, is expected to come up over 12 acres at Master Canteen square near the railway station.

As per plan, the height of the building is supposed to be 80 metres (25 floors), but this had come in for scrutiny from the AAI, given that the proposed building is within 3 kilometres from the airport and could pose a problem for flights. Initially, the AAI had given clearance to a 40m-tall building. The BDA again approached AAI for approval of the remaining 40m, following which a survey was carried out.

Officials from the AAI, Bhubaneswar airport and BDA visited the site earmarked for the project.

‚ÄúOfficials of the Air Traffic Control (ATC) surveyed the area. Since the airport is around 3km from the site, the AAI had cited technical reasons given that high rises often pose problem to flights. But, from their assessment, we feel we will get the approval for the entire 80m tower,‚Äù BDA planning member Gouri Shankar Bhuyan said.
