The ambitious project is called a multi-modal hub because of the confluence of three modes of transport ‚Äî train, cab and bus. Besides, two huge towers of 80m height will be developed which will have multiplexes, shopping malls, high-end hotels, amphitheatre and recreational facilities. This area comes under Bhubaneswar Town Centre District (BTCD), a demarcated area, which has been planned to be developed as the down town of the smart city.

In 2016, the BDA had signed a MoU with Singapore-based Jurong Consultants India Limited to develop the multi-modal hub, which will cost around Rs 1,000 crore. The East Coast Railways is one of the major stakeholders of the project.

BDA officials said the multi-modal project will also include retail outlets and malls, nature plaza, landscape, town plaza, art plaza, experience plaza and children‚Äôs plaza besides food courts, service apartments and cycling tracks.

Title: Italian who tested +ve toured many tourist hubs
Content: JAIPUR: Health authorities are worried that the 69-year-old Italian national, who was travelling with a group of 23 tourists from Italy, not only tested positive for coronavirus (Covid-19), but he had also visited major tourist destinations of the state, putting a lot of people who came in contact with him at risk.Taking precautionary measures, rapid response teams have been constituted to strengthen surveillance on Covid-19 at places visited by the tourist group. According to the health department officials, the group reached Delhi airport on February 21 from Italy and has travelled by bus to many cities in Rajasthan.He reached Mandawa of Jhunjhunu district, which is famous for old havelis and their explicit architecture. He stayed at Hotel Castle in Mandawa on February 21. From Mandawa, the Italian tourist group reached Bikaner and stayed at Gaj Kesri for one day on February 22.The group moved to Jaisalmer from Bikaner and stayed at Rang Mahal on February 23 and February 24. They reached Jodhpur on February 25 and stayed at Zone Park. They spent February 26 at Hotel Trident of Udaipur. They checked in at Ramada hotel in Raja Park on February 28, the health department officials said.During their stay in the state, the Italian tourist group visited forts and other tourist places. However, the health department suspects that since he has been tested positive for coronavirus, there are chances that he might have infected others who came in contact with him. However, when he complained of fever, cough and breathlessness, he was shifted to a private hospital by ambulance. He was referred to Sawai Man Singh Hospital on February 29.Since he fell ill, he and his wife stayed back in Jaipur, while the rest of the 21 persons in the group went to Agra on March 1. They stayed at Crystal hotel for two days.After that, the group of 21 went to Delhi on March 3. The group stayed in Surya hotel, in New Friends colony, Delhi. ‚ÄúThe group had plans to fly back to Italy as they checked out at 12 midnight,‚Äù a health department official said.

Title: Swine flu killed only 3 of 9 dead: Audit report
Content:
Representative image

MEERUT: With two more patients testing positive on Tuesday, the number swine flu cases has increased to 81 even as the health department found in an audit that out of the nine reported deaths in the district, only three occurred due to the H1N1 virus.

Worried over increasing toll ‚Äî eight‚Äî and confirmed cases ‚Äî 81 ‚Äî which are likely to go up, the health department had constituted a six-member committee to ascertain whether the deaths were caused by swine flu. Initially, the health department said nine people had died, but the audit confirmed that only three deaths.

‚ÄúAs many as two new cases of swine flu have been reported in Meerut, with the total rising to 81. We have enough stock of medicines and are keeping a check on the people who have come in contact with patients confirmed positive. Tamiflu medicines have been given to all those who have come in contact with swine flu patients,‚Äù said Dr Raj Kumar, Meerut chief medical officer.

All the private and government hospitals have been instructed to stay ready with isolation wards, which might be needed in case the number of swine flu patients increase further.

Title: Nature and wildlife in myriad hues
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: There was no better day than the World Wildlife Day to kick-start the exhibition of photographs by John T L. The photographs that capture nature and wildlife in myriad hues, displayed at Museum Auditorium, will take the spectators to the mesmerizing dense forests.

The three-day exhibition is part of John‚Äôs mission to promote the message of protection and preservation of nature and wildlife. ‚ÄúI earnestly feel that it is the duty of mankind to protect and preserve the beauty of our Mother Nature. We may have to pay a heavy price for any damage caused to her, because once it is lost, it is lost forever,‚Äù said John.

His trips to forests and ecological hotspots proved that human interventions such as contamination of oceans, plastic waste, agriculture expansions and unplanned eco-tourism schemes have done more harm to the nature that anyone could estimate.

Photos, including that of a tiger cooling off in a lake, a white tiger eyeing a distant prey and playful moments of flocks of migratory birds, have been captured by John over five decades.

John is a trained artist and painter. During his student days itself, he became passionate about photography and enrolled as the disciple of renowned nature photographer T S Lal. The lessons he picked from Lal proved to be worthy when he joined the University of Kerala as an artist and photographer. During his 32-year-long career, he had worked in Botany, Marine Sciences, Zoology and Aquatic Biology departments.

After his retirement in 1997, John took up wildlife photography as a full-time p hobby and continued his travels and adventures. He is also a recipient of Lalithakala Academy Award in 2011.

The exhibition at Museum Auditorium will conclude on Thursday. The gallery will be open for public from 10am to 6pm.

Title: Cylinder blast in Jaipur: SHRC seeks report on safety steps
Content:
Representative image

Jaipur: Taking cognizance of the LPG cylinder blast incident killing two in a house close to Tadkeshwar Temple situated at Chaura Rasta area in the Walled City, the Rajasthan State Human Rights Commission (SHRC) on Tuesday sought a detailed report from Union petroleum and food & civil supplies ministry on the precautions and safety measures taken by the companies supplying LPG cylinders for domestic use.

Chairperson of the commission Justice Mahesh Chandra Sharma has also asked the ministries concern to give a detailed report by April 20. Two people were killed and one injured in a gas cylinder blast near Tadkeshwar Temple in Chaura Rasta area of Jaipur on Monday.

Justice Sharma took congnizance of the news reports and has asked if the agencies providing LPG cylinders for domestic use are taking enough safety and precautionary measures or not? In the report the respondents including union petroleum ministry and union food and civil supplies ministry have also been asked to provide a detail on if there is any prescribed expiry date of older LPG cylinders which are getting re-filled.

Title: KTR must clear air on farmhouse row: Cong
Content: Hyderabad: AICC general secretary in-charge of Telangana RC Khuntia demanded that TRS working president KT Rama Rao come clean on Janwada farmhouse issue. ‚ÄúIf the farmhouse has been constructed legally, let KTR produce the documents to put an end to the controversy,‚Äù Khuntia said. tnn

Title: Covid: Frantic citizens call corpn, seek advice
Content:
Chennai: As cases of people affected by corona virus across the country increase, Greater Chennai Corporation‚Äôs officials are getting calls from across the city and the state. Frantic callers are inquiring about precautions to be taken if they come across co-workers or neighbours who have symptoms of flu.

Senior officials in the health wing of the civic body told TOI that they got calls from Madurai and Ramanthapuram. This is because mobile numbers of all officials are available on the civic body‚Äôs website.

On Monday, a techie from an office on Anna Salai called and sought advice after he saw a few co-workers coughing.

‚ÄúWe ask them to take basic precautions like washing hands and wearing masks if necessary,‚Äù the official said.

The official said if corona virus is detected in the city, the corporation is ready. Preparatory works have been on for a few weeks now, he said.

Those who visited countries that reported cases of corona virus in the past few weeks are being tracked on a daily basis by the health department staff. Hotels have been asked to ensure that suspect cases are isolated for 14 days and that food for such guests are prepared separately.

All commercial establishments witnessing big crowds have been asked to intensify cleaning activities, with special focus on door handles.

A sensitisation meeting of private doctors in the city has been conducted. The corporation has kept a stock of personal protective equipment of around 500 N95 masks and 10,000 triple layer masks ready. The ground level health workers have been sensitised on the due course of action.

As of now, isolation wards are ready at Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital, Kilpauk Medical College and Stanley Medical College. The communicable diseases hospital in Tondiarpet is on standby.

The measures were reviewed by a joint secretary of the Union health ministry for Chennai and Pondicherry region on Saturday, the official said.

Title: Coronavirus in Jaipur: 50 people put under surveillance
Content: JAIPUR: Fifty persons have been identified who came in contact with the Italian tourists who tested positive for coronavirus ( Covid-19 ) at Sawai Man Singh Hospital in Jaipur. Among 50 persons, 42 of a government and a private hospital have been identified who came in contact with Italian tourist.Four employees of a hotel in Raja Park area, where the Italian tourists were staying, have also been identified. All the 50 persons have been isolated for 14 days at their homes. They have also disinfected the rooms of the hotels where the Italian stayed. Besides, hospital attached to Rajasthan University of Health Sciences has been developed as a centre for isolation for suspected coronavirus cases. ‚ÄúIt has been decided to develop medical college hospital of RUHS as isolation hospital. For necessary arrangements for all suspected/confirmed cases of Covid-19 patients as per protocol issued by ministry of health and family welfare,‚Äù wrote Vaibhav Galriya, principal secretary, medical education department to registrar, RUHS.

Title: ‚ÄòIndia‚Äôs democracy a challenge to Beijing model‚Äô
Content:
Former foreign secretary Vijay Gokhale

PUNE: Former foreign secretary Vijay Gokhale on Tuesday said a strong democracy, economic development and strengthening of the country is the biggest challenge that India can pose to China. India has a paucity of scholarship on China, he added.

Gokhale was speaking at the inauguration of a seminar on ‚ÄòIndia China Relations in the 21st century: Challenges and Opportunities‚Äô organised by Centre for Advanced Strategic Studies , Centre for China Analysis and Strategy, and MES Institute of Management and Career Courses on Tuesday.

‚ÄúDemocracy is our greatest asset which presents a challenge to the Beijing model. Our success in building our national strength through the democratic process makes it ideologically difficult for China to justify its idea of non-elected leadership. This is the single greatest challenge the Chinese government faces. Therefore, even though we are militarily backward compared to them, even though we are economically weaker, India represents the largest ideological challenge to China because of our democracy. They would like to see our democracy fail,‚Äù Gokhale said.

He called for lesser dependence on China for raw materials, intermediate goods and capital goods.

‚ÄúThere is no substitute for serious economic growth. We need to re-engineer our policies so as to ensure that we attract companies (willing to leave China) to India. We need to emulate China in building independent R&D and cutting edge technology,‚Äù he said.

Gokhale said the Chinese feel that India is unlikely to develop independent military capabilities to rival them for the next 25 years.

‚ÄúMilitary modernisation is vital. We are lagging behind in manufacturing military hardware, especially new means of warfare. If we cannot make defence equipment of a certain quality and if we cannot ensure that we get uninterrupted supply of defence equipment in spares, there is a serious limitation on whether we can take on the Chinese beyond a certain time,‚Äù he said.

He stressed on reviving relations with Russia , which, according to him remained the only supplier of defence equipment and technological know-how during India‚Äôs crunch time. Gokhale said a stronger relationship with the US is a must but on equal terms.

Gokhale said China may follow two strategies with India.

‚ÄúA soft approach by lessening tensions and making tactical concessions to prevent us from tilting towards the US and remaining neutral would be their plan. The second option would be to build pressure through military and security means at the line of actual control, the border in the northeast and through Pakistan,‚Äù he added.

Title: Man returns to Jodhpur from Iran, tests negative
Content:
Representative image

JODHPUR: A suspect here has been tested negative for the novel coronavirus. The suspect had returned from Iran a few days back and had been admitted to the isolation ward in MDM Hospital on Monday afternoon, after he was found possessing the symptoms of COVID-19.

His swab sample had been taken on Monday immediately after admission in the hospital and had been sent for examination. ‚ÄúWe received the report on Tuesday and it was negative‚Äù, said the Superintendent of the MDM Hospital M K Aseri.

According to the information, the suspect belonged to Shergarh subdivision of Jodhpur and worked in Iran for past some time.

He had returned to Jodhpur a few days back and had fallen sick on Sunday.

Title: Norms set to recruit village court officers
Content:
Vijayawada: The state government on Tuesday issued orders notifying the rules for recruiting grama nyayadhikaris for 42 grama nyayalayams which are to be established across the state.

The government has notified 42 special courts and the staff pattern for these courts. It has been has decided that the ratio of grama nyayadhikaris to be recruited as 3:1:1 from the members of the bar by direct recruitment, appointment by transfer from among the staff of subordinate judiciary in the cadre of superintendent (category-II) on deputation and the staff of the high court in the cadre of assistant section officer in high court service and by recruitment on ad hoc basis of retired judicial officers.

The rule of reservation shall only be applicable for direct recruitment as provided under Andhra Pradesh service rules. The age limit of candidates under direct recruitment should not be above 35 years.

When it comes to the judicial officers by way of transfer should be below the age of 48 years and the retired judicial officers should be under the age of 68 years.

All appointments for the posts will be made by government in consultation with the high court. All postings and transfer orders of grama nyayadhikaris will be made by the high court.

Every grama nyayalayam will have a grama nyayadhikari, one superintendent, one stenographer, one junior assistant and one office subordinate.

All appointments made on ad-hoc basis shall deemed to come to an end on framing regular rules under the Gram Nyayalayas Act, 2008.

Title: SCERT‚Äôs silver jubilee fete today
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: General education minister C Raveendranath will inaugurate the silver jubilee celebrations of the State Council for Educational Research and Training (SCERT) here on Wednesday.

‚ÄúThe celebrations will showcase the contributions of the council to the school-education sector over the past several years. The council is committed to enhance the quality of general education from pre-school to higher secondary. The ongoing public education rejuvenation mission has brought about sweeping and promising changes in the sector. The renewed interest that public now shows towards government schools would give further impetus to the activities of SCERT,‚Äù council director J Prasad told reporters on Monday.

The council, Prasad said, has started taking steps to address widespread complaints against the continuous and comprehensive evaluation (CCE) taking place in public schools.

‚ÄúWe have started taking solid measures to ensure that students really undergo continuous and comprehensive evaluation. Ernest efforts by teachers are pivotal. The effective rollout of CEE has started in lower classes. Assessment in higher classes would infallibly improve over the course of time,‚Äù he said.

According to Prasad, SCERT will start a teacher-transformation course that would improve the skillsets and knowledge base of teachers who mould the lives of lakhs of students. The course will be of six months‚Äô duration.

Cooperation and tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran will launch the course during the silver jubilee celebrations. An exhibition of academic materials developed by SCERT over the last 25 years is being organised at the SCERT headquarters here.

Title: Rapid response teams to track movement of Italian tourists in state
Content: JAIPUR: After holding video conferencing with officials of ministry of health and family welfare on coronavirus on Tuesday, additional chief secretary (health) Rohit Kumar Singh issued directions to principal and controller of all government-run medical colleges to constitute rapid response teams (RRTs) to support the health department in fight against coronavirus (Covid-19).One of the members of the Italian group has already been tested positive for Covid-19. His wife has also been diagnosed with Covid-19 at SMS Hospital. The group reached Mandawa of Jhunjhunu on February 21 and then they visited places in Jaisalmer, Barmer, Jodhpur and Udaipur before reaching Jaipur on February 28.The RRTs will do listing of cases and those in contact with them and their mapping. Singh said that RRT will be comprised of senior professors in Preventative and Social Medicine (PSM), medicine, microbiology, paediatrics and epidemiologist of Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme.‚ÄúThe teams have been assigned the job of inspecting tourist places, hotels and other places visited by a group of 23 Italian tourists who came to Rajasthan on February 21,‚Äù said Singh.The nodal officer of the RRT will be senior professor of PSM department. The team will identify hotel staff who came in contact with the Italian group and if necessary the RRT will recommend for coronavirus test. The senior professors of medicines and paediatrics of RRT will clinical examining those people including hotel staff to find out if they are clinically fit and do not have any symptom of Covid-19.

Title: Puri admin launches beggar rehab process
Content:
Bhubaneswar: The Puri administration on Tuesday started rehabilitating beggars from the pilgrim town. In the first phase, as many as 500 beggars have been sent to shelter homes called Niladri Nilaya from where they will be rehabilitated and efforts will be made to bring them back to the mainstream.

‚ÄúSix Niladri Nilayas have been opened in the town, each with a capacity to accommodate 50 people. They will be provided free food and shelter. The mental and physical health of these people will be checked and after assessing their conditions, the next course of action will be taken,‚Äù said Prasanna Kumar Patra, an officer with the Puri municipality.

Official sources said many of these beggars are from outside the state, while some are physically and mentally challenged and have been abandoned by their family members in Puri. There are also leprosy patients and drug-addicted people.

‚ÄúBegging is a complex thing. Many people are into begging due to circumstances, many after losing their mental balance while there are some who do it for their love for Lord Jagannath. So we have to first segregate them into different categories like elderly, physically and mentally challenged. We have been asked not to use force on anyone and counsel them to quit begging,‚Äù said Patra.

For those from outside the state, the district administration is trying to find their identity and address so they could be sent back to their families. There are also plans to provide them skill training as per their abilities so that they can be brought back to the mainstream. ‚ÄúBut this will take time,‚Äù admitted one official source.

The state has as many as 5,950 full-time beggars with the highest (1060) in Cuttack district, followed by 545 in Ganjam, 485 in Mayurbhanj, 423 in Sundargarh, 366 in Puri, 344 in Balangir and only three in Deogarh, social security and empowerment of persons with disability (SSEPD) minister Ashok Chandra Panda had informed in the assembly.

Title: Farmer seeks compensation as Gir cow gives less milk
Content:
Vadodara: The district consumer disputes redressal forum was left in a quandary when they had to come face to face with a miffed farmer and his Gir cow! The court had to decide if the cow‚Äôs owner can be considered to be a consumer or not.

The court made a swift and technical verdict: Turning down the farmer‚Äôs case, it upheld that the case was untenable as he had purchased a live animal and not an inanimate product or taken any service!

As the case details have it, Dabhoi farmer, Fulji Patanwadiya filed a case in the consumer court demanding Rs 32,000 to be paid to him for a Gir cow he had purchased from Naran Rabari was not ‚Äòmilking‚Äô as claimed. According to Patanwadiya‚Äôs complaint filed in December 2016, Rabari, a cattle-rearer from Dabhoi, had claimed that the cow gives 7 litres of milk daily and is also lactating.

Not only relying on Rabari‚Äôs claim, Patanwadiya got it inspected by a familiar cattle inspector, and then paid Rs 32,000 on August 10, 2016 to Rabari and took the cow home with him. However, a few days later, Patanwadiya‚Äôs noticed that the cow gives only three litres of milk in a day. he also found out that the cow was also not lactating as told. The expenses he incurred in its maintenance and fodder was higher than the money he could earn by selling three litres of milk, he alleged.

Patanwadiya then sought his money back from Rabari asking him to take his cow back. But Rabari refused. Aggrieved, Patanwadiya approached the court to intervene so that he can get back Rs 32,000 along with 18% interest and compensation worth Rs 40,000.

Taking cognizance of Patanwadiya‚Äôs complaint, the court issued notice to Rabari who appeared for himself and even filed a reply to Patanwadiya‚Äôs notice. Rabari told the court that Patanwadiya had purchased the cow after getting it properly checked by a cattle inspector known to him and so, the complaint filed against him is false.

After hearing the two sides, the court concluded that Patanwadiya does not come under the definition of a consumer as per the Consumer Protection Act.

‚ÄúSince the forum does not have authority to hear the matter as the complainant is not a consumer, it is proper to cancel the case,‚Äù the forum stated.

Title: Minor boy dies in crossfire as two goons open fire
Content:
Representative image

MEERUT: A 17-year-old boy who was having lunch at a wedding was caught in the crossfire between two goons and died when a bullet hit him on the head on Tuesday.

According to police, the victim, identified as Pankaj, was having lunch in a wedding at Rachoti village in Mundali area here when a fight broke out between the two goons -- Monu and Devendra. The two men opened fire at each other in the wedding venue. The guests were taken completely off guard as bullets whizzed past them. One of the bullets hit Pankaj on the head and he died on the spot before the terror-stricken guests.

While Pankaj lay dead on the spot, Monu sustained bullet injuries. Devendra fled the spot, police said. ‚ÄúEfforts are being made to arrest Devendra who still at large,‚Äù said Avinash Pandey, superintendent of police (rural areas).

According to sources, Monu and Devendra were once thick as thieves. Later, they had a bitter fallout. When the duo spotted each other at the wedding venue, their old animosity was reignited. As they started shooting at each other, most of the guests ran for cover, said a witness. Pankaj, however, failed to take cover and was hit.

Police are yet to ascertain whose bullet hit Pankaj. Police have already registered an FIR and efforts are being made to arrest Devendra. "Several police teams have been pressed in service to find Devendra who fled after the shootout,‚Äù added Pandey.

Title: Rajasthan government‚Äôs cluster containment strategy to curb coronavirus
Content: JAIPUR: The state government has chalked out a strategy to contain coronavirus after Rajasthan reported its first case on Monday. It has formulated a cluster containment plan to ward off risk of spreading of Covid-19. The objective of cluster containment is to stop transmission, morbidity and mortality due to the virus.The cluster containment strategy would be to contain the disease with in a defined geographic area by early detection, breaking the chain of transmission and thus preventing its spread to new areas. This would include geographic quarantine, social distancing measures, enhanced active surveillance, testing all suspected cases, isolation of cases, home quarantine of contacts, social mobilization to follow preventive public health measures.‚ÄúIf an area reports a Covid-19 case, then the containment will be the radius of three kilometre. If more cases are reported from the area, then it will be expanded to 5km,‚Äù said DB Gupta, chief secretary, state government after holding a meeting with health department officials on Tuesday.The health department will conduct active surveillance in containment zone with contact tracing within and outside the containment zone. Apart from implementing social distancing measures, the health department will establish surge capacities for isolating all suspects/confirmed cases for medical care.Moreover, there will be a check on outward movement of population from the containment zone except for maintaining essential services (including medical emergencies) and government business continuity. It will also limit unchecked influx of population into the containment zone, said a health department official.The authorities at these entry points will be required to inform the people entering about precautions to be taken and will also provide them with an information pamphlet and mask.Health workers posted at the exit point will perform screening, measure temperature, record the place and duration of intended visit and keep complete record of intended place of stay).

Title: Andhra Pradesh to move resolution opposing NRC in the next assembly session
Content:
Y S Jaganmohan Reddy

AMARAVATI: The state government has decided to move a resolution opposing the National Register of Citizens (NRC) in the next assembly session.

The government will also move another resolution seeking the Centre to revert to the 2010 model of National Population Register ( NPR ).

Chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy took the decision on Tuesday after holding discussions with the minority legislators and religious leaders. Soon after the meeting, chief minister tweeted that some of the questions proposed in the NPR are causing insecurities in the minds of minorities in the state.

‚ÄúAfter elaborate consultations within our party, we have decided to request the Central government revert to the conditions that prevailed in 2010 NPR,‚Äù said Jagan. He had also said that they would be introducing a resolution to this effect in the coming assembly session.

Speaking to the media after the review with the CM, deputy chief minister SB Amzath Basha said that the government was fully committed to protect the interests of the minorities in the state. He said that chief minister had assured them not to worry about the NPR and NRC as long as YSRC in power.

He said that they would be moving separate resolutions in the coming assembly session to oppose the NRC and conditions laid down in the new NPR.

Kurnool legislator Hafeez Khan said that following 2010 model NPR would not cause any apprehensions among the minorities.

‚ÄúSeveral questions included in the latest version of NPR created lot of panic among the minorities. Questions about parents and their birth place were main cause of worry among the minorities. The Since chief minister had assured them to ask the Centre to go back to the 2010 model, it would not be big issue now,‚Äù said Khan.

Minority legislators have also expressed satisfaction about the chief minister Jagan‚Äôs commitment to implement the four percent reservations to the minorities. They said that CM had personally monitored the issue before the case came up for hearing in Supreme Court on Tuesday. ‚ÄúThe SC adjourned the case to March 2021. The reservations will continue till the SC takes a call,‚Äù said Khan.

Title: Quack held after man dies due to injection in Jaisalmer
Content:
Representative image

JAISALMER: A man died on Monday after wrong injection was administered to him by a quack at Khuiyala village in Jaisalmer. A team led by Jaisalmer deputy SP arrested the quack and produced him before the court.

‚ÄúPurnaram, a resident of Khuiyala village, gave a written report at Ramgarh police station that his cousin Mehranram (28) was sick and quack Vivek Kumar Yadav administered wrong injection after which his cousin fell unconscious. He was taken to Poonamnagar CHC where his blood pressure was checked and he was referred to Jaisalmer where doctors declared him dead,‚Äù SP Kiran Kung said.

He said that he suspects his cousin died due to the wrong injection.

Title: UP: Ahead of Holi, FSDA seizes 35 tons of ghee, 106 tons oil
Content:
BAREILLY: The Food Safety and Drugs Authority (FSDA) officials on Tuesday seized 35 tons of ghee worth Rs 2.67 lakh from Alamgiriganj and Basmandi localities after they suspected them to be adulterated.

The seizure came during an ongoing drive against adulterated products ahead of Holi.

According to officials, a team of FSDA seized 15 tons of ghee worth Rs 1.43 lakh from one shop in Basmandi and sent one sample to a laboratory for testing.

The team later seized another 15 tons of ghee worth Rs 97,066 from one shop and 5 tons of ghee worth Rs 27,140 from another shop in Alamgiriganj and sent samples for the laboratory test.

Apart from that, the FDSA officials also seized 106 tons of mustard oil worth Rs 1.58 lakh and 28 tons of soya refined oil worth Rs 42,000 on the suspicion of it being adulterated.

The team also seized 150 packets of sweet priced at Rs 9,000 and 110 packets of munakka costing Rs 72,000.

Officials said they collected samples of mawa, chena, kachri, paneer and besan from a few shops in different parts of the district for the laboratory test.

Designated officer, FSDA, Dharamraj Mishra, said, ‚ÄúThe drive against adulterated food or drinks will continue till Holi across the district.‚Äù

Title: Pune: Woman goes to cops & says she killed live-in partner
Content: PUNE: A 25-year-old woman walked into the Sinhagad Road police station in the wee hours of Tuesday and told the on-duty policemen that she had killed her childhood friend in a rented flat at Narhe over their strained live-in relationship.Police said the woman told the officers that she had slit her 26-year-old partner‚Äôs throat with a surgical knife while he was asleep because he was not maintaining proper conjugal relationship despite their ‚Äúmarriage‚Äù at Alandi in August last year.Senior inspector Nandkishor Shelke, sub-inspector Sudhir Ghadge and their team rushed to Narhe and found the victim lying dead in the third-floor flat of the building. They recovered the murder weapon from the site.The man was murdered sometime between 1am and 4am on Tuesday. Later, the woman was arrested for the murder.Ghadge said, ‚ÄúThe woman told police that after committing the murder, she tried to end her life by hanging herself from a ceiling fan in the flat using an ‚Äòodhani (a shawl-like scarf)‚Äô, but changed her mind because of her pregnancy and, instead, decided to approach the police. We have recovered the ‚Äòodhani‚Äô, hanging from the ceiling fan, from the spot.‚ÄùHe said, ‚ÄúOur preliminary investigation has revealed that in June last year, the woman (a medical support staffer with a city hospital) had lodged a rape complaint against the deceased and the case was due for hearing on Tuesday before a city court. For the past couple of months, the man was pursuing her to withdraw the rape complaint and even threatened her on multiple occasions.‚ÄùGhadge said, ‚ÄúIn view of the court hearing on Tuesday, the man came to the city from his native place Jat in Sangli on Monday night thinking that the woman will withdraw her complaint. He went to her flat, where both had an argument before going to sleep. Sometime later, the woman woke up and slit the victim‚Äôs throat using the surgical knife.‚ÄùHe said, ‚ÄúIn May last year, the victim went to his native place for attending his brother‚Äôs wedding. One of the woman‚Äôs friends in Jat told her that the victim had got married. Disturbed over this piece of information, the woman lodged an FIR of rape with the Sinhagad Road police in June last year.‚ÄùGhadge said, ‚ÄúThe victim was arrested in the rape case earlier, but the woman had furnished his bail. So, he was out on bail.‚Äù

Title: Udaipur gang-rape: Survivor‚Äôs male friend was sodomised
Content:
Udaipur: The male friend accompanying the 24-year-old woman, who was allegedly gang-raped in Udaipur on Sunday night, was sexually assaulted too. No arrest has been made in the case so far.

‚ÄúFive accused, identified as Fardeen, Chota Mewati, Moin, Shahrukh and Pradeep, have been named in the FIR,‚Äù police said. Teams have been fanned out to Ajmer and Bhilwara in search of the accused who had allegedly abducted, looted and raped the woman and sodomised her male friend on the outskirts of Udaipur. Though the police didn‚Äôt inform the media about the unnatural sex committed by the gang, an FIR has been registered under IPC sections 376D (gang rape) and 377 (unnatural sex) besides sections 323,341, 365,366,394 and provisions of the IT Act.

Both the victims worked in an event management company. The gang allegedly made video clips of the incident and made extortion calls to the owner of the company, said police. The men tortured the duo the entire night when their boss did not fulfil the ransom demand and dumped them at Thokar Chauraha on Monday morning. On Tuesday, the rape survivor‚Äôs statement was recorded before a magistrate where she stated that two men had raped her on a railway track in Debari. ‚ÄúThe rape survivor and her male friend were taken to different locations to identify the the spots where they were taken by the gang. Through our technical system, we have identified all the accused,‚Äù Udaipur SP Kailash Chandra Bishnoi said. tnn

Title: Bijnor man kills 8-yr-old adopted sister, arrested
Content:
Representative image

A 19-year-old youth, who allegedly slit the throat of his eight-year-old adopted sister while his family was out, was arrested in Kiratpur town in Bijnor on Tuesday.

Lakshmi Nivas Mishra, SP (city) said, the child‚Äôs mother informed police on Monday night that someone had killed her. Police grilled family members and finally, the accused admitted to killing the girl as she had caught him stealing in the house and raised an alarm. The youth is a drug addict.

The boy‚Äôs mother learnt of the truth and in order to save her son, informed police that unidentified people had killed the girl, the SP added.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Sample sent in cargo to NIV as Jaipur airport raises alarm
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: The blood sample of Italian national, which was sent to National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune, was stuck in security check at Jaipur airport on Monday night.

A health department official was carrying the sample in a box packed properly but he was stopped at the security check. ‚ÄúThey did not allow the official to carry the box with him as a luggage in a Pune-bound flight. So, the sample was not sent on Monday night,‚Äù said a health department official.

At the box of the sample, it was written highly infectious, which caused panic at the security check. The flight was scheduled at 10pm.

The official returned back from airport in the night. However, the health authorities send him again to Jaipur airport on Tuesday morning claiming that the sample has to be sent to NIV, Pune urgently. The airport authorities agreed to send the samples in cargo, said officials.

However, the sample reached Pune on time and the NIV issued the report on the same day. The patient tested positive for the disease, said SMS medical college officials.

Title: UP: Couple commits suicide after families oppose their relationship
Content:
Representative image

BAREILLY: A young couple committed suicide by consuming poison on Tuesday morning in their respective houses after their families opposed their relationship in Roza area of Shahjahanpur district.

According to the police, the girl was 19-year-old while her lover was 24-year-old. Both belonged to the same community. The couple was in a relationship for the past two years.

According to sources, Ramniwas, a resident of ITI colony in Roza, used to work in Roza mart as a labourer. He was in a relationship with his brother‚Äôs sister-in-law, who lived in the same locality.

However, his family members wanted him to marry elsewhere as they didn‚Äôt want to marry both the sons in the same family. The couple tried hard to convince their families, but couldn‚Äôt find any success. Meanwhile, Ramniwas‚Äôs parents had started searching for alliances for him.

On Monday night, Ramniwas reportedly met the girl and came back home. Later, he went to sleep without having dinner and on Tuesday morning, he was found dead. Similarly, the girl was also found dead in her house.

After getting information about the incident, police arrived and tried to seize the bodies, but both the families refused to give the bodies for autopsy.

Forensic experts also arrived to ensure that there was no foul play. Later, the bodies were sent for autopsy after a local representative mediated between the police and the aggrieved families.

Roza police station Station house officer Ashok Pal said, ‚ÄúIt seems to be a clear case of suicide. The family members of the couple refrained from saying anything about their children‚Äôs death, but the residents told us that both the deceased were in a relationship and wanted to marry each other. We have sent the bodies for autopsy and waiting for the report.‚Äù

Notably, since 2017, nearly 48 couples have committed suicide in Bareilly after their families refused to solemnise their marriage.

Title: Rampur court rejects bail pleas of Azam Khan and family
Content:
Azam Khan

RAMPUR: A local court in Rampur on Tuesday rejected the bail pleas of Samajwadi Party MP Azam Khan , his wife Tazeen Fatma and son Abdullah Azam in connection with a forgery case.

Azam Khan and his family members will remain in Sitapur jail under the judicial custody till March 20.

Senior Samajwadi Party (SP) leader and Rampur MP Azam Khan, his wife Tanzeen Fatimah and son Abdullah Azam were sent to judicial custody of six days on February 26 after the trio surrendered before the court in Rampur in a case involving the alleged forging of Abdullah‚Äôs birth certificate.

The accused were booked under sections 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property), 467 (forgery of valuable security, will), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating) and 471 (using as genuine a forged document) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

Abdullah allegedly submitted incorrect date of birth certificate while filing his nomination papers for the assembly election. Following a high court order, he lost his membership of the state assembly last December after he was found guilty of forgery.

Meanwhile, police have sought 10 days custody of Azam Khan and his family in a case registered against them for allegedly forging documents to acquire land for his Mohammad Ali Jauhar University .

The investigating officer, sub-inspector Suresh Veer Singh , informed Additional District and Sessions Judge Dhirendra Kumar Kamboj that the accused persons are not cooperating with the investigation.

The court has fixed March 7 for the next hearing.

District government counsel Dalwinder Singh claimed that during the preliminary investigation it was found that Azam had forged documents to acquire a land falling under the Enemy Property Act.

The Enemy Property Act, 1968 is an Act of the Parliament, which enables and regulates the appropriation of property in India owned by Pakistani nationals. The ownership in such cases is passed to the Custodian for Enemy Property, usually a government department.

Title: PMC squad razes eateries, removes encroachments on JM & FC Roads
Content:
Several personnel from the department, policemen, an earth mover and several trucks were part of the drive.

PUNE: As many as 15 to 20 establishments came under the anti-encroachment drive conducted by the Pune Municipal Corporation ( PMC ) on Jangli Maharaj Road and Fergusson College Road on Tuesday.

Several personnel from the department, policemen, an earth mover and several trucks were part of the drive. According to Rajesh Ingole from the department, the squad walked on both the roads to pull down encroachments.

‚ÄúBanners, standees and other advertisement material displayed in the front margins of stores were confiscated. Illegal constructions along the side margins and front margins of buildings were razed. Several eateries running in temporary structures in the side margins were brought down. Stalls encroaching upon footpaths were removed and the material confiscated,‚Äù Ingole said.

An employee of an eatery that was brought down on Jangli Maharaj Road said, ‚ÄúThe PMC often razes temporary sheds that are built to cover the eatery. They confiscate the tarpaulin and bring down the bamboo structure.‚Äù

Ingole said the front and side margins of buildings are meant for parking. But, they are occupied illegally at many spots along both the arterial roads.

‚ÄúSome complaints have been received regarding the illegal structures as well. So, we decided to conduct a drive across both roads,‚Äù Ingole said.

Eateries are up and running soon after such drives raising questions about the effectiveness. On sighting the squad, encroachers along the roads and footpaths moved their wares to avoid action. Stalls encroaching upon the footpaths close to Garware bridge on JM Road removed temporary sheds and moved back to prevent losses.

No action is taken against the building owners for permitting encroachments on the side margins, Ingole said. Owners of the confiscated material can get their belongings back after paying the fine.

Title: Bundi schoolteacher held for molestation
Content:
Representative image

KOTA: A 40-year-old government schoolteacher was on Tuesday evening arrested for allegedly molesting and misbehaving with two minor girl students at a school in Chardana village under Kapren police station of Bundi district.

The accused, identified as Sadanand Meena (40), a resident of Adeela village of the district who teaches history at a school in Chardana village allegedly molested and misbehaved with two girl students of the school last week, following which the girls reported the matter to their parents, who along with other villagers locked the school gate on Monday, demanding arrest of the accused teacher.

On the report by the girls‚Äô parents, the accused Meena was on Monday booked under Section 354 of IPC and Section 9,10 of the Pocso Act, for allegedly molesting and misbehaving with the girls, SHO at Kapren police station Budhiprakesh Nama said.

The accused teacher had been molesting and misbehaving with them for past some time now, the girls have alleged in the report, he added. Meena, following investigation, was on Tuesday evening arrested and would be produced before the court on Wednesday, the SHO said.

The accused teaches history and was sent to Awaiting Posting Orders (APO) , said the ASI of the police station.

Title: MP constable booked for raping girl in Jhalawar
Content:
Representative image

KOTA: A Madhya Pradesh police constable, posted at Mayana police station of Guna district, was on Monday evening booked for repeatedly raping a 20-year-old girl of Devlikhurd village under Kamkheda police station of Jhalawar district on pretext of marriage.

The accused has been identified as Ramhet Lodha, a resident of Guna in Madhya Pradesh.

An investigation into the case has been launched. Kamkheda police station SHO Madan Lal said the girl lodged a case against Lodha on Monday evening for repeatedly raping her.

The accused was recruited as constable in Madhya Pradesh police a few months ago and was posted at Mayana police station of Guna district, he added.

The rape survivor in the report stated that she was engaged with the accused around two years ago following that, she alleged, he started visiting her house and established physical relations with her, the SHO said.

Lal said, the accused was recruited as constable in MP police and following his recruitment, he started raising higher demands for dowry that included a four-wheeler and eventually refused to marry.

The rape survivor was on Tuesday sent for medical examination, however, her statements under section 164 before the magistrate are yet to be recorded, he said.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Duo lived together from 2016
Content:
Pune: Police said the woman and the victim grew together as childhood friends and they both hailed from Jat in Sangli district.

They started living together from 2016 after coming to the city, where the man took up an executive job with a private firm and the woman joined the hospital.

‚ÄúWhile staying together, they decided to get married, but the victim‚Äôs parents were opposed to it as their families belonged to different castes,‚Äù sub-inspector Sudhir Ghadge of the Sinhagad Road police said.

He said, ‚ÄúThe woman told the police that after she lodged the rape complaint against the victim in June last year, she came to know from a common friend that he had shifted to Chennai, but she managed to get his cellphone number. She told the police that he then came to Pune and they got married privately at Alandi on August 5 last year. Then the man left Pune and stopped answering her calls.‚Äù

He said, ‚ÄúThe woman then visited his home at Jat, but his parents and relatives threw her out of their residence. A couple of months ago, the man called and threatened her with dire consequences while insisting that she should withdraw her rape complaint against him.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe woman told the police that he made a few threatening calls, which made her apprehensive about his intent to cause her physical harm and this prompted her to buy a surgical knife for self-protection,‚Äù he added.

Title: Two rare species of wildlife spotted in Pilibhit Tiger Reserve
Content:
Coral red kurki snake was sighted in Haripur range

PILIBHIT: Two rare species of wildlife ‚Äì Rusty spotted cat and Coral red kurki snake-- were spotted by chance in Pilibhit Tiger Reserve (PTR) by field director H Rajamohan while passing through the forest area during routine monitoring.

The Rusty spotted cat, the smallest member of the cat family, was spotted in Mala range while the Coral red kurki snake was sighted in Haripur range, said Rajamohan.

In 2018, the snake was spotted in Sonaripur forest range of Dudhwa Tiger Reserve.

The Rusty spotted cat is classified as ‚Äúnear threatened‚Äù in the Red list of the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). The field director has ordered forest personnel to collect all possible details about this tiny cat in PTR so that a conservation plan for this rare species is worked out.

Citing wildlife reports, he said, this cat is nocturnal by nature. It is just 35 to 45 cm in length and weighs about 1.5 kg. Its survival is being threatened due to the loss of its habitat. Its first picture was captured 10 years ago by the camera traps installed in PTR for the tiger census. But the cat not seen again since then.

‚ÄúNow, it has been spotted after a decade. It needs to be conserved because it is listed in schedule I of the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972. This little carnivore survives on insects, birds and rodents,‚Äù Rajamohan added.

Till date, the Coral red kurki, he said, was seen in DTR and in Chitwan National Park in Nepal that has contiguity with the Valmiki Tiger Reserve in Bihar.

‚ÄúLike Rusty spotted cat, this snake is also nocturnal in nature and normally preys on earthworms and larvae. Its innate characteristic is to remain underground most of the time. It is rarely seen on the ground in day hours,‚Äù Rajamohan said. The Coral red kurki is listed in schedule IV of the Wildlife Protection Act.

Title: Summer holiday bookings dip 35% due to Covid-19 scare
Content: VADODARA: Rajiv Patel, a city-based art connoisseur, was all set to leave for the US and spend some time with his friends this summers.But the COVID-19 (coronovirus) scare compelled him to change his plans. ‚ÄúI have postponed my tour due to the travel advisory and may visit Los Angeles later this year,‚Äù Patel said.Patel isn‚Äôt the only one whose holiday plan was sabotaged, in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak. According to estimates by tour operators, at least 35% of bookings to destinations in the far eastern countries have already been cancelled, after the news about widespread outbreak of coronavirus infections appeared.‚ÄúAt least 35% of the ticket bookings for holidays in the far east for travel scheduled in April, have already been cancelled. On the other hand, some are still in wait and watch mode and waiting for a revised notification from these countries about the epidemic situation,‚Äù said Anuj Pathak, secretary, Tour Operators and Travel Agents‚Äô Association of Gujarat (TAG).‚ÄúEven routes such as Dubai, and by extension UAE, have also got affected,‚Äù he added. A travel agent from the city said that his business too got severely affected as an auto show in Berlin got cancelled due to Coronavirus and it led to cancellation of travelling plans of many Barodians.‚ÄúI had made travel plans to Europe in May to escape the summer heat here. But the COVID-19 outbreak has put break on my plans. I may now consider some other destination,‚Äù said Ananda Joshi, an HR professional.‚ÄúSeveral inquiries are now about destinations such as Almaty, Prague, Vienna, and Budapest, among others in eastern Europe including Russia due to cheaper airfare and hotels. This season, we have cancelled about 35 per cent of overall bookings,‚Äù said Manish Sharma, secretary of TAFI‚Äôs Gujarat chapter.

Title: Pune: 60% staffers out of biometric attendance system, civic body plans to cover them all
Content:
The PMC has decided to expand the biometric attendance system to cover all the 15 ward offices in six months.

PUNE: Nearly 60% employees of the Pune Municipal Corporation are not covered under the biometric attendance system as they did not register for it.

After the introduction of the five-day-week system from Monday, the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has decided to expand the biometric attendance system to cover all the 15 ward offices in six months. The tendering process for procurement and installation of machines will be done in a week.

‚ÄúOnce the tenders process is completed, the remaining machines will be fitted. The staffers not registered with this system will be added to it,‚Äù said Shriniwas Kandul , the head of the civic electricity department.

He said some of the ward offices implemented the project on a pilot basis. These ward offices, along with the others, would be equipped with biometric attendance machines. The staffers would be monitored as per to the new timetable that came into effect from Monday, he said.

One of the operators of the biometric attendance system said, ‚ÄúIt is an online system and the attendance is monitored through a software. Its access is given to the heads of the respective departments. Datasheets of arrival and departure timings are generated through this system. This data is used for paying salaries to the staffers. Some updates in the system software are due to make it foolproof.‚Äù

As per contractors, nearly 160 machines were given to the PMC two years ago. Some of them are not functioning now due to technical glitches and are being repaired. The machines would be upgraded and additional gadgets would be installed.

The civic administration had started a project to launch Aadhaar-based biometric system after a man was caught posing as a PMC employee. The system was aimed at doing real-time monitoring and was integrated through text-based communication channel.

Title: Italian in Jaipur confirmed virus +ve; now, wife infected
Content: JAIPUR: The Italian tourist who had tested positive for the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) at a Jaipur hospital on Monday was confirmed virus-positive on Tuesday by the National Institute of Virology, Pune which examined his throat swabs and blood samples. His wife, meanwhile, also tested positive in screening at Jaipur‚Äôs Sawai Man Singh (SMS) Hospital on Tuesday.Health authorities in Rajasthan are now worried that the 69-year-old Italian national and his wife might have put a lot of people at risk because he visited major tourist destinations in the state as part of a group of 23 tourists from Italy.‚ÄúWe are sending her samples to Pune,‚Äù the SMS Hospital superintendent, Dr D S Meena, said. Since her husband had fallen ill, she had stayed back in Jaipur while their group of Italian tourists went on to Agra. ‚ÄúWe have admitted her to the isolation facility,‚Äù said SMS Medical College principal Dr Sudhir Bhandari.

Title: Bhagasara bags max votes in Youth Congress polls
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Sumit Bhagasara got the highest number of votes for the president‚Äôs post in the Rajasthan Youth Congress elections held on Tuesday.

He bagged as many as 46,304 out of 1,13,877 of total votes polled. However, the official announcement will be made only on March 9, said chief spokesman of the state Youth Congress Ayush Bharadwaj . His close rival Mukesh Bhakar secured 30,349 votes and Amardin Fakir got 16,720 votes. They will share the post of vice president.

Bhagasara has earlier served as the state president of the National Students Union of India .

Title: Jaipur: BJP zeroes in on 5 names for Rajya Sabha elections
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: BJP is brainstorming to zero in on a Rajya Sabha (RS) candidate that can give maximum political mileage to the party in the state. The saffron party has discussed five probable names prominently pushed by different pressure groups like RSS and former chief minister Vasundhara Raje in its first round of talks ahead of the polls scheduled this month.

Elections for three RS seats from the state will be held on March 26. The outgoing RS members on these three seats are from the BJP whose term will be ending in April 2020 are ‚Äì Narayan Lal Panchariya, Ramnarayan Dudi and Vijay Goel.

The state has 10 RS seats in a total of 245 seats in the upper house. Since BJP has lost the assembly polls in the state with 79 MLAs in its kitty, BJP will able to retain one seat out of three. The names making rounds are former state presidents‚ÄîAshok Parnami and Arun Chaturvedi. Other names include former Jhotwara MLA Rajpal Singh Shekhawat , former minister Prabhu Lal Saini and former Nagaur MP CR Chaudhary.

‚ÄúThe discussion is in the initial stage and names which come to the fore have been floated from the different power centres in the party. It is true that the final decision would be taken by the party high command but the recommendation from the state will be highly considered,‚Äù said a party source. It is also reported that BJP state president Satish Poonia had discussed the names with the RSS leaders and the latter has showed agreement that state leader would strengthen party more than any outsider.

Title: Woman, lover arrested for killing her ex-boyfriend in Bareilly
Content:
Representative image

BAREILLY: A girl and her beau were arrested on Tuesday for allegedly killing a 28-year-old man, whose charged body was recovered near Kumar cinema hall in the heart of Bareilly city on Monday.

Bareilly SSP Shailesh Pandey had announced a cash reward of Rs 15,000 to solve the case within 24 hours.

According to police, victim Yogesh Saxena was killed because his girlfriend Uma Shukla wanted to get rid of him and marry Sunil Sharma, who is a storekeeper at IVRI Bareilly on contractual basis.

Uma, who was living separately after she filed a dowry case against her husband in 2014, was in a relationship with Yogesh for the past eight years.

Uma wanted to marry Yogesh, but he told her that her elder sister was unmarried and asked her to wait.

‚ÄúUma wanted to get rid of Yogesh and asked him to come to an abandoned area near his shop at 9.30 pm on Sunday where Sunil was waiting. Sunil sprayed red chilli powder in his eyes and slit his throat with a sharp knife. Thereafter, Sunil left the place and met Uma outside a private hospital. Later, both of them came back to the murder spot to ensure that Yogesh was dead. They then burned the body with petrol,‚Äù Pandey said.

He added, ‚ÄúAdditional SP (crime) RK Bhartiya, along with SHO Kotwali Geetesh Kapil, and their teams did a remarkable job solving the case within 24 hours. We have also added section 201 (causing disappearance of evidence) under the Indian Penal Code against the accused because they attempted to dump the dead body by burning it.‚Äù

Title: Woman beats up doc after child‚Äôs death
Content:
Sambalpur: Tension gripped Veer Surendra Sai Institute of Medical Sciences and Research ( VIMSAR ), Burla, after a 15-year-old girl, who was admitted to the Central Intensive Care Unit (ICU) of the hospital died on Tuesday.

The girl‚Äôs mother allegedly manhandled the PG student, Ananta Narayan Patra, who was in the ICU, following the girl‚Äôs death. The superintendent of VIMSAR lodged a complaint with Burla police in connection with the incident.

According to reports, Shabina, 45, brought her daughter, Saheen, who was diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease to VIMSAR after she was referred from IGH, Rourkela on February 29. Farheen was admitted to the ICU after her condition deteriorated on Sunday.

On Tuesday morning, the PG student, who was in-charge of the ICU, Ananta Narayan Patra informed the patient‚Äôs mother that the heart of Saheen had stopped working and they are doing cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) to revive the patient. But after sometime, Patra informed Parveen that her daughter has died. Saheen allegedly confronted the doctor and assaulted him.

‚ÄúA case has been registered and further investigation is on,‚Äù said IIC, Burla police station, Bibhuti Bhoi.

Title: Wife, crew of cargo vessel in Cuttack hospital over coronavirus fear
Content:
Representative image

BHUBANESWAR/KENDRAPADA: The crew member of a cargo ship and his wife, both Indian nationals, were admitted to the isolation ward of SCB Medical College and Hospital in Cuttack on Tuesday for the suspected novel coronavirus (COVID-19) after they showed symptoms of mild fever.

The ship ‚ÄúChemstar Stellar,‚Äù a chemical tanker sailing under the Panama flag and carrying 24 crew members and their families reached the Paradip coast on March 1. They were quarantined as the the ship had touched Zhapu in China (February 8), Onsan in South Korea (February 12) and Singapore (February 24) during its journey.

‚ÄúSince the couple showed symptoms of fever, they have been moved to the isolation facility in Cuttack from Paradip on Tuesday while others on board remain in the vessel and will be under observation,‚Äù said Ashok Paikray, state surveillance officer.

Hospital authorities said the condition of the couple is stable. ‚ÄúThey are being treated for their symptoms. The couple‚Äôs blood and throat swab samples have been collected. These will be sent to National Institute of Virology, Pune, by the Regional Medical Research Centre (RMRC) in Bhubaneswar for further tests to rule out COVID-19. They will be here till their test results come in the next three to four days. Future course of action will depend on the test results,‚Äù said Bhubanananda Maharana, emergency officer at SCB.

Paradip Port Trust (PPT) authorities said there is no impact on cargo handling at the port because of the development. ‚ÄúThe ship was allowed to anchor at the port to unload 20,000 metric tonne of sulphuric acid. On berthing, the health officials boarded the vessel and examined all the crew members as per protocol. As a precautionary measure, no crew member is allowed shore access because of the vessel‚Äôs travel history. However, there is no impact on the development of cargo handling work in the port,‚Äù said Rinkesh Roy, chairman of PPT.

Daily update of health status of crew has been made mandatory for all the vessels during their stay in Paradip. ‚ÄúPeople of Paradip are being made aware about the symptoms and preventive measures, through messages displayed on big electronic boards in the township,‚Äù Roy added.

The state government on Tuesday decided to increase vigil on possible cases. ‚ÄúThe director of medical education and training have been asked to keep close watch on the situation. While there is no reason for people to panic, the government is focusing on greater awareness and stricter vigil,‚Äù health minister Naba Kishore Das said.

Title: Decent pay hike for teachers likely: Bihar deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi
Content:
Sushil Kumar Modi

PATNA: Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi on Tuesday said the state government would soon make a ‚Äúrespectable‚Äù increase in the salary of around 4 lakh contractual (Niyojit) teachers, who are on strike for the past 16 days demanding pay parity with regular teachers.

‚ÄúIt was the NDA government, which had earlier increased their salary, and again we will make a respectable increase in their emoluments,‚Äù Modi said in the state legislative council. He was responding to a debate on the third supplementary budget for FY 2019-20.

SuMo urged the striking teachers, who are demanding ‚Äòequal pay for equal work‚Äô, to return to work as the state government has declared its intention to hike their salary.

Earlier, several opposition members raised the teachers‚Äô strike in the council and urged the government to accept their demands to end the stir in the interest of lakhs of students whose copies of Intermediate examination are not being evaluated because of the strike.

‚ÄúCM Nitish Kumar has already declared that the state government would make a ‚Äòrespectable‚Äô increase in their salary. Today, I announced it in the council. Now, teachers should return on their duty,‚Äù Modi told TOI over phone.

However, on being asked whether the state government was ready to accept the striking teachers‚Äô demand of ‚Äòequal pay for equal work‚Äô, Modi said there was no relevance of such demand in the wake of the Supreme Court‚Äôs order in this matter.

In a landmark order passed on May 10 last year, the Supreme Court had refused to regularise the services of contractual teachers and set aside the Patna high court ruling that they were eligible to get ‚Äòequal pay for equal work‚Äô.

A bench of Justices Abhay Manohar Sapre and U U Lalit, while allowing the plea of the Bihar government challenging the October 31, 2017 high court order, had also declined to treat contractual teachers on a par with regular teachers.

The apex court had said the Bihar government was justified in having two different streams or cadres for teachers and there has been no violation of the rights of the 'Niyojit' (contractual) teachers nor has there been any discrimination against them.

The SC, however, raised concern over the emoluments made available to the contractual teachers at the initial stage and suggested that the state government may consider raising the scales of such teachers at least to the level suggested by the three-member committee.

Around 4 lakh contractual teachers are on an indefinite strike since February 17 to press for fulfilment of their 8-point demands, including equal pay for equal work and old pension scheme.

Title: 14-year-old tribal raped by 2, including minor, in Jhalawar
Content:
Representative image

KOTA: A 14-year-old tribal girl was gang-raped by two persons, including a minor, under the Jawar police station of Jhalawar district late Monday evening. Following a complaint by the rape survivor, police have arrested a 22-year-old youth, detained the minor, and booked the two accused under various sections of IPC, Pocso and SC/ST acts.

The accused youth was produced before the Pocso court on Tuesday and remanded to judicial custody. The Juvenile Justice Board ordered to minor to be send to a juvenile home, police said.

‚ÄúThe minor girl from the Bheel community lodged the complaint against the 22-year-old, identified as Pawan Lodha, and his friend, a 15-year-old boy, on Monday night,‚Äù Jawar police station SHO Bannalal said.

In her complaint, the survivor alleged that the minor boy from her village covered her mouth and took her to an abandoned anganwadi centre of the village around 8pm on Monday, where she was raped by Lodha.

Moving quickly, police arrested the accused youth and detained the minor. ‚ÄúThe survivor was sent for medical examination on Tuesday. Further investigation is on into the matter,‚Äù he said.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Shivajinagar among coolest Maharashtra spots as mercury slides below 15¬∞C mark
Content:
Citizens welcomed the slight chill returning to Pune amid expectations of a soaring mercury in March.

PUNE: The minimum temperature at Shivajinagar dropped marginally below 15¬∞C on Tuesday, making it one of the coolest spots in Maharashtra .

Shivajinagar‚Äôs minimum temperature stood at 14.9¬∞C on Tuesday against 15.7¬∞C the previous day.

Citizens welcomed the slight chill returning to Pune amid expectations of a soaring mercury in March. Working professional Sayali Inamdar said, ‚ÄúAfter an usually warm February, I was expecting nights in the city to get warmer. But, it got quite cool last (Monday) night.‚Äù

Ahmednagar, Nashik, Malegaon , Nanded and Shivajinagar (in that order) were the coolest spots in the state on Tuesday early morning, with minimum temperatures at 13.1¬∞C, 13.8¬∞C, 14.4¬∞C, 14.5¬∞C and 14.9¬∞C respectively.

An India Meteorological Department (IMD) official said the drop in night temperature was a result of clear sky conditions prevailing during the night hours. ‚ÄúLack of clouds causes the terrestrial radiation (emitted from the earth‚Äôs surface) in the night to escape directly into the atmosphere. Conversely, when skies are cloudy, they hinder the passage of this radiation into the atmosphere, causing it to linger closer to the earth‚Äôs surface. Hence, cloudy skies are generally associated with high night temperature,‚Äù the official added.

When it comes to Lohegaon , the minimum temperature stayed at 17.5¬∞C on Tuesday as against 17.7¬∞C on Monday.

In the next few days, the minimum temperature in Pune is expected to stay between 15 and 16¬∞C, while the maximum might hover between 33 and 35¬∞C, stated the IMD forecast.

Title: Will heat slow coronavirus spread?
Content: AHMEDABAD: A ray of hope for Gujarat and India in the coming days may come from the intense summer heat, which experts believe could function as a shield against coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19).While not much is known about how the virus might behave under sustained heat, experts point to earlier cases of Coronavirus strands ‚Äî severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) ‚Äî which showed a downward trend in summer months.Dr Vivek Dave, an Ahmedabad critical care specialist, said that the medical fraternity hopes that once heat increases, viral infections will come down. ‚ÄúBut since it has been identified as ‚Äònovel‚Äô coronavirus, we still have to learn a lot about how it behaves under different conditions,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe epidemic will take a few months to settle down completely.‚ÄùDave added that while it‚Äôs always sensible to take all precautions possible, it‚Äôs also important to disseminate the message that there is no need to panic. ‚ÄúIf one has contracted COVID-19, it doesn‚Äôt mean the end of life ‚Äî even in China, the most affected country, the death rate is about 2%,‚Äù Dave said. ‚ÄúThe need of the hour is to follow the basics and improve the screening of those who have returned from epidemic zones.‚ÄùDr Gunvant Rathod, the medical superintendent of Civil Hospital, said that as the base hospital for COVID-19, the facility is ready with adequate beds, medicines, masks, and diagnostic and coordination teams. ‚ÄúWe have not received any positive case so far,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWith testing being done at the hospital, diagnosis has become faster.‚ÄùSources said that the civic authorities want foreign passengers screened at the airport. Manoj Gangal, the director of the city airport, could not be reached for comment. Sources added that hand sanitizers will be made available at multiple places in the terminals.

Title: Promised Rs 65 crore, sugarcane farmers call off stir in Bijnor
Content:
Representative image

BIJNOR: Sugarcane farmers staging a dharna outside 21 police stations in Bijnor over pending cane dues called called off their protests on Tuesday after they were assured they would be paid Rs 65 crore over the next few days.

The nine sugar mills in the district owe a total of Rs 725 crore to some 75,000 cane farmers.

Confirming that the agitation has been called off, state president of Bharatiya Kisan Unions ‚Äôs youth wing Digambar Singh, said, ‚ÄúOf the nine mills which owe Rs 725 crore, those in Bijnor, Chandpur, Bilai and Barkatpur have hardly paid anything to farmers.‚Äù

Talking with TOI, Digamber Singh said, ‚ÄúThe administration has assured us that Rs 65 crore will be paid by defaulter sugar mills. On Tuesday, the mills paid Rs 32 crore while Rs 33 crore will be cleared within the next 15 days. However, we want all dues cleared.‚Äù If administration fails to stick to its promises, we will raise banner again. ‚Äù

Yashpal Singh, district cane officer, said, ‚ÄúGovernment is set to release a subsidy of Rs 55 crore, which is pending since last year. Apart from this, the credit limit of Bijnor and Chandpur mills will to be extended to Rs 80 crore by the UP Cooperative Bank. In the coming days, mills will be able to pay farmers their pending dues. In facr, in Bijnor, we have paid 65% of total dues.‚Äù

Title: Couple go to Khadakwasla canal for a bath, currents sweep them away
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

PUNE: A couple, who went to the Khadakwasla canal for a bath on Tuesday morning, drowned after being swept away by the strong currents.

The Sinhagad Road police identified the deceased as Reshma Chavan (35) and her husband Kailash Rajendra Chavan (38) from Kondhwa-Dhawade on NDA Road.

The police said the couple informed their family members that they were going to the canal near Nanded Phata for a bath.

They reached the spot on their individual bikes one after the other around 9am.

Investigation officer Rustum Shaikh from Sinhagad Road police told TOI, ‚ÄúKailash first stepped into the water and was immediately swept away by the strong currents. Seeing him drifting away, his wife, Reshma, tried to catch him, but she, too, fell into the water.‚Äù

‚ÄúTheir bodies were recovered by the PMRDA‚Äôs fire brigade from Dhayari , around 7km from the incident spot, around 10am. The firemen and beat marshals rushed to the spot after passersby informed the city police control room,‚Äù Shaikh said.

The Sassoon General Hospital in its advance post-mortem report certificate confirmed the cause of the couple‚Äôs death as drowning.

Reshma was a music teacher and Kailash used to run a spectacle shop. They have a four-year-old daughter.

A complaint of accidental death was registered with the Sinhagad Road police under section 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure Code.

The case will be transferred to the Haveli police in Pune rural for investigation, he added.

Inspector Ashok Shelke from the Haveli police told TOI, ‚ÄúWe have seized two vehicles, a mobile phone and the clothes worn by Kailash from the banks of the canal.‚Äù

‚ÄúEyewitnesses told police that the couple was swept away by the gushing waters,‚Äù he said.

Title: Jaipur: What‚Äôs in a name? Artisans of Bagru discover it the hard way
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: A trademark threat is looming over artisans practising the 400-year-old craft of Bagru block printing from the namesake village near Jaipur.

The block printing technique has created the identity of the village where generations of artists have been practising it for centuries.

But now an artisan, belonging mostly to the Chippa caste (a community of painters), has been served a legal notice for using the word ‚ÄòBagru‚Äô for selling his product.

The notice was sent by one Hemant Kumar Sethia , who claimed that he had acquired the ‚Äòtrademark‚Äô in 2008 under the Trademarks Act 1999, and that no one is allowed to use the name while selling any cloth material. The artisans of Bagru have countered the claim and said that they have already received the Geographical Indication (GI) certificate in 2009.

The block printing method is used to produce cotton fabrics, including bedsheets, suits, sarees, table cloth and other such material.

Speaking for his client Sethia, lawyer Ashok Kumar Sharma said that he had registered the trademark a year before artisans of Bagru.

‚ÄúThey got the GI certificate a year later. My client has done nothing wrong as when he registered the trademark there was no such one in the market. We are not objecting the practise of the craft by them as it is ancient, but they cannot use the name. It is hampering our business and my client is facing financial losses. The rights of my client are protected under the law. They have to sell their products under some other name,‚Äù Sharma said.

Padam Shri awardee Ram Kishore Derewala, a Bagru artisan, said that the delay in getting the GI tag does not make the claim of Hemant Kumar Sethia valid.

Artisans of the village will be completely destroyed if this claim is allowed to stand. More than 10,000 people are involved in this multi-crore business for centuries. How can a person trademark a name of the village? Our livelihood is dependent on this. This is the specialty of Bagru and a man from outside the village or our community cannot get a trademark for it. If he thinks that our claim is not valid, he should have objected to it in 2009 when we got the GI certificate. We will take appropriate legal action,‚Äù Ram Kishore said.

However, reacting to the claim and counter claim Bagmisikha Phuan, an intellectual property rights lawyer based in Delhi, opined, ‚ÄúAt the outset, The Geographical Indications of Goods (Registration and Protection) Act, 1999, prohibits the registration of geographical indication as a trademark. Section 25 of the Act clearly states that an interested party may move the Registrar of Trade Marks for the invalidation of the registration of a trademark which contains or consists of a GI, whereby such usage is likely to confuse or mislead the persons as to the true place of origin of such goods or class of goods.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn the present situation, the usage of the trademark is misleading. The artisans may choose to file a rectification petition under Section 57 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, and seek the cancellation of the trademark registered incorrectly,‚Äù she said.

Title: Pawar opposes any move to hand over probe to CBI, ED, I-T
Content:
Nagpur: Rejecting all allegations made against him in the multi-crore irrigation scam, deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar once against opposed any move to hand over the probe to central agencies like Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI), Enforcement Directorate (IT), Serious Fraud Investigating Office (SFIO), and Income Tax (I-T) Department.

Ahead of next week‚Äôs final hearing into the PILs filed by petitioners Jan Manch and Atul Jagtap, Pawar, who is respondent No 7, asserted that no exceptional case was made out by petitioners for handing over the probe to central agencies.

Earlier, the Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB) had opposed the handing over of the probe to CBI, ED, SFIO and I-T stating that it would hamper its ongoing investigations. It added that it was working diligently and registered many offences against contractors and VIDC officials through its Special Investigations Teams (SITs) in Nagpur and Amravati divisions.

Justifying his demand, Pawar, in his latest affidavit filed before Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court this week, stated that change in the government after assembly elections can‚Äôt be the ground for change of investigating agency. ‚ÄúWhen the petitioner has full faith in investigating agency earlier, how has he lost faith after the change in the government?‚Äù

Questioning the locus standi of Jagtap, Pawar claimed he was himself the contractor and had filed many tenders in various projects. ‚ÄúThe petitioner shouldn‚Äôt use courts for settling personal scores. He‚Äôs having a mala fide notion of a scam which is yet to be proved. The courts can‚Äôt look or supervise investigations and also can‚Äôt direct that particular person should me made an accused.‚Äù

Denying Jagtap‚Äôs allegations that probe against Pawar wasn‚Äôt being conducted properly, the three-time deputy CM said, he was being questioned and interrogated on September 11 last year, and also made to provide written replies to questionnaire. ‚ÄúThe petitioner shouldn‚Äôt have biased approach as investigations against him were conducted during previous (BJP) government and various FIRs against contractors were lodged in their tenure. I can‚Äôt be called on to answer every question, as I am not made as an accused in any complaint so far.‚Äù

Rejecting allegations that he had interfered in the ACB‚Äôs working, Pawar said there was nothing on record to prove it. ‚ÄúThe petitioner has decided to don the role of investigating agency by pointing out the defects and contradictions in probe which are completely imaginative. The PILs are filed with a motive of troubling me. Every HC order is complied by the government and even SITs are constituted accordingly.‚Äù
