This contradicts the process laid down in the manuals,‚Äù he said adding that it leaves virtually no time for debate.

The Congress lawmaker further stated that the manual has also laid down a time period of 19 days to present the budget and for department-wise debate. ‚ÄúI fail to understand why the government is in such a hurry. It is evident that the BJP government is not interested in holding a session at Gairsain,‚Äù he added.

Leader of opposition, Indira Hridayesh , supported of the party MLA and sought an extension of the session. ‚ÄúWhen other states can do so, then why not in Uttarakhand. With just four days, when will the budget be presented, debated and then passed in the House. Mere formalities are being fulfilled under the cover of holding an assembly session at Gairsain,‚Äù said the legislator from Haldwani.

Meanwhile, BJP refuted these allegations and said that Congress is delaying business by disruptions in the House.

Urban development minister Madan Kaushik said, ‚ÄúCongress was in power for 10 years and for five years Hridayesh was the parliamentary affairs minister. Then why were these guidelines not followed during her tenure. Had she forgotten the manuals. The budget session at Uttarakhand is being held as per the tradition of last 20 years. Secondly, if Congress wants the session at Gairsain to be extended, they why is it disrupting the House and delaying work.‚Äù

Title: High court dismisses contempt petition against Ayurvedic College
Content:
Representative image

NAINITAL: In a major relief to the Himalayan Ayurvedic Medical College , the Uttarakhand high court (HC) on Tuesday dismissed the contempt petition against it.

This comes just a day after the court had taken into custody the principal of the college who was let go only after the counsel appearing for them promised that the managing director of the institute will appear in person.

However, as the proceedings began on Tuesday, it was pointed out to the single judge bench of Justice Sharad Kumar Sharma that the copy of the order presented with the petition does not belong to the petitioner. ‚ÄúThe court while hearing a bunch of petitions had ordered all the colleges to refund the extra money that they had charged from students. The current petition has been filed by a student named Manish Kumar while the order copy attached here was of someone else. Therefore, the court dismissed the petition,‚Äù said advocate Vinod Tiwari, the counsel appearing for the petitioner.

Tiwari, however, said that the court has given them liberty to file another petition which will be done soon. ‚ÄúThe court didn‚Äôt say that our grounds were not legitimate. It was a technical matter which will be sorted out soon and a fresh case will be filed before the high court soon,‚Äù Tiwari added.

As reported by TOI earlier, the state government, through a Government Order (GO) had in October 2015 increased the fee of Bachelor of Ayurvedic Medical Sciences (BAMS) by almost Rs 1.4 lakh. The fee was increased retrospectively. However, after a petition was filed, the court quashed the GO and ordered all the colleges to return the extra fee that had been charged from the students. The colleges then filed a Special Leave Petition (SLP) before the division bench. However, that appeal was also dismissed by the court and they were again ordered to return the fee. However, as the colleges did not return the amount again, students approached the court and filed a contempt petition against the college.

Title: Punjab stares at Rs 25,000 crore burden from faulty PPAs
Content:
Punjab CM Amarinder Singh (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The Punjab government is staring at a cumulative financial burden of over Rs 25,000 crore from litigation over faulty power purchase agreements with two private power plants, which were set up after power demand was artificially increased and then, the excess power generated by these plants was surrendered, the state‚Äôs top law officer has said.

After Punjab State Power Corporation Ltd (PSPCL) artificially raised the state‚Äôs power demand from 1,800 mw to 3,100 mw in 2007 and then by a further 2,100 mw in 2008, two power plants were set up by Talwandi Sabo Power Ltd (TSPL) and Nabha Power Ltd (NPL). PSPL entered into power purchase agreements (PPAs) with them on the basis of this artificially increased demand for power, state advocate general Atul Nanda said in his opinion to the Amarinder Singh government rendered two weeks ago.

For the power contracted but not utilised by PSPL, consumers had to pay ‚Äòsurrender charges‚Äô of Rs 1,633.97 crore to NPL from 2012-13 to 2019-20 and Rs 2,050.37 crore to TSPL from 2014-15 to 2019-20.

Thus, Rs 3,684 crore was paid for surrendering excess power contracted by PSPL from the two power plants. Production of excess electricity expended extra fuel costing Rs 84 crore, Nanda said in his detailed opinion after studying documents relating to the state‚Äôs power sector for the last 15 years.

Despite the huge financial ramifications, the matter was referred to the AG only in the last week of December 2019. The AG expressed surprise at how the coal linkage decision, approved by the PSPCL board of directors and the council of ministers, for higher grade and cheaper coal from PSPCL‚Äôs captive Pachhwara coal mine was ‚Äúdropped‚Äù by two officers. Use of coal from captive mines would have reduced the power tariff, he said.

The power companies imported coal at a much higher price and an additional Rs 400-500 crore per annum had to be passed on to consumers. Nanda also faulted PSPCL for seeking power tariff approval from the state electricity regulatory commission (SERC) based on wrong premises. ‚ÄúPetitions preferred by PSPCL for approval of tariff to be paid to NPL and TSPL were based on assumptions/factors which were either false, technically incorrect, contrary to decisions taken/approval given or otherwise contrary to law,‚Äù he said.

Explaining how power demand was exaggerated, Nanda said the four-month peak during the agriculture season was shown as 24x7 demand round the year. ‚ÄúThere has been impermissible deviations from the 2005 Competitive Bidding Guidelines and aspects which are required to be corrected/reviewed and remedied and which would then have a significant impact leading to a revised/reduced tariff structure,‚Äù he said.

Advising the state to initiate urgent measures in SERC to review approved tariff to save money, Nanda gave a chilling account of what lay in future. ‚ÄúA rough and ready analysis of such litigation (linked to a myriad issues relating to faulty PPAs) shows that the financial burden of all this litigation would be a cumulative and staggering amount of at least Rs 25,030 crore on PSPL which would then eventually be burdened on the state of Punjab and its electricity consumers,‚Äù he said.

Warning against routine litigation by PSPCL, Nanda said, ‚ÄúGiven the staggering financial impact of all such litigation, PSPCL is advised not to deal with this litigation in a routine manner but to set up a specialised legal team which may handle such litigation in the four fora ‚Äî courts where they will occur, that is district court Patiala (arbitration matters), Punjab State Electricity Regulatory Commission and Appellate Tribunal for Electricity, Punjab and Haryana High Court and the Supreme Court.‚Äù

Title: More schools join scheme to make students eat veggies
Content:
Trichy: As more city schools started adopting Akshaya Pathiram scheme ‚Äì a novel method to make children consume more vegetables along with their meal ‚Äî a corporation primary school at Edaimalaipattipudur became the latest entrant to the list on Tuesday.

School children are asked to bring a few vegetables from home while coming to school which is cooked and served to them at the school. ‚ÄúThese vegetables will be an add-on to the regular lunch for students who bring their food from home and for those who have their lunch at the school as part of noon meal scheme,‚Äù said assistant teacher H Pushpalatha. There are a total of 380 students at the school of which 200 are covered under the noon meal scheme.

While it was the government aided Subbaiah School that initiated the scheme, it is now being adopted by others as well.

Since children often hesitate to eat vegetables along with food at home, they were asked to bring vegetables from home and put them in an exclusive vessel named ‚ÄòAkshaya Pathiram‚Äô at the school. Vegetables collected as part of the initiative are utilised to make the school‚Äôs noon meal which subsequently turns richer in vegetables.

Getting one or two vegetables from their kitchen while coming to school will not be a big task for children, said district elementary education officer K Maruthanayagam. ‚ÄúAt the same time, we will make it a habit for these tender minds not to avoid vegetables,‚Äù he said.

The initiative also took shape because of complaints from many parents that their children were avoiding vegetables in their meal.

‚ÄúMany children hesitate to take bitter gourd along with their food despite its nutritious value. We received around 5 kg of bitter gourd. Now parents can give these vegetables to their children which will be evenly distributed to all children,‚Äù he said.

Title: 9.5kg tumour removed from ovary
Content:
Kolkata: A 23-year-old woman, who had been running from one hospital to another for months, seeking treatment for a mammoth tumour in her ovary, was finally operated upon at a hospital in Jadavpur. Even the doctors were taken aback by the size of the tumour that weighed 9.5kg.

‚ÄúThis kind of an ovarian tumour is usually found in a post-menopausal woman. This is patient is a young woman,‚Äù said gynaecologist Payal Banerjee Roy at KPC Medical College, where the patient underwent the surgery. The tumour adhered to her bladder and the vessels supplying blood to pelvic organs and her legs. Doctors said this kind of fibrosis accounted for only about 4% ovarian tumours. A biopsy report proved it to be benign.

Other hospitals had allegedly turned her away, saying the operation was way too risky. At KPC Medical College, a multi-disciplinary team, comprising doctors Bala, Pushkar, Shyam Choudhury, Amitabha Chakrabarti and Payal Banerjee Roy, finally decided to take up the challenging surgery. ‚ÄúThe patient is recovering. We plan to send her home soon,‚Äù said an official.

Title: Anti-CAA protesters to suspend stir for 6 days during Holi
Content:
The anti-CAA protesters -- who have been protesting since January 27 at Dehradun's Dharna Sthal, on the lines of Delhi's Shaheen Bagh

DEHRADUN: The anti-CAA protesters -- who have been protesting since January 27 at Dehradun's Dharna Sthal, on the lines of Delhi's Shaheen Bagh -- have decided to suspend their agitation from March 7 to March 12 after police allegedly "warned" that FIRs would be lodged against them if any untoward incident took place during Holi.‚ÄúWe will be back after Holi,‚Äù said Razia Begh, a social activist and ex-chairman of Dehradun bar council who is also among the people spearheading the protest.Begh said the protesters were planning to organise a 'Holi Milan' event on Thursday at the dharna site but have now cancelled it. She said the protesters had lined up two separate events for Holi.Begh claimed police used to "threaten" the protesters almost every third day to vacate the spot. On Tuesday, a large posse of police personnel arrived at the dharna site and told the protesting women to end their stir.‚ÄúThey (police) asked us to leave the spot immediately. When we told the police that we were silently trying to send a message, they said our message had reached the authorities concerned and that we would be held responsible if any untoward incident took place in the area during Holi. Thousands of people had come to participate in the peaceful protest,‚Äù she said.Yaasmin Ali, a protester who has already prepared gujia for the event, is disappointed. ‚ÄúI will still give these gujias to my Hindu brothers and sisters. We all celebrate Holi every year. We are taking utmost care to ensure that nothing untoward happens, at lest not in our name. This is why we are moving out from the protest site for the time being,‚Äù she said.SP city, Shweta Chaubey, said police have not asked or threatened anyone to vacate the protest site. "The protesters themselves told us that some anti-social elements were trying to disturb peace. After a discussion with the administration, the protesters agreed to suspend their stir during Holi celebrations. This has been done to ensure that no law and order situation arises during the festival," she added.

Title: BJP to contest 43 seats in zilla panchayat polls: Goa CM Pramod Sawant
Content:
Pramod Sawant

PANAJI/SALIGAO: On Tuesday, BJP announced its third list of eight candidates, and MGP announced its second list of three candidates for the zilla panchayat elections . The last day for the filing of nomination papers is March 5.

Speaking to mediapersons, BJP state president Sadanand Shet Tanavade listed out the names of the eight candidates‚Äî six from South Goa and two from North Goa.

In South Goa, BJP named Shramesh Bhosle for the Betki-Khandola ZP seat, Shivram Naik for Veling-Priol, Sanjana Velip for Guirdolim, Suresh Kepekar for Rivona, Shobhana Velip for Poinguinim and Anita Thorat for Sancoale.

In North Goa, the party will field Diksha Kanolkar for Sirsaim and Shruti Ghatwal for Latambarce.

Chief minister Pramod Sawant told reporters that BJP would contest 43 seats out of the total 50.

‚ÄúWe are confident of winning the ZP polls in both districts. None of the recent issues will have an impact on our win‚Äî the people of Goa will vote for BJP as they trust the party wholly,‚Äù Sawant said. BJP has until now announced 39 candidates in total‚Äî23 in North Goa and 16 in the South.

A large number of BJP workers on Monday rallied behind Aldona BJP ZP candidate Manisha Naik after she came to file her nomination papers at the deptuy collector's office at Mapusa. Naik is currently the deputy Sarpanch of Bastora village panchayat and the president of the Aldona Mahila mandal.

Meanwhile, MGP will field Shailesh Naik for Kumbharjua and Pravin Vaigankar for Harmal, and Vinda Sawant will contest the Darbandora seat. The party has decided to contest 19 seats, and has already announced the names of 15 candidates.

Title: ‚ÄòPower to choose tourism board should lie with goverment‚Äô
Content:
Goa tourism minister Manohar Ajgaonkar (Image credit: Twitter)

PANAJI: There is still no clarity over the nature of the composition of the proposed Goa tourism board (GTB) under the draft tourism policy. Uncertainty has arisen after tourism minister Manohar Ajgaonkar raised the ante over allowing the tourism trade body the freedom to appoint its representatives on the board. Ajgaonkar wants the goverment to retain the power to appoint representatives of the tourism industry.

A heated discussion ensued at a meeting held last week to finalise the tourism master plan, a vision document initiated in 2014. The meeting was also attended by chief minister Pramod Sawant.

‚ÄúThe tourism minister is not in favour of the trade body choosing its representatives to be nominated to the board. He wants the power to appoint industry members,‚Äù said an official who present at the meeting.

A consensus on the composition of the board, he said, was reached a year ago. It was decided that the board will comprise members of the trade as well as government officials, with the tourism minister as chairman. It was agreed that five representatives of the tourism industry bodies would also be part of the 15 member-GTB.

The meeting, said the official, was inconclusive, with Ajgaonkar remaining adamant on his stand.

Ajgaonkar however said he was not opposed to having trade members on the board, provided the government appoints them. Let the president of the Travel and Tourism Association of Goa (TTAG) be a board member, but the other industry representatives should as per the government‚Äôs choice, the minister said .

‚ÄúIf they are allowed to nominate representatives , they (trade) will dictate terms to us,‚Äù he said.

It was proposed that members other than those from TTAG and Goa Chamber of Commerce and Industry (GCCI), shall hold a position for two years, on rotation-basis.

The TTAG is hoping that better sense will prevail, and their efforts of the last two years would not go to waste in finalising the finer points of the policy.

‚ÄúIt has taken more than three years for the tourism master plan to be drawn up, and the tourism policy drafted. We do not want any further delay,‚Äù a TTAG member said.

Their concern, he said, also stems from the ground reality that ministers ensure that persons of their choice - it could be a relative or a loyalist- are appointed to corporations which are governed by them.

‚ÄúIn the last two years, the GTDC board was changed thrice to accomodate such members. We do not want any non-professional, or a person having no sound knowledge of the tourism sector to be part of the GTB. That‚Äôs why it was suggested to appoint representatives of various bodies of the tourism sector,‚Äù he said.

The TTAG is concerned by the latest development but some members are confident that the chief minister will work out a solution. TTAG president Savio Massias declined to comment on the issue.

Besides the trade representatives, key officials of the tourism ministry ‚Äì the tourism secretary, tourism director and managing director of the Goa State Tourism Corporation (GTDC) ‚Äì were also to be appointed on the board. It was also decided that an environment expert will be included in the tourism board, and there is also a provision to appoint a qualified professional as its chief executive officer.

Title: Indonesian hackers breach Uttarakhand‚Äôs tourism website
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand‚Äôs tourism website ‚Äî uttarakhandtourism.gov.in ‚Äî was hacked by a group of Indonesian hackers called ‚ÄúOne Hat Cyber Team‚Äù on Tuesday. The hackers took control of the website for a while and flashed a message saying ‚Äî we are ‚ÄòIndonesian Muslim citizens‚Äô.

A tourism department spokesperson told TOI that the website has been secured now and is under maintenance. ‚ÄúA police complaint seeking cyber investigation has been filed and the website would be up and running shortly,‚Äù said the spokesperson.

The website is the only platform for all visitors who want to check out information like homestays, state-run guest houses, tenders, and all contacts of the state tourism department.

A police official posted at the cyber wing told TOI, ‚ÄúA complaint has been received from the Uttarakhand tourism department and the investigation to trace the hackers is on.‚Äù

Notably, the tourism department hires a private firm to maintain the website for smooth operations. In order to boost the tourism business in Uttarakhand, the tourism department had recently tied up with OYO, a mobile aggregator firm, for homestays and guest house booking.

Title: Tejas Exp move bemuses train stakeholders in coastal K‚Äôtaka
Content:
Mangaluru Central Railway station

Mangaluru: A move by Southern Railway (SR) to introduce Tejas Express between Mangaluru Central and Coimbatore has raised the hackles of local train activists. While the local stakeholders normally welcome the introduction of new trains, what has upset them this time is the denial of entry for intra-state trains, especially those operating to Bengaluru, to the Mangaluru Central station citing lack of availability of platform and termination of these trains at Mangaluru Junction itself.

The Inter-Railway Timetable Committee (IRTTC), that met in Bengaluru last week, approved the proposal by the Chennai-headquartered zonal railway to operate the new semi high-speed train with tentative departure of 6am from Mangaluru Central to reach Coimbatore at 12.10pm. The train is scheduled to depart Coimbatore at 2.30pm to reach Mangaluru Central at 8.40pm on all days except Mondays as per the timetable approved by IRTTC.

Pashchima Karavali Rail Yatri Abhivriddhi Samiti‚Äôs Anil Hegde, being critical of the ‚Äúbias of Southern Railway‚Äù, said Yeshwantpur-Mangaluru Central tri-weekly express (train 16585) is departing Yeshwantpur at 4.30pm and arriving at Mangaluru Central at 3am. This is only due to the claim by Palakkad division, that controls Mangaluru Central, that no platform is available at Central after 5am. ‚ÄúHow could SR find platform for Tejas Express?‚Äù he wondered.

Endorsing Hegde‚Äôs concerns, Sudarshan Puttur, convener of Kukke Subrahmanya-Mangaluru Rail Abhivriddhi Samiti, said Tejas proposal has exposed double standards of SR that is denying the entry of Karnataka trains into Mangaluru Central for a decade. ‚ÄúIt did not allow Mumbai CSMT-Mangaluru-Mumbai CSMT superfast express into Central citing platform congestion while starting Mangaluru Central-Coimbatore Intercity Express in the interim,‚Äù he said.

Activists Raveendran Nambiar and Dinesh Bhat, both from Puttur, said SR cannot justify the non-availability of platforms to start and receive Karnataka trains at Central as four trains leave Central towards Kerala/ Tamil Nadu between 5am and 7.30am. Even when there is inordinate delay in constructing additional platforms at Central by SR, its move to push Tejas‚Äô proposal is classic example for step-motherly treatment towards Karnataka, Bhat rued.

Yogendra Swamy, representing Mysuru Grahaka Parishat, said SR and Palakkad division have cited platform constraint to Karnataka trains, including Yeshwantpur-Mangaluru Junction-Yeshwantpur Gomateshwara Express, Vijayapura-Mangaluru Junction-Vijayapura special Express. ‚ÄúWon‚Äôt the same constraints apply to TN- and Kerala-bound trains?‚Äù he asked. The practice of using Mangaluru as the terminal for North Kerala should stop, he suggested.

Speaking on the developments,Pratap Singh Shami, divisional railway manager of Palakkad division, said he was not aware of the (Tejas Express) proposal. ‚ÄúSalem division must have sent the proposal. Palakkad division is yet to work on it,‚Äù he added.

Title: BDU to set apart 2 seats in each dept for wards of staff
Content:
Trichy: Two separate seats will be created in each of the 40 departments in Bharathidasan University (BDU) to accommodate a ward each of the university‚Äôs teaching and administrative staff respectively who are unable to get seats. The decision which was taken based on the demand put forward by staff, especially from the administration, will come into effect from the coming academic year.

A committee was set up to analyse the demand and make recommendations for the approval of the vice-chancellor. Following this, a resolution was also passed at the recently held syndicate meeting and finance committee also approved it.

Welcoming the move, M Selvam, dean, faculty of management, and syndicate member, said securing seats in some of the popular university departments is indeed difficult. These include departments like Chemistry, Biotechnology, Physics and English. Saying that there will be 50% concession in fees for wards of class IV staff, he said the idea was to recognise staff who worked tirelessly for the development of the university by giving preference to their wards.

BDU registrar G Gopinath told TOI that there will not be any special treatment to the students claiming the two seats as they will have to follow all admission procedures followed by any other candidate. Only those wards of employees who were unsuccessful in making it to the merit list will be considered based on their request. Seats will be allotted on first come first serve basis if there are more than two candidates claiming the seats, he said.

On whether reservation policy is not applicable for these seats, he said they are not violating any norms as such. Recalling the practice of ‚Äòmerit-cum-means quota‚Äô he said the university was reserving a few seats in some of the popular courses for those who can afford the seats by paying more than the stipulated fee.

‚ÄúWe are only adding two seats but wards of staff cannot get seats just like that and they must follow all procedures. This practice was there in the past but was suspended for some years in between as there were less takers,‚Äù said the registrar.

Title: ‚ÄòSufficient water in state‚Äôs dams to tide over summer‚Äô
Content:
Panaji: With the onset of summer, reservoirs in the state are being closely monitored, WRD chief engineer Shrikant Patil said. Presently, two of the state‚Äôs biggest reservoirs, Anjunem and Selaulim, are 100% and 69% full, respectively.

The other important reservoir at Amthane, which supplies raw water to the Assonora water treatment plant, is at 72% capacity, WRD officials said.

The water level at Amthane had dropped to 32% in January, raising concerns for the approaching summer. This happened because the PWD stopped using raw water from the Tillari dam in Maharashtra for most parts of December and January, as it was highly turbid and instead, tapped the Amthane dam.

However, Patil said the PWD has resumed using water from Tillari for treatment at Assonora and that after pumping water from the Sal into Amthane, the reservoir is up to over 70% now.

During the monsoon of 2019, a wall of the Tillari canal had collapsed. It was repaired and supply to Goa from the Tillari dam resumed by December 10, 2019, but the water was still highly turbid.

Normally, Amthane acts as a back-up to meet shortages during the peak of summer. It supplies raw water to the Assonora plant, which supplies water to the whole of Bardez and large parts of Bicholim taluka.

‚ÄúWe are monitoring the reservoirs closely and ensuring that there will be no shortage in supply of raw water during the summer. We are also going to begin pumping water from the Selaulim into the Opa river early this year,‚Äù Patil said. The Opa water treatment plants supply water to Ponda and Tiswadi talukas.At present, Chapoli dam in Canacona is 79% full, while the Panchawadi reservoir is 50% full.

Last summer, Goa faced one of its worst water shortages. Levels in the Opa river had dropped below 3m , and the WRD was forced to tap bandharas and quarries to ensure basic water supply.

Title: GHMC clears branches obstructing traffic in Kothapet
Content:
Hyderabad: A bunch of dried up branches was cleared by the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) after a complaint was published in TOI‚Äôs Citizen Journalist column on February 26.

The GHMC had cut branches of a tree that remained uncleared at Kothapet for two days.,obstructing passage of vehicles and pedestrians in the area. A resident of the area, Nikhil Sai had raised a complaint over the same on TOI‚Äôs citizen journalist app. The resident complained that the uncleared branches kept on the sides narrowed down the road further, resulting in traffic congestion.

‚ÄúTrees branches were sheared by the authorities in Kothapet but remained uncleared. This behaviour of the municipal corporation led to traffic congestion in the area,‚Äù stated Sai.

Soon after the complaint was published in the columns, the GHMC stepped in and cleared the green debris on February 28. Now, the residents of the locality have asked the GHMC to display similar swiftness in cleaning a park in the area. ‚ÄúThere is a well near the location in a park which is full of waste, including plastic waste. It is very unhygienic for those who regularly visit the park to exercise as the well emits foul smell and has led to mosquito menace,‚Äù said Sai.

Title: UP ex-minister, 8 others awarded imprisonment in Rudrapur land grabbing case
Content:
Representative image

RUDRAPUR: Nine persons, including a former Uttar Pradesh minister and former district government counsel (DGC) of Udham Singh Nagar district were awarded imprisonment by the judicial magistrate at the district and sessions court on Tuesday for forging a bequest in order to grab 32 acres of land.

In May 2014, Prabhavati Devi had filed a complaint against nine people ‚Äî Prem Prakash Singh, former legislator of Barhaj constituency in Deoria district of Uttar Pradesh; Singh‚Äôs wife Manju Lata Singh; son Shiv Vardhan Singh; daughter-in-law Nidhi Singh; former DGC Swatantra Bahadur Singh, ex-DGC‚Äôs wife Geeta Singh, daughter-in-law Shikha Singh, and two witnesses ‚Äî Navnath Tiwari and Prem Narayan Singh.

Prabhavati Devi told the police that her father was a sepoy in the Azad Hind Fauj. He joined the police force after Independence and retired as a DSP. For his contribution to the freedom struggle, he was awarded 50 acres of land in Bagwala village, around five kilometers from the city. Singh passed away in June 1999 and the land was inherited by his only descendant Prabhavati Devi, who had moved to Sihaura village of Azamgarh (UP) after marriage.

She had alleged that as she could not come to watch her parental property often, the accused occupied her land by forging the will in the name of Prem Prakash Singh, who is a two-time MLA from Barhaj and a former minister as well. All of the accused were booked under sections 420 (cheating), 467 (forging documents), 468 (forging for the purpose of cheating), 471 (using forged document fraudulently as genuine), 506 (criminal intimidation) and 504 (intentionally insulting and provoking to break public peace) of the Indian Penal Code. On June 17, 2016, a chargesheet was filed in the court by the police which added sections 342 (wrongful confinement) and 120B (criminal conspiracy) of the IPC in their report.

Title: Kolkata: March orders may impact Indian university image abroad
Content: KOLKATA: The back-to-back deportation orders to foreign students studying in universities in the state has led to anxiety and unease among the fraternity as well as academics. Many of them felt the recent incidents were an overreaction by the authorities and it might hurt India‚Äôs image abroad.A Polish student at Jadavpur University , Kamil Siedcynski, and Afsara Anika Meem, a Bangladeshi girl studying at Visva-Bharati, were recently issued ‚ÄúLeave India‚Äù order by Foreigners Regional Registration Officer in Kolkata for ‚Äúimproper conduct and violating visa norms‚Äù after they allegedly participated in anti-CAA protests.The marching order has so shaken a group of students from an Asian country studying at a university in the city that they have decided not to go anywhere near any protest venue. ‚ÄúThis is a scary situation, where orders to leave India are being handed out to students without even giving them an opportunity to explain themselves,‚Äù said one of them. ‚ÄúThere have been anti-citizenship protests at almost all colleges and universities in the city. They may issue deportation notice if one of us is spotted even watching the demonstrations from a distance.‚Äù Another student from a European country sounded equally anxious: ‚ÄúIt is a dangerous practice, which may hinder student exchange programmes in future.‚ÄùJU professor emeritus Sukanta Chaudhuri said, ‚ÄúStudents will state their views and have the curiosity to visit rallies and take photographs. If they are doing something against the interest of the country, then such a reaction was acceptable but just for attending a rally or clicking photos, such a reaction is bit too strong. Foreign students, including Indians, take part in large-scale protests against politically unpopular movements abroad but I have not heard that anybody has suffered any consequences.‚ÄùPresidency University dean Pradip Basu called it ‚Äúa naked restriction on the freedom of expression in the world‚Äôs largest democracy with a democratic Constitution‚Äù. ‚ÄúMoreover, exchange of ideas on any topic will suffer within a university as there will be constant fear. Internationally, Indian universities may face issues,‚Äù he said. Echoing him, Partha Pratim Ray of Jadavpur University Teacher‚Äôs Association said, ‚ÄúIndia is known to accommodate every section of people from different parts of the world. The recent incidents will not only hurt India‚Äôs image in the academic world, but our students will also face problems outside.‚ÄùDean of students at St Xavier‚Äôs College Argha Banerjee, however, felt foreign students should exercise caution and not get directly entangled in the country specific political issues. ‚ÄúEveryone is entitled to his or her opinion and that should be respected in no uncertain terms. Students from abroad should focus on academic and cultural enrichment and exchange between the two countries. While they should have their share of opinions on global issues, like climate and environment, they should be careful not to get caught in specific political issues. But these students should have been issued a warning before being asked to leave the country. If they failed to adhere to the directives, only then they should have been asked to leave.‚Äù

Title: VMC posts candidates‚Äô OMR test sheets online
Content:
Vadodara: In an attempt to bring in transparancy in the recruitment of staffers for various positions in its health department, Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) uploaded the answersheets online. Job aspirants had filled optical mark reader (OMR) sheets for the recruitment tests.

VMC had recently conducted the tests for recruitment of 242 personnel in the health department.

The positions for which the tests were held included medical officers, lab technicians, pharmacists, female health workers, multi-purpose health workers, staff nurses and x-ray technicians.

Officials said that after the tests were conducted, the answer key for the OMR test was also made public. Going a step further, VMC decided to post online the OMR sheets filled by the candidates along with their results.

‚ÄúThey will be able to compare the sheets with the answer key for themselves,‚Äù said an official. The civic body claims that it is the first proactive disclosure in the state showing the OMR sheets to the job aspirants in such a manner. If the experiment is successful, VMC may adopt a similar system for other tests in the future.

Title: Three attacked over TikTok video
Content:
Vadodara: The detection of crime branch (DCB) on Tuesday arrested two men and detained three minors for attacking a man and his friends in Pratapnagar area.

The accused attacked Taseen Dhobi with a knife after they entered into heated arguments over making of a TikTok video in Hazirabaug.

Sameer Sheikh, a resident of Yakutpura, told the police that he had gone to Hazirabaug with his friend Taseen and Abrar Sheikh on Monday afternoon to make a TikTok video. While the video was being made, Taseen threw a fruit in the air which accidentally hit one of the accused, Krishna Thakore. Even though Taseen apologized to Krishna, but the latter began to abuse him.

Sheikh told the cops that Krishna attacked Taseen with a knife injuring him on the stomach and back. When Sheikh and Abrar tried to intervene, they too were thrashed by Krishna‚Äôs friends who were present at the site. Police arrested Krishna, Chirag Rajput and also detained three minors from Gajrawadi area on Tuesday. tnn

Title: Delayed paddy harvest affects pulse cultivation
Content:
The cultivation of pulses including black gram and green gram in the delta districts has come down drastically as farmers are able to sow only on 65 per cent of the normal area covered during the season. Farmers and agriculture department officials attributed this to the delayed paddy harvest due to unexpected rain in the delta districts.

Traditionally, farmers in Trichy , Thanjavur , Tiruvarur and Nagapattinam districts broadcast seeds of pulses manually amid standing samba paddy crop seven to 10 days before harvest. After a gap of about five years they were expecting bumper samba paddy harvest for the recent October - January season thanks to the continuous flow in Cauvery and adequate rain. However, the unexpected rain which lashed the delta districts in mid-January played spoilsport flattening thousands of acres of standing paddy which was ready to go for harvest in a few days. Hence the farmers could not cover the required acreage in pulse cultivation, they said.

K Rajamani, a Thanjavur farmer, said his samba paddy crops fell along the field itself. Though he sowed black gram on his two acres, only 80% of seeds germinated properly. Water stagnation on the field also prevented many farmers from sowing pulse seeds, he added. Though the harvest was being done manually earlier, machines are used now for harvesting paddy. This would cause damage to the pulse seeds already sown on about 20% area, they said.

Agriculture officials said only 3.67 lakh acres of the usual 5.65 lakh acres in three districts has been covered with pulses so far. ‚ÄúAs of now, we have covered 1.62 lakh acres in Nagapattinam district against the targeted 2.25 lakh acres. Being a tail-end area, residual moisture will extend for some more days. So, we hope we will attain our target ‚Äù, S Panneerselvam, joint director of agriculture (in-charge) from Nagapattinam said.

Title: Kundapur flyover opening gets another new date ‚Äî March 31
Content:
The flyover coming up on national highway-66 at Kundapur.

Mangaluru: The Kundapur flyover is expected to be thrown open to traffic by March 31.

Shishu Mohan DGM and project director, National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) said the Kundapur flyover work is progressing at a brisk pace and should be completed by March 31.

The project director was responding to a grievance raised by Vignesh Shenoy, a resident of Kundapur, who had drawn Prime Minister Narendra Modi‚Äôs attention to the pending work. The grievance was examined by NHAI‚Äôs independent engineer Aarvee Associates, Architects Engineers and Consultants Private Limited, Udupi.

On the project, Shishu Mohan said that a vehicle underpass (VUP) was proposed at the ‚ÄòY‚Äô Junction near Shastri Circle.Various alternatives were studied for a feasible solution like double vent VUP and others. However, the public insisted on a flyover. Finally, a flyover of five spans was approved.

On in principle approval for a flyover, the concessionaire commenced work in June 2013 by providing diversion for traffic with safety barricading and completed the super structure in July 2018. Completion of the work was delayed due to paucity of funds. On June 21, 2019, the concessionaire submitted a plan for completion of work by December. However, it was delayed again due to financial problems and prolonged rains.

At a meeting in Bengaluru on December 10, 2019 and Gurugram on January 23 this year, the concessionaire promised to complete the work by March 31, stated Mohan.

Regarding the toll, NHAI said that toll is being collected only for the completed length of project and where traffic is plying. ‚ÄúOnce the balance main carriageway work is completed, that portion will be added to the toll length and toll will be increased for the same.

Title: Experts discuss strategies to conserve urban wetlands
Content:
Vadodara: A national workshop on urban wetlands kicked off in the city on Tuesday at the Community Science Centre at Subhanpura.

Hosted by the city-based Gujarat Ecology Society, the national workshop on conservation and management of urban wetlands saw various scientists, environmentalists and researchers deliberating on the topic and presenting their studies. Dr Diwakar Sharma from the World Wildlife Fund-India delivered the keynote address on the need of conservation of wetlands in urban areas. Prof Geeta Padate from MS University spoke on wetlands and its relevance in conserving biodiversity. Padate talked about several wetlands in Vadodara district like the Wadhvana lake in Dabhoi and the ponds in the city.

Deputy director of GES Dr Jayendra Lakhmapurkar spoke on geo-climatic considerations in wetland management, while environmental activist Rohit Prajapati highlighted the flaws in the laws and policy that govern wetlands in the country.

There were also presentations by researchers on distribution pattern of heronries in Tamil Nadu, Bhukhi Kaans of Vadodara among others.

More lectures by urban planners and environmentalists are in store for the sessions on Wednesday.

Title: Coronavirus cases in Delhi: Schools in Delhi issue advisories to parents
Content: NEW DELHI: While two schools have been shut in Noida over fears of a coronavirus outbreak , authorities in the capital are not taking any chances either. Many Delhi schools have issued advisories to parents, requesting them to keep their wards at home if they show respiratory symptoms such as cold and cough.Shri Ram School, Vasant Vihar, said it will remain closed from Thursday, while its Aravali and Moulsari campuses will be shut from March 9. The report cards will be sent online, while the other events of the schools have been postponed. ‚ÄúThe spring break has been advanced by a few days. The holidays will be utilised for sanitisation work. This is being done as a precautionary measure,‚Äù the school said.The school has sent a detailed advisory to the parents on the precautionary measures they should take as also the steps being taken by the school itself. A note sent to the parents read: ‚ÄúWe are doing regular handwashing in class for the children, teachers and didis, also along with our usual hand-sanitising sessions. Our washrooms are also cleaned and sanitised at frequent intervals.‚Äù The school also requested parents of the children who had recently acquired flu to submit fitness certificates from their paediatricians.Another school has asked parents to educate their house helps and drivers about the virus. While Sardar Patel Vidyalaya urged parents not to believe in rumours, it also requested them to keep the authorities informed if their child was suffering from cold and cough. The school, in a note, stated: ‚ÄúEven if any other member of the family has such symptoms, please do inform the vidyalaya so that appropriate preventive measures can immediately be taken at this end.‚ÄùApart from general guidelines, the schools have suggested that consumption of raw and undercooked meats be avoided. ‚ÄúAvoid crowded public places and close contact with people who are unwell or showing symptoms of illness. Practice frequent hand washing with soap and good personal hygiene. Wear a mask if you have respiratory symptoms, such as a cough or runny nose,‚Äù a note by another school stated. It also mentioned that masks neither guaranteed prevention of the spread of coronavirus nor were they an alternative to quarantine. Tania Joshi, principal of Indian School, said: ‚ÄúWe have put up an advisory on our website. We have also sent an advisory to the parents and told the children about the precautions that need to be taken.‚ÄùMany parents, themselves, are taking no chances at their end. ‚ÄúIt is difficult to ascertain who is affected by the virus. So, I am not letting my son go out and play. Avoiding crowded spaces is important,‚Äù said Pratima, whose child studies in a private school in east Delhi.

Title: We are doing our job very honestly, says ACB‚Äôs affidavit in irri scam PIL
Content:
Nagpur: The state‚Äôs anti-corruption bureau (ACB) in an affidavit has said that the agency has been doing its job honestly and so, there‚Äôs no need to hand over the probe into the alleged irrigation scam to any other agency.

The affidavit that was filed in response to a PIL by activist Atul Jagtap seeking transfer of the investigation in the case to CBI, says adding new respondents and handing over the probe to any other agency will only hamper the pace of the investigations.

The ACB has stressed that it will be conducting the inquiries entrusted to it diligently and so there is no need to transfer the case anywhere else.

The PIL was filed after the ACB had filed an affidavit giving a clean chit to NCP leader Ajit Pawar who was the deputy chief minister in the then Congress-NCP government during whose tenure the alleged irregularities took place. Later, Pawar once again took over as the deputy chief minister in the MVA government.

The case is being heard by the Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court. The PIL has also sought to make central agencies like the CBI, ED, and SFIO as the respondents in the case. However, the court had also rejected the plea for addition of parties in the matter on a temporary basis. The next hearing in which the inclusion of other agencies will also be heard is slated for March 13.

The ACB affidavit says that the special investigation teams (SITs) formed by the bureau have made substantial progress. The agency has progressed a way long in the case and adding new respondents and handing over the case to any other agency will only hamper the pace of investigations.

The Amravati unit filed 12 offences, while the Nagpur unit registered 27. At the same time, open inquiries of 15 projects have been completed and closed as no criminal offence was found, said the affidavit.

The affidavits said the investigators have also shown honest endeavour considering the voluminous documents to be scrutinized and statements to be recorded. The cases are being investigated by the Amravati and Nagpur units of ACB.

The Nagpur ACB is investigating the contracts given for Gosikhurd projects. Investigations by the Amravati ACB cover the Jigaon dam in Buldhana district apart from the Lower Pedhi, Raigargh and Wadhadi projects in Amravati district.

Title: Afcons gets 2nd penalty notice of Rs245cr in excavation case
Content:
Nagpur: Wardha district administration has served second penalty notice of Rs244.64 crore to Mumbai-based Afcons Infrastructure Limited for excavating murrum without permission from 22 land parcels in Selu tehsil for construction of Samruddhi Mahamarg. With earlier penalty of Rs238.99 crore, the total amount goes up to Rs483.63 crore if the latest penalty is confirmed.

Selu tehsildar Mahendra Sonone served a show cause notice to projects manager of Afcons asking why penalty of Rs244.64 crore should not be recovered. ‚ÄúSubmit reply to the notice within 15 days. Order will be passed and penalty amount will be recovered forcefully in case no reply is given in time period,‚Äù Sonone said.

In similar case of Hyderabad-based Cozy Properties, Sonone had first served show cause notice and then finalized the same penalty amount rejecting the reply filed by Afcons, citing various reasons already in the notice.

TOI had, in August last year, exposed excavation of murrum by Afcons and its petty contractors for construction of Nagpur-Mumbai Samruddhi Mahamarg without permission from land owned by Cozy Properties, other private persons and zudpi jungle, hillock owned by government, forest land under forest department, Digras lake and extra excavation from Bor river at mouza Charmandal, Kotumba, Itala and Ganeshpur.

Wardha district administration had conducted preliminary survey in August and served notices to Afcons in September. But penalty was not levied in case of land owned by government and private parties other than Cozy Properties.

TOI had sought statements from Wardha collector Vivek Bhimanwar and sub divisional officer Suresh Bhoyar on Sunday and Monday. TOI had highlighted that no action has been taken despite passing of six months.

Sonone issued show cause notice to Afcons on Monday. The notice dated February 20 was issued a day ago, as TOI has copy of the letter with received date of Monday by Afcons. This shows notice was ready but issued only after TOI report.

Also, MLC Girish Vyas had submitted LAQ on this topic in ongoing budget session.

An Afcons spokesperson told TOI, ‚ÄúAfcons denies any illegal excavation of murrum in the survey areas referred to in the show-cause notice. It may also be noted that similar issue is sub judice before Nagpur bench of Bombay high court, wherein the HC had granted stay in favour of Afcons. Afcons shall take necessary steps in response to the show cause notice in due course.‚Äù

Though Sonone mentioned excavation of murrum without permission in 24 land parcels, penalty has been calculated for only 22. Two excluded land parcels are khasra no-7 of mouza Itala, which is reserved for zudpi jungle, and khasra no. 65 of mouza Giroli, which is hillock. These two land parcels are owned by the state government.

In September last year, Sonone had also confirmed excavation in these two land parcels in notice issued on the basis of preliminary survey.

TOI had also reported excavation of murrum without permission from forest land with khasra no. 206 of mouza Kotumba quoting activists from Kotumba. However, there is no mention about this land in notice.

Bhoyar said, ‚ÄúSurvey through electronic total station (ETS) system is pending on land parcels ‚Äî khasra no. 7 of Itala and khasra no. 65 of Giroli, so penalty amount is yet to be calculated. Appropriate action will also be taken in these two land parcels and remaining ones soon,‚Äù he said.

Penalty amount will increase if charges are also fixed in remaining land parcels.

However, Wardha district administration is yet to register any case with the police in all these cases. In case of Cozy Properties, Selu police had registered the case and also arrested the concerned persons.

Of total 25 land parcels, 22 are owned by private persons and remaining three by government. There is ban on giving lease of government land. Also, permissions are not given on zudpi and forest lands, and any excavation attracts charges of Forest Conservation Act.

Title: Intern doctors attack junior clerk at SSH
Content:
Nagpur: A group of five or six interns (MBBS graduates pursuing internships) at Government Medical College Hospital (GMCH) allegedly assaulted a junior clerk working at OPD registration window at the Super Specialty Hospital (SSH) on Tuesday afternoon. After sustaining minor injuries, 30-year-old Sharad Sable rushed to Ajni police station and submitted a written complaint against unidentified doctors. GMCH dean has constituted an internal committee to probe the matter.

‚ÄúI was working on a OPD window reserved for government staffers and senior citizens. An intern doctor from GMCH brought his mother to the hospital at around 10.15am, and insisted that I should register her at my counter. As her card was of general category, I asked him to get her registered at the general window. This enraged the intern, and he threatened me with dire consequences,‚Äù said Sable.

At around 1pm, when the OPD registration closed, the same doctor came back to SSH with four or five friends.

‚ÄúThey shouted at me, pulled me out of the registration counter, and one of them slapped me on the face. They tried to assault me but I was saved by fellow staffers and people around. They ran away when other staff members came to my help,‚Äù he said.

Sable claimed he does not know these doctors by name but he noted the registration numbers of their bikes when they were moving out of SSH premises.

The association of medical college employees has decided to gherao the dean‚Äôs office on Wednesday. Trisharan Sahare, president of the Vidarbha Medical and Health staffers‚Äô Association, said they will resort to strike if intern doctors responsible for this attack are not punished.

‚ÄúClass IV employees will go on strike from 10am on Wednesday and we won‚Äôt resume work unless the administration takes action against the culprit doctors. No one can assault government staffers who work for patients,‚Äù he said.

Dean Dr Sajal Mitra said an internal committee has been constituted to investigate the matter and those who attacked the staffer will face action.

Title: Waiving dead farmers‚Äô dues helps heirs get loans
Content:
Nagpur: The state‚Äôs loan waiver scheme helps banks recover pending dues of the farmers‚Äô no longer alive. In the first list of eligible farmers released in Nagpur division , there were at least seven persons who are no more. Four were from in Wardha and three from Nagpur, said sources.

As the case was referred to higher ups by the district officers, it was clarified that the legal heirs of the farmers could register themselves. The dead borrower‚Äôs Aadhaar number will be replaced by that of the heirs. After that, the amount will be repaid to the bank by state government, said a source.

This will help the survivors clear the charge on the land they inherit. However, it will not bring any cash benefit to the relatives because the amount will directly go to the bank. The process has nothing to do with the inheritance of the property either, said an officer handling the waiver cases.

Once the list is out and the borrower is dead, the legal heirs can report the matter and replace the Aadhaar number so the amount is credited to the loan account. The provision was there in the waiver scheme of previous government too.

The MVA scheme covers loans up to Rs2 lakh. On the basis of the first list, farmer will have to provide biometric matching for their Aadhaar numbers provided to the bank. Aadhaar is taken at the time of granting loans as a part of know your customer (KYC) norms, said a source.

In the scheme launched during BJP regime, the farmer was suspposed to apply for the waiver. In case the borrower had died, the heirs could apply on the person‚Äôs behalf after going through the verification process, an official said. BJP scheme waived loans upto Rs 1.5 lakh and there was a one time settlement scheme for higher amounts.

In the Nagpur division data for over 2.4 lakh farmers‚Äô loan accounts where repayment is due have been uploaded in the system. Of these, Aadhaar verification has happened in more than 40,000 accounts.

Title: 69 candidates file ZP papers on Day 5
Content:
Valpoi/Quepem/Bicholim: Sixty nine nomination papers were filed on Tuesday for the March 22 general elections to zilla panchayats in the state.

Officials of the state election commission (SEC) said that 45 nominations were received for the North Goa zilla panchayat and 24 candidates for South Goa . With this, the total number of nominations received by SEC is 87.

On Tuesday, the highest number of five nominations were filed from Mayem constituency in North Goa. Three nominations were filed at Cola constituency in the southern district.

BJP filed eight nominations on Tuesday taking their number so far to 39. So far the ruling party has nominated 16 in south Goa and 23 in North Goa. Chief minister Pramod Sawant said that BJP will contest in 43 constituencies out of the 50 seats at stake for the polls, which are being held on political lines.

Brezy Barreto, a close supporter of Nuvem MLA Wilfred D‚ÄôSa filed his nomination papers as an ‚Äúindependent‚Äù from Nuvem ZP constituency. D'Sa is among the ten Congress MLAs who joined the BJP in July last

In Sanguem, Sandesh Shashikant Gaonkar, brother of Sanguem MLA Prasad Gaonkar also entered the fray as he filed his nomination papers for the Barcem constituency, accompanied by his brother.

Khushali Jorgo Velip, a two-time ZP who fought his earlier elections as a Congress candidate filed his nomination for the Barcem constituency for the BJP . He was accompanied by Quepem MLA and deputy chief minister Chandrakant Kavalekar along with QMC chairperson Dayesh Naik and other BJP supporters.

After filing the nomination papers, Kavlekar said that BJP workers, including former Congress supporters who joined BJP along with him, would elect Velip with a thumping majority.

The BJP candidates were accompanied by CM Pramod Sawant and BJP functionaries while filing their papers. Congress candidates were accompanied by party president Girish Chodankar.

Title: At 61, Everest trek provides life lesson
Content:
My love for the mountains took me on a gruelling hike to the base of the world‚Äôs highest peak - Mount Everest. And the experience was nothing short of life changing.

Reaching an altitude of 5,545 meters in two weeks was a challenge for a novice like me. The trek was scheduled for May 2012 and my training started three months before that. I brisk-walked for nearly two hours daily and a month before the trek, I started walking in my new trekking shoes with a back pack with nearly 3 kg weight.

The average age of the 14 trekkers in our group was 25. Only my friends and I were above the age of 50. And at 61, I was the one with most life experiences to share and the most excited to make new memories.

The group met in Kathmandu and flew to a small village named Lukla. We had to trek for nearly four hours from the airport to reach our night halt. I fell sick on the second day but luckily for me,this happened on our altitude acclimatisation day and I soon got better.

By the third day, I felt that the air was becoming thinner and I needed to activate all my senses to stay focused. I think my sudarshan kriya ( breathing exercises),which I practised every morning before starting for the trek, came to my aid.

But the more I progress I made on the trek, the more confident I became. My boots felt more comfortable, my bag felt lighter. The lovely weather, incredible views of snow-capped mountains and beautiful flower filled valley gave us all strength.

The journey was demanding in many ways, we walked across 100-feet high suspension bridges made of mostly rope, stayed in quaint tea houses. Sometimes we had to climb up 7-8 storeys to reach our rooms which seemed to be an steep task after a 9-10 hour long hike. The cold was excruciating, and sometimes drinking water would harden up into ice.

But the pros far outnumber the cons. It snowed on the seventh day, adding beauty to our trek. But when the sun came out, the ice hardened and it became slippery. making the hike significantly tougher. When we reached Gorakshep, just one stop short of our final destination, some of us started doubt if we would be able to make the last stretch.

Both my friends decided they couldn‚Äôt do it. I realised then that I would have to rely on my mental strength to make it through the last stretch and that our mental strength was more important that our physical prowess.

The climb to the Gorakshep was very steep and I slipped, but was saved by a fellow trekker. With nothing more to stop me, I made it to the Everest base camp . It was an incredible moment and I felt like I was on top of the world. Through this journey, I felt closer to nature and God, and the beauty of the world left me humbled.

(The writer is a home-maker)

Title: Caught on cameras: Just 24,000 traffic challans in six months in Delhi
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

NEW DELHI: The Delhi traffic police have issued only 21,406 notices for red light, stop line , driving against flow of traffic and speeding violations caught by cameras in the capital in the past six months since the amended Motor Vehicle Act came into force. On the contrary, the number of notices issued for such violations captured by such cameras was as high as 24.36 lakh during the previous seven months, which comes to over 3.48 lakh challans issued every month.

In a written reply, MoS (home affairs) G Kishan Reddy indicated how the number of challans issued has been impacted as the Delhi government has not yet authorised traffic police to compound the challan amount, which is necessary under the amended MV law.

As per the new system (detection of violations by cameras), notices were sent by Delhi Police electronically through SMS to the violators and e-payment gateway facility was given for depositing the challan amount. However, after the notification of the amended MV Act with effect from September 1, 2019, the process had to be stopped since traffic personnel of Delhi Police have not been authorised to compound the challan amount by the Delhi government, Reddy said.

Compounding offences are those for which a spot fine is allowed and the driver doesn‚Äôt need to visit a court. The violator can pay the fine to the designated official after the respective state governments notify such officers.

The Act says offences under 24 categories can be compounded at any stage which include not having PUC, not wearing seatbelt or helmet, driving without licence or insurance, honking in silent zones. For these, the respective state government can notify its own quantum of fine and other penalties within the range which have been provided in the MV Act.

Title: EU lawmakers support PM Narendra Modi‚Äôs efforts to tackle cross-LoC terror
Content:
SWITZERLAND: Members of the European Parliament have backed PM Narendra Modi ‚Äôs efforts in defeating cross-border terrorism, and rejected Pakistan‚Äôs narrative on the Kashmir issue following the Indian government‚Äôs move to abrogate Article 370 of the Constitution.

The discussion in this regard took place at an event held at Geneva Press Club on Monday to discuss and assess the situation in Kashmir after the abrogation of Article 370. Gianna Gancia, a member of the European Parliament, criticised Pakistan for portraying a picture of crisis in Kashmir on the international platforms.

Nathan Gill, a former member of the European Parliament and member of the Brexit party of Britain said, ‚ÄúWhat right has Pakistan to discuss the internal affairs of India on International fora? No one makes hue and cry when France fights radical terrorism but creates so much panic and tension when India does something which is solely and wholly an internal matter of India.‚Äù

Tehmeena Syed, a women rights‚Äô activist from Kashmir said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm coming from a world which is known as paradise.‚Äù She added that this ‚Äúparadise‚Äù was destroyed by the insurgencies, and ‚Äúthe abrogation of Article 370 was undeniable need of the hour to get rid of cross-border terrorism and insurgencies in Kashmir‚Äù. Brian Toll, expert on South Asia from European Commission and Paulo Casaca, executive director, South Asia Democratic Forum, said after the decades of ongoing instability and terrorist incidents in J&K, the Indian government abrogated Article 370 to bring peace and prosperity in the region. President of Gilgit Baltistan Studies, Senge Sering, supported India‚Äôs decision on acting against the factors that destabilise Jammu and Kashmir.

Title: AMC launches mega drive against illegal hoardings after HC order
Content:
Aurangabad: A day after the Aurangabad Bench of the Bombay High Court issued directives to the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) commissioner to remove illegal hoardings in the city, the civic body has initiated a drive on Tuesday.

The drive that began from the market areas of Gulmandi was extended to all parts of the city.

The order in this regard was issued by the court on Monday. The bench comprising justice ZA Haq and justice SM Gavhane had asked the municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey to file an affidavit in the court stating as to how many illegal hoardings are removed till March 5.

The affidavit should contain details about the losses caused to the civic body by those whose illegal hoardings will be removed over the three day period and the amount spent for the removal of the hoardings, the order states. If the affidavit is not filed before 10.30am on March 6, the municipal commissioner should remain present before the court, the order adds.

The order was issued during the hearing of a 2013 intervention application filed by NGO Jagruti Mahila Manch Bahuddeshiya Sanstha in 2011 suo-moto Public Interest Litigation (PIL) against illegal hoardings in the city.

Subsequently, the civic body started its drive against illegal hoardings, banners, flexes in all areas of the city on the direction of Pandey. The drive started from Gulmandi and Paithan Gate where big and small hoardings of political figures, commercial advertisements and others were removed. Simultaneously, the drive was carried out in different areas of the city. The drive continued from 10 am to 5 pm. The Civic officials said that the drive will continue over the coming days.

AMC under fire for Swachh Bharat hoardings

In a failure to set an example for putting up hoardings according to rules, the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has put up ‚ÄòSwachh Bharat‚Äô hoardings on roadsides and squares in different parts of the city, including the irrigation office on Jalna Road and TV Centre. When asked, mayor Nandkumar Ghodele said that municipal corporation should be setting an example in the matter, adding that orders have already been issued for the removal of hoardings.

Title: Gondia govt hosp ‚Äòborrows‚Äô 21 teachers from city GMCs
Content:
Nagpur: The state directorate for medical education and research (DMER) has ordered two government medical colleges (GMCs) in the city to relieve 21 academicians ‚Äî professors, associate professors and assistant professors ‚Äî immediately and directed them to join government medical college hospital (GMCH) in Gondia.

As per the DMER order, these teachers will be posted in Gondia on ‚Äòdeputation‚Äô to cover-up more than 20% deficiency of faculty in the college. According to MCI rules, if the faculty deficiency is more than 20% in an institute, then it is not considered for the renewal of admissions. Thus, the DMER did the patchwork so that Gondia GMCH would not lose its 100 MBBS first year seats for the year 2020-21. The college is scheduled to face a compliance inspection of the MCI in a few days.

Director of DMER, Dr TP Lahane, said that the teachers have been transferred on deputation only from those departments that have enough number of faculties.

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt lose 100 MBBS seats of Gondia GMCH just like that. It‚Äôs a responsibility of all academicians to accept postings on deputation and work in Gondia during this period. It‚Äôs a temporary arrangement and teachers will be brought back when others will be available,‚Äù he said adding that those who refuse these deputation orders will face action.

Generally, such midterm transfers, effected in view of upcoming MCI inspection, are temporary. Even DMER order has clear mention that salaries and allowances of these teachers will be paid by their original institutions only. Earlier too, similar arrangement was done in 2017 and 2018.

The list of teachers transferred include 19 academicians from GMCH and two from IGGMCH. Following DMER order, both medical colleges have issued office orders to their respective professors to join Gondia GMCH by handing over charge to the seniors. Out of 19 names of GMCH, the dean has issued transfer orders to 17 teachers. Orders for others will be issued soon.

DMER‚Äôs PATCHWORK

Four-year-old Gondia GMCH received show cause notice from MCI on February 17

MCI found 29 major flaws during physical and academic inspection of the college

College is facing 20.75% deficiency of faculty and 46.77% deficiency of residents

According to MCI, such institute is not considered for renewal of admissions

Fearing loss of renewal of 100 MBBS seats, DMER swung into action on February 27

21 teachers from GMCH and IGGMCH in Nagpur were ordered to join Gondia GMCH

Title: On WGSHA students‚Äô menu ‚Äî jackfruit sausages
Content:
WGSHA (Manipa) students Sahil Joshi, Sanjana Apte, Pradyumn Nayak, Shaun D‚ÄôSillva and Noah George are working ... Read More

Mangaluru: Students from Welcomgroup Graduate School of Hotel Administration (WGSHA, Manipal), are working on the commercial launch of ‚ÄòJackwurst- better off the meat curse‚Äô. There is an increase in the number of people cutting down on meat/ dairy and going vegan. This has inspired a group of five students to experiment on sausages from raw jackfruit .

Sanjana Apte, final year degree student at WGSHA, said their aim is to work on a product that is unique and has a universal appeal. ‚ÄúRaw jackfruit is a popular food used extensively by generations owing to its health benefits. Since jackfruit is a superfood and a lot of people are going vegetarian these days, we decided to develop a unique dish. Researchers worldwide are exploring its health benefits. So far, not many chefs have experimented with jackfruit sausages in India,‚Äù she claimed.

The team of Sanjana, Sahil Joshi, Shaun D‚ÄôSilva, Noah George and Pradyumn Nayak is mentored by chefs Dayanand Prabhu and Partho Pratham Seal, and supported by their HoD, chef Vasanthan Sigamany, and principal, chef Thirugnanasambantham.

Speaking on the sausage recipe, Sanjana said the star of the dish is raw jackfruit and vital wheat gluten powder. Raw jackfruit is cured with lemon juice, steamed and ingredients are added to it. The team has used cellulose casing. ‚ÄúThe dish has received positive reviews and we will soon be sending the samples to the microbiology lab and discuss ways to increase its shelf life and to assess its nutritional value. Trials are happening simultaneously. In about two months, we are hoping to launch the product commercially,‚Äù she added.

Jackwurst received special mention at the innovation festival of Manipal Academy of Higher Education (MAHE) that concluded on Saturday.

Title: Surat diamond polisher‚Äôs priceless gift to child battling for life in Mumbai
Content: SURAT: Polishing stones to a sparkle for years now, this 25-year-old owner of a diamond polishing unit from Surat has turned into a rare diamond himself. Bhautik Moradiya‚Äôs donation of stem cells towards saving the life of a 14-year-old child, who is diagnosed with fatal disorder, is priceless.‚ÄúI feel humbled to be able to save one‚Äôs life,‚Äù said Moradiya, who got himself registered as a potential donor in 2016 with DATRI. He donated his blood stem cell in Ahmedabad on Tuesday for the child who is admitted to a hospital in Maharashtra.Moradiya had given a cheek swab at the country‚Äôs biggest adult unrelated blood stem cell donors for registration as a life saver in a million, said that he was overjoyed to receive a call on Monday telling him his stem cell matched with a child‚Äôs.‚ÄúI consulted my parents who encouraged me to go ahead and donate my blood stem cell and save the child who‚Äôs fighting for his life,‚Äù said Moradiya, while talking to TOI.The native of Ugamedi village in Botad district owns a diamond unit in Surat.‚ÄúThe probability of finding a matched donor is only 1 in 10,000 to 1 in over a million,‚Äù explained Jalpa Sukhanandi, Region Head, (Gujarat), DATRI.With such low probability, it is necessary to have a large database of willing blood stem cell donors and donors like Moradiya are life saviours, she said.‚ÄúAn estimate states that by 2020, as many as 1,32,574 cases of blood cancer are expected to be reported every year. Every year thousands of lives are lost due to unavailability of potential donors. Looking at how precious this donation is, Surtis have done exceptional work to set an example,‚Äù Sukhanandi added.

Title: Drunk youth stones grandma to death
Content:
Nagpur: A 20-year-old drunk youth has stoned his 70-year-old grandmother to death following a quarrel in their hut in the wee hours of Tuesday at Manavta Nagar slums. The deceased has been identified as Raulabai Ganvir.

Gittikhadan police, under senior PI Sunil Gangurde, have registered a case of murder against the accused, Lucky, following a complaint from his mother Sarita. They also arrested Lucky within an hour after the incident came to light.

According to police, Lucky used to live with his parents, a younger sister and his grandmother. The sister wanted to get married with a man and entire family was ready for the match, except Lucky. On Sunday, a major fight broke out at the house over marriage proposal.

Police said even earlier Lucky, who worked at a vegetable shop, used to beat up his sister as he did not like her talking with another person. Following the fight, Sarita and her daughter left the house and went to a relative‚Äôs house. On Monday night, Lucky came home drunk when Raulabai was alone.

Raulabai tried to talk to him about his sister‚Äôs wedding. However, Lucky got angry and began a quarrel with his grandmother. In a fit of anger, Lucky brought a big stone from the outside and smashed Raulabai‚Äôs head with it.

The neighbours heard the ruckus and called police control room. Gittikhadan police rushed to the spot and arrested Lucky who was standing among the crowd. Cops sent the body of Raulabai to Mayo hospital where post mortem was conducted on Tuesday and the body was handed over to family members.

Police have also seized the stone used in the crime from the spot. Lucky was produced before a court on Tuesday and sent to police custody till February 6.

Sources said the Raulabai had taken care of Lucky and his sister since they were children.

Title: Gold coins recovered from Trichy temple date to 18th Century
Content:
The coins were unearthed from a depth of about 7 feet during restoration work at the Akilandeswari Jambukeswar... Read More

TRICHY: The treasure trove of 505 gold coins depicting Hindu deities and Persian letters unearthed last week from a temple in Trichy dates to the 18th Century of Hyder Ali‚Äôs rule in the kingdom of Mysore. While it was speculated to be from the Chola period, state archaeology department officials said the hundial unearthed had four different types of gold coins, all belonging to 18th century.

The coins were unearthed from a depth of about 7 feet during restoration work at the Akilandeswari Jambukeswarar temple in Thiruvanaikaval. T Thangadurai, archaeological officer, department of archaeology, who studied the coins, has submitted a report to T Udhayachandran, principal secretary and commissioner, on the findings.

‚ÄòDutch Pagoda‚Äô (Varahan), also known as Pagoda, a unit of currency, was one type of coins recovered from the hundial. Thangadurai said there were a total of 493 of them depicting the deity Vishnu on one side and random dots on the other. Besides this, Star Pagoda coins (10 numbers), also known as British pagoda, were in the hundial released by Britishers. They depicted a half-figure of Vishnu on one side and a star symbol on the other, he said.

‚ÄòHyder Ali 4 pagoda‚Äô was the rare finding among other coins in the hundial, said A Seetharaman, a noted numismatist in Thanjavur. He said only one Hyder Ali 4 pagoda coin was found in the hundial which cannot be found even in Mysore. Weighing about 10-11 grams, it has Hyder Ali‚Äôs name on both sides in Persian. Unlike the other coins, the market value of this one could be more than Rs 1 lakh. Another type of coin was ‚ÄòHyder Ali 1 Pagoda‚Äô depicting Siva-Parvathi in seating position and his name on the other side. One such coin weighing about 3-3.5 grams was recovered from the hundial, he said. Author of 33 books on numismatics, Seetharaman said that similar hundials have been used right from Chola period but this one belongs to 18th century.

Asked how coins with Hindu deity were brought out by a Muslim ruler, Thangadurai said they were released as a continuation from the Arcot Nawab in 16th century and Vijayanagar kingdom of 14th century. It was then a traditional practice to acknowledge the sentiments of Hindus.

However, Thangadurai said it is difficult to conclude as to how these coins were buried in this place. Unlike an archaeological excavation where related evidence will be available, the place where the coins were found would have been dug up on several occasions. These coins will be kept in the government museum in Chennai for display after the museum department takes their custody under Indian Treasure Trove Act, 1878.

Title: Sushmita Sen and her beau Rohman Shawl pose for adorable pictures as they step out in the city!
Content: Vidya Balan is all set to kick-start shooting of her upcoming film, ‚ÄòSherni‚Äô in Balaghat, Madhya Pradesh by the last week of October. The makers have roped in a special agency to monitor safety norms on the set amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

Title: After students raise issue, NU says reval fee refund from summer
Content:
Nagpur: A day after a group of students led by Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) included refund of revaluation fee in their list of demands, Nagpur University (NU) announced that a decision would be taken soon on the issue. This is perhaps the first time a students group has included the demand in its memorandum.

Vice-chancellor SP Kane told TOI, ‚ÄúThe modalities have been completed and the scheme would be started from this summer exam. Students will get forms having relevant columns for the refund. Those who have paid the fee since 2016 too would be eligible for refunds.‚Äù

Though the announcement was made in 2016, the scheme never saw the light of the day as NU did little to initiate the process or create awareness about the issue. Since NU never issued any communication in this regard, students were unaware of the decision.

Of late, several queries were posed by Senate members and media too raised the issue. Some students decided to include it in their list of demands and submit it to the VC. Kane assured them that the facility will be made available to not just them but also those from 2016 onwards.

TOI had reported about the VC‚Äôs move in January. But NU refused to divulge any information about it during last Friday‚Äôs Senate meeting.

Acting Pro-VC Vinayak Deshpande said the committee set up to study the issue submitted its report recently and therefore queries regarding it were not entertained. The committee led by the Pro-VC comprised registrar, finance and accounts officer, and director of examinations and evaluation.

‚ÄúThe report would be put before the management council. A finance committee too has been formed as the move will result in loss of revenue. Unless sanctioned by the council and the finance section, the scheme can‚Äôt be implemented,‚Äù Deshpande said.

The acting Pro-VC said as per the panel‚Äôs recommendation the change in marks has to be more than 5%. Earlier it was 10%. The panel has also recommended deduction of 25% as administrative expenses, which means eligible students are likely to get around 75% refund of the revaluation fee.

There is also some confusion regarding the period of implementation. The panel hasn‚Äôt recommended retrospective implementation while the VC has been assuring that it will be done from 2016 onwards.

‚ÄúUltimately, it will be the management council and VC‚Äôs decision. The report is not final,‚Äù Deshpande said.

OTHER DEMANDS BY ABVP

* Appointment of full-time principals and teachers

* Expediting inquiries and making them public

* Setting up sanitary pad vending machines

* Timely payment of teachers working on clock-hour basis

* Timely payment of students in earn and learn scheme

Title: NMC staffer dismissed in bogus appointments case
Content:
Nagpur: Within a span of 18 days, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has dismissed third employee from service. The latest action is related to bogus appointments scam unearthed in the civic body in 2013.

Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe on Tuesday dismissed Class III employee Jyotsana Bhivgade, working as property tax collector in the NMC‚Äôs Mangalwari zone, after departmental inquiry found her guilty in the scam.

An NMC official told TOI that Bhivgade had given fake appointment letters to three persons in 2013. ‚ÄúBhivgade was working with the NMC‚Äôs general administration department (GAD) then. When the three persons reached NMC‚Äôs property tax department with the ‚Äúappointment letters‚Äù to join duty, a clerk raised suspicion and alerted property tax superintendent. The superintendent inquired with the GAD only to know that the three appointment letters were fake,‚Äù he said.

The matter was reported to Sadar police who had registered a case and arrested Bhivgade and a Class IV employee Sadanand Janbandhu. NMC also initiated department inquiry and the two were suspended.
