At around 9am, when Shahu‚Äôs brother-in-law reached the flat, he knocked and got no response. He then left, assuming that they were sleeping. The owner of the flat also came and he too got no response. A neighbour then showed the owner where the Dhumales usually hung the keys of the flat outside the door. The owner used those keys to open the door, only to find Shahu hanging in the living room.

Police said that the owner then informed the police. When cops reached the site, they found Shahu hanging, and three other bodies in the bedroom. All four bodies were shifted to Goa Medical College for a postmortem examination. Colaco said that there were no external injuries on the bodies of the wife and children.

In his diary, Shahu wrote about how despite his best efforts, he hadn‚Äôt become successful, because of which he had to take drastic steps.

Police said that Shahu had purchased the flat but wasn‚Äôt in a position to repay the bank loan.Shahu then sold the flat and repaid the loans, cops said.

However, he has mentioned that he was unable to pay a bank loan indicating that he was under pressure due to the mounting debt. There was correspondence between him and the bank, police said. Hence, police are looking at the financial angle leading to the deaths.

As there is no witness in the case, it is not clear what may have really happened and how they died. The police are analysing the material on record and will wait for the post mortem report to piece together the circumstances for clarity in the mysterious death case.

Police said that would call family members of the deceased and question them to find the exact cause of death. Shahu‚Äôs sister, who is in Goa, is in a state of shock, police said.

Title: Agra shoe barons, kin queue up at district hospital for coronavirus screening
Content:
People waiting outside the isolation ward of the district hospital in Agra on Tuesday

AGRA: People in Range Rovers seldom come to a district government hospital. But Tuesday was different when Covid-19 scare proved to be an equalizer of sorts. Agra leather exporters‚Äô fraternity and their relatives descended on the district hospital premises in their premium SUVs on Tuesday to get themselves screened for coronavirus.

Health department officials tried to calm down the panicking people outside the isolation ward as at least 50 shoe exporters and their family members queued up outside the premises.

A shoe exporter, who had come with his wife and two kids wearing N-95 masks, said ‚ÄúLast month, my family and I had visited Italy to attend a leather trade fair. Following reports of the spread of coronavirus in Italy and now in India, we have come for a medical examination. We have given our blood and throat swab samples for tests. Hospital authorities have told us that the medical report will come after 48 hours.‚Äù

Puran Dawar, president of the Agra Footwear Manufacturer and Exporters Chamber (AFMEC), said, ‚ÄúThere were four major shoe and leather component trade fairs in Italy from February 17 to 22. Over 45 shoe exporters had gone to attend these fairs. Some of them travelled with their family members and staff. They all returned in the last week of February. Following reports of coronavirus positive cases linked to Italy which were found in India, we have requested all the exporters who have recently visited abroad to get themselves screened. I sent my own son, who was also in Italy recently, to the district hospital. For now, there is nothing to panic. We need to be alert and follow government advisory.‚Äù

Satish Verma, superintendent in charge of the district hospital, said, ‚ÄúOn Tuesday, we collected nasal, oral and blood samples of 35 people from the leather exporters‚Äô fraternity having foreign travel history. The process will be continued on Wednesday. The samples have been sent to Lucknow and reports are likely to be received between 48 and 72 hours.‚Äù

Chief medical officer Mukesh Kumar Vats said, ‚ÄúWe have already constituted a 10-bed isolation ward at the district hospital and SN Medical College. Besides, a Rapid Response Team has been formed to tackle the situation and ambulances to transport suspected patients.‚Äù

Meanwhile, a high-level team of National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) inspected the district hospital to check all the arrangements. District magistrate PN Singh also chaired a meeting of the CMO and other health officials to ensure required arrangements are in place to deal with any emergency.

Title: Timely precautions can avert birth defects, say doctors
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: India is the second most populous country to have a large number of infants born with birth defects, which can be prevented through timely precautions. Preconception counselling, discouraging pregnancy after 35 years to minimize chromosomal birth defects, vaccination against viral infections like Rubella and restricting smoking, alcohol and tobacco are some of these preventive methods, says the Birth Defects Registry of India (BDRI).

March 3 is being observed as world birth defects awareness day since 2015 to create awareness on this. BDRI Madurai representative Dr Revathi Janakiram said 1.7 million children are born with birth defects annually. Congenital disorders are also known to be associated with stillbirth and prematurity, which can lead to infant mortality. Increased maternal age at conception was one reason for birth defects in infants. Other causes include chronic medical disorders like diabetes, genetic defects and exposure to teratogens like smoking, alcohol, tobacco, recreational drugs and radiation as well as consanguinity. Maternal deficiencies of folic acid, iodine, macro and micro nutrients could also lead to these defects.

Some medicines consumed for high BP and epilepsy may cause defects in the foetus and the mother should change to safer drugs by consulting a doctor before planning pregnancy. Any medication during pregnancy, especially in the first 12 weeks, must be taken only after consulting the specialist, she said.

Brain growth starts very early and hence starting folic acid at 40 microgram a day at least a month before pregnancy and continuing up to 12 weeks will help prevent neural tube defects. ``In fact it has another name called ‚Äòengagement pill‚Äô as it is recommended that a mother have it from her engagement,‚Äô‚Äô she said. Folic acid and B12 prevent up to 70 % cases of neural tube defects like spina bifida, cleft lip and cleft palate.

Santhini (name changed), mother of a 16-year-old boy with down‚Äôs syndrome, says she never had counselling when she was pregnant. ``It is heartbreaking to see my son suffer. I would have been grateful if I had the opportunity to put him out of his misery before he was born,‚Äô‚Äô she said adding that her son‚Äôs birth discouraged her from wanting more children. Head of the department of obstetrics and gynaecology at Government Rajaji Hospital Dr N Sumathy said they were maintaining a registry on birth defects in the hospital. Any mother who shows symptoms of defects in a child is counselled based on the type of anomaly, gestation age and severity.

Title: Year‚Äôs first thunderstorm catches Kolkata off guard
Content:
Kolkata: The year‚Äôs first thunderstorm struck Kolkata on Tuesday, leading to an intense shower in several parts of the city that lasted more than an hour. Some areas of north and east Kolkata received a hailstorm. There could be more such thunderstorms on Wednesday and on Thursday, predicted the Met office. Kolkata received 4.1mm rain till 8.30pm on Tuesday.

Even though rain and thunderstorms were predicted between Wednesday and Friday, they struck early, taking the city by surprise. Dark clouds started gathering around 5.30pm and within the next 15 minutes, the city was lashed by a downpour accompanied by frequent thunder and lightning. The intense spell caught those returning from work off guard.

A cyclonic circulation over Madhya Pradesh triggered the thunderstorm, according to the Regional Meteorological Centre (RMC). ‚ÄúIt received moisture from a high-pressure zone over Bay of Bengal. The system approached Bengal from the west, leading to thundershowers in the districts of Bankura, Purulia, Birbhum, East and West Midnapore in the morning. As the system moved east, it sailed across the other south Bengal districts triggering similar thunderstorms and rain later in the day,‚Äù said RMC director GK Das. East and West Burdwan, Howrah, Hooghly, Nadia, North and South 24 Parganas were lashed by thunderstorms as well.

Sudden bursts of rain and thunderstorm are set to continue over the next two days. A cyclonic circulation or a trough may develop over Jharkhand by Thursday. ‚ÄúIt may move southeast and travel across south Bengal, triggering rain. But the rain will be short and intense unlike the drizzles we have in winter. We have already had the first thunderstorm of the season and there will be more,‚Äù added Das. Kolkata recorded a maximum temperature of 31.3¬∞C on Tuesday.

The rain slowed down vehicle movement leading to traffic congestions across the city. Central Kolkata came to a virtual halt. EM Bypass, CR Avenue, JL Nehru Road, Vivekananda Road, APC Rod, AJC Bose Road, SN Banerjee Road, Lenin Sarani and Strand Road witnessed congestion through the evening.

‚ÄúThe Met office had predicted rain but I didn‚Äôt expect it to be so sharp. The downpour slowed down traffic in central Kolkata. It took me half an hour more to reach my Jadavpur home from my BBD Bag office,‚Äù said Shuvam Bera, a bank employee.

A tree got uprooted at Mahatma Gandhi Road while several more and a lamppost were collapsed near Nicco Park in Salt Lake. On February 18, the city had received several spells of light drizzle.

Title: At 79, LU‚Äôs historic Tagore Library celebrates memories of the Bard
Content:
Lucknow: Tagore Library at Lucknow University ‚Äî one of the oldest central research libraries in the country ‚Äî turns 79 on Wednesday. On the eve of its foundation day, TOI finds out how the iconic building was named after polymath and Nobel laureate Rabindranath Tagore.

According to documents, the foundation of the library was laid in 1937 and the facility that was inaugurated in 1941 was initially known as ‚ÄòLucknow University Library‚Äô. After Independence however, the building took its name after Gurudev to celebrate his bond with the varsity.

The first LU journal published in 1922 recorded Tagore‚Äôs visit to the campus. It stated that on March 6 that year, he delivered a lecture on the vision of India‚Äôs history at Bennett Hall (now Malviya Hall).

Not only did Tagore‚Äôs lectures echo on the university campus, some of his famous plays were also staged by students. ‚ÄòThe Waterfall‚Äô (originally Muktadhara), written in 1922 and widely acclaimed as one of Tagore‚Äôs finest dramatic works, was staged by the English department at Bennett Hall on January 25 that year. The symbolic play has been interpreted as his nationalist critique of colonial exploitation

Whenever the poet, musician and artist visited the LU campus, he stayed with English professor NK Siddhanta. He had a deep connect with Dhurjati Prasad Mukerji (Economics). In fact, Mukerji penned a couple of books on him too. ‚ÄòTagore: A Study‚Äô and ‚ÄòSur-o-Sangeet‚Äô, the latter in Bengali, sheds spotlight on their correspondence on music and art. Tagore also shared a special bond with LU sociology professor Radhakamal Mukerjee.

In November-December 1925, Tagore was on the campus to attend the All Indian Music Conference and listened to Pandit Srikrishna Narayan Ratanjankar, a distinguished scholar and teacher of Hindustani classical music who later served as the principal of Marris Music College (Now Bhatkhande Music Institute).

The visit finds a mention in the thesis of Professor Nupur Sen of LU‚Äôs education department. ‚ÄòA critical study of Rabindranath Tagore‚Äôs contributions to educational thoughts and practices‚Äô also mentions that he came to the campus yet again in February-March 1935 and delivered two lectures.

The paper states that to perpetuate the memory of Tagore‚Äôs visits to the campus, a special ceremony was organised to name the library after him.

Deputy librarian Jyoti Mishra told TOI that the library actually opened in 1921, but was initially housed in the main Canning College building, which now houses the faculty of arts.

As the library grew in size and turned home to rare tomes and manuscripts, the need for a separate building was felt. A new library project was chalked out and American landscape architect Walter Burley Griffin ‚Äî known better for designing Australian capital Canberra ‚Äî was hired for the job.

The foundation stone was laid by then Chancellor Sir Harry Haig on March 4, 1937, and the new building was inaugurated on April 2, 1941, by then Chancellor Governor Sir M Hallet.

Title: Nagpur Heroes is truly inspirational, say fans
Content:
The awards ceremony of Nagpur Heroes was well attended

The countdown for the most awaited and upcoming Nagpur Heroes has begun. Citizens as well as avid readers of TOI are excited. Some shared their experience of attending the programme and reading about the inspiring heroes.

Environmentalist Shrikant Deshpande remembered attending the function and shared his thoughts on how the TOI initiative is motivating budding social workers and professionals. ‚ÄúNagpur Heroes is an amazing initiative by TOI. I feel honoured that I got an opportunity to attend the event last year. This initiative is encouraging others to lend a helping hand to contribute for the development of our city.‚Äù he said.

Ravindra Fadnavis, who runs an educational institute, was all praise for this wonderful initiative. ‚ÄúThe newspaper had a lot of motivating profiles of the Nagpur Heroes. It was a source of inspiration for many. I would like to congratulate TOI for honouring and acknowledging the work of people who have contributed immensely in their respective fields.‚Äù he said.

Right from environment to education, readers enjoyed reading a potpourri of amazing profiles and some were fortunate enough to attend the awards ceremony.

‚ÄúThe message of Nagpur Heroes was loud and clear. The energy at the ceremony was amazing. Every nominee is a hero in his own way. It‚Äôs a great feeling to know that such extraordinary personalities reside in our city,‚Äù said Bilal Ahmed, a travel operator.

Secretary of Vidarbha Taxpayers‚Äô Association (VTA), Tejinder Singh Renu, was one of the attendees. He believes that the TOI initiative is motivating many, especially youths, to join social service, which is no less than nation building. ‚ÄúHeroic stories inspire citizens to contribute and not complain. My best wishes to the citizens and thanks to Team TOI for providing this fabulous opportunity to Nagpurians.‚Äù he said.

Vijay Kant Kumar, a TOI reader, also attended the awards ceremony. He has lauded the TOI initiative which is a great platform to acknowledge the selfless work done by all the nominees. ‚ÄúSuch programmes carry a deep message. It‚Äôs not only about a token of appreciation, but it‚Äôs a celebration of life, work and dedication. I had a wonderful time when I saw so many deserving people winning awards. I‚Äôm looking forward to this year‚Äôs ceremony.‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúApart from the routine news, reading a newspaper becomes more enriching when we go through profiles of heroes in the true sense of the word. Nagpur Heroes has a lot to offer in terms of social work and humanity in particular,‚Äù said Ayesha Mirza, a home maker.

Kaustav Chatterjee, founder of Green Vigil Foundation, is a regular at the Nagpur Heroes awards function. ‚ÄúNagpur Heroes is a truly transparent and unique awards ceremony. It is the right platform which recognizes the unsung heroes of the city. The curiosity begins immediately after the announcement. It peaks on the penultimate day with the nominees at par with each other. One can feel the buzz a fortnight before the finale. Even nominees feel like winners as getting nominated is a reward in itself,‚Äù he said.

Title: Boats supplied under ‚ÄòBlue Revolution‚Äô scheme are inferior: Rameswaram fishers
Content:
MADURAI: Fishermen from Rameswaram have petitioned the director of fisheries, G S Sameeran, about the inferior quality boats that were supplied to them under the visionary ‚ÄòBlue Revolution‚Äô scheme of the central government. The scheme, under the department of animal husbandry and dairying, aims at increasing fisheries production and productivity from aquaculture and fisheries resources.

General secretary of the Tamil Nadu - Pondicherry Fishermen ‚Äôs Federation, N J Bose said the scheme was an outstanding one which aimed at promoting and encouraging deep sea fishing. Fishermen are given a subsidy of Rs 40 lakh by the central government, Rs 16 lakh by the state government, while they had to contribute Rs 24 lakh to purchase a mechanised boat.

However, apart from the Rs 80 lakh for each boat, fishermen have to spend another Rs 50 lakh for infrastructure, nets, manpower etc. ‚ÄúThus, this is a scheme from which only rich fishermen can benefit, and the subsidy should be increased if all are to benefit,‚Äù he said.

So far, the fishermen from Rameswaram have been supplied with 22 boats, of which 16 are from the Cochin Shipping Yard .

Five of these boats had been fitted with inferior engines of 140 HP when an mechanised boat would require a 200 HP motor for smooth operations.

Those whose boats were fitted with the inferior motors were spending much on repair. John Keter, a fisherman who possessed one of these boats, got stranded 170 nautical miles away from the shore and it took him six days to reach the shore, with mechanics guiding him with the help of satellite phones. These engines were also consuming more fuel and emitting black smoke that engulfed the entire boat.

Bose himself had got a boat with an inferior motor and asked the manufacturers to replace it, but it was still to be attended after two months. ‚ÄúThey delay the process, but I have to repay the interest for the loan I obtained for the boat, and this is an additional cost for me,‚Äù he said.

Title: Kolkata Metro News: 21 residents move out of Metro cave-in zone
Content: KOLKATA: As tunnel-boring machine (TBM) Urvi moved into the cave-in zone on Tuesday, 21 residents from Gour De Lane off Bowbazar were evacuated. The area of subsidence that saw buildings fall like a pack of cards begins here. Kolkata Metro Rail Corporation (KMRC), the agency implementing the East-West Metro project, had started evacuation on Sunday by shifting 12 residents.KMRC is extremely cautious this time. No one wants a repeat of August 31 when the TBM digging the west-bound tunnel of the Metro project hit an aquifer and water flooded the tunnel, bringing with it sand and soil. Many buildings had collapsed and several others were damaged in the subsidence that could be arrested only after 12 days.‚ÄúAt that time, our house was damaged even though the TBM was digging at a distance. This time, the tunnelling will be carried out right under our building. We are extremely worried,‚Äù said Suneet Sarkar of 4B, Gour De Lane. Durga Pithuri Lane and Shyakrapara Lane were the worst-hit. The buildings of Gour De Lane, next to Shykrapara Lane, were also affected. ‚ÄúThe last time we had to stay in a hotel for 28 days. When we came back, we found several cracks in the walls of our house,‚Äù the 68-year-old said. ‚ÄúThe KMRC notice says we can return on Sunday, but many people haven‚Äôt been able to return on the scheduled date. The tunnelling, we were told, is slow and, hence, the delay,‚Äù Sarkar said.Although five homes could be evacuated, Somnath Banerjee of 2B, Gour De Lane, refused to leave his house. ‚ÄúI shall not move until my nephew gets the Rs 5 lakh compensation. He refuses to pay the electric bills and house tax because I received the money and he didn‚Äôt,‚Äù Banerjee told TOI.Urvi‚Äôs twin Chundee that hit the aquifer is now lying defunct below Durga Pithuri Lane. It was building the west-bound tunnel. Urvi, was building the east-bound tunnel and had dug till the Nirmal Chunder Street-Chaitan Sen Lane crossing at the time of the tunnelling fiasco and had been stuck ever since.Following a Calcutta high court order to resume tunnelling operations, it resumed digging on February 18. It has built around 1,100 rings till now. As the TBM burrows, an industrial robot places segments of a 1.2m wide pre-cast concrete ring. And thus, a 12m stretch of the tunnel gets created every day. But thanks to Urvi‚Äôs slow progress, only around 100m has been covered in the last fortnight.

Title: Kolkata: Emergency landing after hail cracks windshield
Content:
Representative Image

KOLKATA: A flight to Bagdogra had to return to the city and make a full emergency landing after takeoff due to damage to the cockpit caused by the hailstorm on Tuesday evening while another flight that was arriving in Kolkata from Guwahati had to be diverted to Ranchi to avoid the inclement weather. Departure of several flights were also delayed.

AirAsia flight I5 536 bound for Bagdogra took off from Kolkata around 4.30pm when the sky was beginning to turn ominously grey. On board were 171 passengers, including state minister Aroop Biswas. As the plane climbed through the clouds, passengers saw flashes of lightning and felt the turbulence. The plane was nearing 12,000ft when it was struck by hailstones . A particularly large hailstone suddenly struck the cockpit windshield and shattered it. The plane had then travelled around 50km.

Following protocol, the plane's captain contacted the air traffic control in Kolkata and sought permission to turn around. Permission granted, it headed back to Kolkata and touched down at 4.50pm. With the damage grounding the aircraft, the airline had to requisition another plane. It took off for Bagdogra at 7.18pm.

Meanwhile, an Alliance Air ATR aircraft from Guwahati that was bound for Kolkata got diverted to Ranchi. The diversion happened around 7.45pm and the plane landed in Ranchi at 8.34pm.

Five flights that were to depart Kolkata for Gwalior, Ahmedabad, Varanasi, Chennai and Bengaluru were held back due to the storm. Delays ranged between two and three hours.

Title: 50k to take II PU exam from today
Content:
Mangaluru: As many as 34,346 candidates from more than 200 colleges are scheduled to write the II PU examination at 51 centres in Dakshina Kannada from Wednesday.

The Dakshina Kannada department of pre-university education has made elaborate arrangements across Dakshina Kannada, so that the examination takes place smoothly. Five special squads have been formed to ensure that no malpractice takes place during the examination.

Mohammed Imtiyaz, DDPU, said that out 34,346 candidates, 30,897 are regular or fresh candidates, 1,264 repeaters and 2,185 private candidates. A total 17,137 boys and 17,209 girls will take the examination.

The commerce stream has the highest number of candidates (16,237), followed by science (13,577) and arts (4,532). An official from the department added that to ensure that examination proceedings are foolproof, CCTV cameras have been installed in all the examination centres.

Deputy commissioner Sindhu B Rupesh said a team headed by additional DC Roopa M J and district treasury officer has been tasked with distributing the question papers.

The vehicles provided to route officers have been fixed with GPS and papers to far off examination centres such as Sullia will be dispatched first, she said, adding the administration has taken all steps as directed by the department of PU education.

On the first day, physics, history and basic mathematics examinations will be held.

In Udupi

A total 15,100 candidates will take the II PU exam in Udupi, out of which 7,733 are boys and 7,367 are girls. The examination will be held in 27 centres.

The commerce stream has 8,236 candidates taking the exam, followed by 5,075 in the science stream and 1,789 candidates in the arts stream.

Chief minister B S Yediyurappa tweeted from the handle @CMofKarnataka:

‚ÄúGood luck and Best wishes to all the students appearing for the 2nd PUC exams. May you all come out with flying colours and bring much more glory to our state and country.‚Äù

Title: Visitors‚Äô book at Tagore Library witness to British legacy, freedom movement
Content: When Sarojini Naidu ‚Äî the first woman governor of UP and independent India ‚Äî came to Tagore Library and was asked to write her name and address in the visitors‚Äô book, she just wrote ‚ÄòIndia‚Äô as her address. Like Naidu, a number of eminent citizens recalled their fond association with LU in the historical register that has been successfully restored by INTACH as a gift to the university its centenary year. ‚ÄúThe register is a witness to the visits of British viceroy to India Lord Irwin (1926-1931) and socialist Ram Manohar Lohia,‚Äù said deputy librarian Jyoti Mishra. Mishra revealed that the visitors‚Äô book has, among many gems, an emotional letter from former Punjab CM Surjit Singh Barnala who had recalled his university days at the time of Quit India. ‚ÄúI was a student of Lucknow University from 1940 to 1946. I passed my LLB during the Quit India Movement. After some disturbance and student participation, the university was closed down for an indefinite period but the library remained open. I along with the other students attended the library and reading room very frequently,‚Äù Barnala‚Äôs letter reads.

Title: Lucknow: Aadhaar card with ‚Äòjail address‚Äô helps cops nab murder accused
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: An Aadhaar card mentioning ‚ÄòLucknow Jail‚Äô as residential address helped police arrest the murderers of a mini-truck driver found dead in Gosainganj last month. On Tuesday, police said driver Santosh Tiwari (40) was found dead on the roadside in Shekhnapur area. The autopsy report said he died due to head injury. During probe, police found that Sunny Chauhan drove the truck to deliver it to the transporter on February 24.

SHO Gosainganj DP Kushwaha said, ‚ÄúWe found Sunny‚Äôs Aadhaar card showing Lucknow Jail as address. Sunny claimed his father works in Lucknow Jail but when we enquired, jail officials said he had been in jail during trial under the Gangster Act.‚Äù The card was found fake. When confronted, Sunny accepted he was among the four who killed Tiwari in a drunken brawl. Tewari was killed when he snatched a bottle of liquor, said Sunny, who was arrested.

Title: No mechanism to screen over 30k visitors to Taj Mahal daily, says ASI
Content: AGRA: As the scare of coronavirus grips Agra , tour operators and local residents are concerned about their well-being amid absence of any mechanism to screen around 30,000 visitors from all parts of the world to the Taj Mahal daily.Vasan K Swarankar, ASI ‚Äôs superintending archeologist, Agra circle, said that there is no special equipment or technology at the monument to screen tourists. He said though he has advised his team to inform the health department, if anyone is visibly found having symptoms of extreme cough, cold and fever.‚ÄúWe cannot do much until someone informs us,‚Äù said Swarankar, adding that the airport is already using thermal imaging for screening tourists coming to India as part of precautionary measures and an advisory has also been issued to hotels.Some local residents said that the Taj Mahal should be closed for some time, as most of the foreign tourists visiting India come to see the world heritage site in Agra. ‚ÄúNo one can get to know about the spread of the disease among public, as many tourists don‚Äôt stay in hotels and leave the city by road after visiting the monument,‚Äù said a resident of Tajganj area.However, hoteliers and tour operators said closing the Taj Mahal should not an option as it will lead to global panic.Hotelier Sandeep Arora said that the Mughal-era monument should have facilities like thermal imaging. ‚ÄúNot only this, a team of health official should be available there as it is the major spot in Agra,‚Äù he said.The government‚Äôs decision to cancel visas to Italians, Koreans, Iranians and Japanese tourists is a ‚Äúknee-jerk reaction‚Äù, the tour operators said. ‚ÄúThis shows that we are not equipped to handle the crisis,‚Äù said Tourism Guild, Agra, vice-president Rajiv Saxena. He added that such steps should be avoided at large and only suspected cases should be quarantined.‚ÄúThe government should maturely handle the situation instead of creating panic among tourists. We may lose tourists from other countries due to such restrictions. Tourists travelling to India on valid visas are being unnecessarily harassed despite adhering to all prerequisite terms and conditions. Instead, we should restore confidence in them that India is safe to travel,‚Äù Saxena added.

Title: Poets focus on social issues, hues of life
Content:
Khwaja Rabbani (from left), Supantho Bhattacharya and Prajwala Tatte during the programme ‚ÄòKokeel Kavya‚Äô, on M... Read More

Nagpur: With most of the people hooked to electronic gadgets these days, it was a soothing experience to see many footfalls at ‚ÄòKokeel Kavya‚Äô, organized by Maharashtra Gandhi Smarak Nidhi, Bajaj Nagar, where poets presented many hues of life and won accolades on Tuesday.

Aesthetes had a whale of a time as the programme provided many unheard poets a platform to render their and others‚Äô compositions. Poets poured their heart out in expressing love for poems and kept the audience spellbound with their recitations.

Tributes were paid to freedom fighter Sarojini Naidu in whose memory the programme was organized.

While Sunita Jhade recited poems in Hindi and Marathi which spoke of dying humanity, Minal Evle conveyed the message that a person should fight problems that life throws at.

Gauri Asate reminded that the sense organs should be used to bring about a change in the society as they are meant to be for that purpose. Ability to speak, hear, observe, smell and touch should be utilized to optimum to enjoy every aspect of life, she said.

Other poets spoke on social matters that need to be addressed. A few among them rendered their emotions in a poetic form.

Litt√©rateur Supantha Bhattacharya gave a brief insight into Sarojini Naidu‚Äôs poems and explained a few of them. He categorized her poems into three sections ‚Äî patriotism, cultural and those in which she paid tributes to her colleagues during freedom struggle. Referring to some of her poems, he highlighted the intellect of Naidu.

Khwaja Rabbani shared his thoughts on the poems presented at the programme. In times where technology has taken over humans, it is wonderful to see people gathering, listening and analysing poems, he said.

Anchor Surekha Devghare recited her Hindi poem ‚ÄòPhoenix‚Äô. Prajwala Tatte paid tributes to Suhasini Sakhre by reciting her poem. Tatte also recited poems written by Naidu.

Poems written by Vaibhav Ogle were translated by Tatte in English. ‚ÄòWorry‚Äô, a poem, highlighted the worries that humans face in day-to-day life.

(Reporting by Janhavi Dave)

Title: Delhi riots: Government to give Rs 10,000 for reporting hate messages
Content:
Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal

NEW DELHI: To encourage people to report fake or/and hate messages that have the potential to incite violence, a Delhi assembly committee has decided to reward the informers with Rs 10,000 for each FIR registered on their complaints.

The newly formed committee on Peace and Harmony of Delhi Assembly launched a WhatsApp number and an email ID where people can send complaints regarding fake news and hate messages from various social media platforms that can cause communal disharmony.

Committee chairman Saurabh Bharadwaj said the committee would get the messages fact-checked by an agency and also verify them with a team of legal experts. If the legal team agreed that the content could potentially cause hatred or disturbance or enmity between two communities or groups, it would be forwarded to the law enforcement agencies with a recommendation for criminal prosecution.

‚ÄúIt will be the first time in India that informers of hate messages whose complaints are converted into FIRs will be rewarded with Rs 10,000 each,‚Äù Bharadwaj said.

The complaints, said Bharadwaj, could be sent on WhatsApp to the number 8950000946 and email ID ‚Äòdvscommittee@delhi.gov.in‚Äô.

Bharadwaj added that sharing fake and hate messages, which could cause enmity between two communities, was a criminal offence and invited a jail term of three years.

‚ÄúThese numbers will be widely publicised through every possible way that will include advertisements on TV, radio, newspapers and other mediums. Hoardings and unipoles will be put up at public spaces, schools, bus stops and in Delhi Metro, hospitals and government offices,‚Äù he said.

The committee will also work in close association with a ‚Äúfact-checking‚Äù agency, which will look into the authenticity of the content. A team of lawyers will be formed to provide legal assistance while a group of IT experts will extend technical assistance to the committee.

At its first meeting on Monday, the nine-member committee had observed that unverified hate messages on social media were one of the biggest reasons behind flaring up of communal violence and there was an urgent need to check their circulation.

The other members of the committee are AAP MLAs Abdul Rehman, Atishi, BS Joon, Dilip Pandey, Jarnail Singh, Kuldeep Kumar and Raghav Chadha and BJP legislator Ajay Mahawar.

The committee, Bharadwaj said, would also hold a peace meeting with the six MLAs of the violence-hit areas on February 5. ‚ÄúProminent religious leaders and people from the civil society of these areas will also join. The committee has observed that before Holi and the Friday prayers, a message of communal harmony should be sent across to avoid any flare-up,‚Äù Bharadwaj said, adding that the police commissioner would also be invited for the peace meeting.

Title: Madurai: Man, 32, murdered by wife‚Äôs paramour near Thirumangalam
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: A man from Virudhunagar was stabbed to death by his wife‚Äôs paramour near Austinpatti in Madurai district.

The murdered man has been identified as M Manikandan, 32, a sales executive at a private bank here. Manikandan was murdered by his wife Jothilakshmi‚Äôs paramour S Kathick, 25, of Vellalakshmi Nagar in Austinpatti.

Police sources said Jothilakshmi's father had met with a road accident a few months ago, which left him bedridden for weeks. Jothilakshmi stayed in her parents‚Äô house at Kappalur to take care of her father. She developed an extramarital relationship with Karthick during her stay at her parents‚Äô home.

She returned to her husband‚Äôs house recently. When Manikandan learnt about the relationship and picked up a quarrel with her, she went back to her parents' home.

Meanwhile, Karthick approached her parents and urged them to conduct the marriage between them. Her parents denied it, citing that she was married and has a child.

On Monday evening, Karthick picked up Manikandan from his home on his two-wheeler under the pretext of holding peace talks. As he did not return home, Manikandan‚Äôs parents started searching for him.

After murdering Manikandan, Karthick went to the home of Jothilakshmi‚Äôs parents. He told them that he had murdered Manikandan.

Jothilakshmi‚Äôs relative alerted the Austinpatti police. Later, the police nabbed Karthick from a hideout. Based on information provided by him, the body was recovered from a farmland in Gandhi Nagar in Austinpatti. There were at least seven stab injuries on the body.

The body was shifted to the Government Rajaji Hospital and an inquiry was under way with Jothimani and her family members. Meanwhile, a search is also on for Karthick. Police said they will know whether anyone else was involved in the murder.

Title: Covid 19 West Bengal: Anxious Bengalis return from Italy, some stay back
Content:
Sanjana Panja

Sourin Guha Thakurta

KOLKATA: Sanjana Panja left Kolkata six years ago to study in Milan. In all these years, she has never seen Milan so deserted. After the Covid-19 outbreak, schools and universities have suspended classes for two weeks and the bustling streets have gone empty. With the Indian government on Tuesday deciding to cancel all visa/eVisa that had been granted to nationals from Italy, Iran, South Korea and Japan on or before March 3, the situation has become complicated.Panja doesn‚Äôt want to risk returning to Kolkata now. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to take the risk of taking flights where I can contract the virus from any passenger. I also do not want to take the risk of taking the virus to my hometown and endanger my family,‚Äù she said.According to her, majority of the Indian students there have already gone back. Sourin Guha Thakurta, a construction engineering student from JU who worked for four years in Kolkata before leaving to do his Masters for Politecnico di Milano, had returned home on February 27. ‚ÄúMost of my friends from India are back. Initially, I thought the situation would be contained. But overnight, I found 100 new cases. Entire milk section of the supermarkets was empty. People were stocking up. That‚Äôs when I decided to return home,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHad I stayed back, my visa would have been cancelled. My university has started e-learning courses and I will not return till the situation improves.‚ÄùPanja was supposed to go on a trip to the nearby town of Imbersago on last Saturday. ‚ÄúOn Friday, the total count of Lombardia in Italy was approximately 73. When we returned from the trip, the count had gone up to 130,‚Äù said this former student of Jadavpur University‚Äôs architecture department.This rise in figures was enough to get Panja and her friends and acquaintances talking about what to do. ‚ÄúWe were constantly messaging each other on Whatsapp to understand what was happening. Five major league football matches were postponed and currently matches are being played in spectator-free stadia. Ten towns in Italy are on lockdown now. Offices and workplaces are open but everyone has instructed employees to take precaution and self-isolate themselves and work from home,‚Äù said Panja, who also teaches mathematics in a school.Being the design and marketing head of a fashion company, Panja has also seen the impact of the outbreak on the world‚Äôs fashion capital. Giorgio Armani's Autumn/Winter 2020 show at the Milan Fashion Week was held in an empty theatre. The show was livestreamed in front of an empty Teatro [theater] on the Armani website. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt attending the show but was aware of the developments. The show was held behind closed doors. People were asked not to attend the show,‚Äù she said. In fact, Armani himself was also photographed putting on a face mask as he entered the building. ‚ÄúFrom Sunday onwards, the cosmetic stores and pharmacies stopped selling masks and sanitizers. Our guess was that since people were not really affected in Milan, they didn‚Äôt want to sell masks and sanitizers to avoid panic,‚Äù added this Bengali resident of Milano Villapizzone.Canned food available at the supermarkets are fast getting over. ‚ÄúSome have really panicked and not even going out to buy groceries and have stocked up for weeks. Others like us are calm. We are wearing masks and using sanitizers but going out for important works,‚Äù she said.

Title: Madurai: Depressed over wife‚Äôs death, man kills sons, ends life
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: A 42-year-old labourer in a village near Alanganallur in Madurai district murdered his two sons by feeding them with poison-laced bananas and committed suicide by consuming the same.

The deceased have been identified as R Sundar, 42, of Ariyur and his sons, S Sunil, 13, and Vimal, 9. Sunil and Vimal were studying in classes VIII and V, respectively. Sundar took the extreme step on Monday night.

Sundar‚Äôs wife Indhumathi, who had been suffering from an ailment, died on October 7, 2019. Since then, Sundar was finding it difficult to take care of his sons. He had to leave the house in the early hours for work. He was also depressed by the death of his wife, police said.

On Monday evening, after his sons returned home, he fed them the bananas laced with pesticide used for agricultural purposes and consumed it. Soon, they went unconscious and died.

The murders and suicide came to light on Tuesday morning. Neighbours, who found the door remaining closed till late in the morning, looked into the house through a window and found Sunder and sons lying on the floor. They alerted the Alanganallur police.

A team rushed to the spot and broke open the main door and entered the house. They found that the three had died long ago. The bodies were shifted to the Government Rajaji Hospital, where a postmortem was carried out.

Based on a complaint a case was registered with the Alanganallur police station and a detailed inquiry was under way.

Title: Sex workers meet demanding equal rights held
Content:
Thrissur: As part of the international sex workers right day , New Network of Sex workers (NNSW), and national-level sex workers collective organized a meet with the support of Kerala Network of Sex Workers organized a meet at Kozhikode Sports Council Indoor Stadium on Tuesday demanding fear-free working atmosphere.

It is for the first time in the state that a sex workers collective meet is held on the sex workers right day, said organizers. Social activist and writer Gargi Harithakam inaugurated the meet.

‚ÄúEarlier in Kerala, a sex worker Nalini Jameela, shared her life with the public. It is for the first time in the state after this that a group of sex workers called a meet. These types of collectives should open windows to raise their voice in public,‚Äù said Gargi.

As part of the meeting a signature campaign was also held in the venue. 52 sex workers from seven districts of the state participated the meeting.

‚ÄúSex workers also have a right to live in public. But goons and police officials are attacking us. In the Kottayam KSRTC bus stand the police officials don‚Äôt allow us to stay there and tried to forcibly remove us from the area,‚Äù said a sex worker, Sindhu (name changed).

‚ÄúMost of them believe that sex workers choose this job of their own accord. But the reality is that most of them are pushed to this job due to personal and family issues,‚Äù said another sex worker, Maya (name changed) ‚ÄúIn my case my father sexually abused me at the age of 13 and the family avoided me. But the sex workers didn‚Äôt get any consideration from the society and government,‚Äù she said.

Rajaneesh M R, programme co-ordinator of the Kerala Network of Sex Workers said, ‚ÄúSex work is the same as any other job and sex workers have right to do their job. But the sex workers face many issues including police torture and other issues.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe demand that the government should assure the security of the sex workers,‚Äù said Rajaneesh.

Title: Fishermen stuck in Iran not hit by Covid-19: Min
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: No fishermen from the state trapped in Iran are known to have been affected by Covid-19 , fisheries minister J Mercykutty Amma told the assembly on Tuesday.Replying to a submission by Kovalam MLA M Vincent, the minister said that the government is doing everything possible to bring the fishermen back. She said that the Indian embassy in Iran has been contacted by the Noraka to provide assistance to the fishermen.She also said that the chief minister has written to external affairs minister S Jayashankar and Norka has contacted the embassies in other countries like China, Japan and Saudi Arabia for aiding the Keralites trapped in those countries. ‚ÄúWe are taking all possible steps but we can take such steps only in accordance with the law of those countries,‚Äù she said.Earlier, Vincent said that the videos that have come from the camps in Iran where the fishermen have been trapped shows that the sponsors are threatening them by cutting their food and water supply.As many as 60 fishermen are trapped in Iran and they are unable to leave their rooms in the fear of being affected by Covid-19. Vincent alleged that no one from the Indian embassy or Norka have contacted them so far.

Title: Woman duped of Rs 1 lakh in Aurangabad
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

AURANGABAD: A 25-year-old woman has been duped of Rs 99,900 while she was trying to return a dress bought using a mobile application.

According to the complaint, the woman bought a dress for Rs 1,300 and had opted for cash on delivery option. However, after receiving the package she saw that the colour of the dress was different from what she had chosen.

To return the dress and get the refund, the woman contacted the customer support on the number provided on the application. The suspect promised the woman to return the money and schedule a pick-up for the dress.

The suspect then sent a link to the woman asking the latter to click on it in order to process the refund. Falling for this trap, the woman clicked on the link on February 25 following which Rs 99,900 was debited from her bank account.

Title: Coronavirus Cases in Agra: 6 from Agra shoe exporter‚Äôs family show Covid-19 symptoms, shifted to Delhi
Content: Agra: Two local shoe exporters, who had visited Italy last month, were shifted to Delhi ‚Äôs Safdarjung Hospital on Tuesday along with their four family members on suspicion of having contacted the deadly coronavirus According to health officials, the two exporters, who are brothers, had been kept in the isolation ward in district hospital since Monday after they had developed symptoms of the disease, including high fever and respiratory problems. Their other family members had been advised to ‚Äúquarantine‚Äù themselves at their home and their throat swabs were taken for testing.They along with a host of other local leather exporters had participated in Lineapelle, an international exhibition of leather products, held in February in Milan, Italy.The decision to shift them to Delhi was taken after the close relative of the exporters, who, too, had visited Italy with them, had tested positive for Covid-19 in Delhi.Agra district magistrate Prabhu N Singh told TOI that the health department on Tuesday collected samples of 26 people, including the doctors who had directly or indirectly came in contact with the suspected coronavirus patients. He said this was done as a precautionary measure. All samples will be sent to Pune for testing, the DM said.Following the detection of these suspected cases, Rapid Response Teams of the state and central governments reached Agra on Tuesday morning and conducted a series of meetings with the district authorities and health officials for taking appropriate steps. The UP government has also called an emergency meeting of the technical committee and directed the officials to prepare and implement a containment plan for patients suspected to be suffering from the symptoms of Covid-19.According to the DM, the two exporters had gone to Europe on February 18 and had travelled to Italy and Germany. One of them had returned on February 28 and the other had come back on March 1. Their throat swab samples have been sent to National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune, for confirmation.Puran Davar, president of Agra Footwear Manufacturers and Exporters Chamber (AFMEC), told TOI that many shoe manufacturers from the city had visited Italy recently to participate in the global leather fair. He said that he has advised all of them to get themselves tested at the district hospital. The samples of all the suspected Covid-19 patients are being sent to either NIV, Pune, or King George Medical University, Lucknow.On Monday evening, Agra tourism department officials had issued an alert to the travel and hospital industry operators, Archeological Survey of India (ASI), Agra circle, and Agra Development Authority (ADA) informing about a group of 19 Italians, whose one member had tested positive in Jaipur, had travelled to Agra. The CMO told TOI that another group of 19 Italians had arrived Agra on Monday evening. They were screened and showed no symptoms of coronavirus.

Title: Poll affidavit: SC junks plea of Devendra Fadnavis for verdict review
Content:
Former Maharashtra chief minister Devendra Fadnavis (File photo)

NEW DELHI: In a setback to former Maharashtra chief minister Devendra Fadnavis , the Supreme Court on Tuesday refused to re-examine its verdict reviving trial for allegedly not disclosing all pending criminal cases against him while filing nomination papers for the 2014 assembly elections.

Reviving the complaint filed by advocate Satish Ukey, the apex court had in October ruled that a candidate must disclose all criminal cases in which the court has taken cognisance at the time of contesting elections. ‚ÄúIn view of the clear averments made in the complaint to the effect that Fadnavis had knowledge of two cases against him which had not been mentioned in the affidavit filed by him along with his nomination papers, we unhesitatingly arrive at the conclusion that the order of the trial court, upheld by the Bombay High Court , is legally not tenable and the same deserves to be set aside,‚Äù SC had said.

Alleging that his ‚Äúfate has been sealed‚Äù by SC by reviving the trial, Fadnavis sought review of the verdict and contended that it would have huge ramifications for other candidates in future elections as it could be misused. Senior advocate Mukul Rohatgi , appearing for him, contended that a false case could be filed due to political rivalry and the court could take cognisance of the case just a day before filing of nomination papers and a candidate might not know about it.

Fadnavis contended that in such cases, a person has to face prosecution for not furnishing information which he did not know. He said a candidate should be asked to disclose only those criminal cases in which charges have been framed or chargesheet filed.

But a bench of Justices Arun Mishra, Deepak Gupta and Aniruddha Bose dismissed his petition. ‚ÄúWe find no ground to interfere in the review petitions. The same are dismissed,‚Äù it said.

The two cases which Fadnavis did not mention in his election affidavit of 2014 are ‚Äúsummary case no. 232 of 1996 (u/s 500 of IPC ‚Äî defamation) and regular criminal case no. 343 of 2003 under various sections of IPC, both pending before Nagpur courts‚Äù.

Referring to letters issued by the Election Commission to the chief electoral officers of all states and UTs, the apex court had said, ‚ÄúA reading of the said letters would go to show that a contesting candidate is mandated to furnish information concerning cases in which a competent court has taken cognisance along with the cases in which charges have been framed.‚Äù

Title: Student-run ‚Äòraftaar‚Äô gang busted, 3 held
Content:
Lucknow: Greed for quick money and thrill for speed landed two students and their trader friend in jail on Tuesday.

The trio was part of a gang that had committed multiple loots of chains and purses while zipping past the victims on bikes.

Calling themselves the ‚ÄòRaftaar‚Äô gang, the accused used their expertise of driving bikes at high speed in congested and narrow roads for the job. Shekhar Verma, a final-year student pursuing bachelor‚Äôs of computer applications in a Noida college, Ashish Mishra, a law student in a private college in Lucknow and Aashay Anand, who runs a medical store in Jankipuram, were arrested near LDA Stadium in Aliganj, said DCP north Sarvshreshth Tripathi.

‚ÄúThe accused confessed that they had formed the gang in 2016 and have been involved in over a dozen loot and snatching cases,‚Äù said Tripathi. There are several other gang members who are on the run, he added. ‚ÄúAll are in their early 20s and had a deep desire to make big money in less time,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúApart from loot cases, we have slapped Arms Act against them after recovery of two country-made guns and three live cartridges from them,‚Äù he added.

Title: TAPMI announce their placements for PGDM courses
Content:
Manipal: TA Pai Management Institute ( TAPMI ) announced placements for its flagship postgraduate diploma in management (PGDM) general and PDGM-BKFS programmes for the batch of 2018-20. The institute witnessed an increase in average salary to Rs 11.5 lakh, from Rs 11.1 lakh last year.

The highest package offered was Rs 25 lakh, an increase of 25% from last year. The average package of PGDM (BKFS), the specialist programme of TAPMI, designed on the lines of MS (finance), has increased to Rs 12.7 lakh from Rs 11.3 lakh offered last year. TAPMI students have achieved 2.8 times increase in their salary after completion of their programme, in comparison to the salary offered before the programme.

The BFSI sector was the largest recruiter (28%) followed by consulting (25%), IT, analytics and e-commerce (30%), FMCG and retail (12%), and manufacturing & core (11%).

The key recruiters included Bajaj Finserv, Arcesium, Lowe‚Äôs India, Diageo, Enhance Group, WCCLG, HDFC, Titan, Qualcomm, AB InBev, Salesforce, Deloitte, Godrej and Boyce, Aequs, Tresvista, Accenture, Citibank, Pin Click, Virtusa, Berger Paints, Capgemini, People Business, VIP, ITC, Next Education, Airtel Payments Bank, Mahindra & Mahindra, Oyo, Tata Capital, Quess Corp, Brillio, Extramarks, Inspirage, Chai Point and AO Smith.

Congratulating the batch for their splendid performance, and reiterating TAPMI‚Äôs commitment towards quality academic inputs and career development, Madhu Veeraraghavan, director, TAPMI, said, ‚ÄúTAPMI‚Äôs consistent strong placements is a reflection of its academic focus coupled with real-world training, which enables students to take up the challenges in industry and carve a great career for themselves.‚Äù He also said, ‚ÄúPlacements for the specialist PGDM (HR) programme have commenced and are on track, and will be completed by the second week of March.‚Äù

This year 428 students were eligible for placements of which five students opted out of the placements to venture out on their own. A total 421 students got placed in 102 companies. Some 78 students were offered placement before passing out, through summer internships, at an average package of Rs 12.9 lakh, of which 76 students accepted the offer. The highest package offered before passing out was Rs 25 lakh.

Title: Coronavirus in West Bengal: Another 345 under lens; 986 in home isolation
Content: KOLKATA: As many as 345 people in the state were added to the list of coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) suspects and advised to be put in home isolation on Tuesday. So far, there has been no positive case of Covid-19 in the state. All the swab samples collected from Covid-19 suspects in West Bengal tested negative. But the state health department is on its toes and is continuously monitoring 986 persons kept in home isolation, many of them from Kolkata.With increasing number of people returning home from places affected by the virus, the health department has scaled up the number of isolation beds in hospitals, taking more such facilities into the fold.‚ÄúThough all 28 samples collected from suspects so far have tested negative for the virus, we are on our toes with strict surveillance,‚Äù said Dr Ajay Chakraborty, director of health services.Earlier, 30 persons had been kept under observation in hospital isolation. While 89 people who had travelled to the affected regions have completed the home-quarantine period, 986 continue to remain in home isolation till the 28-day surveillance period is over, even if they do not have any symptom.As a precautionary measure, the first isolation facility to treat the affected was set up at Infectious Diseases & Beliaghata General (IB&BG) Hospital in Kolkata with 20 beds, much before India reported its first confirmed Covid-19 case in Kerala. At present, apart from the medical colleges in the city, eight state-run facilities in the districts have also set up isolation wards, taking the number of isolation beds to 92.‚ÄúSo far we have been able to manage. We are equipped to increase our isolation facilities if the situation demands,‚Äù Chakraborty added.The Covid-19 scare surfaced in the city in January when a Thai national died at a private city hospital. However, her swab samples sent to National Institute of Virology, Pune, tested negative for Covid-19. ‚ÄúApart from one or two samples in the initial days, all swab samples have been tested at the National Institute of Cholera and Enteric Diseases, ICMR. This is saving a lot of time in procuring the reports. It is also taking the load off the NIV, Pune, laboratory,‚Äù said Shanta Dutta, director, NICED.Earlier, NICED, Kolkata, was also getting samples from the neighbouring Jharkhad and Chhattisgarh. But after the central government expanded the network of laboratories, NICED has been testing samples from only West Bengal. On Tuesday, three suspects who were under hospital observation were discharged after their samples tested negative. Currently, no patient is under hospital isolation.

Title: Railway minister promises electrification by 2021
Content:
Union railway minister Piyush Goyal

AURANGABAD: Union railway minister Piyush Goyal has assured that electrification work in Nanded division would be completed by 2021.

The assurance was given by Goyal to a delegation of advocacy group Aurangabad First that met the minister in Delhi on Monday.

‚ÄúThe railway minister told us that the tendering process for the desired electrification was over and the actual work will commence soon. Goyal said the work would be carried out in a speedy manner. The electrification work would be over by 2021,‚Äù Mansingh Pawar of Aurangabad First said on Tuesday.

Fulfilling the long-pending demand, the South Central Railway (SCR), in January 2018, had started a survey for rail electrification in Nanded division. The survey involved collection of details on bridges, level crossings, curves, signals, points-crossings and locations of high tension wires.

Nanded division, which caters to parts of Marathwada including Aurangabad, has nearly 1,000 kilometer of railway track. The meeting between Aurangabad First and railway minister also saw discussion on some other key demands, including pit-line at Aurangabad and new originating trains from Nanded division.

Meanwhile, railway activists sounded skeptical about the deadline announced by the minister.

‚ÄúGoing by the past experiences, we have developed a notion that the railway ministry gives step-motherly treatment to Nanded division for reasons best known to them. The latest example is the track doubling work on the Mudkhed-Parbhani route which took seven years to complete. Still, we hope that the railway minister keeps his word and complete the electrification process by 2021,‚Äù railway activist Omprakash Varma said.

Electrification plays an important role in rail operations that help in increasing the capacity of train movements and speeding of rail services. It also ensures seamless operation of trains without change of locomotive engines and reduces running time of passenger trains and makes possible to run longer train.

It is also preferred for long and heavy freight trains to ensure quicker transportation of goods. Besides, it is hailed as clean technology and energy efficient mode of transport worldwide.

Title: CRRI begins study on Nadukani Ghat Road
Content:
Malappuram: An expert team from Central Road Research Institute (CRRI), Delhi, has started a study on redesigning the Nadukani Ghat Road which was damaged due to multiple landslides triggered by heavy rain in the region last year.

The team led by Vasant G Havanagi, senior principal scientist of CRRI has conducted inspections in various parts of the road, including damaged areas and the inspection will continue for some more days. Chief engineer and other officials of PWD are also accompanying the scientists.

The inter-state highway connecting Nilambur region with Gudalur area in Tamil Nadu was completely washed away in several spots after the heavy rain and landslides in the region during August. After huge rocks were deposited on the road at Thenpara and Thakarappadi the traffic the authorities were forced to completely ban the traffic through the region for many months. As the road spans an 11km area which comes under jurisdiction of Kerala, was seriously damaged in the rain, the PWD authorities have already observed that reconstruction of the road in a conventional method would not be a permanent solution.

G Geetha, executive engineer of PWD (Roads) said that the team is mainly examining the possibility of redesigning and strengthening the road in the areas where the landslips occur frequently.

The team has collected soil samples from different areas of Ghat Road and they have also assessed the depth of rocks. ‚ÄúThe team is trying to find the real cause of frequent landslips and landslides in the region. We are expecting that they will suggest proper remedial measures to avoid soilslips in the region, including restructuring and redesigning of road‚Äù, she said.

It is expected that the team will wind up the inspection on Friday and submit a detailed report to PWD authorities soon.

PWD Minister G Sudhakaran who recently visited the spot last year had announced that government will consider the demand for redesigning the road with bridges and alternate routes.

Meanwhile the PWD is also considering an alternate route for the Ghat Road, through Munderi, Appankappu and Panthalur. The department has already submitted a proposal for a new inter-state highway through Appankappu, as the better alternative for Nadukani Road. According to the proposal, the inter-state highway can be materialized by developing an existing forest road in 10.2km area from Appankappu tribal colony area near Munderi to Pandalur near Gudalur in Tamil Nadu. The total distance from Appankappu to Pandalur in Tamil Nadu is 10.2km.

Title: Residents suffer as packaged water dealers go out of sight
Content:
MADURAI: Dealers switched off their phones while shops took off their 20 litre water cans from view as the strike by packaged water manufacturers entered the sixth day. People struggled to mobilize water as some shops demanded up to Rs 100 per can from those who approached them desperately.

Though the corporation had laid street taps in many of the 28 new wards, the water supplied through them is high in salinity and not fit for drinking or cooking. Places like Anna Nagar, Gomathipuram , Thapalthanthi Nagar, Athikulam and Vilangudi do not have drinking water supply through taps. While the corporation tankers supply water to a small portion in these wards, they never go into the narrower streets like Nehru street, and Roja street in Gomathypuram . ``I have never had the privilege of collecting free water from the corporation water tankers in all the ten years that I have lived here,‚Äô‚Äô said Thangam of Gomathypuram.

For people like her, the supply of private packaged water by local dealers was a boon. ``In fact, I know my packaged water dealer better than my milkman or postman, but now he is refusing to pick up my phone calls, which is disturbing,‚Äô‚Äô said Rajeswari of Tahsildar Nagar .

Offices that do not have RO plants, which usually have a stock of about 10 cans, are running dry and trying to source water from the corporation taps in the neighbouring areas as bottled water is too expensive. ``Installing an RO plant is not a solution as we do not have ground water and the borewell is dry. Packaged water is the only solution,‚Äô‚Äô said S Kumaresan of Vandiyur. He says the court‚Äôs intervention to check the illegal units is justified but it was the responsibility of the government to ensure that people had an alternative drinking water source.

There are about 80 packaged drinking water dealers supplying about two lakh litres of water per day in the city alone. However, packaged water cans are nowhere to be seen now. Sources from the package water manufacturers association say they are ready to supply water as soon as the court allows them.

Title: Delhi riots: Subhash mohalla in Yamuna Vihar swears by its unity in diversity
Content:
Hindu and Muslim families prepared food at a temple for those affected by the riots

NEW DELHI: On a lane in Subhash mohalla in Yamuna Vihar, a Shiv temple stands. It escaped any harm during last week‚Äôs communal riots. The temple priest testified that the Muslim residents ensured its safety. On Tuesday, Hindu and Muslim families prepared food at the temple for those affected by the riots.

As pujari Achal Sharma performed his daily rituals, Asif Khan and his wife Nusrat arrived. Khan recalled, ‚ÄúWe convinced residents not to believe in the rumours. People were scared as there were slogans being chanted and sounds of gunfire. But we stood together.‚Äù Nusrat‚Äôs beauty parlour in Bhajanpura was vandalised. ‚ÄúOur house stayed intact and we ensured other houses too remained undamaged,‚Äù Khan added. ‚ÄúWith the love we share here, we will rebuild the parlour.‚Äù

Anil Kumari, Sharma‚Äôs mother, said self-assuredly that the Muslims in the locality would sacrifice their lives for the temple. ‚ÄúThis is the love we share,‚Äù she said. The priest also said that when the Babri Masjid riots rocked the country in 1992, ‚Äúnot a leaf on this lane was shaken and never will‚Äù.

According to Shabbir Ahmed, ‚ÄúEach night, Pandit ji and we stood guard at the lane entries. Others brought us tea to help us stay awake.‚Äù Retired CISF employee Ramesh Chandra Walia added, ‚ÄúEven women did guard duty, staying alert during daytime too.‚Äù

In Shiv Vihar too, the spirit of harmony helped neighbours avoid violence. Rajaram, 60, who runs a school in the area, said, ‚ÄúWhen Hindus saw Muslims in trouble or vice-versa, they intervened to save each other. We have been living together for 33 years. It was outsiders who indulged in violence.‚Äù Neighbours came to the assistance of Sajid Hassan and his family. ‚ÄúThere was a wedding in my family on February 25, so we had many guests in our house. Our neighbours hid most of us in their houses and we left when police arrived in the morning,‚Äù said Hassan.

Title: Goa: No duplication of courses by private universities will be allowed under new law
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Education officials said that as and when private universities establish institutes in Goa, it will be ensured that there is no duplication of programmes already available in the state.

The state cabinet has given its approval to the Goa Private Universities Bill, 2020. Currently there is only the state-funded Goa University and the new bill will allow institutes affiliated to private institutes to establish campuses here.

As per the provisions of the bill, a committee will be set up to scrutinise and approve the programmes, officials said.

‚ÄúIn no way will institutes offering general stream programmes be allowed to offer programmes in the state. We have sufficient number of colleges offering such programmes to meet the current demand,‚Äù a senior education official said.

Similarly, programmes like engineering will also not be allowed as there are already five institutes in the state, besides the IIT and NIT, the official said.

‚ÄúA committee set up by the state will ensure that only programme that are currently not available in the state are allowed. The state will give preference to niche programmes like in space technology. Goa could also do with another medical programme other than the state-funded one at Goa Medical College,‚Äù the official said.

The bill is presently awaiting the governor‚Äôs nod, director of higher education Prasad Lolayekar said, adding that currently there are no proposals with the directorate of higher education.

An official said that the state is hoping to be modelled as an education hub, where students from other states will be attracted to come and study at these private universities.

‚ÄúGoa obviously does not have the kind of numbers that can make such institutes feasible. It means that students from outside the state will be attracted to come and study here. This will boost the local economy in many ways,‚Äù an official said.

Title: Covid-19: State launches second phase monitoring
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: In the wake of more cases of Covid-19 being reported in the country and in more countries across the world, health minister K K Shailaja has said that the health department will launch the second phase of monitoring process in the state.‚ÄúEven though we have successfully controlled the cases in the first phase, our job is not fully over. Since the cases are being reported in more countries, the surveillance has to be strengthened here. Hence, it has been decided to operate the health desks in the airports round the clock,‚Äù said the health minister.The isolation of those who had direct contacts with the positive patients and also those who are having symptoms of fever, sore throat and cold will continue. All the isolation wards set up in the government hospitals will continue.Since a few cases have been reported in other parts of the country, the Union health ministry has asked all the states to be more cautious. In a video conference the Union health secretary had with the secretaries of all the states, Kerala was showered with praise for the excellent surveillance it did when the first case was reported, she said.35 home quarantined in KottayamKottayam: As part of precautionary measures, 35 individuals are under observation for Covid-19 in the district. This includes 21 individuals who were working as home nurses in Italy. The remaining include three who have returned from Australia, two each from China, New Zealand, Hong Kong and Thailand and one each from Singapore, Japan and Ireland. These individuals arrived in the district since February 27 and are home quarantined.

Title: Bamu‚Äôs dramatics dept to relax admission rules
Content:
Aurangabad: The newly-set up department of dramatics and folk art at the Osmanabad sub-centre of Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University ( Bamu ) has decided to relax the admission norm in order to facilitate interdisciplinary studies.

Started in June last year, the new department will admit students for postgraduate courses even if they do not have a bachelor‚Äôs degree in dramatics and folk art. University senate member Sambhaji Bhosale said relaxation in admission rules would be applicable from the next academic year.

‚ÄúVice-chancellor Pramod Yeole has been strongly advocating interdisciplinary studies and sought necessary proposal to amend the existing rules. The move is expected to witness more takers for the course,‚Äù he said.

Bhosale said no educational institution in Osmanabad offers bachelor‚Äôs degree in dramatics and folk art. ‚ÄúIt was one of the reasons behind changing the admission rules,‚Äù he said.

The new department currently has an intake capacity of 30 students, which will be also increased to 60 from the next academic year.

As part of promotional activity, the department of dramatics and folk art at the Osmanabad sub-centre had organised one-act play competition during the weekend and it received good response.

‚ÄúThe two-day event also provided students and local artists a platform to showcase their talent. More such activities would be organised in future for promoting the new department,‚Äù a Bamu official said.

Speaking at the inaugural programme of the event, artist and film-maker Dilip Bhosale appealed to the youth from Marathwada to refrain from developing inferiority complex.

‚ÄúThe youth from Marathwada is as talented as other students from the country. There is a need to tap the potential in youth and the new university department would definitely act in this direction,‚Äù he said.

Came into existence on August 16, 2004, the Osmanabad sub-centre of BAMU caters to educational needs of students from Osmanabad district and nearby cities.

Title: 71 isolation wards set up in Lucknow hospitals
Content: LUCKNOW: As coronavirus made inroads into the country, at least 71 isolation wards have been set up in all prominent government hospitals in Lucknow to deal with any emergency situation.Chief medical officer (CMO), Lucknow, Dr Narendra Agarwal on Tuesday said, ‚ÄúPeople coming from abroad, especially 12 countries where coronavirus cases have been reported, are being screened at the airport. Six doctors and eight paramedics have been stationed at the airport helpdesk. We have one thermal scanner and two infrared thermometers for diagnosis.‚Äù‚ÄúIsolation wards have been set up at SGPGI, KGMU and Ram Manohar Lohia, Civil, Lokbandhu and Balrampur hospitals. Samples are being tested at KGMU,‚Äù said Dr Agarwal.He said adequate personal protection equipment (PPE) kits and N95 masks were available.‚ÄúTwo lab technicians each have been given training in sample collection at every hospital. Till date, six people from Lucknow have been kept under observation and their samples have been taken. Five of them were tested negative for coronavirus. Nearly 300 people who came to Lucknow from other countries but showed no symptoms were kept under observation at their homes. Their families were asked to take necessary precautions like using sanitisers and maintaining a distance of two metres,‚Äù he said.

Title: Officials retrace runaway man‚Äôs routes
Content:
Kochi: Health authorities are trying to track all places that the 25-year-old man who ran away from Ernakulam Medical College around 2am on Sunday visited.

The man had returned from Thailand after a holiday and on his return, he was found to have cough and fever at Cochin airport screening. As he had Covid-19-like symptoms, he was referred to the medical college.

‚ÄúThe patient is a low risk case. However, we have informed the police and are trying to track where all the patient went,‚Äù said district medical officer Dr M K Kuttappan. He had returned to the hospital by Sunday evening and claimed that he had gone to his home in Aluva. His reports are awaited from NIV, Alappuzha.

tnn

Title: Kolhapur woman knocked down by truck, dies
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

KOLHAPUR: A 45-year-old woman was killed on the spot after she was knocked down by a truck near the busy market yard in Kolhapur city on Tuesday morning. A case in this regard has been registered at the Shahupuri police station.

The deceased has been identified the woman as Ankita Kailas Powar, a resident of Bodke lane in the Juna Budhwar Peth area of the city.

Police have arrested truck driver Mohsin Takdir Mujawar (45), a ressident of Mali colony, Takala in connection with the accident.

According to police, the accident took place when the deceased was crossing the road. She was heading towards her office when she was knocked down by the truck, police said.

‚ÄúWe are investigating the incident,‚Äù said police. Ankita is survived by her husband, a son and a daughter. Her son is a third-year science student while daughter is studying in the 9th standard.

Title: Man held for double murder in Radhanagari
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

KOLHAPUR: A 52-year-old man has been arrested for killing his wife and brother-in-law in broad daylight at Rashiwade village in Radhanagari taluka on Tuesday.

According to police, financial dispute between the couple seems to be the reason behind the crime . The suspect, Sadashiv Khanu Kawanekar, attacked his wife (Manjabai) and brother-in-law Kerba Hiwarappa Yedke (40) with a sharp weapon outside the village‚Äôs grampanchayat office at 10 am.

‚ÄúThe brother-sister duo had gone to the grampanchayat office to update a 7/12 extract. Manjabai and Yedke were rushed to Chhatrapati Pramilaraje Hospital in where succumbed to their injuring during treatment,‚Äù a police officer said.

Title: Hoteliers, residents can no more dump waste into drains
Content:
Residents and hoteliers used to discharge waste into drains and canals from houses and hotels. Now, district a... Read More

KOCHI: Hoteliers who used to discharge food waste and toilet waste to drains and canals will no longer be able to do so as the district administration has started closing these pipelines as part of Operation Breakthrough . Likewise, the pipelines which carry toilet from residences will also be closed.

District collector has given instruction in this regard and contractors have started closing the pipelines. However, residents have raised their objections and councillors are starting to feel the heat.

‚ÄúResidents and hoteliers used to discharge waste water to drains without any objection from authorities so far. But, with the closing of openings, residents won‚Äôt be able to do so. Though we reason with them, they, especially housewives, get angry with us. We tell them the drains are meant for stormwater and residents cannot discharge waste into them. The problem is that 90% residents in Kochi do not have facility in their houses to discharge waste water. Similarly, the hoteliers have been discharging all food waste to drains and blocking them,‚Äù said Krishnakumar , Ernakulam south councilor.

District administration officials said they have asked workers to close all the openings from toilets to drains and canals. ‚ÄúIf the residents raise the issue before the councillors, peoples‚Äô representatives should make them understand that the drains and canals are not the place to dump toilet waste,‚Äù said an official.

Meanwhile on Tuesday, the district administration has approved 28 more new works to be undertaken in the second phase of Operation Breakthrough. Works in the second phase are estimated to cost Rs 16.5 crore.

About 75% works in the first phase have been completed. Though the government sanctioned Rs 10 crore for first phase, only Rs 4 crore has reached the account of the administration, said sources.

Title: Exam lapses: Governor Arif Mohammad Khan seeks report from Calicut University VC
Content:
Arif Mohammad Khan

KOZHIKODE: Governor Arif Mohammad Khan has sought an urgent report from Calicut University based on the report published by TOI on February 12 about the serious lapses in its conduct of exams. The principal secretary to the governor has written a letter to the vice-chancellor, asking him to submit an urgent report in this regard within seven days.

The latest audit report (2017-18) had pointed out various lapses including not maintaining proper record of answer sheet distributed to colleges for conducting exams, which could be misused. Among other lapses, the report had said that CU allowed principals of affiliated colleges to correct internal marks of students after they were uploaded to the website in four instances and there were several instances of evaluators recording wrong marks in the facing sheet of answer sheet.

The syndicates exam standing committee met on Tuesday to discuss the matter. A decision was taken at the meeting to make changes in CU‚Äôs exam software to enable affiliated colleges upload the number of answer papers used for exam and the surplus answer sheets held by them so that CU can track the answer sheets distributed to colleges.

More significantly, it has now been revealed that the CU has recently received an audit enquiry as part of CAG inspection for the year 2018-19 over improper maintenance of answer sheet stocks.
