The senior audit officer pointed out that the stock register of answer books in the prescribed form is not maintained at CU and the details of issue of answer books to varsity‚Äôs study departments and affiliated colleges is not maintained at the university. The audit team will wait for specific remarks from CU on audit enquiries before making final comments.

The audit officer also pointed out that as per the instructions issued by Cu to the chief superintendents of examinations, a quarterly report on the stock of blank answer books is to be forwarded to the joint controller of examinations. But no such data is available in the monitoring section of answer books.

Another serious point raised by the audit officer is that there was no system to monitor or ascertain the number of answer books and additional sheets already present in affiliated colleges and study departments. Hence, chances of malpractices couldn‚Äôt be ruled out.

‚ÄúIn 2018-19, 4,385 bundles of answer books and 5,638 additional sheets were supplied to the store. There were huge bundles of answer books and additional sheets in the store. Unused, old damaged answer books were dumped in the same store, the details of which were not available, said the audit enquiry sent to CU in December 2019. It added that there was no mechanism to fix responsibility for instances of missing/ non- tallying of answer books.

Title: CBSE students, parents sign online petition
Content:
Kochi: Students and teachers have alleged that the Physics paper of CBSE Class XII board examination held on Monday was ‚Äòtough and tricky‚Äô and have started an online petition to CBSE seeking a liberal evaluation of the answer papers.

The petition has been signed by nearly 35,000 people across the state. Almost all schools have informed CBSE about the complaints from students.

The students have expressed their concern over the remaining theory exams as well. Parents and teachers said the students are yet to come in terms with the Physics exam and that it would affect the preparations for the remaining exams.

‚ÄúMy daughter returned home and said she could not even attempt all questions though she was well-prepared. It took her nearly one hour to answer Section A which featured 20 MCQs carrying single marks. She did not even eat the whole day and collapsed at night. We had to take her to a hospital. Many other students are also still in shock,‚Äù said a parent.

Many students and parents said the question paper included out of syllabus questions.

‚ÄúPhysics paper is always a bit tough but this time it was tougher than we expected. 90% questions were application-level questions while in curriculum only 33% is allowed. There were some out of syllabus questions. For example, the question on electric field on the axis of a uniformly charged ring was out of syllabus. Almost all questions were difficult to comprehend even for those students who have worked out the questions papers of previous years,‚Äù said a Physics teacher.

The CBSE had earlier said the moderation policy has been stopped from this year onwards. ‚ÄúThis is not fair as the board was allowed to give grace marks to the previous batches and for succeeding batches, the syllabus would be reduced. The present Class XII students will neither have a reduction in the syllabus nor grace marks,‚Äù said a student.

Title: Councillors demand alternative for WTE plant
Content:
Kochi: Councillors who attended corporation council meeting on Tuesday to discuss waste management stressed the need to consider alternative proposals with the National Green Tribunal (NGT) team questioning the viability of the waste-to-energy (WTE) plant at Brahmapuram. Reduction of waste at source, recycling and reuse, among other things, should be encouraged, they opined.

Councillors cutting across party lines raised objection against the state government‚Äôs decision to convert the concessionaire agreement, signed between the corporation and GJ Eco Power Private Limited allotting 23 acres of land for setting up the plant, into a lease agreement.

‚ÄúWe shouldn‚Äôt depend solely on the proposed WTE plant. Alternative projects must be considered, which can promote reduction, recycling and reuse of garbage,‚Äù said V P Chandran, secretary, LDF parliamentary party, Kochi Corporation.

A B Sabu, Congress councillor and former chairman of welfare standing committee, said the conversion of the concessionaire agreement into lease agreement would be detrimental for the local body.

‚ÄúThe private firm would be mortgaging the property for raising funds to set up the plant. If the private firm fails to repay the loan, the responsibility of paying back the amount would fall on the local body. Then, the corporation will lose the land,‚Äù Sabu said.

C K Peter, councillor from Konthuruthy, said the local body has been shelling out a huge sum for transportation and treatment of waste and improving infrastructure facilities at the solid waste treatment plant at Brahmapuram.

‚ÄúThe corporation has spent Rs 3.22 crore for hiring trucks in 2015-16 fiscal while it increased to Rs 3.68 crore in 2016-17 fiscal. In 2017-18, the amount stood at Rs 4.78 crore and increased to Rs 6.86 crore in 2018-19. The cost of treatment of waste has also been going up,‚Äù Peter said.

K J Antony, opposition leader, said leasing out the 23 acres to the private firm can‚Äôt be approved. It will lead to alienation of the land, he said. Gracy Babu Jacob, a ruling front councillor, said the local body authorities have miserably failed in ensuring effective waste management. ‚ÄúThe corporation has been spending crores for hiring trucks for carrying garbage from the city to Brahmapuram. Still, many trucks, bought by the corporation have been lying idle at a yard,‚Äù she said.

Many of the councillors said the local body has been spending so much money to improve the infrastructure at Brahmapuram. It is suspected to have helped GJ Eco Power. ‚ÄúWe have been erecting a 530kVA tower-line at Brahmapuram at a cost of Rs 42 lakh. It should have been done by the private company as it stands to benefit from it,‚Äù Peter said.

Ironically, the council meeting held for finding a solution to the vexed issue of garbage treatment failed to pass 13 out of the total 14 items in the agenda of the meeting. While mayor Soumini Jain blamed the opposition for objecting to the proposal alleging corruption, the opposition leaders said proposals worth crores were introduced without discussion with concerned committees.

Title: Fighting cancer, one smile at a time
Content:
What started as an awareness camp with 200 people, in 2013, has touched over 5,00,000 lives since then. Dr Chinnababu Sunkavalli‚Äôs motivation -- to carry on his mother‚Äôs legacy and improve as many lives as possible, just as she did as a social worker. Through his initiative, Grace Cancer Foundation, the oncologist has reached remote areas across Telangana and Andhra Pradesh to perform cancer screening and awareness programmes for locals.

‚ÄúIn rural areas, not everybody is educated to keep track of their health. We teach them basic self-test techniques. At our mobile screening units, we perform a thorough five-stage procedure and give them the results there and then. If somebody is found to have cancer, we refer them to the nearest centre where they can receive treatment under the Aarogyasri scheme,‚Äù says Dr Chinnababu.

The doctor has now expanded his initiative and established the Indur Cancer Hospital in Nizamabad where he can be found every Friday, sometimes supervising two simultaneous surgeries in different halls. ‚ÄúMy payment lies in people‚Äôs smiles. I want to be an agent of change,‚Äù the doctor says. The centre performs around 30 surgeries and 300 chemotherapy procedures every month.

One of the beneficiaries under Dr Chinnababu‚Äôs schemes, Mr Abdus Salim from Warangal says: ‚ÄúIt is because of the foundation that my cancer was detected. I was having severe bleeding issues and could not afford treatment. But due to the foundation‚Äôs efforts, I was operated free of cost and now am on a path of speedy recovery. Ek nayi zindagi mil gayi hai.‚Äù Salim was suffering from rectal cancer and underwent robotic abdominoperineal resection on February 13.

‚ÄúI thought there was little hope for my wife as treatment was impossible given our financial situation. But through Grace Foundation, she received free treatment and is now recovering well,‚Äù says Ghouse Mohiuddin, a resident of Tolichowki.

While Dr Chinnababu is satisfied with the number of cases cured through his foundation, his ultimate goal is to educate and create awareness. ‚ÄúIf people are educated and shown that lifestyle changes can help them lead healthy lives, it will go long way than simply curing them,‚Äù he says.

Title: AMU academic gets Sahitya Akademi Award
Content:
AGRA: Noted bilingual critic, scholar and columnist, professor Shafey Kidwai has received the prestigious Sahitya Akademi Award (2019) in Delhi for his seminal Urdu work ‚ÄòSawanah-e-Sir Syed - Ek Bazdeed‚Äô.

President of Sahitya Akademi, the National Academy of Letters prof Chandrashekhar Kambar gave the award to prof Kidwai along with the awardees of other languages including Dr Shashi Tharoor at a function presided over by the chief guest eminent poet and lyricist Gulzar. Dr Madhav Kaushik, vice-chairman Sahitya Akademi presented a shawl and certificate to Prof Kidwai. According to AMU administration, the book seeks to revisit the biographical details and literary accomplishments of Sir Syed and it supplements what has escaped the attention of biographers of Sir Syed including Khawaja Altaf Husain Hali.

Prof Kidwai has been honoured with Madhya Pradesh government‚Äôs prestigious award ‚Äò Iqbal Samman ‚Äô in 2016 and Uttar Pradesh Urdu Academy award ‚Äò Amir Khusro Award‚Äô in 1918.

Title: Delhi shows its big heart: People offer own homes for relief work
Content:
Members of Shiromani Akali Dal provide food and clothing to victims of violence at Mustafabad

NEW DELHI: People are opening up their hearts and their homes to citizens affected by last week‚Äôs violence in northeast Delhi. While members of the Shiromani Akali Dal provided relief material to riot victims at Mustafabad and Shiv Vihar on Tuesday, in other areas, people have offered their own homes to civil society for use at relief camps and medico-legal facilities.

Prabhrit Singh Sarna, who was accompanying his father, SAD Delhi president Paramjeet Singh Sarna, revealed that the elder Sarna had recalled the Sikh riots of 1984 when they visited the violence scarred northeast Delhi. ‚ÄúHe said the sight reminded him of 1984,‚Äù said Prabhrit, who described SAD‚Äôs relief distribution as adhering to the Sikh tenet of seva bhav.

Several trucks filled with food and clothing went around Mustafabad and Shiv Vihar. At the Eidgah relief camp, the SAD city head met the victims expressed happiness that with the sub-divisional magistrate and government officials themselves involved in the compensation filing, the relief effort would be quickened.

‚ÄúI told the officials that they should visit the relief camps and try to provide the compensation amount as soon as possible because the victims people have lost a lot,‚Äù the senior Sarna said. ‚ÄúWe want the chief minister and ministers to meet people. That is how you remove their grief. People shouldn't be scared to go back to the mosques and pray.‚Äù

The relief camps were in full swing on Tuesday, providing materials and other help to the dislocated people. Jameel Ahmed, an imam of a mosque at Babu Nagar, opened up a room in his home for the civil society group that had to shift its free medical service camp from Al-Islah School. ‚ÄúI wanted to provide whatever assistance in helping people get back on their feet, so made space in my home for the medical camp,‚Äù Ahmed said.

Ahmed‚Äôs neighbour Mohammad Dilshad also went ahead and freed the living room in his home for medico-legal work. ‚ÄúWe have told the relief providers that we are ready for everything. Everyone faces bad times, but we can all do something to help,‚Äù Dilshad philosophised.

Title: On a solo bike ride from M‚Äôluru to Nepal & Bhutan
Content:
Sayyed Muhammed Saleem, a resident of Ullal working in Kuwait, who has completed a 12,635km solo ride on his R... Read More

Mangaluru: It has been a dream come true for Sayyed Muhammed Saleem, 29, a resident of Ullal , working in Kuwait . On his Royal Enfield Classic 350, he has completed a solo ride in 39 days covering a distance of 12,635 kms and visiting more than 100 cities and riding on some of the treacherous Himalayan stretches. A member of Mangalore Bulls Motorcycle Club , Saleem started his journey from Kadri on January 8 and returned on February 15.

‚ÄúIt is one of the most memorable journeys of my life. I did face a few problems ‚Äî travelling in the wrong direction once, maintenance and repairs on the bike etc. North Indians have a lot of respect for South Indians and it is not at all dangerous to travel alone. Whenever I needed a break, I relaxed near toll gates as I felt they were safer. On an average, I covered a maximum of 500-800 kms per day and there were also days when I rode only 50 kms, ‚Äú he said.

Although Saleem had not planned in advance for the trip, he had always wanted to ride to Nepal. From Mangaluru, he travelled to Hyderabad, Nagpur, Varanasi and Sanwali. On the Indian- Nepal border, after all the formalities and permits, he travelled to Chitwan district and spent about three days there. Subsequently, he went to Pokhara and Jomsom .

‚ÄúAt a few stretches, it was very difficult to ride. In fact, two-wheeler riders generally denied permission there because of the risks involved. I had to ride at a very slow speed. It took almost two days to complete 100 kms,‚Äù he said.

He also participated in the Brotherhood of Bulleteers Motorcycling Consortium Rider Mania in Nepal.

From Nepal, he went to Gangtok. ‚Äú At some stretches, I was probably the only one riding a bike,‚Äù said Saleem. From Gangtok , he left for Jaigon and after completing formalities, went to Tiger‚Äôs Nest Monastery in Bhutan , also known as Paro Takstang. After spending some time in Bhutan, he travelled back to India, via Agra, Lucknow, Indore and Pune.

‚ÄúAfter returning to India, I visited major tourist spots in north and enjoyed local cuisine. Subsequently, I travelled to Belagavi and via Hubbali- Ankola and returned back to Mangaluru,‚Äù Saleem added.

Title: Maiden ‚ÄòEducation Day‚Äô sees no activities
Content:
Aurangabad: The maiden Education Day ‚Äî to be observed on the first Monday of every month ‚Äî witnessed no activity in Aurangabad and other parts of the region.

State school education minister Varsha Gaikwad , while making a formal announcement about Education Day last month, had said the new initiative would be introduced on the lines of Lokshahi Din that witnesses redressal of complaints and issues related to different government offices.

As part of Education Day, complaint-boxes were supposed to be installed in schools for lodging complaints related to academic and non-academic fields. A grievance redressal committee each at the level of school, district and division were also expected to set up for complaint redressal.

When contacted, Aurangabad zilla parishad education officer (primary) S P Jaiswal said no official communication was received from the government for observing Education Day.

‚ÄúWe are expecting official guidelines for observing Education Day. Once the official communication is received, we will follow the guidelines in letter and spirit,‚Äù he said.

Educational activist Prashant Sathe said Education Day announced by the government could be fruitful for students and parents if implemented in a wholehearted manner.

‚ÄúThe concept behind the initiative is good and could improve the school functioning significantly. Proper official attention could ensure that Education Day runs on a sustained basis,‚Äù he said.

Meanwhile, Gaikwad could not be reached for comments.

Title: Officials play blame game as travellers of Vasco-Collem trains complain of delays
Content:
Representative image

MARGAO: Inordinate delays in running of local passenger trains between Vasco and Collem along the South Western Railway (SWR) route has irked regular commuters. As repeated complaints registered at various railway stations enroute have failed to yield the desired results, enraged commuters have threatened to stage a protest at the railway stations.

Commuters said that while they often reached late for work in Vasco on account of late running of 56961 Collem-Vasco train, inordinately long halts at intermediate stations of 56966 Vasco-Collem train almost every day subjects them to ‚Äústressful situations‚Äù.

Anupkumar Desai, a resident of Cacora, who works as an instructor at the industrial training institute at Vasco, says that the late running of the Collem-Vasco train affects his official as well as domestic schedules.

‚ÄúThe scheduled arrival of Collem-Vasco train at Vasco is 8.20am. But the train invariably runs late and reaches Vasco well past 9am. The Vasco-Collem train departs from Vasco at 5.30pm and should reach Collem at 7.10pm, but it never reaches on time, and many a times is delayed by more than half-an-hour. Imagine the plight of regular commuters like me who leave from home as early as 6.30am to catch the morning train,‚Äù Desai said.

Joseph Fernandes from Sanguem, also a regular commuter, said, ‚ÄúOur patience is now wearing thin. We are getting no proper explanation from the railway officials for the train delays. The other day, irate commuters pulled the emergency alarm to stop the train in protest at Majorda after it had halted at the station for over 20 minutes,‚Äù he said.

The situation has led to a blame game between the Konkan Railway Corporation Ltd (KRCL) and the South Western Railway. Margao and Majorda railway stations come under the Konkan Railway section. Highly placed sources in the SWR said that the Vasco-Collem train has often to be detained at Majorda railway station for want of path clearance from the Konkan Railway‚Äôs Margao railway station.

‚ÄúThe problem is mostly due to large volume of traffic on the Konkan Railway route. As the track is engaged for the movement of several long-distance trains through Margao station, the signal displays ‚Äòno path‚Äô and the local trains have to be detained at Majorda or preceding stations until the path clearance signal is given from Margao station,‚Äù a SWR source familiar with the signalling system on the route in Goa told TOI.

Deputy general manager, public relations, KRCL, Baban Ghatge, however, had a different version to attribute to the late running of local trains. ‚ÄúAs there is a movement of large number of goods‚Äô trains along the route around the same time, the SWR may be giving preference to goods trains. The Konkan Railway has no role to play in scheduling of the trains,‚Äù Ghatge said.

The spokespersons of the SWR however, failed to provide any official statement over the matter.

President of the Sanvordem-Curchorem Rail Users Association Devanand Bhandari urged for close coordination between the KRCL and SWR so that regular commuters along the route aren‚Äôt affected.

Title: Screen all inbound flyers, crew: Tour operators to government
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: The Indian Association of Tour Operators has requested the government to screen everyone flying into India ‚Äî from passengers to crew ‚Äî for the virus, irrespective of the country they are coming from.

As of now, passengers from China, Hong Kong, Japan , South Korea, Thailand, Singapore, Nepal, Indonesia, Vietnam, Malaysia, Italy, and Iran are being screened on arrival in India. To be sure, this list is being expanded as the situation evolves, with Italy and Iran becoming the latest entrants on Monday.

Title: Hearing of plaint in Solapur court to begin today
Content:
CLEARED SKHER

Kolhapur: Hearing of a complaint filed by Akkalkot tehsildar against BJP Solapur MP Dr Jaysiddheshwar Mahaswami for allegedly submitting fake caste certificate is expected to begin in Solapur court on Wednesday.

Earlier, Bombay high court on Monday, refused to grant any interim stay on the hearing on the ground that Akkalkot tehsildar had already filed complaint against Mahaswami. The HC had said that they would have given stay had the tehsildar not filed any complaint. The next hearing of the case in high court is scheduled for Friday.

Akkalkot tehsildar Balsaheb Sirsat filed a criminal complaint against Mahaswami as directed by district caste verification committee. The complaint was filed on Saturday.

The complaint has been filed under various sections of Indian Penal Code (IPC) including 467 (forgery of valuable security or will and etc) 469 (forgery for purpose of harming reputation), 471 (using as a genuine forged document) and 480 (using false trademark).

BJP MP is in trouble because his caste certificate was declared invalid by district caste verification committee on February 24. The committee has said in its ruling that Mahaswami belongs to Jangam community while he submitted a certificate showing that he is from Beda Jangam community. The committee had ordered Akkalkot tehsildar to file criminal case in the court.

Title: ‚ÄòSaints championed cause of brotherhood, social harmony‚Äô
Content:
Sardar Atal Bahadur Singh was felicitated on his 79th birthday, on Monday

Nagpur: Saints laid the foundation of equality and set a benchmark for the society to follow certain norms to keep the social fabric intact. They were the real harbingers of peace as is evident in their literature, said Sachin Pawar, editor of Warkari Darshan, Pune, at university convocation hall on Monday.

He was delivering the keynote address on ‚ÄòSantanche samajik yogdan‚Äô, organized by Nagpur University and Navshakti Mitramandal as part of Sardar Atal Bahadur Singh lecture series. Vice-chancellor SP Kane, officiating pro-VC Vinayak Deshpande, former MP Datta Meghe and former mayor Atal Bahadur Singh were the chief guests.

With caste and creed taking the centre stage in the present context, the teachings of saints who always promoted brotherhood should be assiduously followed. Their words of wisdom should be implemented to keep the society well-knitted, he said.

‚ÄúSaints like Dnyaneshwar, Tukaram and Namdev were at the forefront of enlightening the society of the perils of caste and creed. They did not allow caste to become a barrier and treated all as one. We need this ‚Äòoneness‚Äô at this juncture,‚Äù Pawar said.

Maharashtra has the rich legacy of ushering in social reforms. This land not only produced saints but also towering social reformers who brought about a change and ensured that people lived with harmony. Therefore, it is the duty of the society to stay united irrespective of differences of opinions, he added.

Expansion of social networks seems to have made people forget values their forefathers strove for. People should not allow vested interests take control of their life, he said.

In his introductory remarks, Sahebrao Raut underlined the need to keep aloft the values saints and social reformers preached for centuries and carry forward their mission.

Kane thanked Pawar for highlighting important issues. Pawar and Atal Bahadur Singh were felicitated on the occasion.

Amrita Indurkar conducted the proceedings.

Title: UP: Retired IAS to reboot free SC/ST coaching
Content:
One of the free coaching centres

LUCKNOW: Taking note of the dismal record of the free coaching institutes for SC/ST and OBC aspirants to help them prepare for the civil services exam, the social welfare department is now planning to appoint retired IAS officials at the helm of these institutes to streamline their operations and deliver better results.

In the past 20 years, only three students of these coaching institutes could make it to Indian Revenue Service (IRS) and customs and excise, while some cleared other exams, but none were able to gain entry into the IAS or IPS.

Officials say the infrastructure of these residential coaching centres is so poor that around 200-300 seats of the 1,250 on offer are vacant and cite poor policy and lack of funds as reasons for the poor conditions.

There are seven institutes in UP ‚Äî two in Lucknow and one each in Prayagraj, Hapur, Aligarh, Agra and Varanasi.

The building of the co-ed institute in Hapur is in a rundown state and needs immediate repairs and renovation. Around 300 seats are vacant due to the poor state of buildings and lack of resources, said an official. Students, whose family income is less than Rs 6 lakh per annum, are selected for the coaching through a written test.

Retd IAS to head 6 out of 7 centres

‚ÄúThese coaching institutes were set up by Mayawati government. The idea was good, but due to practical operational difficulties their results have not been up to the mark. The government is, however, addressing these issues and we are planning to improve the quality of education in these institutes,‚Äù said a senior government official.

The department is planning to post retired IAS officers as head of six of the seven institutes for a term of two years to streamline their functioning and improve results.

‚ÄúEarlier, the coaching duration was just six months, but in 2019, we increased it to a year. The coaching for a tough exam like civil services cannot be of six months since the duration is too short to prepare the aspirants well enough to crack the exam. However, many students we get come from underprivileged category background and they are happy to clear recruitment exam for lower jobs after undergoing the coaching. We need to motivate them to work harder to qualify for IAS and IPS,‚Äù the officer said.

‚ÄúThere are certain other aspects also which need a rethink. For instance, students can take this coaching just once. Civil services aspirants prepare for years, hence those from deprived sections cannot be expected to clear the exam in one attempt. Besides, the guest lecturers are also not paid very well, which is one reason why the quality gets compromised. The appointment of retired bureaucrats as directors of these institutes would improve functioning and results,‚Äù he said.

Title: Kerala HC relief for Arooja‚Äôs students
Content:
Representative image

KOCHI: The high court on Tuesday allowed 34 Class X students of Arooja‚Äôs Little Stars School at Moolamkuzhi here to write the remaining CBSE board exams.

A division bench of Justice AM Shaffique and Justice VG Arun issued the order after considering an appeal by 28 students through advocate T Sanjay. They had challenged a single bench‚Äôs decision not to allow them to appear for the ongoing exams.

In addition to the 28 students, the division bench also allowed six more students of the school, who were not parties in the appeal, to appear for the exams.

The court also allowed four students of Al Azhar school of Palluruthy, who were in a similar predicament, to appear for the remaining exams.

Through the interim order, the court directed CBSE to allow the students to appear for the exams provisionally. As per the order, the students can appear for the exams to be held on March 4, 12, and 18. The court clarified that the students cannot claim any equity on account of its interim order and that declaration of their results will be subject to further orders to be passed by it.

The interim order came after CBSE informed the court that it is not possible to file an affidavit explaining whether any student from any unrecognized school has been allowed to write the ongoing Class X exams through any recognized school. CBSE had told the court that there are around 25,000 schools under it and it was practically difficult to file an affidavit on the issue.

During the hearing, CBSE had submitted that Arooja‚Äôs school lacked basic facilities and there aren‚Äôt adequate toilets for its 350 students. The state government also informed the court that Arooja‚Äôs school did not have the required facilities and that it operates in a very small space. The government further submitted that there are practical difficulties in allowing the students from unrecognized schools to appear for board exams conducted by it as the subjects and internal assessment methods differ. The court will consider the case again on March 23.

Title: Out-of-state firms control 50 per cent Kerala‚Äôs IMFL market
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The decision in the latest excise policy to charge fee on distilleries from outside the state for tie-ups with the distilleries in the state was taken after facts revealed that at least half of the IMFL market in the state is controlled by companies outside the state.Even though the government had earlier claimed that 92% of IMFL consumed in Kerala is locally manufactured, detailed statistics dispute the claim. Figures show that bigger companies outside the state control half of the IMFL supplied in the state.While a minuscule share of IMFL is produced from outside the state by such companies, the rest of the IMFL supplied is manufactured in the locally-registered units, many of which function as proxy units for the outsiders. According to excise department sources, the outside majors enter into a ‚Äòtie-up‚Äô arrangement with the local manufacturers, who lease out their men and machinery to the outsiders on commission basis for the outsiders to manufacture their products here, on commission basis per case of IMFL produced.Data accessed by TOI for 2016-17, 2017-18 and first half of 2018-19, shows that the actual share of outside liquor manufacturers who supply their products by producing them in the local units in the state are 46.78%, 43.61% and 35.34%, respectively. This is in addition to the 8% that are brought from outside the state, which would take the market share of outsiders to more than 50%.As per data, some of the outsiders from Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra, Punjab, Uttar Pradesh, Telangana, Madhya Pradesh and Goa have manufactured all their products in the state from local units like Empee Distilleries, Polsons Distillery, United Distilleries and Elite Distilleries.With the latest excise policy deciding to charge Rs 2 lakh per company entering into a tie-up with a local company, it is expected that the government will earn at least Rs 1 crore.At present, the state has issued licences to 18 compounding blending and bottling units, and three breweries. Of these, 17 blending units are operational, while United Spirits Limited at Cherthala and Palakkad are dysfunctional, though their licences are still valid. Till now, the government has been charging approximately Rs 6 lakh per year as licence fee for a blending unit, and approximately Rs 4 lakh per year for a brewery licence. As per the latest excise policy, this fee will be doubled to Rs 12 lakh and Rs 8 lakh, respectively.

Title: MOCCA invoked against Sangli‚Äôs Koli gang
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

KOLHAPUR: Sangli police have invoked Maharashtra Control of Organized Crime ( MCOCA ) against five members of Santosh Koli gang. Inspector General (special) Suhas Warke has sanctioned a proposal in this regard.

Five members of the gang, including Santosh Mahadeo Koli (40), Shantkumar alsia Shantnu Mahadeo Koli (35), Hari Patgaonkar (39), Suraj Shahaji Diwse (29) and Sachin Kakasaheb Gaikwad (27), who have already been arrested, will now face MCOCA charges.

Miraj police inspector Raju Tashildar said that the gang was operating gambling dens at several places in Sangli, Miraj, MIDC and Kupwad and was involved in several other criminal activities.

Koli gang was also involved in private moneylending, police said, adding that the gang often intimidated people for recovery of principal amount and interest. Police said that Koli gang had amassed a lot of wealth and property by illegal means.

Around two months back, the Sangli police had arrested Sanjay Koli and others when a complaint was filed against them by Sanjay Mirajkar . The complainant said that he had taken Rs 51 lakh from Koli and had repaid more than Rs 2 crore; however, he was being continuously threatened.

According to police, Mirajkar had taken the said loan to start a business. In his complaint, Mirajkar said that Koli gang had threatened to get his kidney removed if he failed to give them money.

Meanwhile, in a separate case, Miraj police arrested three more people for threatening and assaulting a man who had taken money from nine people to start a photography business.

Title: Data seized, accused in judicial custody
Content:
Kochi: The crime branch on Tuesday seized the hard disk of the office computer used by Vishnu Prasad , a clerk with Ernakulam district administration who was arrested on Monday.

Investigators also seized the personal laptop of Vishnu Prasad, the first accused in the case related to diversion of flood relief fund, from his residence in Kakkanad. Vishnu Prasad, who was attached to the disaster management cell of Ernakulam collectorate was earlier suspended for alleged misappropriation of the funds to the tune of Rs 10.54 lakh.

Vishnu Prasad was produced before the vigilance court in Muvattupuzha on Tuesday and remanded in judicial custody for two weeks.

According to officials, two others Mahesh B and Anwar M M, the second and third accused in the case are absconding.

Vishnu Prasad, who has been charged with criminal conspiracy and misappropriation of property, had illegaly shared the account details of those people to whom fund transfer had failed. These account numbers were then tampered with and funds were transferred to an account in Ayyanad cooperative bank and Kakkanad branch of Federal Bank, sources said.

Anwar, who had an account in Ayyanad cooperative bank, then withdrew part of the amount and transferred the rest to accounts held by him and his wife at HDFC bank.

Title: 2,641 new industrial units provided jobs to 57,314 state residents: Uttarakhand Governor
Content:
Representative image

GAIRSAIN: Amidst uproar by the Opposition members, Uttarakhand governor Baby Rani Maurya, on Tuesday, addressed the joint House on the opening day of the budget session of the state legislative assembly.

In her 40-minute-long speech, she said that 2,641 industrial units have been set up in the state bringing an investment of Rs 3,524 crore. She added that these units have provided jobs to 57,314 state residents. She also mentioned that land for construction of a mini secretariat at Gairsain has been identified.

Governor Maurya further stated that the state government has taken significant steps in strengthening the industrial sector. She pointed out that hill state has moved from 23rd to 9th position in the Ease of Doing Business index. ‚ÄúTo boost state‚Äôs economy, the government has made amendment in the policies of eight sectors and introduced 10 new policies,‚Äù she said.

Coming to the steps taken for disaster management, governor Maurya said, ‚ÄúTo gauge the magnitude of an earthquake, the state used Rapid Visual Screening technology to set up 107 automated weather stations, surface field observatories, 16 snow gauges and 28 automatic rain gauges. With technical support from India Meteorological Department , a Disaster Management Authority has also been set up.‚Äù She added that Rs 1,794 crore has been released for the rehabilitation of 609 disaster-hit families of 22 villages.

Governor Maurya also assured that the country‚Äôs longest motorable single lane bridge in Pratapnagar's Dobra Chanti would soon be dedicated to the people.

With regards to the steps taken in the education sector, governor Maurya said that virtual classrooms would be developed in 500 public schools of the state. Sanitation facilities and computer education in primary and secondary public school is also a priority, she added.

Title: Man arrested for duping woman
Content:
Karveer police have arrested a man for allegedly cheating a woman by offering her attractive returns on investing in the share market. Gayatri Dhruv Jadhav, a resident of Ramanandnagar, had lodged a complaint against one Prithviraj Mohite (45), a resident of Rajweer Heights, Ramanandnagar on February 21. As per the complaint, Mohite promised Gayatri handsome returns on investing in the share market and made her invest Rs 14.1 lakh between February 2018 to September 2019. Initially, Mohite gave her the returns but with time, he delayed or refused Gayatri her due payment. Mohite had been on the run ever since Gayatri lodged a complaint. He has now been remanded in police custody for five days.

8 get 3-yrs RI: District and sessions judge D K Gudghe sentenced eight people to three-years rigorous imprisonment for attemp to murder. Kundlik Chowgule, Nitin Chowgule, Ajit Chowgule, Santosh Bhalekar, Uttam Chowgule, Dinkar Chowgule, Vishal Chowgule and Sarjerao Chowgule‚Äîall residents of Thadyachiwadi, Bhidargad taluka‚Äîwere convicted. The eight convicts had attacked three people from the same village over a local dispute in April 2015.

2 jailed for misconduct: Sangli court has sentenced two people to two-months simple imprisonment for misbehaving with government employees. In April 6, 2014, Vilas Subhash Nikam, who was in an inebriated state, refused to pay the fare for the state bus he was travelling in. When the conductor had asked him to get down, Nikam, along with one Sunil Uallappa Hurde, stopped the bus and abused the bus conductor and the driver.

Title: 45-yr-old woman dies after truck hits scooter from behind
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: A 45-year-old woman was killed after the scooter she was riding pillion was hit by a speeding truck near Maukampur flyover in Nehru Colony police station area on Tuesday.

The deceased has been identified as Bindu Nayak, a resident of Sainik Colony in Nehru Colony area. She was reportedly going with her husband from Jogiwala to Harrawala.

According to police, the couple was heading towards Maukampur flyover when a speeding truck coming from behind hit their scooter and they fell on the road. Bindu Nayak was crushed to death by the truck coming from behind. However, Bindu‚Äôs husband escaped the accident with minor injuries.

Meanwhile, the police have seized the truck and have initiated action against the accused driver.

Title: BJP ignored pipeline project: Cong-NCP
Content:
Kolhapur: Congress and NCP corporators on Tuesday slammed their counterparts from BJP and Tararani Aghadi leaders for delay in completion of Kalammawadi direct pipeline project .

The Rs 488 crore project meant to supply water from Kalammawadi dam to the city started in 2014. On Monday, BJP-Tararani Aghadi corporators, who are in opposition in the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC), had stated that owing to poor planning the project is yet to be completed and Congress leaders should be held responsible for it.

In reply, Congress and NCP corporators on Tuesday said since 2014, the BJP was in power and did nothing to get the permissions required from various departments to speed up the work.

Sharangdhar Deshmukh, Congress corporator, said, ‚ÄúWe believe that for petty political gains, the then minister and now BJP‚Äôs state president Chandrakant Patil and former BJP MLA Amal Mahadik obstructed various departments from granting permissions. Both did not hold a single meeting with authorities to speed up the work or visit the project sites. We believe this project is very important for the citizens. Around 90% of the work has been completed and we are hopeful that the project will be commissioned by this year end.‚Äù

The opposition has challenged the Congress and NCP corporators to complete the project and start supplying drinking water to the citizens before the civic elections that are due in November this year.

‚ÄúIf the project is commissioned, the BJP-Tararani Aghadi will not contest the election and if not then the Congress and NCP should stay away from contesting,‚Äù said BJP corporator Vijay Suryawanshi.

Deputy mayor Sanjay Mohite said, ‚ÄúIn recent Lok Sabha and state assembly elections, the BJP-Tararani Aghadi corporators raised the issue of delays in pipeline project. However, people did not buy their argument. They were the ones who opposed the project and do not have right to speak on it.‚Äù

Title: Coronavirus in Pune: Four more travellers isolated to rule out coronavirus infection
Content: PUNE: Four more travellers were quarantined at the Pune Municipal Corporation‚Äôs Naidu hospital on Tuesday after complains of flu-like symptoms. The seven individuals, who were isolated at the facility on Monday, have tested negative for the contagion.‚ÄúThe newly admitted travellers complained of cough, cold, fever, sore throat and headache. Their throat swab samples have been sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) for testing. We will get their reports on Wednesday,‚Äù a civic health official said, adding that three of them had returned from Italy, while one from the US via Dubai.As per the new guidelines issued by the Union health ministry, travellers arriving from China, Hong Kong, Thailand, Singapore, South Korea, Japan, Nepal, Indonesia, Vietnam, Malaysia, Iran and Italy are being screened at the airports.A total of 65,621 passengers returning from China and other affected countries have been screened at Mumbai‚Äôs Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport (CSMIA) since January 18. Of them, 401 were put under 14-day surveillance and 152 were quarantined in Mumbai, Pune and Nagpur, among other parts of the state, after they complained of flu-like symptoms. Most of them tested negative for the infection and were discharged.A total of 318 of the other travellers, who also visited the affected countries but didn‚Äôt develop any symptoms, have completed the mandatory 14-day follow-up by staying quarantined in their respective homes.Apart from Pune, Mumbai and Thane, travellers are also being monitored in Nanded, Buldhana, Nagpur, Wardha, Sangli, Ahmednagar, Amaravati, Palghar, Jalgaon, Chandrapur and Satara districts.Health officials have said family, friends, colleagues and other close contacts of the travellers who returned from the affected countries should report themselves to health officials in case of developing flu-like symptoms.

Title: Sangli health department's letter on coronavirus monitoring goes viral
Content: KOLHAPUR: A letter, dated February 27, which was undersigned by the Sangli district health officer and district civil surgeon and instructed medical officers to keep an eye on individuals with travel history to coronavirus-infected countries (to monitor their situation) has gone viral in the Sangli region.The letter has names of seven individuals and their detailed addresses. After getting to know of the goof-up, Sangli district civil surgeon Sanjay Salunkhe clarified that the said individuals merely had a travel history to these countries and they were asymptomatic.In his appeal to the media, Salunkhe said: ‚ÄúThe details of individuals who have returned to Sangli have wrongly been made viral, saying that they are infected by coronavirus . The truth is, they are all asymptomatic in nature. They are normal people just like every one of us. They have already been screened by the state government authorities upon their arrival at the airport. They were later released after it was made sure that they had no symptoms.‚ÄùHe further added that generally, the returning passengers, who have travel history to the coronavirus-hit countries, are sent to their respective district‚Äôs civil surgeons and survey officers of the health department, so that they can be monitored for any kind of health-related issues.He said until now, not a single coronavirus patient has been found or reported in the Sangli district and it is the need of the hour to stop spreading the rumours about these individuals being patients or even suspects. They are all healthy.Salunkhe has appealed to people to not reveal the names of these individuals, as it is a violation of their privacy.While speaking to TOI, he said that the individuals are regularly monitored as per the health department‚Äôs protocol. Meanwhile, the medical experts have said that while no specific anti-viral treatment is available for the ailment, precautionary steps are advised including good personal hygiene, handwashing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, close contact with people who are sick and consumption of raw or undercooked animal products.

Title: Google, Microsoft funds boost for government schools in Uttar Pradesh
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: Government schools in the state will get a helping hand from corporate giants like Google and Microsoft in building infrastructure and using technology to provide better education.

In a first-of-its-kind two-day ‚ÄòCSR conclave‚Äô, to be organised by UP basic education department from Wednesday, Google, Microsoft, Indian Oil and other bigwigs will pledge an assistance of Rs 114 crore to revamp infrastructure and strengthen foundation learning in UP‚Äôs government schools.

Organised at Dr Ram Manohar Lohia National Law University, the conclave will focus on adoption of best practices for imparting quality education. Various brainstorming sessions and panel discussions on governance framework for basic education and foundation learning will be held.

The event will also witness the signing of a memorandum of understanding between the corporate giants and the basic education department.

‚ÄúAs many as 109 multinational companies have extended their support to improve infrastructure and impart quality education by use of information and technology,‚Äù state minister for basic education Satish Chandra Dwivedi told mediapersons on Tuesday. Dwivedi said: ‚ÄúThese companies will provide support of Rs 114 crore for the purpose.‚Äù Various non-government organisations will also be a part of the conclave.

The event will be inaugurated by chief minister Yogi Adityanath . On the occasion, 10 academic resource persons will be felicitated by the department and 20 students will be awarded for their work in Meena Manch‚Äîa club for adolescent girls in UP government schools. The club motivates students to reject child marriage, continue their education and develop leadership and life skills.

Director general of school education Vijay Kiran Anand said that this conclave will help in getting support of institutions, and big names of the corporate sector will provide a boost to usage of hi-tech technology to impart education in government schools. It will also help enhance framework of basic education by adoption of the best practises for primary education, he said.

Title: Cows injure 5-yr-old in Gujarat, owners booked for culpable homicide
Content:
Two cattle owners were booked for attempted culpable homicide by city police on Monday, as their cows hit a fi... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Two cattle owners were booked for attempted culpable homicide by city police on Monday, as their cows hit a five-year-old girl in the Odhav area of the city on Sunday night. The two were also booked under the SC/ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act as the girl belongs to a Dalit community. The accused knew it and allegedly hurled casteist abuse at her father.

In his FIR with Odhav police, Hitendra Parmar, 26, a resident of Umiyanagar near Rabari Vasahat, stated that the two accused, Ashish Desai and Amrut Desai, both around 25 and residents of the same neighbourhood, were herding 10 cows when Parmar‚Äôs five-year-old daughter Neha suffered injuries.

Parmar said the incident took place due to the negligence of the duo, who were prodding the cows along by hitting them with sticks while riding two motorcycles.

‚ÄúOn Sunday at around 8.30pm, my children were playing outside the house and the two accused were herding their cows, during which a cow hit my daughter. She suffered severe injuries to her shoulder. Another girl who was playing with my daughter also suffered injuries,‚Äù Parmar said in the FIR.

Parmar and other local residents rushed to help the injured girl and some of them reprimanded the duo for their negligence. The two accused persons, instead of showing remorse, began threatening the residents.

The duo threatened Parmar with dire consequences if he allowed his children to play outside again, claiming that they obstructed the path of his cattle, the FIR states.

Parmar then took his daughter to Shardaben Hospital in Saraspur, where she was diagnosed with multiple fractures in her shoulder. Parmar later approached Odhav police and filed a complaint against Ashish and Amrut.

Inspector Ravirajsinh Jadeja of Odhav police said the case was transferred to the ACP of the SC/ST cell for investigation. ‚ÄúThe accused persons uttered casteist slurs and hence atrocity charges were invoked against them,‚Äù he said.

Title: Goa: Canacona school chosen to aid girls pursue science, technology
Content:
Representative image

MARGAO: Jawahar Navodaya Vidyalaya , ( JNV ) Canacona , has been identified to act as Vigyan Jyoti Knowledge Centre in Goa to cater to girls from small towns and rural areas of South Goa. It has been tasked with bringing in girls from diverse backgrounds in science , technology , engineering and mathematics (STEM).

The Vigyan Jyoti programme was formally inaugurated at Jawahar Navodaya Vidyalaya, Canacona, recently.

Vigyan Jyoti is a new scheme by the department of science and technology (DST) which aims at increasing the participation of women by making focused interventions during the early years of education.

Based on the selection criteria issued by the DST, 50 Class XI girl students studying in different schools of Canacona like Jawahar Navodaya Vidyalaya, S S Angle Higher Secondary School, Government Higher Secondary School and Shri Mallikarjun Senior Secondary School have been inducted to this year-long programme consisting of science camps, visits to knowledge partners (KPs), hands-on experiments, workshops at Atal Tinkering Lab, interaction with women role models, counselling of students and parents, visits to other R&D lab, industry, NGO, lectures, special needs-based classes. A scholarship of Rs 1,000 per month will also be provided to girl students participating in the project.

ICAR-CCARI Goa director Eknath Chakurkar stressed the need of educating girl children and said that rural girl children who are deprived of higher education would highly benefit from this programme.

Knowledge partners of this Vigyan Jyoti Programme are Goa University , BITS-Pilani Goa Campus, ICAR and NIO.

Title: MBBS final year student from Punjab hangs self at AIIMS Rishikesh hostel
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: An MBBS final year student of All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) Rishikesh hanged himself at his college hostel late on Monday.

The body has been handed over to the family after conducting post mortem.

Talking to TOI, PRO of AIIMS Rishikesh Harish Thapliyal said that the student, identified as Saheb Deep Singh (21) and a resident of Punjab, was found hanging in his hostel room. ‚ÄúWe had informed police and an FIR was also registered. The brother and uncle of the deceased had reached AIIMS to claim the body,‚Äù he said, adding that a suicide note was recovered from the boy‚Äôs room which mentioned that no one should be blamed for the act.

According to Singh‚Äôs teachers, he was one of the brightest students of his class and used to score among top 10 in all subjects. He was also good in sports and used to play badminton.

‚ÄúThere was no sign of depressing in him. His father met with an accident last month due to which he was bedridden but he was recovered now. So, we don‚Äôt see any point of him killing himself for any reason,‚Äù a teacher said.

Meanwhile, the institution observed condolence of two minutes to remember the student. His friends and teachers are in a state of shock.

‚ÄúWhile finances and domestic violence are prime reason of suicides in the country, academic stress is a major reason for suicides among both female and male students in India,‚Äù said Dr Vipul Singh, a psychologist.

Title: Coronavirus prevention: What is your best defence against COVID-19
Content: The highly infectious novel coronavirus (COVID-19) has spread across more than 70 countries, with nearly 3000 people succumbing to the epidemic. The number of confirmed cases has already crossed 80,000 worldwide and more countries are reporting their first coronavirus fatalities. With no vaccine or definitive cure in sight, people across the globe are frantically searching for means to prevent themselves from this fatal infection.It is important to get your basics right when you are dealing with any kind of infectious disease and the same is applicable to COVID-19. This respiratory condition is known to spread through droplets and vapours that we eject through our mouth as we cough, sneeze or talk. If you get these respiratory droplets in your hands and touch your mouth, nose and eyes, you are quite likely to get infected.The best way to protect yourself is sticking to the basics i.e. washing your hands frequently. Yes, practising basic personal hygiene still remains the most effective method of prevention in this battle against the epidemic. It is important to understand that washing your hands with soap and water and using an alcohol-based hand sanitizer isn‚Äôt one and the same thing.According to experts, hand sanitizers are not able to get rid of stomach bug norovirus and the bacteria causing the C. difficile infection. On the contrary, handwashing not only actually kills the germs but it also removes dirt and grime which can make you sick. So, make it a point to only use hand sanitizer when you cannot get your hands to a clean water supply and soap. However, at the same time, it is important to wash your hands properly to get rid of all the pathogens. Here is a step-by-step guide on how you should wash your hands thoroughly to prevent the spread of infections1. Wet your hands with clean, running water. Use your elbow to turn off the tap as touching it with your hands may increase the risk of contamination.2. Lather up your hands and fingers with soap.3. Be sure to lather the backs of your hands, between your fingers, and under your nails.4. It is important to rub your hands together for at least 20 seconds, as it creates friction which helps in getting rid of dirt, grease, and microbes from skin.5. As a rule of thumb, hum the ‚Äúhappy birthday song‚Äù from start to finish twice to time how long you should wash your hands.6. After you are done scrubbing, wash your hands with clean, running water.7 Dry your hands using a single-use clean towel or air-dry them.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: 36 of Hyderabad techie‚Äôs contacts show symptoms of coronavirus
Content: HYDERABAD/ BENGALURU: At least 36 of the 88 people that the 24-year-old software professional from Hyderabad came in contact with after returning from Dubai are showing ‚Äúsome symptoms‚Äù of Covid-19, Telangana government officials said on Tuesday.While 45 of his contacts were taken to the state-run Gandhi Hospital since Monday night, the remaining, who were not symptomatic, have been kept in isolation at their homes. The results for the 36 symptomatic patients are expected on Wednesday, said health authorities. ‚ÄúThe 36 include his co-passengers in the bus that he took from Bengaluru to Hyderabad and family members,‚Äù said Vijay Kumar, state nodal officer for Coronavirus detection. Sources, however, said that showing symptoms doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean that they have been infected and their samples may still test negative for the virus.The IT professional works at a tech park in the outskirts of Bengaluru and stays in a PG accommodation. He travelled to Dubai on an assignment on February 15 and returned to Bengaluru on February 20. He attended office for two days ‚Äî February 20 and 21 ‚Äî before taking the bus to Hyderabad. His samples had tested positive on Monday.The Telangana government, for its part, has allocated Rs 100 crore for preventing and containing a possible virus outbreak. The fund will be used for extensive awareness activities. Besides, private hospitals have been given a directive not to delay reporting cases when they have symptoms of the virus.State health minister Eatala Rajender has sought 50,000 additional masks from the Centre given the shortage in Hyderabad. He has also sought help to enhance testing capacity in the state. Also, 104 helpline has been established exclusively for Coronavirus-related queries.The decisions were taken after Rajender, municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao and Panchayat Raj minister Errabelli Dayakar Rao met officials of various departments on Tuesday.‚ÄúThere is no local transmission so far. The only positive case is with a travel history of Dubai but all precautionary measures have been put in place. We are constantly in touch with the Centre over preparatory measures to be taken. A 15-member team will visit Kerala on Wednesday to study the measures taken there,‚Äù said Rajender.The health department will run awareness campaigns and put up hoardings, notice boards at parks, courts, bus stands, in flights, rail, cinema halls, schools and hospitals.In addition to three designated hospitals for isolating patients, military hospital, TB sanitorium Vikarabad and all teaching hospitals around Hyderabad have been asked to prepare isolation wards. With state and government hospitals put together, the government has identified 3,000 beds for isolation.‚ÄúSince Covid-19 affects lungs, pulmonologists are required for the treatment. Currently 24, pulmonologists have been allocated to deal with cases, 20 more have been identified and kept on standby. We are also contacting retired doctors, professors and nurses to have a pool of workforce to press into action, if the need arises,‚Äù said Rajender.Rajender added that he had spoken with the Union minister of health Dr Harsh Vardhan and urged him to sanction an additional laboratory at the Institute of Preventive Medicine (IPM). "As of now, we have only one laboratory at Gandhi Hospital which can test 120 samples a day," he said.The minister asked people not ‚Äòshake hands‚Äô and only say ‚Äònamaskaram‚Äô with folded hands at least for some time. Also, he asked the people to postpone their travel abroad if it is not important.

Title: States race to put brakes on spread of virus and rumours
Content: NEW DELHI: As the coronavirus scare hits home, states are scurrying to plug holes in health surveillance, put preventive mechanisms in place, and stem the panic fuelled by a surge of rumours and misinformation since two more positive cases were reported on Monday.In Telangana, two back-to-back cabinet meetings were held on Tuesday to review the situation and devise an action plan. One of the decisions taken was to send a team to Kerala on Wednesday to speak to officials there on what they did right to combat the threat after the first case was reported. Hoardings carrying information on novel coronavirus will come up across Hyderabad district in three languages ‚Äî Telugu, Hindi and English ‚Äî as part of an awareness drive to combat fear. Telangana is also enhancing the capacity of its call centres dedicated to answering coronavirus-related queries.Rajasthan, too, has been on high alert since an Italian tourist tested positive for Covid-19. CM Ashok Gehlot took stock of the state‚Äôs preparedness in an emergency meeting late on Monday, after which the health department issued an advisory to all hotels to fumigate the rooms in which a large group of Italian tourists had stayed during their Rajasthan trip. The health department is also drawing up a list of hotel staff who were in contact with the tourists.Surveillance of patients with severe acute respiratory infection and influenza-like illness has been strengthened across all 33 districts. A series of awareness activities have been planned to bust myths and dispel rumours. ‚ÄúRapid response teams have been formed in all districts. Sanitisation of hotels is under way. We are advising people not to panic. They only need to remain vigilant and follow basic hygiene regularly,‚Äù additional chief secretary (health) Rohit Kumar Singh told TOI.In Bengaluru, health minister B Sriramulu said, ‚ÄúKarnataka has set up 630 beds in isolation wards across hospitals exclusively for suspected cases. Besides, 1,689 beds have been reserved in private hospitals.‚Äù Screening of international passengers from affected countries had started at Bengaluru airport on January 20. Till Monday, 39,391 people underwent thermal screening. Of the 468 people who had come from virus-hit countries, 284 were recommended home isolation. Of them, 179 have completed the mandated 28 days of observation. All samples from suspected cases have turned out negative.

Title: After enjoying a short trip to Dubai, Hrithik Roshan returns to Mumbai; gets snapped at the airport
Content: Rhea Chakraborty continues to be under the scanner for abetment to suicide. However, the CBI is yet to find any motive for abetment. An audit of Sushant‚Äôs bank account was recently conducted which did not suggest that Rhea siphoned off funds and this led to the actor‚Äôs suicide.

Title: Man to spend 15 years in jail for raping two seven-year-old girls
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: A special Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act court on Tuesday convicted and sentenced a 30-year-old man to 15 years of imprisonment for sexually assaulting two seven-year-old girls in 2017. The accused, Vijay Shaha, was caught redhanded by a man who saw him assault one of the two girls.

Among the witnesses examined by special public prosecutor, VD More, were the two minors who deposed in August 2019. The mother of one of the girls, who also deposed, told the court she ran a tiffin service and Shaha was her customer.

The eyewitness had told the police he worked as a watchman in a cement godown and used to be stationed in the parking area. He said on October 29, 2017, he

arrived for duty around 6 pm. The man said 10-15 minutes later, he saw the accused walk in the direction of the godown with the two minors. He said they walked into the nearby bushes.

The eyewitness said when the trio didn‚Äôt return after several minutes, he got suspicious. He said when he went to the bushes, he saw the accused sexually assault one of the minors.

He said he caught the accused and slapped him. The witness said that he also screamed for help. He said people gathered at the spot and they thrashed the accused. With their help, the accused was handed over to the police. The minors were also taken to the police station.

The minors told the court they were playing when the accused came and asked them to accompany him. They described the assault.

The mother said on the evening of the incident someone came home to inform her her daughter was taken to the police station. She said when she rushed there, she saw the accused and the girls.

The mother said the girls told her about the assault and how the accused had been caught. She said she then filed the complaint against the accused. She identified the accused in court.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Mumbai: Senior executive appeals conviction in flight molestation case
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: The Bombay HC on Tuesday admitted a flyer's appeal against his conviction for sexual assault of a child actor in mid-air, suspended the sentence and continued his bail.

When the appeal by Vikas Sachdeva, a former senior executive of an entertainment firm, came up before Justice Prithviraj Chavan, he granted bail of Rs 25,000 with two sureties of like amount, but directed him not to leave the city without court permission.

"There is no scope of the appeal being heard and decided in the near future and since the sentence imposed is short, it stands suspended," the HC said.

On January 15, special trial court judge A D Deo had held Sachdeva, 41, guilty under Section 8 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act. He had been accused of putting up his foot and touching the 17-year-old co-passenger, sitting ahead of him in the business class, on her shoulder and neck on a flight from Delhi to Mumbai in December 2017. Relying on the complainant's deposition, the judge had convicted Sachdeva and sentenced him to three years' imprisonment. He was granted bail.

On Tuesday, Justice Chavan asked why the Pocso victim be disbelieved. Sachdeva's counsel Aniket Nikam argued there was "no independent evidence" to support her case and that her deposition was "shrouded in omissions and improvements".

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: NCLT clears NBCC offer for Jaypee Infratech
Content:
Jaypee Infratech still has to deliver apartments, plots and villas to nearly 21,000 homebuyers (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The National Company Law Tribunal on Tuesday approved NBCC ‚Äôs offer to take over Jaypee Infratech , which has to deliver apartments, plots and villas to nearly 21,000 homebuyers.

NCLT‚Äôs principal bench, headed by acting president BSV Prakash Kumar, approved the PSU‚Äôs proposal to take over the company, along with the Taj Expressway, with certain conditions. The details would be known once the written order is issued.

The tribunal ruled the Rs 750-crore deposited by JIL‚Äôs promoter Jaiprakash Associates Ltd (JAL) with the Supreme Court registry will be returned to JIL and be part of the resolution plan.

Jaypee buyers hope NBCC will stick to 2024 deadline

It makes more attractive proposition for NBCC. Last week, the apex court had ruled that 858 acres of JIL land was wrongfully mortgaged by JAL to secure its bank loans.

The NCLT ruling came just ahead of the expiry of the SC deadline for deciding on the case that has been through various legal forums since the government and RBI ordered insolvency proceedings against 12 high-profile companies, including JIL, in August 2017.

Government sources, who have been closely monitoring the case given the massive public interest, said it could take a few months for final commencement of work on the ground as any of the parties in the long-drawn legal battle can appeal against the NCLT ruling in the National Company Law Appellate Tribunal or SC.

Homebuyers, some of whom have been waiting to get their apartments for a decade, were elated by the decision and hoped that NBCC could stick to the schedule and complete construction by mid-2024.

For the government too, it has been an arduous battle with finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman stepping in a few months ago with the corporate affairs and urban development ministries joining hands to ensure that NBCC came on board, while the lenders and UP government agencies were also on the same page.

Title: Coronavirus News in Andhra Pradesh: Andhra Pradesh transport department, railways on high alert
Content:
Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: Following reports of a person having tested positive for coronavirus (COVID-19) in Hyderabad, the Andhra Pradesh public transport department and the railways are on high alert. Health authorities have noted that since the virus can be transmitted upon direct contact, it is necessary to be vigilant on the public transport front.

On February 20, a techie arrived in Bengaluru and subsequently journeyed to Hyderabad on a bus on February 22. On being tested positive for the virus, he has been placed under observation at a government-run hospital. Telangana government is also on high alert.

Speaking to TOI, Ravi Kumar, executive director of the public transport department said that the department has started taking precautionary measures to spread information about COVID-19.

He added that posters about the disease have been pasted on buses going to and arriving from Hyderabad. He informed that the public transport department runs nearly 100 buses along the route, along with those that run between Visakhapatnam and Hyderabad. Nearly 3,000 passengers commute between Hyderabad and the Visakhapatnam region every day.

Health authorities have also instructed operators of private buses to track the health of passengers before they board the buses in Hyderabad.

The Railways is also on alert. Authorities informed that around 25 trains move between Hyderabad and Visakhapatnam daily. The most popular trains among these are Godavari Express, Garibrath, Duronto and Visakha Express.

‚ÄúWe have received orders to track the health of passengers at railway stations. Passengers coming from Hyderabad to stations in Andhra Pradesh should ideally wear masks and avoid direct contact with people,‚Äù said a railway official.

Meanwhile, 11 people have been tested for the virus in Andhra Pradesh yet, five of them from Visakhapatnam.

A 26-year-old man who was under observation at Government Chest Hospital was released on Tuesday. He had reportedly visited South Korea a few days ago. All 11 people have tested negative for the virus, including the 26-year-old.

Title: Mumbai's Shivaji Park exempted from parking fines
Content:
TimesView The BMC cannot have different sets of rules for different areas of the city. The change in parking fine rules for Shivaji Park is a clear case of discrimination, and regardless of the reasons for the move ‚Äî political exigency or public pressure ‚Äî it must either be reversed at the earliest or the fines uniformly slashed across Mumbai so that the residents of other localities don't suffer merely on account of their addresses.

Parking pardon: BMC cites locals, but politics may be behind move

MUMBAI: In two questionable decisions that largely favour residents of Shivaji Park, the BMC has dropped parking penalties and allowed vehicles to be stationed on 15 roads that were designated no-parking till now.Last July, the BMC imposed Rs 5,000-23,000 penalties for parking on the road in a spot within 500 metres of a public parking lot (PPL). The policy, which was for the entire city, was modified in January, where the penalty was no longer a flat charge based on vehicle type, but a calculation that was 40 times the parking charge levied by the PPL near which a vehicle would be found.Now, for Shivaji Park, the BMC has dropped penalties to zero from Rs 4,000‚Äî the fine for a four-wheeler (as per the January policy modification) based on the parking charge at Kohinoor PPL, the only PPL in Dadar (West). Similarly, parking on one side of 15 roads in the same area has been allowed; these roads were earlier earmarked as no-parking zones.Advocate Pradeep Havnur, who has argued a PIL on public parking, said the move amounts to discrimination and could be tested in court.Activist Anandini Thakoor, managing trustee, Khar Residents Association, said, ‚ÄúThey should stick to the rule of not allowing parking near a PPL. If parking space is available close by, why should exemptions be given to park on certain roads, which will cause congestion?‚ÄùShivaji Park had stopped following the BMC‚Äôs parking policy around the time of the assembly poll campaign. But two days ago, municipal commissioner Praveen Pardeshi signed an order formally granting an exemption to the area.Additional municipal commissioner P Velrasu said, ‚ÄúThere was a demand from residents and local political representatives to allow street parking near Kohinoor PPL. We have allowed it as there‚Äôs enough space on one side of a road. If residents near other PPLs make such a demand, we may consider their request too.‚ÄùThe issue may have a political angle. Dadar is considered to be a politically sensitive area, where the Sena wants to keep its splinter organization MNS out. The local corporator, Vishaka Raut, is from the Sena, which also controls the BMC house. Shivaji Park falls in G-North ward, which covers Prabhadevi, Dadar (West), Matunga (West) and Mahim (West), and which includes the Shiv Sena‚Äôs headquarters.During the assembly election campaign last year, MNS candidate Sandeep Deshpande had raised the parking issue. The Sena reacted immediately, asking the BMC to stop levying penalties for parking violations in the area. The BMC did not officially grant the area a policy exemption, but went slow and removed from around Kohinoor PPL signboards displaying parking fines. Soon, locals began parking their vehicles on the road.Justifying the exemption, G-North ward officer Kiran Dighavkar said, ‚ÄúMost buildings here don‚Äôt have parking space, and so there‚Äôs a demand for on-street parking.‚ÄùThe opposition has criticized the move. ‚ÄúThis is selective. Did they conduct any study before taking such a decision? Did they take the Parking Authority into confidence?‚Äù asked Congress corporator Asif Zakaria, demanding answers.

Title: VMRDA invites design ideas for planetarium in Kailasagiri
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority ( VMRDA ) is inviting concepts to design the planetarium on Kailasagiri Hill-top Park. Interested architects or architecture firms from across the country can apply.

Upon submitting concepts, a design competition will take place from where three designs will be shortlisted for presentation and subsequent finalisations. These top three designs will receive cash prizes.

The hybrid planetarium is being developed by VMRDA across seven acres of land on Kailasagiri Hill-top Park. It will have a seating capacity of nearly 200 and a dome size of 18 metres.

Moreover, a science museum will also be developed along with the first planetarium in the state. A gallery will be created to display scientific exhibits and artefacts. There will also be a space dedicated for workshops, conferences and seminars.

Speaking to TOI, P Koteswara Rao, VMRDA metropolitan commissioner said that the urban development body will choose the best design of the received entries and will prepare a consolidated design based on the entries after taking inputs from the technical committee.

Interested architects or architecture firms will have to submit their entries online through http://www.vmrda.gov.in/planetarium. The application process will begin on March 4 and conclude on March 23, VMRDA informed.

Title: Now, ‚Äòcorona-free‚Äô certificate must for Kuwait travel
Content:
People wearing protective masks cross the street in Kuwait City on March 2, 2020 (AFP)

NEW DELHI: Indians, and some other foreign nationals like Bangladeshis and Sri Lankans , travelling to Kuwait will from Sunday (March 8) need to carry a health certificate saying they are ‚Äúfree for coronavirus‚Äù issued by health centres approved by Kuwait embassies to be allowed entry there.

Travellers without this certificate will be deported on the same airline they flew in on and the carrier will be fined for violating the circular issued by the State of Kuwait‚Äôs directorate general of civil aviation on Tuesday.

Title: Scientist heads to Iran to help Indians there
Content:
MUMBAI: The National Institute of Virology in Pune has sent one of its scientists to Iran to help Indian citizens stranded there with the testing and diagnosis of Covid-19 as the testing facilities are not adequate there. ‚ÄúThere are about 1,200 Indians from Kargil in Iran,‚Äù an Indian Council of Medical Research official said.

This is the first time since the outbreak happened that an Indian health professional has flown to a foreign country to stay there and help with the testing and diagnosis of citizens stranded there.

Title: It‚Äôs March & forest dept yet to get Rs 1,373cr out of Rs 2,306cr
Content:
Nagpur: With over Rs1,373 crore still not released even as the last month of financial year 2019-20 has set in, state forest department is staring at huge budgeting blues.

According to sources, the overall plan outlay of the forest department for 2019-20 was Rs2,306 crore. Out of this, till date only Rs933 crore has been released, which is hardly 40% of the total budget. The funds pertain to all three wings ‚Äî territorial, social forestry and wildlife.

Officials fear non-release of funds will hamper crucial forestry activities like plantation, protection, relocation, various social and welfare schemes, construction activity, contractor bills, labour payments among many others.

‚ÄúThe money has not been released despite proposals were submitted well in time. When the budget is announced, state releases part payment with which works are carried out. Over 93% of the amount released has already been spent and new instalment is awaited,‚Äù said sources.

‚ÄúLast year, the state government had planted 33 crore saplings. These first-year plantations need more money for maintenance. If money is not released in time, the plantations will die. Secondly, nursery works have not been started yet, thus new plantation works cannot be taken up,‚Äù said a section of officials from the field.

A section of RFOs said, ‚ÄúThe department doesn‚Äôt have money for petrol and diesel and hence patrolling has taken a hit. Besides, funds for fire line works have also not been released yet. The department, which till last year had no fund problem, is crying for funds now. We are back to square one.‚Äù

During the last BJP-Shiv Sena government, Sudhir Mungantiwar had both finance and forest ministries with him. Hence, the department never faced fund crunch.

According to sources, the cash-strapped Maharashtra Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government is curtailing budgets of most of the departments to fulfil the promise of loan waiver to farmers. ‚ÄúIf the money is not released in time, it will lapse,‚Äù said officials.

Under the MVA, finance ministry is with the NCP while forest is with Shiv Sena and revenue with Congress. ‚ÄúThere seems to be lack of coordination between the three,‚Äù said senior forest officers.

The government funding includes budget for plan and non-plan outlay. While 60% plan budget money is awaited, of the Rs2,000 non-plan grants, 80% has been spent as it mostly includes salaries.

Senior officials with budget and planning department said they were hopeful to get the grants released soon. Forest minister Sanjay Rathod has talked to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray for releasing Rs500 crore. There are indications the money will be released soon. If the funds get lapsed, we will seek it in supplementary demands.

Title: Coronavirus in Mumbai: Four municipal hospitals in Mumbai identified to set up coronavirus isolation wards at short notice
Content: MUMBAI: Four municipal hospitals where isolation wards can be set up at short notice in case of a Covid-19 outbreak have been identified by the BMC, said additional municipal commissioner Suresh Kakani on Tuesday. Currently, only Kasturba hospital has an isolation ward in the city.The hospitals shortlisted are Hinduhridaysamrat Balasaheb Thackeray Trauma Care Hospital in Jogeshwari; Bhabha hospital in Bandra, Bhabha hospital in Kurla and Rajawadi in Ghatkopar. ‚ÄúThe goal is to have over 500 isolation beds, including those in private hospitals. In case of an outbreak, there should be effective measures in place to contain the spread as the population density in Mumbai is high,‚Äù Kakani said.Among the other measures being taken by the municipal corporation include upgrading facilities in Kasturba, developing facilities at other locations by roping in more civic, state government and private hospitals.Kakani said the BMC has already started talks with two private hospitals.
