He said the third step would be to ensure adequate stock of medicine, material and protective gear, enough to last at least 10 days. ‚ÄúWe have also issued a tender for long-term purchases so that we can procure material as and when we want,‚Äù he said, adding that finally if an outbreak does occur, the BMC would also focus on spreading awareness and information on combating the virus.The state had also told government medical colleges to be ready to set up isolation wards. ‚ÄúIsolation wards could be set up in district hospitals so that there are over 500 isolation beds to tackle an outbreak,‚Äù Dr Pradeep Awate, disease surveillance officer, state government, said.Awate was speaking at a discussion organised by the Observer Research Foundation on ‚ÄòCombating Coronavirus‚Äô. He said surveillance was being carried out at the district level where telephonic contact was made with travellers who had been to places under Covid-19 threat. ‚ÄúIf they develop any symptoms, they are referred to isolation wards,‚Äù he said.He said 3,245 samples had been tested in the country so far and that many of these were repeat tests done after 15 days of quarantine. ‚ÄúIn the last four days itself, 365 samples were tested,‚Äù he said.The BMC has also been tracking passengers who arrived from countries battling the virus outbreak. ‚ÄúEven if they are asymptomatic, we make a phone call to them for 14 days. We have deputed people for this,‚Äù Kakani said.

Title: Ambazari pool: Swimmers oppose extra charge, operator says will sort out
Content:
Nagpur: Swimmers going to NIT‚Äùs Ambazari pool have accused the private operator Midland Sports and Wellness Pvt Ltd of increasing the tariff against the tender norms on the pretext of registration charge on every renewal of yearly/monthly membership.

NIT Swimming Pool Members‚Äô Association said so far they had to pay only a one-time registration fee but recently the operator started levying it without giving due notice or consultation. This move, it said, has hiked the annual fee by around Rs 850 from Rs 3,600 to Rs 4,484.

They said though a hike has been enforced, the operator is not providing any additional facility. NIT executive engineer DR Gaur referred the queries to private operator saying all powers now vest with the company and the civic agency could not interfere in maintenance or any other issue at the pool.

Association president Manmohan Bajpai said as per the company‚Äôs agreement with NIT, it could raise charges by 8% to 10% but only after following due procedure. ‚ÄúEvery month an additional amount of Rs 200+18% GST is being levied in the name of registration which is actually meant to be one time. The operator says those having valid cards will not have to pay registration charge. On Sunday, a member was charged additional fee,‚Äù Bajpai said.

He added this was nothing but tariff hike through backdoor. The company director Savithav Nair agreed registration charge was a bone of contention and said it will be sorted out during a meeting with the pool users on Thursday.

Nair ruled out any tarrif hike as it would amount to breach of terms and condition of its contract with NIT. The director also said the revenue sharing model has changed from January and they can‚Äôt afford to leave users unhappy.

‚ÄúThey had called me and wanted to discuss the issue. Whatever problems they are facing, we can sit across the table and sort out. We have not hiked the charges. We are continuing with whatever charge NIT recommended. The issue is one-time registration charge. We need to check if NIT was waiving off or levying it on expired memberships,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúWe have been operating the pool for the last 20 years. But now the style of operation has changed. Earlier, NIT was paying us for the upkeep while now we are paying the civic agency,‚Äù he said.

Title: GB orders Thakur‚Äôs transfer, Mundhe seeks continuation
Content:
Nagpur: Yet another controversy has erupted between the ruling party BJP and municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe in the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC).

On February 20, the general body had ordered Mundhe to send back chief accounts and finance officer (CAFO) Mona Thakur to the state government with immediate effect. Though Mundhe wrote to the state government on Tuesday informing about the general body‚Äôs decision, he also requested Thakur‚Äôs continuation in the NMC.

NMC sources said that Mundhe requested Thakur‚Äôs continuation as she is preparing his budget for 2020-21. Already, Mundhe‚Äôs budget is late as he is preparing work-wise budget. Mundhe also reportedly stressed the need for Thakur‚Äôs continuation till new accounts and finance officer is appointed by the government.

Now, the ball is in the court of Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government. MVA is already taking steps to take direct control over the NMC and also bring back Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT) as planning authority for unauthorized areas of the city.

Thakur is known to be very strict when it comes to financial issues. Her decisions have irked ruling party leaders in the NMC many times. Hence, Dharampal Meshram, chairman of NMC‚Äôs legal consultative committee, raised the issue in the general body meeting on February 20.

Citing section 47 (2) of the Maharashtra Municipal Corporations (MMC) Act, Meshram said that any officer who earlier worked as CAFO in the NMC cannot occupy the same post later.

Thakur was CAFO in the NMC between June 15, 2017, and September 6, 2018. After assuming charge, Mundhe had requested the government and brought Thakur back on the same post on February 11. Accordingly, mayor Sandip Joshi had ordered Mundhe to relieve Thakur with immediate effect.

On Tuesday, Joshi wrote a letter to Mundhe asking further action in the case of orders given by him in the general body.

Meshram said, ‚ÄúIt is expected that Mundhe should work as per the Act. He should also inform the government about provisions of the Act which do not permit Thakur to continue as CAFO.‚Äù

Meanwhile, Mundhe transferred Praful Farkase, OSD of standing committee chairman, as junior engineer at NMC Dhantoli zone. Farkase had prepared budget of standing committee chairpersons for the last 14 years.

After Mundhe‚Äôs budget, the standing committee chairman will have to prepare and present the budget. Without Farkase, the chairman is likely to face problems in preparing the budget.

Title: IndiGo puts 4 crew members under home isolation
Content:
NEW DELHI: IndiGo Airlines has quarantined its crew who ferried a passenger who flew from Dubai to India and later tested positive for the coronavirus. Air India, which did the same with the crew of a Vienna-Delhi flight, has now reached out to other passengers on that flight to take necessary precautions.

A spokesperson for IndiGo said: ‚ÄúThe affected passenger in Hyderabad travelled on IndiGo flight 6E 96 (Dubai-Bengaluru) on February 20, 2020. Under the guidance of APHO Bangalore all 4 cabin crew who operated this flight have been placed on home observation immediately, from March 2, 2020.

Title: Coronavirus in Bangalore: Karnataka puts 71 under watch; schools on alert
Content: BENGALURU: With details of the Bengaluru links of the Covid-19-positive patient from Hyderabad emerging, state health authorities on Tuesday got down to tracking any infection trail he may have left behind before heading home.Schools from southeast Bengaluru asked parents to send students with masks and hand sanitizers or keep them at home if they had fever. Medical shops in Bengaluru reported panic buying of masks and hand sanitizers.Two persons with no symptoms ‚Äî the Hyderabad man‚Äôs flatmate in city, and a colleague ‚Äî reported at Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases and put under watch at the isolation ward. Their test results are expected on Wednesday.The authorities tracked down 71 people who had come in contact with the Hyderabad man and put them under surveillance. The 24-year-old techie had travelled to Dubai for work on February 15 and returned to Bengaluru on February 20. He attended work on February 20 and 21 before taking a bus to Hyderabad. His flat has been sealed for sanitizing.According to Telangana officials, at least 36 of the 88 people who came in contact with the techie are showing some symptoms of Covid-19.Contrary to reports, the infected person was not tested at the KIA since guidelines don‚Äôt say flyers from Dubai must be screened. WHO guidelines say identification of the infected person should not be revealed. However, WhatsApp groups were flooded with messages on where the infected person lived and details of his flatmate.

Title: Central Railway to sort traffic mess outside Mumbai's CSMT
Content:
Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminal

MUMBAI: Central Railway will have a comprehensive plan to streamline traffic outside the station by tackling the menace of hawkers and unauthorised parking. Senior divisional security commissioner KK Ashraf has called a meeting of multiple agencies, including the BMC and police, on March 5.

CSMT is the one of the oldest railway stations in the country with an average daily footfall of around four lakh. Besides, the station sees over over 1,000 local trains and more than 45 pairs of long distance trains daily.

A senior railway official said, "CR has written to the deputy commissioners of police (DCP) for traffic, railway and zone I as well as assistant municipal commissioner of 'A' ward to seek a solution for the rampant unauthorised parking and hawking in the CSMT station precincts. CR officials pointed out that several tourists visit the station to observe its architectural magnificence. The haphazard parking and hawkers are not just a hindrance to smooth flow of traffic, but also put off tourists.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Karnataka ready with over 2,300 beds in isolation wards, says health minister B Sriramulu
Content: BENGALURU: The Karnataka government has provided 630 beds in the isolation wards of its hospitals to exclusively deal with suspected coronavirus cases. Besides, 1,689 beds have been reserved in private hospitals, said health minister B Sriramulu.Addressing media on the state‚Äôs preparedness in the wake of Covid-19 scare on Tuesday, the minister said all measures are in place to tackle the situation.Screening of international passengers coming from Covid-19-hit counties began at Kempegowda International Airport on January 20. Since then, 40,207 people have undergone thermal screening. Among them, 560 travellers (from virus-affected nations) have been identified and 352 of them are under home isolation. Of them, 179 patients have completed 28 days of observation. So far, 251 samples of suspected cases have tested negative. Karnataka hasn‚Äôt seen a single positive case yet. The results of 13 samples are yet to be known.At Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases, three patents are in the isolation ward. Stating that there is no medicine for Covid-19, the minister said the public must be cautious of anyone who claims to have home remedies and alternative therapy. ‚ÄúThe health department hasn‚Äôt endorsed any medicine. Hygiene factors have to maintained as per the guidelines issued,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúIn Karnataka, the samples are being tested in two laboratories in Bengaluru ‚Äî National Institute of Virology, Bengaluru branch and the virus research and diagnostic laboratory on Victoria Hospital campus and it takes just over four hours to get the results,‚Äù said medical education minister K Sudhakar.

Title: Why‚Äôs government averse to debate on riots if situation in Delhi is normal: Congress
Content:
Leader of opposition Ghulam Nabi Azad (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The Rajya Sabha was adjourned thrice and could not transact any business on Tuesday over the opposition‚Äôs demand for a debate on the recent riots in Delhi. Leader of opposition Ghulam Nabi Azad wondered aloud why the government was adopting double standards by claiming on one hand that the situation in Delhi was normal but insisting that a discussion could not be allowed at present.

Despite Om Birla‚Äôs warning on Tuesday morning ‚Äî that any MP crossing to the other side would be suspended for the remainder of the session ‚Äî the Lok Sabha witnessed dramatic scenes with Congress ‚Äôs Adhir Ranjan Choudhury rushing to the well to protest against transaction of legislative business.

The Speaker had tried to resolve the standoff when he met opposition leaders in the afternoon. Though non-Congress opposition parties seemed ambivalent, Choudhury is understood to have stuck to his guns. Parliamentary affairs minister Pralhad Joshi sought to point out that the bill in question needed to be passed before March 31 as it had serious financial implications.

In the Rajya Sabha, Azad said, ‚ÄúAll of us, whether in the opposition or government, condemn the incidents. That Delhi violence is talked about in foreign countries but not discussed even though Parliament is in session... is a little odd. We are not looking to confront the government. We are all saddened; the victims, be it from any community or religion, were fellow humans,‚Äù he said.

Leader of the House Thaawarchand Gehlot got up and said the government was ready for a discussion as per the schedule decided by the Rajya Sabha chairman.

In the LS, amid slogans of ‚ÄòDown, Down Amit Shah ‚Äô and ‚ÄòSave our India‚Äô, opposition MPs tore up papers even as the Speaker allowed finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman to introduce the Banking Regulation (Amendment) Bill, 2020. Though the LS passed six clauses of the ‚ÄòVivad se Vishwas‚Äô tax resolution bill amid the din, it could not pass the bill because of the ruckus that followed. As Congress, TMC, SP and DMK MPs rushed to the well, BJP MP Locket Chatterjee attempted to prevent Chowdhury from moving towards the treasury benches. Amid the din, BJP and Congress MPs pushed one another while some were seen banging the swivel door leading to the secretary general‚Äôs desk.

Title: Post-Holi debate date fails to placate Congress
Content:

Outside Parliament, leader of Congress in Lok Sabha Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury said the opposition disrupted Lok Sabha proceedings only to assert that riots in Delhi must be given top priority. ‚ÄúThe government says we leave it to the Speaker, the Speaker says debate will happen after things will be normal. Title: No muscle-flexing in civic polls, TMC tells councillors
Content:
Kolkata: Trinamool Congress chief Mamata Banerjee does not want a repeat of the 2018 panchayat polls in the coming civic elections. Trinamool MP and number 2 in the party, Abhishek Banerjee, issued this warning to party councillors of Kolkata Municipal Corporation at a closed-door meeting held at Trinamool Bhavan on Tuesday. Election strategist Prashant Kishor was present at the meeting.

Learning it the hard way from the 2018 Bengal rural polls that affected Trinamool‚Äôs performance in the 2019 Lok Sabha polls, Abhishek wanted the councillors to avoid muscle-flexing during civic polls and risk the party‚Äôs prospects in the 2021 assembly polls.

According to Trinamool insiders, the party is way ahead in most of the 144 wards under KMC. Trinamool leaders held that there was no point taking a heavy-handed approach for a couple of more seats because such tactic offends public feeling.

Taking a cue from Mamata‚Äôs speech at Netaji Indoor Stadium on Monday, the Trinamool MP said that distribution of tickets will be based on performance of the councillors, their transparent public image and their ready contact with people.

Of the three parameters, Trinamool senior Subrata Mukherjee gave primacy to transparent image of councillors. Mukherjee cited the instance of Congress councillor Prakash Upadhyay, who defeated the TMC candidate in the last civic polls because of his ‚Äútransparent image‚Äù.

Abhishek also referred to the tendency among a section of councillors to blackmail the party over ticket distribution. ‚ÄúSome seats have been reserved for women. Councillors who were elected from these seats are pressing for their candidates from the reserved ones. If someone wants to blackmail the party over ticket distribution, s/he can leave the party now. I will give you the bus fare to go straight to the BJP headquarters,‚Äù Abhishek said.

Team PK has already submitted a primary performance report of councillors to the Trinamool top brass. The report points to the falling public image of a section of councillors who couldn‚Äôt ensure transparent delivery of services, and at times misbehaved with people. Trinamool seniors will take this report into account among other things during selection of candidates.

The TMC top brass will hold another meeting with councillors after 15 days before finalising the candidate list for the KMC polls.

‚ÄúMamata Banerjee has said that transparent image, mass contact and performance will be the three criteria for selection of candidates. We discussed several organisational aspects before taking the plunge for the civic polls,‚Äù said Trinamool secretary general Partha Chatterjee.

TMC president Subrata Bakshi and Kolkata mayor Firhad Hakim asked party organisers and councillors to start door-to-door campaigns to improve mass contact.

Title: Coronavirus in Kolkata: ‚ÄòNovel‚Äô experience for the tourists travelling from Kolkata, but doctors advise caution
Content: KOLKATA: Tourists from Kolkata travelling in South-East Asian countries under the virus scare are having quite the ‚Äònovel‚Äô experience in more ways than one: rock-bottom prices and unbelievably low hotel tariffs, and even the most popular destinations wearing a deserted, almost unrecognisable, look. But even as several of them had pleasant vacations, doctors have warned that visiting these places is risky, and no precaution against nCoV could ever be fool-proof.‚ÄúI have been to Bangkok on multiple occasions. But this time, it seemed as though I was visiting a different city,‚Äù said Satnam Singh Ahluwalia, a resident of New Alipore, who visited Bangkok last month with wife Gurbir Kaur. ‚ÄúThe hustle and bustle of Bangkok was missing. The streets were deserted and the markets were empty, with just a handful of tourists window-shopping. Supermarkets and bars closed early and nearly everyone wore masks.‚Äù The couple also had tickets booked for a trip to Japan later this month, but has cancelled them in the wake of the nCoV outbreak Wearing masks or staying away from crowds, while being safe practices, did not ensure immunity from the virus, reminded doctors.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs advisable to wear masks or steer clear of crowds but even one infected person can give you the vir-us,‚Äù said Heart Foundation of India president K K Aggarwal. ‚ÄúSince it has spread to almost all SE Asian countries, particularly Thailand, chances of infection are high.‚ÄùHeart Foundation of India president KK Aggarwal added that those who have travelled to the region should remain quarantined at home for at least 15 days since their return and consult a doctor if s/he has fever or cough. ‚ÄúEven if you are travelling in an aircraft with a couple of infected people, you may get the virus. So, it would be wrong to assume that a deserted Bangkok would be safer than a crowded one,‚Äù he warned.Financial communicator and social worker Mudar Patherya, who was also in Bangkok last week, received the shock of his life when he boarded the plane. The 180-seater aircraft flew near-empty on February 26, with just 23 passengers on board. ‚ÄúThere was a lull all around. I learned the government had advised citizens to refrain from visiting crowded places. So, people were avoiding even public transport and many preferred to stay indoors,‚Äù Patherya told TOI.Thailand, incidentally, was the first country outside China to report a case of nCoV, on January 13. As of now, the country has recorded 43 confirmed cases.The beach resort of Phuket, Thailand‚Äôs second-most visited destination after Bangkok ‚Äî remained deserted during the annual festival held last month on Walking Street in the heart of town.Railway engineer and Chetla resident Sanjay Prasad was in Bangkok with his wife and another couple last month. He said the nCoV scare had even made the famous street food disappear, both at Pattaya and on Bangkok‚Äôs Khao San Road. ‚ÄúExotic meats like alligator, bat, snake and frog have gone off the menu. Although we were wary about trying out exotic items, we were surprised that stalls weren‚Äôt selling them, either,‚Äù said Prasad.The situation is similar at other South-East Asian tourist destinations like Vietnam, with places like the Literature Temple and Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum in Hanoi ‚Äî often cited as the country‚Äôs two most popular tourist attractions ‚Äî almost devoid of tourists. Nearly everyone around are wearing masks, either voluntarily or under duress, said tourists.‚ÄúTwo of my friends from Delhi had recently been to Hanoi, and they said it‚Äôs not safe to visit. So, I cancelled my tickets to Hanoi,‚Äù said Jadavpur resident Sayani Chaudhari, a freelance graphic artist.A senior official of Thai Airways, which has daily direct flights to Bangkok, said the number of passengers gradually decreased since the last week of January 20. The airline was still receiving ticket-refund requests, he added.

Title: Polish student from JU moves HC over notice to leave India
Content:
Kolkata: Kamil Siedcynski, the Polish student from Jadavpur University who has been asked to leave the country by the Foreigner Regional Registration Office ( FRRO ), has invoked principles highlighted in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (1948) and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (1966) that are applicable to all persons to challenge the order in Calcutta High Court. His petition is likely to be heard on Wednesday.

Siedcynski has also claimed in his petition that the FRRO order of February 14 was contrary to the principles of natural justice.

While the FRRO has found Siedcynski guilty of violating visa norms by participating in an anti-CAA protest, the student has claimed in his petition that he was inadvertently caught in the protest.

He has maintained that as a student with interest in Indian culture, he was merely watching the proceedings and had clicked photographs of the ‚Äòcarnival like‚Äô proceedings from a sidewalk. A student of Warsaw University, Siedcynski, was selected by the Indian Council for Cultural Relations to study at Visva-Bharati University for the academic year 2016-17. After gaining knowledge in Bengali, Sanskrit and Hindi at Santiniketan, he opted for a full-time Masters Degree course in Comparative Literature from JU and was granted visa accordingly. This visa is valid till August 2020, when he is supposed to take his final exams.

According to his petition, Siedcynski had been persuaded by other students of JU to accompany them to the place near New Market for the protest on December 19. He apparently didn‚Äôt know what the protest meet was all about and soon got separated from his fellow students. Thereafter, he stood on the sidewalk watching the event and clicking photographs. He claimed there were other foreigners watching the protest as well and a person approached him wanting to know his name and views on the protest. The man also clicked his photograph after which he left for home. The next day, Siedcynski realised the man he had spoken to was a photojournalist and an article on him had appeared in a newspaper. He has claimed in his petition that much of what was written in the article was made-up.

He received a notice from the FRRO thereafter and was asked to leave the country on February 14.

Seeking an order from the high court allowing him to remain in the country, Siedcynski has challenged the FRRO notice calling it arbitrary, capricious and violative of the fundamental rights guaranteed to all persons by the Constitution.

Title: After ‚ÄòBanglar Abas Yojana‚Äô, Didi unveils ‚ÄòSnehalaya‚Äô housing plan
Content:
Kaliaganj: Direct benefit and prompt delivery have proved to be the two building blocks of Trinamool Congress‚Äôs success in this Uttar Dinajpur constituency in the assembly bypoll in November despite BJP‚Äôs overall gain in north Bengal in the 2019 Lok Sabha polls.

So, at a time PM Narendra Modi is thinking of leaving social media, Bengal chief minister Mamata Banerjee is making effective use of the ‚ÄòDidi Ke Bolo‚Äô campaign to establish direct link with the impoverished, who usually get waylaid in between. Banerjee has carved out the Snehalaya housing plan for those 25,000 people whose wish for home reached the CM‚Äôs grievance cell.

‚ÄúThe Snehalaya scheme is a new scheme other than the existing Banglar Abas Yojana. As many as 25,000 people appealed to me via the CM‚Äôs grievance cell urging for a dwelling unit. I checked the applications and found that many of them do not fit into the ‚ÄòBanglar Abas Yojana‚Äô. I have, therefore, taken up this new scheme to make their dream come true,‚Äù Banerjee said at a public meeting in Kaliaganj on Tuesday.

The state government has also sanctioned a total 5 lakh applications from people mainly from Dalits, Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe communities, granting to senior citizens a monthly pension of Rs 1,000 less than a month after the scheme was announced in the state Budget. ‚ÄúThe money will be credited directly to your accounts,‚Äù the CM said.

Banerjee also assured the SC community and Adivasis that her government has simplified the caste certificate delivery process. ‚ÄúNow, the government will issue caste certificate to applicants without inquiry if one among the family has a caste certificate,‚Äù she said.

The CM also announced that her government has regularised another 119 refugee colonies, giving land pattas that will help them establish their citizenship.

‚ÄúAll of you have voter cards or job cards or land pattas and an address. You are all citizens. There is no need for a fresh citizenship law. Those who have come from Bangladesh are all citizens. Don‚Äôt rely on those who are trying to divide people,‚Äù she said.

Banerjee reminded the people of north Bengal how the BJP pandered to Rajbanshi sentiments ahead of the Lok Sabha polls. ‚ÄúThey (BJP) told the Rajbanshis that they will stay in Cooch Behar, the Bengalis have to go. Months later, during the Assam NRC exercise, Rajbanshis along with Bengalis took the hit. We want food, not division. We want jobs, not riots,‚Äù the chief minister said.

Title: ‚ÄòIndiGo to replace remaining 60 P&W engines by May 31‚Äô
Content: NEW DELHI: The Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) on Tuesday said it has received a firm schedule that IndiGo‚Äôs remaining 60 unmodified Pratt & Whitney (PW) engines will be replaced within the deadline and the schedule for replacing GoAir‚Äôs remaining 32 unmodified PW engines is still awaited. IndiGo and GoAir currently have 92 unmodified PW engines on their Airbus A320 Neos that need to be replaced with modified ones by May 31, 2020, to keep flying after that.In all, IndiGo and GoAir were to get 180 modified engines both as replacement on planes already in their fleet and on new A320/321 Neos delivered to them by May-end. While about 90 of the modified engines were to come as new deliveries and replacement by February-end, the remaining half is expected by May 31. IndiGo at present has 106 Neos and GoAir has 43. Together the two Indian carriers have about 25% of the 585 A320 Neo family aircraft with PW 1100 series engines operating globally, a senior DGCA official said.‚ÄúA total number of 56 (PW unmodified engine) failures (on A320 Neos) have been reported globally, out of which 26 failures ‚Äî 22 by IndiGo and four by GoAir ‚Äî have been reported by Indian carriers, amounting to about 46%,‚Äù the official said.‚ÄúIndiGo got its first A320 Neo in March 2016 and GoAir its first in May 2016‚Ä¶ Post induction of the aircraft into service, technical issues were experienced on these engines worldwide. Most of these issues have been suitably addressed by the manufacturer except third-stage low pressure turbine (LPT) failures‚Ä¶ PW developed a more robust third-stage LPT which was installed on new engines from June 2019,‚Äù said the official.‚ÄúPW is in the process of setting up an MRO (maintenance repair overhaul) in India in collaboration with Air India (engineering arm) for replacement of third-stage LPT at (the latter‚Äôs) Mumbai facility. This will significantly reduce the time taken for the upgrade. The facility was supposed to be operational by the end of February 2020,‚Äù the official added.‚ÄúDGCA is continuously monitoring the performance of these engines and taking appropriate action to address the issues. The manufacturer has been directed to ensure sufficient availability of spare engines for Indian operators to prevent grounding of aircraft due to removal of engines,‚Äù he added.

Title: Chennai suburbs to get 55 new parks in nine months
Content:
With these new ones, the total number of parks in Chennai will go up to 700.

CHENNAI: In a big boost to the city‚Äôs lung space, the corporation has planned to set up 55 new parks across the extended areas. Most of these parks will come up in places such as Perungudi, Sholinganallur, Madipakkam and Madhavaram within the next nine months, say officials.

Two new playgrounds will also come up at Semmenchery and Asirvathapuram.

While the playground in Semmenchery will be a multipurpose facility with a running track, badminton court and gym, major retrofitting will be done to the existing playground in Asirvathapuram. The estimated cost of the project is ‚Çπ52 crore.

‚ÄúWe have already identified open space reservation (OSR) land parcels for the 55 parks and tenders have been floated,‚Äù said an official with the parks and playgrounds department of the corporation.

OSR land areas are those that are reserved for recreational use by communities as a whole before approval of layouts under the state Town and Country Planning Act.

With these new ones, the total number of parks in the city will go up to 700.

‚ÄúSuch green spaces are important for the general wellbeing of the people. We are also looking for public-private partnership to maintain and develop larger parks,‚Äù said an engineer with the parks department. The engineer also said that in areas where public cooperation is minimal, anti-social elements tend to take control of the parks.

Parks asked to take sewage from nearby residential colonies

The civic body is also particular about the maintenance of these parks, which are most likely to be handed over to private contractors after inception. Maintenace of 554 parks in the city has been outsourced and the remaining ones are maintained by the civic body‚Äôs own staff and some by private companies and resident welfare associations.

In a meeting held with the contractors more than a month ago, the corporation commissioner had instructed the contractors to ensure that even minor repair works at the parks should be completed quickly and that the contractors should hold monthly review meetings to monitor their upkeep.

Parks have been asked to take sewage water from nearby residential colonies, treat them and use it for watering plants. To ensure proper security, contractors have been asked to build a separate room for security staff and ensure that only able-bodied staff are employed as security.

Contractors were also told to ensure that composting of wet waste be carried out in all parks and the manure obtained be used for trees and plants.

Title: Gangster Gogi: How this Delhi gangster was caught four years after escape
Content: NEW DELHI: Bringing down the curtain on a four-year chase since the audacious escape of Delhi's most-wanted gangster, Jitender Maan alias Gogi, from custody, Delhi Police's Special Cell arrested him and three of his associates from Gurugram on early Tuesday.As the cell tracked them down to a flat in Mapsko Casabella in Sector 82, Gogi, who is known for opening fire at cops on the slightest pretext, acted differently. He went live on Facebook and released a video saying he was surrendering, and then opened the door and walked towards the police cordon.While Gogi (29) was at the top of the most-wanted list, two others - Kuldeep Fajja (28) and Rohit Moi (27) - also featured among Delhi Police's top 10 criminals. The fourth has been identified as Kaplil (27) from Saharanpur in Uttar Pradesh. While Gogi is from Outer Delhi's Alipur, Fajja belongs to Naya Baans in the same area and Moi to Haryana's Sonipat.The list of their prominent crimes include the murder of Haryana's folk singer, Harshita Dahiya, in Sonipat and a gang war in Burari in 2018. Just a fortnight ago, the gang shot at a rival over 50 times in Kanjhawala and hit him 24 times.The counter-intelligence (CI) unit under inspector Vikram Dahiya was tracking the gang since last December. Gogi, a source said, was left without any major target after his arch rival, Amit Dabang, was nabbed in January-end. "Utilising all resources, suspect persons and locations were put under surveillance," said Manishi Chandra, DCP of the unit.The gang used social media not only to communicate among themselves but also to extort people. Cops managed to identify some of these Facebook IDs, said a source. The Facebook surveillance yielded some crucial internet protocol addresses and eventually their physical locations.Sources were deployed at Kherki Daula toll plaza after some movements were recorded on this route. Finally, the team was tipped off about the gang's presence in the Gurugram society. "As it was an upscale residential condominium, elite SWAT commandos, expert in urban building intervention, were called to assist the raiding party," Chandra said.After the gang, occupying an apartment on the second floor of B4 block, were asked to surrender, there was no response from Gogi and his men for almost 20 minutes. However, a source claimed, they didn't find any escape route and surrendered.Sx imported pistols of Zigana, Taurus and Star make, and over 70 live cartridges were found on them. A Hyundai i-20 car, lifted from Paschim Vihar, was also seized.

Title: West Bengal to procure robots to fight along with firemen in critical cases
Content: KOLKATA: The state fire department will soon have robots in its squad to flight alongside firemen. It is in an advanced stage of acquisition of four such robots, which will be used in situations like extreme heat, suffocating smoke and possibility of explosion. With this addition, Bengal will be the first fighting unit in the eastern region to have robots.If everything goes according to the plan, the robots will be pressed into service in this March itself. Sources said these robots will help in fighting devastating chemical fire like Bagri Market with much greater efficacy.‚ÄúSince our chief minister Mamata Banerjee accorded highest importance in safeguarding people‚Äôs life and property, we are trying fast to complete the tender procedure and acquire them. These robots will certainly be a game-changer in fire-fighting. Bengal will be the first fire-brigade in the eastern region to attain this level of modernisation,‚Äù said Sujit Bose, minister of state for fire and emergency services (independent charge).The decision of acquiring robot was taken after a delayed success in containing the fire at Bagri Market. It was induced by chemicals stockpiled by traders and also many places remained inaccessible because of the intense heat and toxic fume. The fire fighters fought an unequal battle to contain he fire.‚ÄúIn such cases, robots will be an ideal solution. They have inbuilt motors to throw water or foam at such a speed that even a chemical fire can be put out really fast. We will not only save lives of firefighters, but will also help in dousing the flames in shortest possible time,‚Äù said Jag Mohan, director general, fire service.These robots are designed to fight the most hazardous fires. Made with fire and heat-resistant materials, these robots are remote controlled. ‚ÄúThey can reach the seat of the fire and extinguish it most effectively,‚Äù said additional director general Niladri Chakraborty.Since these robots are fitted with sensors and has ability to capture thermal imagery, it will give us live report of actual intensity and extent of the fire. This would also help us to adopt a correct firefighting strategy. They can carry out critical tasks of extinguishing systems in buildings and automatically move to the source of fire to carry out the initial fire extinguishing process until the fire fighters reach the spot.The gadgets can also be used to carry out awareness drives in malls. The robot will be subject to a trial period of three months and then evaluated to determine its technical and operational efficiency, said an officer.

Title: Abhishek Manu Singhvi serves notice to author over references to father in book
Content:
NEW DELHI: Congress MP and senior advocate Abhishek Manu Singhvi has served a legal notice to UK-based lawyer Sarosh Zaiwalla for ‚Äúdefamatory references‚Äù to his father late L M Singhvi in his book ‚ÄúHonour Bound‚Äù and sought deletion of those portions besides a public apology.

In his notice, Singhvi accused Zaiwalla of making ‚Äúfalse, frivolous, baseless and vexatious‚Äù statements regarding his father who was a renowned legal expert and diplomat.

He said the book had made insinuations that ‚Äúthere was undue influence and abuse of power‚Äù on the part of Late Dr L M Singhvi on an arbitration tribunal to pass a favourable award in which he was appearing as counsel.

Zaiwalla was in India for the launch of his memoir, ‚ÄòHonour Bound‚Äô. Singhvi also referred to the interview given by Zaiwalla to TOI ‚Äúthrough which he had deliberately compounded the felony‚Äù. ‚ÄúWe demand that the book titled ‚ÄòHonour Bound‚Äô be recalled forthwith by you and defamatory portions of the book deleted ... You must tender an unconditional apology... ,‚Äù the notice said.
